HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Putting Experience to Work

BYLINE:  By TANYA MOHN 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
BILL SCHACHTER, an instructor in a new Westchester County program for older job seekers, begins his class by whipping out photographs of his grandchildren. At 72, Mr. Schachter, who is frequently older than his students, understands physical as well as emotional hurts, including the frustrations of trying something new.
 In this case, in his classroom at the Westchester/Putnam One Stop Employment Center here, it's tackling the computer, a difficult and often scary undertaking for an age group ill at ease in a high-tech world. In the first five minutes he has broken the ice, created neutral ground. The students bring out their photos, of their grandchildren. 
 "When this is over," Mr. Schachter warns them, "I don't want to hear another word about your grandchildren."
"They laugh, then we get down to business," he said last week. 
For Judith Richburg, program administrator for the Westchester County Department of Senior Programs and Services, Mr. Schachter's rapport with his senior students is no surprise. Choosing a successful peer to teach the program "was not unintentional," Mrs. Richburg said. "Experience Counts," the name of Mrs. Richburg's brainchild begun earlier this year, is also no accident. By using "experience" in the program title, Mrs. Richburg is sending a message to potential employers. 
"Some employers don't realize that by getting a mature worker, they find they are getting a better worker." Often, Mrs. Richburg says, employers do not realize until they have older workers in place that they are motivated, willing to learn new things, and possess an unparalleled work ethic.
But, she said, workers frequently need to reinvent themselves. "All we are doing is retooling them," Mrs. Richburg said. 
Marlene Brennan, 58, of White Plains, is such a case. "You can get to a point where you are unemployable," Ms. Brennan says. "My only problem was not upgrading my computer skills." She enrolled in the pilot program of Experience Counts after being laid off from Kmart. "I felt it helped totally in all areas of job skills." Soon after completing the training, Ms. Brennan was hired as a receptionist for Vocational and Educational Services to Individuals With Disabilities, an office of the New York State Department of Education. 
William Yanez, 64, of New Rochelle also finds the program beneficial. He was an electronic technician with his own television repair business, who is now looking for a job where he can use former skills. The program, he says, helped a lot "in relations with people, how to connect, and how to solve problems" that customers have.
Financed by the National Council on the Aging and the New York State Office for the Aging but administered by the county, classes are offered at no cost, and available to people over 55 with proven financial need. The oldest student to date was 89, but participants average about 65. 
Mrs. Richburg hopes that the program, now in its second series of twice-weekly sessions conducted over eight weeks, will continue and expand. Now, 14 older people are enrolled, for a total of 29 participants. 
Older people generally fare worse than other workers even in the best of times, but job placements are up for program participants. 
This year's placements, numbering 17, are close to triple the six of the previous year when a less comprehensive program was offered, Mrs. Richburg said. 
She attributed this to the fact that many companies, eager to save money by eliminating benefits, are offering more part-time work, which younger job seekers are likely to pass over. Many of these jobs, she said, are in customer service, office support, security and health care. The older people in the jobs earn, on average, $12.42 an hour, more than twice the minimum wage, but as high as $26 an hour. 
Although the program's success represents a small proportion of the county's older population, it is in sharp contrast to the overall picture. For instance, the number of older people receiving unemployment benefits jumped in all age categories above 55, from January 2001 to January 2002, according to Sean MacDonald, associate economist with the state Department of Labor in White Plains. She confirmed that there has been an increase of nearly 42 percent in the last year in the number of people in Westchester County over 55 receiving unemployment benefits. 
Susie King, 65, of Mount Vernon ran her own cleaning business for years, but now needs to find a job. 
"When they see 65, they get frightened," Mrs. King said, referring to the corporate world, adding, "I don't know why they think we are going out to pasture. We have a life too, we eat, sleep, pay bills, and enjoy nice things." 
Arlene Kaplan, 56, a New Rochelle resident, worked for 24 years in administration and customer service for an insurance company before her department moved to a different state, and since then has held a number of temporary jobs. Ms. Kaplan wants a full-time job, but she has not kept up with computer developments, like Windows 2000, or even e-mail. 
Dorene Castle of New Rochelle, (who won't reveal her age for fear of age discrimination) has already received positive feedback. Ms. Castle, who was working freelance part time for a small publishing firm in the World Trade Center, is actively interviewing for jobs. She recounts a conversation with an interviewer several weeks ago. "I asked him what systems he used. He asked 'Do you know Word? I said 'yes.' He was pleased that I knew."
While students in Mr. Schachter's class are taking apart computers, brushing up on software programs, and mastering the Internet, another instructor, John Brown, focuses on people. Mr. Brown's "soft skills" class covers all aspects of customer service, from learning proper professional telephone etiquette and how to direct calls and leave a message, to handling irate customers. "Everything has to do with customer service," said Mr. Brown. He is known for his fondness of inspirational quotes from Aristotle and others, like this one from Thomas Dewar: "Minds are like parachutes -- they only function when open."
"I'm selling attitude, big time," Mr. Brown said. 
Important, Mrs. Richburg says, because when people are unemployed, "anger can ooze out." The class has the dual purpose of helping seniors acquire job skills and learn how to better present themselves. 
"What I really want is for them to walk away with self-confidence and a positive attitude," Mr. Brown said. "They are going out there better equipped than before. They have more customer service training than at least 80 to 90 percent of people on the job." 
Ms. Kaplan has been attending job fairs frequently. She senses more competition than ever, particularly since Sept. 11, but remains hopeful. "You can't give up," Ms. Kaplan said. "That's why I'm in this program." 
For more information, contact (914) 813-6432, or log onto www.westchestergov.com/ wplwis.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Judith Richburg, above, program administrator for the county Department of Senior Programs and Services. Top left: Arlene Kaplan, left, and Alice Jackson. Left: Joe Sosa, front, among students in a customer service workshop in White Plains. (Photographs by Suzy Allman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Wider Loan Pool Draws More Sharks 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THE subprime mortgage industry, which serves people with bad or blemished credit histories, has burgeoned in the economic boom of the last 10 years, allowing people previously deemed uncreditworthy to buy a home or to raise funds by refinancing their mortgage. But as the industry has expanded, so has its dark seam -- predatory lending.
 And as subprime loans have increased, so, too, have foreclosures. 
 Between 1993 and 1999, according to federal statistics, subprime lending jumped from 1 percent to 6 percent of the national home-purchase mortgage market. In the refinance segment -- flourishing in part because of low interest rates -- subprime lending bounded to 19 percent of the market in 1999 from only 1 percent six years earlier. Over the same period, foreclosures rose by 42 percent. 
In the New York metropolitan area, subprime lending grew from 0.9 percent of the total market in 1993 to 9.8 percent in 1999. In the home-purchase market, the share grew from 0.5 percent to 3 percent, while in the refinance segment, it jumped from 1 percent to 20.3 percent.
"We go to great pains to distinguish the subprime lending industry from predatory lending," said Sarah Ludwig, executive director of the Neighborhood Economic Development Advocacy Project, a nonprofit fair credit access organization based in Manhattan. "But what's inside the subprime is a strong undertow of unquestionably abusive and deceptive lending that is gouging people, leading to foreclosures and sapping community wealth." 
And it is "particularly African-Americans, often seniors, who are targeted," Ms. Ludwig said.
Predatory mortgages are typically based on a borrower's equity -- the current value of the home -- rather than the homeowner's ability to repay the loan. "The typical borrower is equity rich but cash poor," Ms. Ludwig said, "and, therefore, these loans are unaffordable. People end up jeopardizing their most valuable asset and, sometimes, their only real asset -- the home. And it relegates individuals to an ever-worsening cycle of bad credit and debt."
Christine Nicoll, 34, only wanted a leaky shower floor repaired at the house she bought in Red Hook, Brooklyn, in 1993 -- paid for outright with funds from the settlement she received after she was struck by a car and left with long-term physical and cognitive disabilities. "The contractor talked me into getting the whole bathroom done," she said.
Within months, Ms. Nicoll, who is on welfare, fell behind on the monthly payments for the original $33,000 home-improvement loan, according to her Legal Services lawyer, Pamela Sah -- and then the broker, who had been brought in by the contractor, convinced her to sign a $98,000 refinance mortgage. Ms. Nicoll is now facing foreclosure.
George McCarthy is a housing economist at the Ford Foundation who specializes in keeping track of mortgage-lending trends and practices throughout the country. "Every time you hear people testify at hearings about these practices, it reduces you to tears," Dr. McCarthy said. "You can't believe anyone would behave this way. I wonder how these guys, the predatory lenders, sleep at night."
As executive director of the National Home Equity Mortgage Association, Jeffrey Zeltzer represents a significant segment of the nation's subprime lenders. Mr. Zeltzer fully endorses the mission of his industry and the integrity of, by far, most of those lenders. 
They are serving "a customer who has been underserved or unserved since the beginning of mortgage financing," he said. "That includes people of color, single-parent heads of households, often self-employed people and certainly immigrants, particularly where they have several generations living in the home."
Yet, Mr. Zeltzer concedes, "I have seen it at the hearings where Mrs. Jones negotiates an 8 percent loan and the paperwork comes in at 10 percent. And the loan officer or the broker says, 'Don't worry, I'll take care of that, just sign here.' "
"What I saw, what concerned me," he continued, "was that some consumers, especially less sophisticated consumers, were being taken advantage of by home-improvement contractors -- not all, just some -- some brokers and some lenders who in their zeal to make the sale were, in some cases, misrepresenting the loan's terms."
Whatever its degree, the proliferation of predatory lending is certainly the outgrowth of an explosion in the subprime market -- distinct from the prime or conventional mortgage market, which serves buyers with satisfactory credit histories. And the subprime explosion since the early 1990's has been fueled by both the booming economy and the creation of new tools that allow lenders -- including Wall Street investors -- to rapidly assess the risk posed by a whole new group of potential borrowers.
T HIS came about because of computerized credit scoring," said Keith Gumbinger, a mortgage analyst and vice president at HSH Associates, a financial publishing company in Butler, N.J. Computerized scoring allows a would-be borrower's credit history to be assigned a single number -- between 300 and 900 -- by which a lender or an investor in mortgage-market securities can determine how likely the applicant is to repay the loan.
"Borrowers can be placed anywhere along that scale," Mr. Gumbinger said, "and investors and lenders adjust their rates and fees to compensate for riskier borrowers."
"It's the big mortgage lenders who fund smaller lending firms and street-level mortgage brokers that pressed these subprime products and predatory products onto the market in order to serve new audiences and get more people to owe them money," Mr. Gumbinger said. For a fee, packed into the loan, brokers bring borrowers and lenders together.
Ms. Ludwig agreed: "It's not just your rogue broker or lender on the street. This is very much built into the whole investment machinery so that even some of the large banking institutions, Wall Street investment houses and bond insurers have figured out a way to profit handily from this market segment."
Lenders provide the capital and either hold the loan or, more commonly these days, sell it either to another financial institution that buys up bundles of loans or to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, the federally chartered corporations that buy first mortgages at discounts, insure and then resell them. "Or it's often securitized through the packaging of these loans, which are then sold through Wall Street investment houses," Ms. Ludwig said, "usually to institutional investors. Without the secondary market, without securitization, you wouldn't have this proliferation of subprime and predatory lending."
Citing data collected by the Federal Reserve under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, Dr. McCarthy at the Ford Foundation said that in 1993, 6.9 million loans were originated in the combined purchase and refinance markets, of which 126,000 were subprime. By 1999, when a total of 6.8 million loans were made, 774,000 of them were subprime. "As you can see, the prime market had no growth while the subprime market increased by a magnitude of more than 6," Dr. McCarthy said.
"And over the same period," he continued, "while foreclosures in the prime market fell, foreclosures in the subprime market were high enough to push the overall mortgage market to an all-time high for foreclosures." In 1993, there were approximately 401,000 foreclosures in the entire market. By 1999, foreclosures had climbed to 573,000 -- a 42 percent jump. "And that includes a 20 percent drop for foreclosures in the prime market, taken alone," Dr. McCarthy said.
Not surprisingly, it is the uninformed who are most preyed upon. In 1999, Dr. McCarthy said, Freddie Mac analyzed its portfolio and found that one third of its subprime borrowers should have been in the prime market, paying lower interest rates and fees. A similar analysis by Fannie Mae found that half of its subprime portfolio belonged in the prime market.
And there is a racial tinge to predatory lending. In 1999, the Department of Housing and Urban Development conducted a study, "The Unequal Burden: Income and Racial Disparities in Subprime Lending," which found that upper-income African-American homeowners across the nation were twice as likely to hold subprime loans than low-income white homeowners; and that in the New York area, high-income African-Americans were four times as likely as low-income whites to have subprime loans. Nationally, high income was defined as $60,240 or more for a family of four; in the New York area, it was $67,440 or more.
Josh Zinner is coordinator of the Foreclosure Prevention Project at South Brooklyn Legal Services, an agency that provides legal assistance to poor people involved in civil cases. "There's two types of mortgage fraud going on," he said -- not surprisingly, one involving home-purchase loans, the other regarding refinancing.
In the home-purchase category it is, particularly, first-time buyers seeking loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration who are targeted. "In these cases, real estate brokers who are acting as kind of one-stop shops will solicit low- or moderate-income people to purchase homes," Mr. Zinner said. Those brokers buy properties that are in poor condition for low prices, often at foreclosure auctions, and "flip" them at a higher price.
T HE reason they are called one-stop shops is because they also have appraisers working for them who go out and over-appraise the properties intentionally," Mr. Zinner said. "Then they slap a coat of paint on to cover the defects, represent to the buyer that the house is in good shape and tell the buyer they don't need an inspection."
"They will provide an attorney for the buyer at the closing -- another part of the one-stop shop -- and they will qualify the buyer, often falsifying that buyer's income for an F.H.A.-backed loan." Such falsified documentation -- attesting to income from, perhaps, baby-sitting or nonexistent tenants -- makes the borrower's income look more substantial, the loan more qualifiable.
"Let's say the property is worth $150,000," Mr. Zinner said. "The loan won't be for that amount; it will be for the over-appraised amount, say $225,000. So the borrower will end up with a property that's in lousy shape, often with significant structural defects, and the buyer will have an unaffordable mortgage that covers far more than the value of the property."
"When the buyer inevitably goes into default because they can't afford the payments, or else they can't afford a second loan they took out to do the repairs," Mr. Zinner continued, "then the lender will foreclose. And after the sale the lender will get paid back through the F.H.A. insurance for the full value of the over-appraisal."
The F.H.A. is a division of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. A spokesman for HUD said that it is increasing efforts to monitor subprime loans and that where it finds unscrupulously high default rates the lenders will be barred from HUD programs.
In April 1999, Pree Parker and his wife, Rachel Dildy, bought a two-story frame house on Grant Avenue in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn, from Better Homes Depot for $257,000, with Madison Home Equities brought in by Better Homes as the lender. Later, a new appraiser -- hired by South Brooklyn Legal Services when the couple sought to avoid foreclosure -- placed the home's value at only $180,000.
"I didn't know much about buying a home," Mr. Parker, 40, a copying machine operator, said. "Better Homes provides you with the lawyer, the appraiser -- which, if I knew what I know now, I would have gotten my own appraiser."
Eric Fessler, the president of Better Homes Depot, said the original appraisal had been agreed upon by two separate appraisers, one of them "an approved Federal Housing Agency appraiser."
The house had no interior floors or walls when the Parkers first saw it. Better Homes Depot hired contractors to rebuild it. Soon after the couple and their six children moved in, structural problems surfaced.
"Holes in the roof," Mr. Parker said. "I have to redo the ceiling. I've had seven floods in the basement, human feces; it was past my knees."
Mr. Fessler said that the house was renovated "utilizing licensed electricians and contractors" and that "the Parkers had 60 days between contract and closing to inspect the premises."
Pamela Sah, the Legal Services lawyer who represents Ms. Nicoll, the disabled woman facing foreclosure in Red Hook, also represents the Parkers. Ms. Sah said the couple was not informed that they could obtain an inspection prior to the closing. 
Mr. Fessler said that claim "is belied by the forms that were signed by Mr. Parker two months prior to closing." Ms. Sah says Mr. Parker signed them at the closing.
At the closing, Mr. Parker said, "they had like 500 pieces of paper for me to sign. I hadn't seen them before."
Ms. Sah said her clients were told they were getting a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage, but at the closing were given an adjustable-rate mortgage. Mr. Fessler said the mortgage the Parkers "entered into had a one-year adjustable rate with a cap of 5 percentage points" -- meaning that during the first year the rate was 5.5 percent, with the possibility of rising by another 5 percentage points over its term.
The Parkers are hurting. After the first year, their payments rose by $200 a month to $1,700 -- a squeeze with six children and a combined income of $50,000. They are facing foreclosure. And there is the emotional toll. "Every time it rains and I'm at the job I feel sad because I know something's wrong at the house," Mr. Parker said. "It turned into the American nightmare."
In 2000, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs filed suit against Better Homes Depot, saying that "the defendants have repeatedly committed deceptive trade practices against home buyers in violation of the New York City Consumer Protection Law." More specifically, the suit charged that the company "sold homes at greatly inflated prices," that it "discouraged buyers from exercising their right to retain an attorney" and that renovations promised by the company were "carried out in a shoddy and incomplete manner." 
In its response, Better Homes denied each of the city's allegations of deceptive practices. The suit, which does not include the Parkers' situation, is pending in State Supreme Court.
THE most prevalent predatory practice is the refinance loan, for which "the classic M.O.," Mr. Zinner said, "is where brokers or contractors, acting essentially as bird dogs for lenders, go door to door in low-income neighborhoods."
Their target, he said, "is the working poor -- someone who bought the property cheap, or their family bought way back in the 50's, 60's, and now property values have gone up; but the person is no longer working, is on a fixed income."
The property may need repairs because the owner has not been able to afford them. "People may need a new roof, for example, but other stuff will appear on the contract -- bathrooms redone, railings on stairways, siding," Mr. Zinner said. "That stuff is added on." The contracts are used to leverage people into high-cost loans.
"At that stage, the broker takes over, refers the loan to a lender, adds broker's fees onto the loan," Mr. Zinner said. "These fees often bear little relation to the actual value of services provided." The fees are called points, with each point representing one percent of the entire loan.
Often, refinance loans are packed with unsecured debt.
"Debt consolidation can benefit the borrower who is making informed decisions," Ms. Ludwig said. "But who we see targeted is the vulnerable senior, the widow living on Social Security who has outstanding credit-card debt at a relatively high interest rate." (Credit card companies are prohibited from collecting against Social Security income.)
And while the interest rate may be lower when credit-card debt is consolidated into a mortgage, "that woman is never going to lose her home if she fails to pay her credit-card debt," Ms. Ludwig said. "Once she consolidates it into the mortgage, however, her home is at stake because now the collateral is her home." 
And what the unsophisticated borrower also doesn't know, Ms. Ludwig added, "is that this is yet another way for the broker to pad the loan and jack up the payments."
Often, loan terms that are neutral or even beneficial in the prime lending market become predatory in the subprime market. Balloon payments, for example, may be appropriate for a co-op that plans to restructure its underlying mortgage after a certain period, or for the home buyer who expects to move within a few years. Under balloon payments, a lower interest rate is paid for, perhaps, three or five years, and then the entire principal comes due.
In a predatory scenario, "while a balloon loan might look affordable at first because monthly payments tend to be low," Ms. Ludwig said, "many borrowers come forward after they have been served with a foreclosure notice and they had no idea that there was a balloon provision in their loan."
"And that is used by brokers and lenders to insure that the homeowner will need to refinance, yet again, to avoid foreclosure," she said, "while the broker and lender hit the cash register again, collecting more points, more fees, perhaps a prepayment penalty, stripping out more equity and putting the borrower in a new loan that yet again does not benefit -- typically -- her."
Another predatory practice is called default interest -- a rate increase that kicks in if a borrower misses a certain number of payments. "It's pretty much a nail in the coffin," Ms. Ludwig said. "If the person can't make the higher payments, the lender files for foreclosure and can get title to the house." In gentrifying neighborhoods, that can be particularly profitable.
The proliferation of predatory lending has not escaped official attention.
In October 2000, the New York State Banking Department issued regulations defining a loan as "high cost" -- though not predatory -- if its rate is 8 percentage points above the prevailing yield on Treasury bonds or if the points and fees exceed 5 percent of the loan amount. It is legal for lenders to originate mortgages above those thresholds, but, according to the regulations, with certain prohibitions, including: charging default interest, paying a home-improvement contractor directly from the proceeds of the loan and charging fees for services not performed.
Some legislators and many fair-credit advocates contend, however, that there are loopholes in the Banking Department regulations. For example, the regulations prohibit "unaffordable loans," except "under compelling circumstances." 
Ms. Ludwig said, "It should be a basic tenet of all sound lending that the loan must be affordable to the borrower."
LAST July, the Assembly passed a bill -- sponsored by Aurelia Greene, a Bronx Democrat and chairwoman of the Assembly Banks Committee -- that would close many of the loopholes. This past Monday, the State Senate Banks Committee held hearings on the bill, which would, among other things:
*Require that borrowers of high-cost loans, as defined by the law, be advised by a HUD-certified mortgage counselor before the loan is executed.
*Prohibit balloon payments and prepayment penalties for high-cost loans.
*Prohibit a lender who is refinancing a loan for the same borrower from charging new fees.
*Allow homeowners to defend themselves against foreclosure if they can prove that the loan was predatory, as defined by the law.
Testifying at Monday's hearing, Michael P. Smith, the president of the New York State Bankers Association, which represents more than 100 commercial banks across the state, said he was "pleased to reaffirm our unwavering opposition to predatory lending practices."
At the same time, Mr. Smith said: "It is critical that while seeking to stop abusive predatory practices, we do not throw the baby out with the bath water. That is, we must be careful not to impose restrictions on legitimate lenders that inadvertently deny access to those very consumers we are seeking to protect."
Mr. Smith said his association was particularly troubled that the thresholds the bill establishes to define high-cost loans -- 5 percentage points above the prevailing Treasury bond rate, and points and fees that exceed 5 percent of the loan amount -- "are so low as to have the effect of restricting credit to worthy borrowers." He also said his members were "concerned that once you are defined as a high-cost lender, there are practices that are either restricted or prohibited -- such as balloon payments and the financing of points and fees -- which could be beneficial to the borrower."
The day after the hearing, the chairman of the Banks Committee, Senator Hugh T. Farley, Republican of Schenectady, said, "The bill will pass."
Asked if it would remain in its present form, Senator Farley said: "It's very difficult for me to say what's going to be changed because we're still reviewing the testimony. We're going to negotiate; I've got to get it through both houses."
"There are some things that the financial community really objected to," the senator continued. "Realtors expressed concern that it would have a chilling effect on the market." More specifically, he said, "We're hoping that the threshold" -- for defining a high-cost loan -- "will be higher than what is currently in the bill." 
"The basic thing is that we want to stop predatory lending," he said, "but we don't want to eliminate credit for people who really need it."

SECTION: Section 9; Column 3; Society Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 403 words

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Susan Jacobs, Anders Matzen

 BODY:
Susan Jacobs, an anthropologist, and Anders Matzen, an economist, were married yesterday at the Fust Library in Boca Grande, Fla. Judge W. Wayne Woodard of the Charlotte County Court in Punta Gorda, Fla., officiated. 
 The bride, 35, will take her husband's name. She works in the social development department of the World Bank, and the bridegroom, 32, works at the International Monetary Fund, both in Washington. 
 The bride graduated magna cum laude from Duke and received a master's degree in anthropolgy from McGill University in Montreal. She is the daughter of Sandra and Eugene Jacobs of Boca Grande. Her father retired as a vice president and securities broker in Jenkintown, Pa., for Advest, investment advisers. Her mother is a travel writer.
The bridegroom graduated with bachelor's and master's degrees in economics from the University of Copenhagen and received a master's degree in international political economy from the University of Warwick in England. He is a son of Sys Matzen and Dr. Peter Matzen of Copenhagen. The bridegroom's mother is an occupational therapist for Horsholm, a city in Denmark. His father is a chief gastroenterologist for Copenhagen and also has a practice there.
Ms. Jacobs and Mr. Matzen met in March 2000 at a party given in Washington by mutual friends. "Another friend had just broken up with her boyfriend, and we went to the party with the goal of finding her a date," Ms. Jacobs said.
Mr. Matzen was the prime candidate for that role. Later that evening, he and the woman, along with Ms. Jacobs and a friend of Mr. Matzen's, went dancing. But instead of drawing closer to the woman he had been earmarked for, he found himself attracted by Ms. Jacobs's humor and intelligence.
"I was dancing with Sue and was having a lot of fun," he said. They exchanged cards at the end of the evening, and within days he sent her an e-mail message inviting her to dinner. He warned during the meal that he was in the United States for only two years. So, he said, "You shouldn't get your hopes too high." Ms. Jacobs replied, "Don't worry, I wasn't planning on more than three weeks anyway."
In fact, Ms. Jacobs, whose professional life had been going very well, had been looking to enrich her social life. Now she had Mr. Matzen in her sights. 
"He thought it was all innocent, but it was not," Ms. Jacobs said mischievously. "He didn't hear the 'click click' of the safety coming off." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Lockbox or Not, Social Security's Ills Grow

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
BRACE yourselves. If you receive Social Security benefits or assume that you will one day -- Republicans and Democrats are about to barrage you anew with claims, counterclaims, promises and warnings about the fate of the retirement system.
 They will have a common theme: that the other side is seeking to embark the nation on a path that will leave the government unable to meet its obligations to the elderly. 
 The budget surplus is gone, and with it Al Gore's lockbox. But the underlying economic and demographic problems that have cast doubt on Social Security's long-term financial soundness are unchanged. So is the reality that beating up Republicans over the retirement system is still the best political weapon in the Democratic arsenal. 
Democrats are casting this year's budget fight in Congress as a test of which party can do more to wean the government off of using excess Social Security revenue to pay for general programs.
As one way of making their point, Democrats are preparing to assail the administration for having to request an increase in the legal limit on the national debt, a step they say proves that the tax cut last year was fiscally irresponsible.
In the wake of the Enron collapse -- and looking for an issue to carry into the Congressional elections this fall -- Democrats are trying to focus attention again on the push by Mr. Bush and many conservatives to let workers invest a portion of their Social Security taxes in the stock market.
The debate is sure to be as confusing as it is ugly. Following is a voter's guide to the issue.
What's really going on with Social Security costs?
The population is getting older. When the 76 million baby boomers start retiring in earnest at the end of this decade, the cost of paying retirement benefits will soar.
As perhaps the most successful and popular government program of all time, the effects on Social Security have dominated political discourse in recent years. But the problem is just as bad, if not worse, for Medicare, the health insurance system for retirees.
Dan L. Crippen, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the Senate Finance Committee this month that the cost of paying Medicare benefits would grow to 5.4 percent of gross domestic product in 2030 from 2.3 percent today, reflecting both the demographic shift and the rising cost of health care. Medicare and Social Security together would rise to nearly 12 percent of G.D.P. in 2030 from just over 6 percent today. That would be more than half the total federal budget.
In Social Security's case, the tax levied on workers and employers to pay benefits will not be nearly enough to cover the bill.
So what does any of this have to do with this year's budget or the national debt?
Under President Bill Clinton, the Democrats adopted the view that the best way to prepare for the demographic tidal wave was to use the budget surplus to pay down the national debt. The idea was that by leaving the government debt-free by 2012, Washington would have more flexibility to borrow money again over the next few decades to help cover benefits.
Republicans bought into the idea. The two parties agreed on a target with tremendous symbolism but no particular economic meaning: they would reduce the debt each year by at least the amount of the temporary surplus in Social Security revenue. Thus was born the lockbox.
But after Mr. Bush's tax cut and the recession, the non-Social Security budget surplus disappeared, leaving the government again partly dependent on Social Security revenue.
The economic effect is less debt reduction. The political effect has been a battle royal over what's to blame. The Democrats say the tax cut. The Republicans say the combination of war and recession.
Democrats are pushing a budget plan in the Senate that they say will end the practice of spending the Social Security surplus by 2008. Republicans say their plan is smoke and mirrors. They are pushing their own plan through the House that they say sets the stage for dealing with the problem by making the country militarily and economically secure.
But what are the two parties actually doing to address the underlying problem?
So far, not much. No one can change the demographic outlook. The Republican approach of adding personal investment accounts to the program would not by itself solve the financial shortfall, and in some ways would make it worse. The Democratic plan amounts to hoping for a return of the budget surplus.
But don't expect either side to be contrite between now and Election Day.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SILICON ALLEY; 
A Once-Evocative Name Falls Victim To the Bursting of the High-Tech Bubble

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
It's now official. Silicon Alley, the district that presided over a thousand dot-com pies in the sky, is dead.
 This month, the giant billboard that proclaimed "DoubleClick Welcomes You to Silicon Alley" and long served as the area's unofficial gateway, was removed from its rooftop at 22nd Street and Broadway. 
 "We are putting our ad dollars into more strategic media allocations," explained a spokesman for DoubleClick, a well-known online advertising company.
Requiems for the short-lived neighborhood were hard to avoid. 
"It's obviously the end of an era," said Ben Silverman, 27, a former executive at Bla-Bla.com who now runs an Internet news site, Dotcom Scoop, from his apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
Others were exuberant. "What a great thing!" said Bill Lessard, a co-author of "Netslaves: True Tales of Working the Web" (McGraw-Hill Professional Publishing, 2000).
"To me, it represents that the stupidity is finally over."
The DoubleClick welcome mat went up in early 1998, just as the company went public and New York dot-coms were struggling to compete with Silicon Valley in California. There were also half a dozen "silicon alleys" around at the time, in London, San Francisco, Boston and elsewhere.
"But here in New York, we defined it and made it stick," said Jason McCabe Calacanis, former publisher of The Silicon Alley Reporter, which ran a map of the new district in its inaugural issue.
The heart of the alley extended roughly from the Flatiron Building on 23rd Street to Union Square, a corridor of industrial lofts that saw its rents bubble over, as old sewing stations were replaced by Herman Miller work pods. 
Today, the words "Silicon Alley" have disappeared from Mr. Calacanis's magazine, which is now called Venture Reporter. A computer search of New York publications found only 32 references to "Silicon Alley" so far this year, compared with 168 for the same period in 2001 and 144 in 2000. And, in contrast to the past, the phrase is virtually absent from the real estate listings.
"I can't remember the last time I heard the term used," said Mark Mandell, a commercial broker at Cushman & Wakefield, who once had clients asking for a street named Silicon Alley. "It's lost its cachet completely."
Some people still defend the term. "I regard Silicon Alley as the tristate area," said Steve Brotman of Silicon Alley Venture Partners, an investment firm in the garment district. "It's shorthand for saying technology in New York."
Alice O'Rourke, executive director of the New York New Media Association, an organization whose membership has declined to 6,300 from 8,200 two years ago, is optimistic. To her, the removal of the billboard "suggests a new beginning."
But in some circles the term "Silicon Alley" is already mud. Michael LeFort, president of Mammal Fish, an Internet company, recalled a recent meeting at which a client had dismissed his Web design as "too Silicon Alley." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
The Market Is Bracing for a Telltale Earnings Season

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
FIRST-QUARTER corporate earnings reports start appearing next month, and if the results disappoint, the stock market will be in for a tumble.
Company guidance for the second quarter and the rest of the year is also crucial and will be scrutinized like entrails.
 The attention is warranted, because the reports are the first company data since the economic outlook for 2002 was turned on its head. Instead of being in the last quarter of a recession, the economy is now in recovery, a fact reflected in recent economic data and confirmed by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. 
 Chris Wolfe, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan's Private Bank, said, "Failure to deliver on earnings in this environment means that stock prices have nowhere to go but down." 
That is not to say that earnings will disappoint, but that they are particularly important because the stock market, at its current ratio of price to earnings, is much overvalued. According to J. P. Morgan, the P/E ratio of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, using operating earnings, was 44 at the end of last year. That was the highest since the late 1940's and three times the average since then. The only recent brush with such high valuations came in the spring and summer of 1999, not long before the stock market buckled in March 2000.
A dose of strong earnings is needed to bring this price-to-earnings barometer back down to more livable levels.
As of now, earnings forecasts for the first quarter gathered by Thomson Financial/First Call may not offer that reassurance. Charles L. Hill, director of research at First Call, said he expected earnings for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to decline 12 percent in the first quarter, compared with a year earlier.
But Mr. Hill does see some encouraging signs. The percentage of positive earnings pre-announcements and the percentage of positive earnings forecast revisions by company analysts have been climbing recently. And while the outlook for the second quarter is still fuzzy, he expects earnings to inch up 2 percent to 3 percent, which would make it the first quarterly increase after five declines.
J. P. Morgan is upbeat about the profits outlook. In forecasting a 20 percent surge for the year in overall corporate profits based on the gross domestic product, the firm is banking on the traditional profit jump associated with economic recovery. With that recovery coming sooner than expected, so will the rise in profits.
A slide in unit labor costs is expected to play a larger-than-usual role in helping companies raise profit margins as sales volume picks up and productivity remains strong. Unit labor costs fell at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter last year.
Still, Bruce Kasman and Robert Mellman, the economists who conducted the profits analysis for J.P. Morgan, said the earnings increase over the next four quarters would be less than the average first-year rebound during the last five economic expansions. The biggest were the 64 percent surge after the 1973-75 recession and the 56 percent increase that began at the end of 1982. After the 1990-91 recession, profits rose just 6 percent in the first year. Mr. Wolfe is forecasting a climb of 15 to 18 percent in profits for the S.& P. 500.
A SURGE in earnings this year does not mean that the trend will continue. "Although the economy will experience a cyclical bounce, it is not positioned for a sustained upturn in profit margins," Mr. Kasman and Mr. Mellman wrote in their report. "Pricing power remains limited in an environment of global excess capacity and a strong dollar. And without the benefits of the labor market slack and falling interest rates present in the early 1990's, it is unlikely that costs can be compressed on an ongoing basis."
Worrisome, too, is the quality of the rising earnings. The accounting problems highlighted by the Enron scandal may make some companies more careful about pushing the profits envelope. But investors are likely to be skeptical for some time. So big profit numbers might not produce the stock rallies that they used to.

Graph shows ratio based on operating earnings and stock prices through the end of last year, calculated monthly from the 50's to the 90's. (Source: J. P. Morgan)

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Craig T. Callahan and Derek N. Rollingson; 
Icon Financial Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IN choosing stocks for the $58 million Icon Financial fund, Craig T. Callahan and Derek N. Rollingson don't rely on company visits, meetings with management or detailed studies of a company's competitive advantages.
 Instead, they base their decisions on a quantitative analysis of a stock's value, inspired by Benjamin Graham, the co-author, with David L. Dodd, of "Security Analysis," the 1934 classic text for value investors. 
 "We believe that markets have themes, with industry leadership typically lasting one or two years," Mr. Callahan said from his office in Greenwood Village, Colo., a Denver suburb. The managers analyze the relative value of financial-services industries, selling stocks in overpriced ones and buying in underpriced ones, he said. 
The fund returned 13.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, versus 6.2 percent for its peer group of financial funds and a 2.7 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500, according to Morningstar. It returned 18.5 percent in the last 12 months, versus 14.5 percent for its group and 4.2 percent for the S.& P. 500.
Mr. Callahan, 51, is the lead manager of the fund and the chief investment officer of the Meridian Investment Management Corporation, the fund's adviser. Meridian manages more than $1 billion for individuals and institutions. Mr. Rollingson, 29, is assistant portfolio manager. 
Looking among 200 to 300 financial services companies of all sizes in the United States, the managers use an industry rotation strategy to choose the fund's 30 to 40 stocks. It typically own stocks in five or six of the nine financial services industries in the S.& P. Super Composite 1500 index.
To pick the financial industries in which to concentrate, the managers use a valuation system based on the "central value equation" devised by Mr. Graham, taking into account historical earnings, projected five-year earnings and stock price volatility. 
The model, run daily, creates a per-share intrinsic value for every company in each industry. Dividing the intrinsic value by the company's market price and then averaging the results for each industry yield what the managers call the industry's value-to-price ratio. Over all, this ratio is 1.2 for the portfolio companies, meaning that for every $1 invested, the managers believe they are receiving $1.20 in value.
The fund's biggest stake, at 39 percent of assets, is in diversified financial services companies, mainly brokerages and money managers. "When people feared a slowing economy last fall, these stocks became bargains," Mr. Callahan said, "and they have a big potential to rebound as the economy improves."
Its next biggest stake, at 16 percent, is in property and casualty insurers. When the market reopened after Sept. 11, insurers' stocks tumbled. "We saw them as great bargains then, and we still think they're underpriced," he said.
To pick companies in the selected industries, the managers screen them for low debt levels and high liquidity. "We try to protect against companies that won't participate in the industry move because of risks unique to themselves," Mr. Callahan said.
They pore over income statements and balance sheets, looking for evidence that a company is run efficiently. Among brokerage firms, they want steady or improving profit margins; among banks, a big difference in what they pay out and what they receive on loans. 
They sell stocks in financial industries that fall to the bottom 10 percent of value-to-price rankings among the 123 industries in the S.& P. Super Composite.
 THE managers like Eaton Vance, the investment company in Boston. The fund started buying shares in December 2000, paying an average of $32.34; they now trade at $38.15. The company is flush with cash, Mr. Rollingson said, and its profit margin is now 39.25 percent.
Among property and casualty insurers, they like MGIC Investment of Milwaukee, a mortgage insurer. The company's operating profit has increased every year the last 10 years. The fund first bought shares in January 2001, at $66.50, on average; they are now at $67.40. 
Last April, the fund started buying shares of the Investment Technology Group, a New York City company that provides equity trading services and transaction research to institutional investors and brokers. It has a solid balance sheet and high profit margins and no long-term debt, Mr. Rollingson said. The fund paid an average of $34.25 for the shares, which now trade at $51.62.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
It's Time for Investors to Start Acting Like Owners

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
YOU know that investors have left La-La Land when a titan like General Electric is taken to the woodshed by one of them. 
 Last Wednesday, William H. Gross, manager of the world's largest bond fund at Pacific Investment Management, castigated G.E., saying it was not disclosing enough about its operations or financing needs to bond investors. Mr. Gross's comments on Pimco's Web site followed G.E.'s issuance of $11 billion in debt and filing of a $50 billion shelf offering, letting it come to market for that money any time. 
 "I want companies to face up to their owners and yes -- their creditors," Mr. Gross stated. "Pimco will own no G.E. commercial paper in the foreseeable future." 
Interesting that it took a bond guy to break up the lovefest between G.E. and investors. Bondholders usually bank their interest payments quietly, watch closely for signs of deteriorating balance sheets and vote with their feet, not their mouths.
But company balance sheets, which bond investors care about, have become loaded with debt in recent years. So it is not surprising that Mr. Gross spoke out. He is to be commended for it.
It is about time investors start making demands of their companies. After all, the transfer of wealth from companies' shareholders to their executives in recent years has been nothing short of immense. Investors have been amazingly silent as the money changed hands. 
Shamefully willing to let executives do whatever they wanted during the bull market, shareholders have stood happily by even when their stakes have been wildly diluted. Consider the option grants given to executives. According to a recent report by Smithers & Company, an economic consulting firm in London, the value of options granted at the 325 largest companies in the United States equaled almost 20 percent of their pretax profits in 2000, the latest year for which data is available.
Stockholders have also let companies make hare-brained acquisitions that produced significant writedowns almost immediately. 
John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group, says stockholders have been part of a happy conspiracy. Made up of corporate executives, auditors, Wall Street bankers, analysts and shareholders, the conspiracy's shared goal has been a rising stock price. 
Unfortunately, as Enron investors learned, if the rising stock price is built on something other than the rising value of the company's cash flows, they are vulnerable. 
G.E. seems stunned to be the subject of investor doubts. On Friday, Gary Sheffer, G.E.'s spokesman, responded testily when asked why G.E. does not hold conference calls to answer investor questions when it announces quarterly earnings and why the company, one of the nation's biggest issuers of corporate debt, does not provide balance sheets to investors in its earnings releases. 
"We felt we communicated with people interested in following the company pretty well," Mr. Sheffer said. "We have more than 200 analyst meetings a year and are available to answer questions any time."
Later, Mr. Sheffer called back to say that beginning with the company's second-quarter earnings report, G.E. would sponsor conference calls with investors and provide balance sheets in earnings releases. 
Shareholders of the world, take note: Start acting like the owners you are. Make demands of managers, keep a watch on their activities, rein in their obscene pay packages. Corporate executives are your hired hands, after all, but you've let them get pretty uppity in recent years. It's time to show them who's boss.

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
Which Way China? A Collision of Views

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
AS the bureau chief in Beijing for United Press International in 1981 and 1982, I remember the joking among expatriates about the two kinds of foreigners in China. There were those who became teachers and translators and fell in love with the Chinese. They lost all detachment, all perspective. But then there were the foreigners who never really connected to the culture or the language. They might have been present in the Middle Kingdom, but they didn't even try to get the Chinese reality.
 Unfortunately, little has changed over the course of two decades of American-Chinese engagement, judging from two of the latest books about China to be published in the United States -- "China Dawn: The Story of a Technology and Business Revolution" (HarperBusiness, $26.95), by David Sheff, and "The China Dream: The Quest for the Last Great Untapped Market on Earth" (Atlantic Monthly Press, $27), by Joe Studwell. 
 Despite the similarity in titles, the books take diametrically opposed views of what is happening in China. Mr. Sheff, a writer based in San Francisco for Wired, Playboy and Yahoo Internet Life, became infatuated with a group of Chinese Internet entrepreneurs who founded companies like Sina.com, China Netcom and AsiaInfo. He followed their movements across the Pacific Ocean for three years, became an adviser to one company and even invested in it. By any standard of American business journalism, he has a conflict of interest. Mr. Sheff became way too close to his subjects, and he acknowledges it. "I am not objective about my subjects or their work," he writes.
Small wonder that he writes such flattering prose about these young entrepreneurs, whose lives were shaped by the Cultural Revolution and the Tiananmen Square crackdown as much as by finishing their educations in the United States. 
They are helping China roll out high-speed Internet access in a way that Mr. Sheff says just might allow China to leapfrog the West technologically. His entrepreneurs see the Internet as forcing sweeping change, indeed a new revolution, in their homeland. "A new China will emerge," the author writes, apparently with a straight face. How many hundreds of times has a new China been proclaimed? It may be that the Internet will have huge impact, but the reader has to decide if Mr. Sheff is engaged in real arm's-length reportage and analysis, or if he is engaged in promotional writing.
At the opposite end of the spectrum, Mr. Studwell spent 10 years in China, working for a time for The Economist and The Economist Intelligence Unit, its business information arm. Yet there is little evidence in the book that he had sustained contact with Chinese people. Hasn't he seen the explosion of wealth in Shanghai or Shenzhen or Beijing? Hasn't he seen how the clothes the Chinese wear have changed over the years from drab Mao suits to business suits and brightly colored dresses?
Instead, in a strangely distant statistical and ideological argument, he writes that the Chinese economy is doomed to collapse and that nearly all foreign multinationals that have invested there were duped. Western executives who have pumped tens of billions of dollars into the country were merely living out "their China fantasies," Mr. Studwell writes. Moreover, China's attempt to blend some Western economic lessons into Chinese-style socialism is "nonsense," he declares.
Mr. Studwell makes some valid points about the mistakes foreigners have made in China and portrays accurately a political and economic system that is far from perfect. But it seems rash for him to dismiss the system, under which 1.3 billion people live and work, as nonsense. Dripping with condescension, he writes that "the biggest myth about China in the 1990's was that the country ceased to be socialist." Few serious China-watchers ever believed that the Chinese had abandoned their version of socialism. Not then. Not now.
In Mr. Studwell's view, the Chinese will never emerge economically unless they deregulate and debureaucratize their system, and quickly. It seems Mr. Studwell wants the Chinese to go the big bang route to creating instant Western-style democratic capitalism. Many China experts would challenge that approach, particularly in view of how spectacularly the Soviet Union failed in its big bang economic transformation. His 58 pages of often tedious footnotes don't do much to lend his argument objectivity or balance.
Despite its failings, Mr. Sheff's book is by far the better of the two. Yes, there is the irritating way he starts by describing how he went surfing with Bo Feng, a young Chinese venture capitalist who was one of the first to attract Western money to China's Internet start-ups, and who is one of the principals of Mr. Sheff's book. Maybe surfing passes as deep truth for the Wired audience, but not for everyone. Mr. Sheff also makes errors like misstating the meaning of the term "pinyin." It refers to the system of transliterating Chinese characters, not to the characters themselves.
But at least Mr. Sheff has tasted the reality of what is happening in Beijing's Zhongguancun, the Chinese capital's version of Silicon Valley. That does yield some interesting insights. As this generation of entrepreneurs tries to deploy the Internet, a major handicap is the absence of management expertise. Many don't understand the need to define their market, define the competition and actually make money within a finite period. It's noteworthy that the preponderance of these sorts of skills among Chinese entrepreneurs comes from their educations at American universities and through their contacts with American investors.
"CHINA DAWN" also sheds light on the riddle of the Chinese government's attitude toward the Internet. The government wants entrepreneurs to expand their Internet businesses, the private and state-backed variety, so that China's digital economy can grow. In that sense, the Communist Party and the entrepreneurs are united in their desire to use the Internet as a way to jump past economic rivals like the United States. It's true that China has more, newer fiber-optic networks than the United States because American companies are still making money from their older networks and are loath to walk away from them.
The Chinese government occasionally signals that it doesn't want foreign money involved in China's Internet because of its concern about losing control of sensitive assets. Yet entrepreneurs like Edward Tian, 39, who got his doctorate at Texas Tech University and was the first chief executive of China Netcom, know the government does not necessarily mean what it says -- Chinese officials are aware that these companies need foreign capital. That is why the government has devised ways to allow the News Corporation, AOL Time Warner and most recently eBay to invest.
Mr. Sheff's description of the maneuvering among rival government agencies is particularly instructive. Mr. Tian, possibly the star of the book, left AsiaInfo to create China Netcom, a government-backed telecommunications company. Four government entities helped start it -- the Ministry of Railways; the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television; the Shanghai city government; and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, where Jiang Mianhen, son of China's president, Jiang Zemin, played a prominent role.
Mr. Tian was promised that he would be able to run Netcom as a Western-style start-up. Its goal was to lay enough fiber-optic cable to create a broadband network that could compete against the much stodgier, government-controlled China Telecom. The book even describes a visit to China Netcom by the premier, Zhu Rongji, who is impressed at the rapid progress Netcom has made under Mr. Tian's aggressive, American-style leadership.
But the book also describes how Mr. Tian was constantly seeking to please his government sponsors. They couldn't leave him alone, as they had promised. Indeed, after Mr. Sheff finished the book, the government split China Telecom into four entities and merged China Netcom into one of them. It is unclear what role Mr. Tian will play. The maneuvering among government bureaucrats does reduce the transparency of the Chinese system and makes it difficult for private Internet entrepreneurs to thrive.
So, as usual, the messy truth about China's future lies somewhere between starry optimism and cynical dismissal. What's conspicuously lacking in these books, as in many previous ones, is an effort to define a more nuanced analysis of what's happening in China. It appears that all that sells is pie-in-the-sky transformation or utter collapse.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Book Value column on March 24, reviewing "China Dawn," by David Sheff, misattributed the comment "A new China will emerge" in a quotation about the Internet's potential to help modernize China. The words were those of Edward Tian, an Internet entrepreneur in China, not the author's.

HEADLINE: Losses of Equal Value 

BYLINE:  By Michael I. Meyerson; Michael I. Meyerson is a professor at the University of Baltimore School of Law and author of "Political Numeracy."

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
The final rules for disbursing federal funds to the victims of Sept. 11 demonstrate the limits of mathematics in addressing the real but immeasurable values of human existence.
 Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master and administrator of the Victims Compensation Fund, announced earlier this month how money will be distributed to the victims and families of victims. For noneconomic loss, the lives lost are all treated alike. The rules value the pain and suffering of each individual who died at $250,000 and the intangible harm to each spouse or child of a victim at $100,000. But for economic loss there will be enormous differences in payments. 
 The formula bases awards for economic loss on an estimate of the wages the victim would have earned over the course of a lifetime, using his or her average salary for the preceding three years. Because of the formula's emphasis on economic loss, total payouts will vary from less than $400,000 to more than $4 million.
Critics frequently complain that calculations like these (which are often used in the courts) undervalue the loss suffered by people in lower-paying jobs. Even as a purely economic matter, the numbers are questionable. The salary-based calculation stubbornly presupposes that those in public service jobs, like military personnel, police officers, firefighters and emergency workers, would have stayed in those jobs, never changing their circumstances by moving on to other professions or going to medical or law school, for example. Nor does the formula consider that victims who worked only part-time or had left the job market to stay home with their young children might have returned to full-time work.
But even if the calculations were refined, why should lost income be the determining factor for payouts from this fund, permitting the family of one victim to recover more than 10 times what is given to that of another? The answer is that the compensation fund has been seen as a replacement for litigation. To shield the airlines from bankruptcy, the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act, which created the compensation fund, limits the liability of airlines in the Sept. 11 deaths largely to the amount of their insurance coverage. The act also requires that those who take money from the compensation fund agree up front to waive their right to sue.
Once the compensation fund was viewed as a surrogate for litigation, the calculations for disbursement fell into the same trap that has long plagued the legal system. In compensation calculations, concrete factors like lost wages tend to overwhelm intangible factors like emotional loss. It is all too easy to do the math with work hours rather than with heartbreak. How much simpler it is to pay the family that lost a stay-at-home parent for a housecleaning service and tuition at a day care center than to try to assess the lost value of the time the children would have spent with a parent: playing, learning, arguing, living.
The formula reflects the values of the tort system, which pragmatically reduces loss to a monetary calculation. But the purpose of the compensation fund is greater: to serve as a national expression of unity in the face of a tragedy unique in American history, as well as to help survivors. While juries are instructed routinely not to permit their sympathy for victims to enter into their consideration of damage awards, this fund represents an attempt to embody our collective sympathy.
The families of the firefighter and the financier, the broker and the busboy, with their shared emotional losses, should be compensated equally. What ultimately unites the victims and their survivors with each other and with the nation is far greater than the differences in their last paychecks.

HEADLINE: Ex-Leader of Belarus Challenges a Punishment by Pension 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 23 

 BODY:
Political enemies of Belarus's autocratic ruler, Aleksandr Lukashenko, have been hectored and arrested, and sometimes have even vanished. But his predecessor as president, Stanislav Shushkevich, is suffering in especially cruel and unusual fashion: the government refuses to index his monthly pension for inflation.
 In Belarus, where prices tripled annually through the 1990's and the currency periodically sheds zeroes to appear less worthless, that is a heartless fate indeed. 
 "It used to be around $200, which is a good pension by our standards," Mr. Shushkevich said in a telephone interview. "Now it is 3,196 rubles. That equals $1.80." Enough for four loaves of excellent brown bread or a bottle of vodka, but not both.
Mr. Shushkevich's inventive punishment has been going on for more than four years. But it came to light only this month, in a Minsk courtroom, after he sued the Labor and Social Security Ministry, arguing that President Lukashenko was engaging in political revenge.
The government denies that, but no one would dispute that Mr. Shushkevich would be a choice target. In December 1991, Mr. Shushkevich, then the chairman of his nation's Supreme Soviet, met with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Ukraine's leader, Leonid Kravchuk, at a Belarussian hunting lodge and signed the papers that dissolved the Soviet Union.
Mr. Lukashenko, an admirer of Stalin and all things Soviet, has called the dissolution of the Soviet Union a crime. He became president in 1994 by defeating Mr. Shushkevich, by then Belarus's leader, in a bitter election, and extended his rule through a questionable referendum in 1996.
By then, Mr. Shushkevich was a member of Belarus's democratic opposition, drawing a monthly pension of about 3.2 million rubles, about $200, for his past service as the chairman of Belarus's Supreme Soviet. In September 1997, Mr. Lukashenko issued an executive decree setting new rates and cost-of-living conditions for pensions of state officials -- except, it seems, former chairmen of the Supreme Soviet.
By coincidence, the only two retired chairmen were Mr. Shushkevich and Seymon Sheretsky, then the opposition leader. Mr. Sheretsky later fled Belarus after receiving death threats.
Mr. Shushkevich has stayed on, but since Mr. Lukashenko's decree was issued, the only change to his pension has been the lopping off of three zeroes. He calculates that his 3,196-ruble stipend is now less than one-hundredth of the inflation-adjusted pension of an official of similar rank.
Nor is that all, Mr. Shushkevich said. The government has declined to grant him the breaks on rent and city services accorded other retired officials. Nor is he allowed to teach, he said, although the state university still uses a prize-winning radioelectronics textbook he wrote.
Mr. Shushkevich said he had scraped by with the help of American scholars -- he worked at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington and lectured at Harvard, Yale and Columbia in early 2000 -- and by making occasional speeches in Poland.
He said he had been battling for his cost-of-living adjustment for more than two years, to no avail. Only after exhausting those appeals did he go to court, where the filing fee was 15 times his monthly pension.
The government argued that only the rubber-stamp Parliament could index Mr. Shushkevich's pension for inflation. This month, the court agreed.
Although he said he had no hope of winning a reversal, Mr. Shushkevich said he planned to appeal the decision to the highest court. He had better hurry. In the last three months, the value of his pension has dropped by 15 cents.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Stocks Retreat on Threat of Rising Rates

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Wall Street received upbeat news about the economy last week and treated it as a warning of problems ahead for earnings.
 Stocks retreated as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. 
In its announcement on Tuesday, the Fed indicated that it might begin raising interest rates if the economy continued to strengthen. 
 Investors worried that the financial and technology sectors would be hurt by rising rates. Leading a drop in technology was Intel, which fell sharply as analysts lowered revenue and profit predictions.
 Airline stocks also slumped. Delta Air Lines fell more than 8 percent after the company said it expected a quarterly loss of at least $350 million. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 179.56 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,427.67, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite declined by 16.91 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,851.39. The Standard and Poor's 500-stock index fell 17.46 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,148.70.
 The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell for the week on inflation fears. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.39 percent from 5.33 percent. MICHAEL BRICK

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Looking for a Few Good Eggs

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Eastertime is the season for eggs -- a time to hunt for them, dye them and eat them. The egg industry took in about $3.5 billion in revenue last year, and consumption in the United States has gone up steadily in the last few years, according to the American Egg Board. 
The rate is now 260 eggs per person a year, up from 234 in 1991, but still down from the high of 402 in 1945.
 The recent rise can be attributed in part to a revision by the American Heart Association in its recommended intake of egg yolks -- it now allows for up to four a week as a part of a healthy diet, instead of three, because studies have shown that they are slightly lower in cholesterol than previously thought. KATHLEEN O'BRIEN

HEADLINE: Land Advocates and Drivers Reach Fork in the Off-Road 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: BIG CYPRESS NATIONAL PRESERVE, Fla., March 22 

 BODY:
An avid outdoorsman, Lyle McCandless likes to spend his weekends here in the southwest Florida back country hunting for small game and fishing for large-mouth bass. 
 But in recent years, people who enjoy the land like Mr. McCandless have come under intense criticism from environmentalists, who say they are abusing the Big Cypress National Preserve and public wilderness areas throughout the country. That is because to get to the best hunting sites and fishing holes, Mr. McCandless and his buddies from the Collier County Sportsman's Club near Naples drive their off-road vehicles into the most remote sections of this 729,000-acre preserve, a vast undeveloped area of wetlands, cypress groves and protected wildlife. 
 Environmental groups contend that the squat, fat-tired all-terrain vehicles are damaging wetlands and wildlife by creating thousands of miles of deep ruts in the soil. The tracks in Big Cypress are so extensive that, from the air, the preserve looks as though someone has dropped thousands of giant strands of spaghetti on the land.
More than merely causing aesthetic damage, the environmentalists say, the tire tracks have damaged soil, water and vegetation and changed the habitat of endangered species like the Florida panther and the Cape Sable seaside sparrow.
In an effort to stop the damage, the groups have sought to limit or eliminate the use of all-terrain vehicles, swamp buggies and other off-road transportation in the preserve, which is 50 miles east of Naples and borders Everglades National Park.
As a result, a fight is raging between environmentalists and all-terrain vehicle users here that is a microcosm of the battle between interest groups and agencies nationwide trying to balance recreational use with preservation on public lands.
"What you have is a minority of the population using Big Cypress and other places around the nation as an amusement park for their thrill vehicles," said Erich Pica, an economic policy analyst for Friends of the Earth, a national environmental organization. "The environmental degradation it's caused, the air pollution it's caused and the effect on endangered species and other animals has to be factored into this use."
That, of course, is where the environmental groups and the users of all-terrain vehicles part ways. 
"You can't have an area that is public and have people come in and not leave a footprint," Mr. McCandless said. "There are extremists out there who want to have untouched land, and they can't have that when it's public land."
At the core of the issue is whether scars from all-terrain vehicle trails are simply aesthetically unpleasant to environmental purists or a cause of permanent damage to the nation's most fragile and biologically rich lands. The debate has stirred controversy in several states, including Minnesota, where legislators are considering a ban on off-trail use of the vehicles in state forests, and Georgia, where environmental groups are advocating the closing of illegal trails in national forests.
"There is growing public awareness about the damage these machines are inflicting all across the country, from the deserts of Southern California to our national forest in the Rocky Mountains to the state forest in Minnesota to national seashores in places like North Carolina, and the list goes on," said Scott Kovarovics, director of the Natural Trails and Waters Coalition.
Tempers have run so high in some states that people on opposing sides have nearly turned violent. 
"One of our board members had a gun pulled on him by a guy because the A.T.V. users were going anywhere they wanted, and he went out and dragged some debris against the trail," said Brent Martin, director of Georgia Forestwatch, a nonprofit group that has been collecting data on off-road vehicle damage to the Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forests in that state.
At Big Cypress, off-road vehicles have created 22,000 miles of deep ruts that have collected runoff and affected water quality and flow, the National Parks Service says. That has in turn changed animal habitats and plant growth, the agency contends.
Noise from the vehicles and the presence of people so far into the preserve has also frightened endangered species like the Florida panther and the Cape Sable seaside sparrow from their natural habitats, operators of the preserve say. 
In response, the preserve's operators have put into effect a land management plan that will gradually restrict the use of the vehicles to 400 miles of designated trails over 10 years.
"What we're trying to do is make sure people get out to the back country but also to make sure those resources are available for future generations," said John Donahue, superintendent of Big Cypress.
The restrictions, however, have angered Mr. McCandless and other riders, who filed a lawsuit in federal court last year challenging the plan. Negotiations to settle the dispute abruptly ended last month, and the two sides now say they will make their case in court.
The popularity of all-terrain vehicles is steadily increasing, according to the Motorcycle Industry Council. Last year, sales of the vehicles increased 12.4 percent to 825,000 units, according to the association.
Bill Horn, a Washington lawyer representing off-road vehicle users in Yellowstone and Big Cypress, says the debate is a philosophical one between traditional nature lovers, who think the land is for bird watching and hiking, and urbanites fond of vehicles that can tackle any manner of terrain. "It's the difference between some people looking at a swamp and seeing a hostile environment and others looking at a swamp and seeing a fragile ecology," Mr. Horn said. "I think what is happening is that there are attempts to take what are fundamentally subjective, aesthetic judgments and hide them under these illusory resource concerns."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tracks from recreational all-terrain vehicles mark the wilderness in Big Cypress National Preserve, a 729,000-acre area in southern Florida. (David Friedman for The New York Times)
