HEADLINE: Primedia's Improbable DigitalDreams 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR and LORNE MANLY 

 BODY:
PUSHING the elevator button to get to Primedia's offices on the 23rd floor at 745 Fifth Avenue, a block and a half south of Central Park, is like hitting a reset button to spring of 2000, back when digital enterprises were selling for unthinkable multiples. In these corridors, the old buzzwords linger, the traditional metrics do not apply, the PowerPoint diagrams always envelop the consumer, and the monetization of traffic -- remember traffic? -- lies just around the corner. 
 The man in charge is Tom Rogers, Primedia's supremely self-confident chief executive and digital evangelist, who made a huge bet on transforming an old-line publisher with a line of unrelated media properties -- including magazines like New York, Seventeen and National Hog Farmer -- into what he calls an integrated, old-media-new-media enterprise. 
 Mr. Rogers is the last true believer. A former General Electric executive who has spent his career counterintuiting convention in the media industry (he championed CNBC), he continues to engage in the kind of robust digital rhetoric that has others cringing. 
"There are thousands -- thousands upon thousands -- of advertisers that are buying new-media digital components to marketing programs," Mr. Rogers said, the drizzle and low clouds floating in the window behind him giving his words a mystical air.
But while the bubble that lives inside Mr. Rogers's head never popped, more than one bubble has popped out in the rest of the world, and it has left him little room to maneuver. Not only has the digital landscape been denuded of financing and advertising, the magazine publishing business, which even Mr. Rogers would acknowledge is at the core of his company, is awful. As a result, Primedia is laboring under a crushing debt, flat earnings and a depressed stock price that has Mr. Rogers selling assets, cutting costs and madly spinning Wall Street. Primedia's majority investor, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, is standing by Mr. Rogers. But Kohlberg Kravis's on-call consultant, Capstone Consulting, recently stepped in to assess exactly what is going on with Kohlberg's nearly $1 billion investment.
Unless the ad market recovers fast, however, the consultants have few options to suggest other than more layoffs and asset sales. People who covet some of Primedia's prized properties, like New York and Seventeen, are poised like crows on a telephone wire, hoping to swoop in and grab magazines Mr. Rogers can't afford to own. He may be a victim of questionable decisions, bad luck and bad timing, but he says he does not believe he is living in the past. He is too busy building the future.
At the moment, Mr. Rogers is defending himself against the accusation that he bet the company on a digital future and lost. He and Primedia officials contend, for example, that his decision to buy About.com, a collection of special-interest Web sites, in the fall of 2000 was perfectly timed, that his trading of ads for equity in now worthless digital enterprises was actually quite crafty and that his vision of an integrated media company built out of an odd collection of business and enthusiast magazines remains brilliant, if somewhat nascent.
"This is not a future strategy," Mr. Rogers said. "This is a here-and-now reality in terms of how we are approaching the marketplace and using incremental revenue to drive our market share."
Back down the elevator and out on the street, the market is delivering a different message. Mr. Rogers was hired to supercharge Primedia and to get it valued as an Internet company. He has succeeded only too well. From a high of $34.88 in early 2000, the stock closed on Friday at $3.18.
The combination of that stock price and $2.54 billion in debt has hamstrung the company, and Mr. Rogers is being forced to manage more by circumstance than strategy, keeping the debt at bay without mortgaging the future.
When he is on a roll, Mr. Rogers tends to sound like a high-octane mix of Jack Welch, the former G.E. chairman, and Robert Pittman, AOL Time Warner's chief operating officer. But while it is easy to talk about digital synergies between Warner Music and AOL, coming up with the overlay that connects Hay and Forage Grower with New York magazine is a little more difficult.
Mr. Rogers inherited an ornery beast indeed. Few publishing companies have both consumer magazines and trade publications, as Primedia does, because the business models and infrastructure needs, from circulation to ad sales, diverge significantly. And Primedia's consumer guide division, which consists of free directories filled with classified ads, like Apartment Guides, has another, totally different business model. 
THERE are other problem areas, too. The best known of Primedia's television businesses, Channel One, a news network for high-school classrooms, is struggling. It needs hundreds of millions of dollars to upgrade the television sets it provides to the schools that show its advertising. Primedia would clearly welcome a strategic partner to shoulder the bulk of those costs.
"The company is walking a very fine line in terms of financial viability, in terms of both excessive financial leverage and the worst magazine operation environment in the last 40 years," said Peter Appert at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "They have to thread the needle."
The dissonance between Mr. Rogers's vision and Wall Street's verdict threatens the investment of the majority owner, Kohlberg Kravis, which has put more money into Primedia than anything except RJR Nabisco. Little has gone right since Henry Kravis, the firm's boss, ushered out Mr. Rogers's predecessor, William F. Reilly, in 1999, because he was upset with a stock price in the teens and Mr. Reilly's unwillingness to embrace the Internet. Now those old-media days are looking mighty good. 
Mr. Rogers said strength in the company's special-interest consumer magazines, rapid growth in its consumer classified ad publications and declining costs in its Internet outlays will allow Primedia to reduce the debt -- and to soar when the advertising economy recovers.
"We have come up with a way of maximizing growth while minimizing the spending of cash," Mr. Rogers said, arguing that cross-pollination of old and new media will add momentum to both. "There is no metric to value an integrated traditional-media-new-media company."
Mr. Rogers says the press and the Street do not truly understand the company. But the reason Primedia gets no respect is that the company has failed to meet expectations it has created.
"When Tom Rogers came in, there was a lot of excitement and he gave explicit and aggressive guidance, which the company subsequently missed," said David Allen, a fixed-income analyst at Morgan Stanley, noting that the company failed to hit any of its quarterly targets last year.
Wall Street may overlook one-time misses, particularly when the economy slides into recession, but constant surprises from a highly leveraged company are not likely to be forgiven. Especially when the size of the miss is so large. 
For 2001, Mr. Rogers originally promised that Primedia would deliver $325 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, a common method of measuring media company performance. That would have amounted to a 30 percent increase over the previous year. By August, when it spent $515 million to acquire the United States holdings of Emap -- the owner of special-interest magazines like Motor Trend and Hot Rod -- Primedia had scaled back its guidance to a range of $280 million to $300 million. But when it announced its full-year numbers last month, Ebitda from continuing business topped out at $200.1 million on revenue of $1.7 billion.
That history makes analysts and investors just a mite nervous about this year's projections. Primedia has released estimates of full-year Ebitda that fall between $245 million and $260 million. The low end of that range just happens to cover the company's fixed payment costs this year, including $144 million in interest payments and $53 million of cash preferred dividends. Unfortunately, some analysts fear that Primedia's Ebitda will not be enough to cover those payments.
Primedia says its first-quarter Ebitda will be $30 million, meaning the rest of the year will need to account for 88 percent of the company's earnings. But no recent nine-month period in the company's history has accounted for more than 80 percent of a year's total. 
If Primedia misses, it will not be in jeopardy -- it has about $220 million in cash and unused credit lines, and there is no major debt repayment until June 2004. But another big earnings flop will be punished severely by the markets. 
"We said $245 million to $260 million," Mr. Rogers said flatly, adding that a full year of Emap earnings and cost savings would get Primedia there. "That is 22 to 30 percent growth. That is a big number. A lot of analysts think that is pretty aggressive and have us down at $220 million, which is 10 percent growth in a very down environment. If they are right, that is 10 percent growth. If we are right, that is 30 percent growth."
To keep a promise to Wall Street, meanwhile, that he would shed $250 million in debt, Mr. Rogers is trying to find a buyer for Primedia's gun and photography magazines. He has already sold $157 million in assets, including Bacon's Information and Modern Bride. And while the company denies that it plans to sell Channel One, it does say a strategic partner would be nice.
THERE are still believers out there who envision Primedia reaching the other side of the ad recession with an intact mix of potentially profitable enterprises. "I feel very comfortable with the company and with the current management," said Sam Shapiro of Shapiro Capital Management. "We own 11 million shares and are very comfortable with that position."
Mr. Kravis and his firm also say they are fully behind the strategy of Mr. Rogers and his team. "It's a work in process, made more challenging as the industry is in the midst of one of the worst advertising downturns in years," Mr. Kravis said in a statement. "However, K.K.R. remains confident that Primedia is on the right track and we are committed to the company for the long term."
There are investors who remain optimistic about Mr. Rogers's signature strategic move: the merger with About.com. The timing and price of the purchase was unquestionably bad, but there was some logic behind combining forces with an Internet company that created content from readers deeply interested in particular topics. The "theory of the case," a phrase that Mr. Rogers, a former lawyer, is fond of using, suggested that Primedia's primary business of serving people with specific passions would be a wonderful fit with About's huge traffic.
Fifty of its more than 200 magazines have About sites, and another 50 are coming soon. There has been a 45 percent increase in page views and unique visitors on the magazine sites, and the company expects ad revenue for 2002 to be up 70 percent over last year on a cash basis. The company expects to book several million dollars in digital revenue for its enthusiast sites alone. Important franchises like American Baby and Seventeen are doing package deals involving print, television, live events and the Web, according to the company.
About and Primedia's Web holdings are the fifth-most-visited site on the Web, according to the Jupiter Media Metrix numbers for Web use in the United States for January. But it is hard to see how that gusher of clicks comes with any viable business model that justifies the cost of the deal, a stock transaction worth $690 million when it was announced in October 2000 but $428 million by the time it closed the next February. Mr. Rogers says the company got crucial digital capacity without laying out cash it did not have and acquired $109 million in cash at the same time. But analysts say the deal diluted the value of the stock by as much as one-third.
At the time of the merger, Mr. Rogers raved about how About's entrepreneurial culture would spur Primedia properties into the digital age; now Mr. Rogers brags that 60 percent of the company's employees are gone, as are 70 percent of its costs. About, as a result, may break even on a cash-flow basis in the first quarter, according to the company, but revenue will be less than $50 million a year. Total new-media revenue is expected to be 8 percent to 12 percent of the $1.7 billion in sales Primedia expects this year.
DESPITE Mr. Rogers's fervor for his acquisition -- he pushed the deal through over the objections of some of his top executives -- few analysts and investment bankers still try to justify the move. Ad rates for banner ads were already tumbling in the fall of 2000. And the air was rapidly leaking out of the Internet economy, jeopardizing the dot-com advertisers that made up more than 60 percent of About's advertising base.
But the About-Primedia connection, in Mr. Rogers's view, was the niche version of AOL and Time Warner. Unfortunately, About does not have millions of people paying tidy monthly subscription fees to get at the content.
Even Jordan Rohan of SoundView Technologies, who is one of the more bullish among those who track the company, says focusing on acquisitions of yesteryear is not indicative of the company's health. "About gives them reach in the Internet world, but it is not the magic glue people once thought it was," he said.
The balance sheet now tells what Primedia really sees as About's value, thanks to new accounting rules that required Primedia to take a writedown of $326 million. The value is now pegged at $106 million. 
Some analysts believe Kohlberg Kravis will become more involved if Primedia continues to miss estimates. But at today's prices in the mergers-and-acquisitions market, Primedia would fetch barely enough to cover the debt and preferred shares, and Kohlberg Kravis would take a bath on its investment. 
So its only remaining strategy may be to insist that Mr. Rogers manage the margins ferociously and hope for a recovery. "Henry has already tried the C.E.O. fix," said a former Primedia publisher with knowledge of the situation. "Right now, he can't afford a verdict -- it's too big a problem."
Mr. Rogers acknowledges that there may be further divestitures, but he doubts he will be among them. He is confident because he has been right about not being wrong before, most notably with CNBC.
The problems, he said, "come down to something very simple."
"We are a highly leveraged company in the media business in the midst of a media recession," he said. "There was $2 billion in debt when I came to the party. I think we are managing the business pretty well, considering the cards we have been dealt."

HEADLINE: Rural Democratic Leaders Favor Cuomo in Straw Poll 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 23 

 BODY:
Andrew M. Cuomo narrowly defeated H. Carl McCall today in a straw poll of upstate Democratic leaders, a striking upset in one of the early tests in their race for the Democratic nomination for governor.
 The vote offered the most compelling evidence yet that Mr. Cuomo has cut into one of Mr. McCall's greatest strengths, his widespread support throughout the state among elected office-holders and party officials. While Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, still leads in that area -- particularly around New York City, which was not included in today's poll -- it is far from the commanding advantage he enjoyed when Mr. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary, entered the race last year. 
 The poll took place at the convention of the Democratic Rural Conference, a group of state committee members and county chairmen from 41 upstate counties. The group cast 67 votes for Mr. Cuomo, 61 for Mr. McCall.
Mr. McCall had predicted victory in the days leading up to the straw poll, and his advisers were confident, but more cautious than he was. As the convention convened this morning, each side played the game of lowering expectations, with Mr. Cuomo's aides telling reporters that it would be a victory for him if he just came close in the poll, and Mr. McCall's aides insisting that the outcome was a tossup. Yet those same McCall aides appeared stunned by the result.
"I just take this as a great omen," Mr. Cuomo said. "This is a big shock. Tell you the truth, I did not expect to win."
The event, much like the Iowa presidential caucuses, has no concrete importance but is a closely watched barometer that has not, historically, been a terribly accurate predictor of winners in the September primaries for statewide offices.
Some McCall partisans worried aloud today that the straw poll would add to the perception that his campaign is sagging while Mr. Cuomo's is surging. "This is bad, bad news for Carl," said one of his supporters.
Many Democratic leaders said the outcome reflected, in part, the candidates' contrasting campaign styles. Mr. McCall has traveled the state tirelessly, speaking at dinners and attending fund-raisers but has not been explicitly seeking support for this event. 
Mr. Cuomo, by contrast, kept an eye on the vote, working the phones relentlessly in recent weeks to win over uncommitted leaders and wavering McCall supporters, according to Democrats who received the calls. The straw poll was held by secret ballot, raising the prospect that people who have publicly declared their stance one way voted another.
Public opinion polls show the two Democrats running neck-and-neck, with both lagging far behind Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republican incumbent. Last summer Mr. Pataki looked vulnerable, but his public standing has soared -- along with those of nearly all other elected state leaders -- since the Sept. 11 attacks, despite stumbling in his handling of requests for federal aid.
In speeches at the convention today, neither Democrat did more than aim a veiled jab or two at the other, each training his fire instead on Mr. Pataki.
"You have a system in Albany where they collect campaign checks with one hand and give out government contracts with the other," Mr. Cuomo charged. "It's going to stop."
Mr. McCall said: "Our state is adrift. There is no leadership, there is no direction, there is no vision."
Both men spoke at length about the weak upstate economy, a favorite theme for Democrats in recent elections, and one that worked well for Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mr. McCall chided Mr. Pataki for going to Florida this week to raise money for his campaign, rather than tending to problems at home.
The Pataki camp responded to the straw poll by taking aim at Mr. Cuomo's father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whom Mr. Pataki defeated in 1994. "The results of today's straw poll clearly demonstrates that Democratic Party insiders are committed to the failed policies of the past and Cuomonomics," said Sandy Treadwell, the chairman of the state Republican Party. 
In a straw poll of candidates for state comptroller, William J. Mulrow, an investment banker, easily defeated Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City comptroller, 106 to 23, a result that surprised no one. Mr. Mulrow has worked hard over the last year to win endorsements, while Mr. Hevesi, who ran unsuccessfully last year for mayor, entered the race only in January, and has barely begun to campaign upstate.
In the seven-way race for the lieutenant governor nomination, Charlie King, who was a Department of Housing and Urban Development official under Mr. Cuomo, won the straw poll, with 44 votes, followed by Dennis Mehiel, a wealthy businessman from Westchester County, with 30 votes.

HEADLINE: Two Freshmen From Suffolk Learn the Ropes 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
FELIX J. GRUCCI JR. walked alone down a flag-draped marble corridor toward Room 1505, his fifth-floor office suite in the Longworth Building in Washington.
 For a freshman congressman just back from the White House, where he and other members of the New York delegation met with President Bush to hear him renew his pledge of $20 billion in post-Sept. 11 aid to New York, Mr. Grucci looked less elated than weary, a man at the end of a hard week and eager to get home to Long Island. 
 Things were different when he was supervisor of the Town of Brookhaven, the office he held before he was elected to the House of Representatives in 2000. There, Mr. Grucci was something of a feudal king, the No. 1 Republican in a large Republican-controlled town, but home to East Patchogue by dinnertime. 
Now, Mr. Grucci is one of the newest and hence lowliest of the 435 members of the House, albeit the only one with a gold flitter split comet in his office. Wrapped in brown paper and sitting on a shelf, this shell is the signature in a show by Fireworks by Grucci, the family business.
There have also been some political fireworks. Last month, Mr. Grucci withstood reportedly withering pressure from the administration and Republican leaders and joined Democrats in voting for sweeping changes in campaign finance laws. Mr. Grucci said he listened to floor debate but voted according to constituents who complained that the rich and powerful ruled under the current system. "Theirs are the voices I heard the most, because theirs were the most compelling," he said.
But that was a high point. Mostly, he said, he lives a three-cornered existence.
"The triangulation of my life in Washington goes from my office to the Capitol for votes, over to the Rayburn Building where generally all the committee meetings are, and then back here again," said Mr. Grucci, 50. "Then I get in my car and drive to my apartment, get up at 6:30 in the morning and come back in and start all over again."
If the work that comes with the $150,000-a-year job and the pace in the capital are unrelenting, Mr. Grucci and the Island's other freshman congressman, Steve Israel of Dix Hills, are not complaining. Both men say they are dedicated to serving their districts, willing to put in long hours in Washington and back home, and delighted, even awe-struck, to be members of Congress.
"I'm one of those fortunate individuals whose dream came true," said Mr. Israel, 43, whose comfort level on the job seems greater than his colleague's. Mr. Israel's legislative background is lengthy -- he was an aide to former Representative Richard Ottinger, a Westchester Democrat, in the early 1980's and a Huntington town councilman prior to his election in November 2000.
Though Mr. Grucci and Mr. Israel have different backgrounds and represent different parties, they have some interests in common. They share Suffolk County, and both are members of the Financial Services and Science Committees. Mr. Israel is the lone New Yorker in the 33-member Blue Dog Coalition, who are mostly conservative Southern House Democrats and sometimes vote with the administration. Mr. Israel was one of just nine House Democrats who voted to support Mr. Bush's economic stimulus plan, and he displays the president's framed letter of thanks for that vote on the wall of his district office on West Main Street in Bay Shore.
Mr. Grucci has also developed something of a reputation as a maverick, not only by voting against the administration on campaign spending but more recently by criticizing its plans to dilute the Clean Air Act and cut $5.7 million in funding for the Brookhaven National Laboratory, which is within his district.
The two say they are close colleagues. "We have a very friendly relationship," Mr. Israel said. "Often we sit together on the House floor."
Mr. Grucci said he had occasionally driven with Mr. Israel from the airport to the Capitol. "We may have different philosophical beliefs, but we're fairly close," Mr. Grucci said. "We know that if we are going to have a shot, we are going to have to work together." But they are hardly political twins. The League of Conservation Voters' scorecard for last year gave Mr. Israel a 71 rating. Mr. Grucci's score was 21. American Conservative Union ratings for the year gave Mr. Grucci an 80, Mr. Israel an 8. 
Now, barely halfway through their first terms, the two freshmen are gearing up for re-election campaigns.
For Mr. Israel, the worst-case challenger would have been Rick A. Lazio, Republican of Brightwaters, who vacated the seat to run unsuccessfully for the Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton two years ago.
Left without a high-profile replacement candidate for the House seat, Suffolk Republicans ran Joan Johnson, a little-known Islip Town official, in Mr. Lazio's stead. Mr. Israel won handily.
National Republicans, seeing Mr. Lazio as the almost presumptive winner if he agreed to run for the House seat again this year, offered restored seniority, plum committee assignments and help in paying debts from his Senate race. But last week Mr. Lazio, now president of a big financial services lobbying group and clearly reluctant to resume a Congressional drill that would take him from his wife and family, said he was not a candidate.
"These calls for me to return to public service have been appreciated and are humbling," Mr. Lazio said in a statement. "However, my two daughters are very young, and they need a father who will help them as they grow up." He said he also wanted to spend more time with his wife, Patricia. "Both my responsibility and my desire are to share more of life with them," he said.
Mr. Israel, who has two young children of his own, said he respected Mr. Lazio's decision and wished him well. Politically, he moved instantly from a possibly endangered freshman to an odds-on favorite to be re-elected.
Mr. Grucci also came into office after someone else's political hiccup. Michael P. Forbes seemed to have a lock on the seat. Then, after being elected three times as a Republican, he switched parties and ran as a Democrat in 2000.
National Democrats enthusiastically welcomed Mr. Forbes, but his switch proved less popular at home. Regina Seltzer, a lawyer from Bellport who didn't consider Mr. Forbes a Democrat at all, clipped him in the primary, and Mr. Forbes's congressional career was suddenly over.
Mr. Grucci, the hope of national Republicans who wanted to regain the seat and punish the incumbent for abandoning the party, had been bracing for a tough fight against Mr. Forbes. Instead, Mr. Grucci had an easy victory over Ms. Seltzer.
Now, four Democrats -- the Suffolk County legislators Vivian Viloria-Fisher of Setauket and Brian X. Foley of Patchogue; Timothy H. Bishop, the provost of Southampton College; and Felicia Gross, a Wading River lawyer -- have lined up to oppose Mr. Grucci.
None are given much of a chance. "There is just not a good Democratic farm team out there," said Amy Walter, the House editor of the Cook Political Report in Washington. 
The races may be somewhat complicated by uncertainties about the reconfiguration of the congressional districts in New York, which is losing two House seats.
Mr. Grucci's First District, which includes the five East End towns, Brookhaven and parts of Smithtown, would probably be minimally affected by new lines because of its geographic location. But future lines for Mr. Israel's Second District, which includes Islip, Babylon and parts of Huntington and Smithtown, seem less certain.
"New York loses two seats, so it becomes a game of shuffling," Mr. Israel said. "We actually gained population on Long Island, whereas areas upstate lost population, so it would be unfair for Long Island to pay for a population loss it didn't suffer."
As members of the 107th Congress, Mr. Grucci has sponsored 10 bills and Mr. Israel has sponsored 13.
Mr. Grucci's bills honor veterans, seek funding for thermal imagining cameras for fire departments, address Internet abuses and require the attorney general to identify animal rights and environmental groups that recruit young members "to participate in violent and illegal activities." None have made it out of House committees.
Mr. Grucci was described by one colleague as in transition from being thrilled to being ever more aware of the grind that came with the office. But he said he still had to pinch himself when he walked onto the House floor or into the White House.
"You do get that feeling of 'Wow, I was just meeting with the president of the United States, and we talked about the biggest and most pressing issue that is going to be facing America,' " Mr. Grucci said.
He keeps a guitar in his office and played a few chords for a visitor recently. "This thing needs to be tuned desperately," he said.
Mr. Grucci, a man of composed demeanor, has also been trying to tune up the smile he attempts in television interviews. "I probably have the worst smile in captivity," he said. "I am very cognizant of that."
The energetic-looking Mr. Israel, by contrast, is quick to smile and is an agile talker and storyteller. His district office sports a pair of red boxing gloves, a gift from older constituents.
Mr. Israel tells a story of how he buttonholed Mr. Bush to ask for help in changing a federal formula that he said denied 60,000 elderly Suffolk County residents medical coverage from Medicare H.M.O.'s.
"He came to the Hill the day before Christmas to wish all the members happy holidays, and I just planted myself at the exit of the room," Mr. Israel said. "He was going to have to knock me down to get past." 
Mr. Israel said the face-to-face meeting led to "rather intensive dialogue" with Tommy Thompson, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and progress toward resolving a problem that cut the number of Medicare H.M.O.'s in the county from 12 to 2.
Mr. Israel's bills are also in committee, except for one to name a Deer Park post office after a top New York City fire official killed on Sept. 11. It was unanimously adopted in the House and sent to the Senate. His other bills would designate school nurses as first responders in biological or chemical attacks, provide incentives to Medicare H.M.O.'s for multiyear contracts, prohibit targeting minors when marketing adult-rated C.D.'s and other adult-rated products, give tax credits for energy-efficient appliances, eliminate tax exemptions for groups supporting terrorists, protect whistle-blowers and provide Medicare coverage for certain types of ovarian cancer tests.
Both men typically spend at least three days and two nights in Washington when the House is in session, and rent apartments near the Capitol. Mr. Grucci shares his with Jesse Garcia, his chief of staff.
Mr. Grucci relies heavily on people from home. Mr. Garcia was also his chief of staff in Brookhaven and lives in Patchogue. Kevin Malloy, his press secretary, is also from Patchogue. Linda Gualtieri, the legislative director, comes from Wantagh. Nicole Longo, the office manager and scheduler, is from Manhasset.
Mr. Israel leans toward people with Washington experience. Mark Siegel, his chief of staff, is a former executive director of the Democratic National Committee and was signed up by Mr. Israel in Washington. So were his press secretary, Jack Pratt, and legislative director, Francis Creighton.
When the congressmen aren't in Washington, they spend time in district offices, frequently going out to meetings and events running well into the evening.
On one recent day, Mr. Israel went from Great Neck to Melville to Hauppauge to Ronkonkoma before rushing back to the office for a meeting. Mr. Grucci described his office, where glass elephants fill a shelf, as a place to jam five days work into three.
"You do get tired by the end of the day, but it's the job that you signed up for," he said.
Mr. Grucci, who is married and has two grown children, and Mr. Israel agreed that the rigors of duties in the district were far outweighed by the relief of leaving Washington behind.
"Coming home is the best part of the job," Mr. Grucci said.
Mr. Israel said, "I leave skid marks on the floor of the House of Representatives."

(Maxine Hicks for The New York Times); Back in his home office in Patchogue, Representative Felix J. Grucci Jr. talks with Roger and Colette Baker while his receptionist, Katie Sanchez, takes notes. HEADLINE: They Conquered, They Left 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
OPRAH WINFREY, Rosie O'Donnell, Gov. Jane M. Swift of Massachusetts. 
 They are all quitting. 
 Ms. Winfrey, after years of teasing about when she would abandon her daily talk show, announced on March 14 that she would quit after the 2005-6 season, her 20th in television. 
Ms. O'Donnell, after just six seasons on her talk show, which attracts 2.5 million viewers every day, will tape her last show in May. 
And last Tuesday, Ms. Swift, the acting governor of Massachusetts, surprised fellow Republicans from Boston to the White House by bowing out of the gubernatorial race. Her reasons: low numbers in the polls (and in her campaign bank account), the pressure of running a state in the economic doldrums and the inevitable pull of small children at home.
But children don't always play into the decision to step down. Gwyneth Paltrow told the German newspaper Berliner Zeitung last week that she wants to leave Hollywood and slow her moviemaking pace because she is fed up with the male-dominated movie industry. 
Then there's Candice Olson, the former chief executive of iVillage (formerly Candice Carpenter) who quit corporate life altogether last year, married, took her husband's name and became a stay-at-home mom. Cokie Roberts, the veteran ABC News anchor, announced last week that she is leaving "This Week" in the fall. "I want a life," she said. 
All of these women gave up positions of fame and influence well before traditional retirement age. In many cases, they had struggled onto the porch of power, made it inside and were just about to ensconce themselves in an armchair when they suddenly did an about-face and headed back home. Would men? Even as Ms. Winfrey and Ms. O'Donnell were planning their exits, Ted Koppel and David Letterman were hanging on to their interview desks, refusing to budge from their network aeries. Men seem far more reluctant to give it all up. (Even if sometimes they should: think of Mick Jagger and his last album.)
"Men never leave jobs," said Carol Wallace, who quit this year as managing editor of People, the world's most profitable magazine, to relocate to a remote Scottish village. "Men die or get forced out. They are addicted to the power and the status and the games." It is seldom, Ms. Wallace said, that a man voluntarily leaves a position of authority while at the peak of his game.
"But they're missing something," she said, adding that she was happy to be perceived as a quitter. "I don't want to drop dead in my job. I want to be ambulatory. But maybe their DNA says they'd drop dead if they didn't work, that it's their oxygen. But it's not for me."
Dr. Phyllis Moen, a sociologist at Cornell University who has studied gender in the workplace, said that it is easier for women in powerful jobs to quit all at once. 
"You're seeing this now," she said, "because the way that careers are structured, women in high-status jobs can't reduce it, so they have to quit cold turkey. Imagine being a part-time governor. You can't do it." 
Nicole Harburger, press secretary for Janet Reno's gubernatorial campaign in Florida and a veteran of many women's political campaigns, said that men form long-lasting identities with corporations or political posts.
But as long as women have been trudging into the workplace, they've been trickling out. Ostensibly, the reasons are children, lifestyle, exhaustion -- or a combination of them all. Perhaps, also, women are different; some say they have less of a psychic investment in a career -- both the power and the money -- as a source of their identity than men. 
Ms. O'Donnell has said she simply decided that she no longer enjoyed the artifice of fame and the rigors of a daily talk show and that she preferred the quieter work of writing and editing her magazine. Ms. Winfrey, too, has the rest of an empire to run. Perhaps that explains part of it: if you can quit, why stay? 
Geraldine B. Laybourne resigned as president of cable television operations for the Walt Disney Company and ABC in 1998, at the top of her game, to start Oxygen Media, an entrepreneurial experiment whose success has not yet been proven. 
"I had all those cable networks reporting to me, I had a number of windows in my office and I had all the corporate perks you could have possibly imagined, but that wasn't what I was about, so I left," Ms. Laybourne said, speaking from a mobile phone on her way to golf camp in Puerto Rico. "I don't know if it would have been as easy to do if I were a man." 
Sheila Wellington, the president of Catalyst, a New York-based group that works to advance women in business, said the picture brought into focus by the recent spate of high-profile quitters is skewed: there are so few women at the top that each singular event takes on heightened meaning.
"There are so few women in power, we pay more attention to it," Ms. Wellington said. Of the chief executives who run Fortune 500 companies, just six are women, she said.
"That's a whopping 1.2 percent," Ms. Wellington said. "If you start thinking about the fact that women made up about a third of the M.B.A. students in the early 1980's, women have been in the work force and women have been educated for careers for two decades now. So where are they?" 
For one, they are very much in the workplace. In 1975 there were 34 million women in the paid labor market, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In 1995, there were 57.5 million. 
But those at the very top seem to be more prone to dropping out -- probably because they can. A Harvard study of 902 women who graduated from its professional schools from 1971 to 1981 found that 25 percent of the women who earned Harvard M.B.A.'s in the 1970's had left the workplace entirely by the early 1990's, despite their extensive -- and very expensive -- training. Many of those women said they felt "forced out" by motherhood. Although not all. 
But it is equally true that positions of serious authority continue to elude women. In the political arena, Congress added 19 women in 1992. Since then, only 16 more women have been elected to the House. There are 13 women in the Senate and 60 in the House, totaling only about 14 percent of Congress. 
And though more and more women are now serving in the executive branch -- Condoleezza Rice the signal example -- and there are two women on the Supreme Court, not one Congressional committee is headed by a woman.
One who had a shot at any number of the top power positions in Congress was Patricia Schroeder, the former Colorado congresswoman, who was achieving true influence in the House, especially on women's and children's issues, when she quit and headed back West in 1997. Her children were grown, her husband still supportive of her, as he had been through her political career, when she left Washington. In an interview after she left office, Mrs. Schroeder said she "felt like I had been in a huge fight, and I was tired." Last week, Mrs. Schroeder, now chief executive of the Association of American Publishers, a trade group, said she had particular sympathy for Governor Swift.
"We're paying a lot of attention to Jane Swift because it shows us that we still have terrible work and family issues," Mrs. Schroeder said. "I don't know how to say this nicely, but people have simply not supported women in the workplace."
Ms. Swift, however, had cited her family pressures as only one of the issues that drove her to drop out. The overarching reason seemed to be abandonment by her party -- and the threat of an outside force, Mitt Romney, the recent chairman of the United States Olympics Committee, who was getting not only widespread public support for his handling of the Salt Lake Games, but also the dollars needed to mount a hotly contested gubernatorial campaign against a full field of Democrats.
Mrs. Schroeder, however, would not fully concede the point.
"She did not quit," Mrs. Schroeder said. "You have the whole Republican Party of Massachusetts who, if she were male, would have been much more supportive than they have been." 
"Something had to give," Governor Swift said when she announced her decision. "I am sure there isn't a working parent in America that hasn't faced it, that when the demands of the two tasks you take on both increase substantially, something has to give."
Men, too, sometimes quit positions of power while still in their prime. Representative Joe Scarborough, Republican of Florida, resigned in the middle of his Congressional term last year to spend more time with his sons, one of whom has diabetes. 
Meanwhile across the fronts in the gender war last week, there were two striking counterexamples of women who were decidedly not quitting. Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett Packard, led the final skirmishes in her dogged fight to merge with Compaq, which she appears to have won. (The final count from shareholders won't be in for several weeks.) And Ms. Reno the former United States attorney general, campaigned tenaciously in Florida for the Democratic nomination in the gubernatorial race against Jeb Bush, despite being drastically behind in the polls and having been found to have Parkinson's disease. 
It's not the same, said Susan Estrich, the legal scholar and author of "Sex and Power." Just as certain circumstances give women the freedom to quit, so do others make it easier for some women to hang in, to the bitter end in some cases.
Governor Swift, Ms. Estrich said, doesn't "have a guy like Frank Fiorina, who took early retirement to support his wife's career and sometimes drives her to work, and by the way, came with two daughters from a previous marriage, which is how she managed to spend three months flying nonstop around the world to collect proxies."
"Imagine a mother doing that," she added. "Imagine what we'd say about her if she did. Imagine her trying to convince voters to vote for her." 
A spokeswoman for Ms. Fiorina, Rebeca Robboy, said Ms. Fiorina often drives her own car to work. 
In fact, Ms. Estrich said, nothing proves better how tough it is for women in the workplace than the reaction to, say, a Jane Swift decision to quit. "The tenor of the attention, just how personal it is, highlights the very obstacles women face" Ms. Estrich said. 
Ms. Wallace, People's happy quitter, said there's little to be concluded from the current crop of dropout women.
"I don't have kids," she said. "Oprah doesn't have kids. So we have no real dependents, and that gives us some freedom. Rosie is wealthy. These are not regular women."

HEADLINE: The Monster That's Feasting on Newspapers 

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
LATE last year, executives of TMP Worldwide met with the members of the Chamber of Commerce in Cincinnati to propose a new Internet service to help them recruit hourly employees, like truck drivers or cashiers. A TMP unit, Monster.com, had already become the top site for recruiting people for skilled jobs. The new service, which TMP told them would probably be called CincinnatiJobMatch.com, would be more suited to lower-paid jobs and would cost less than Monster, which in turn was cheaper than newspaper help-wanted advertising.
 Word got back to The Cincinnati Enquirer, and it reacted quickly, boasting in big ads that The Enquirer was "the real monster of the Cincinnati job market." Moreover, the paper discovered that TMP hadn't registered CincinnatiJobMatch.com, so it quickly registered rights to that name. And on Monday, the Enquirer used that site to introduce its own service for hourly jobs, a week ahead of TMP, which starts its service tomorrow, at tristatejobmatch.com. 
 If The Enquirer appears a bit testy, it is no wonder. Over the last few years, Internet job sites, especially Monster, have eaten away at newspapers' help-wanted ads, which inch for inch have been their single most profitable product. In the process, Monster has become one of the biggest dot-com businesses around, and the most profitable. With $536 million in revenue last year, it had pretax operating income of $150 million, edging out eBay, which had a $140 million operating profit.
This is grim news for newspapers, and no relief is in sight. "Even if the economy recovers, the newspapers are not ever going to get back to the levels they saw from 1995 to 2000," said Craig Huber, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who estimates that about 10 percent of the help-wanted market is now online; he expects that to rise to 25 percent within three years.
Newspapers have fought back. Most of them allow companies that place help-wanted ads to have them listed on the newspaper Web site, too, for an additional fee. Some, like The New York Times, have adopted some features of stand-alone job sites, like resume databases.
The Tribune Company and Knight Ridder have gone further, jointly buying two independent job sites, Careerbuilder.com and Headhunter.net, to create a hybrid -- under the Careerbuilder name -- that sells listings along with newspaper ads and has a national sales force.
The recession has tilted the balance even more toward Monster, as more employers choose to give what little money they have for recruiting to Internet sites because they are cheaper and more efficient.
Last year, help-wanted revenue at the nation's newspapers fell 35 percent, to $5.7 billion, says IDC, the research firm in Framingham, Mass.; domestic revenue of online job sites rose 38 percent, to $727 million.
TMP is by far the biggest cause of the newspapers' pain. Its share of the online job market has risen from one-third to one-half in the last two years, IDC says.
Not that Monster is unscathed by the recession. It was insulated for a while because many of its biggest customers buy one-year contracts, and it kept growing for much of last year. As the contracts started expiring, though, revenue plunged 20 percent in the fourth quarter.
BUT TMP is a rarity in that its Internet unit is doing much better than its traditional businesses. TMP's revenue is falling, profits are stagnating, and investors are questioning its strategy of buying temporary-help agencies, executive-search firms and Web sites that help students find jobs.
Douglas M. Arthur, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, which took TMP public in 1996, wrote in a scathing recent report that TMP was a "growth stock without any growth." He is bullish on Monster, he wrote, but falling revenue and mounting losses for the search and temporary-help units border "on the embarrassing."
Unabashed, TMP is proceeding with its costly plan to go after hourly jobs. It will back its Cincinnati test with $2 million in advertising on radio and billboards and in direct mail.
The hourly workers will be able to submit applications by telephone and by mail, as well as online.
If all goes well, TMP hopes to duplicate the service in up to 100 markets, starting at year-end. But it will not make the same mistake twice. In February, TMP registered more than 200 Web addresses, from AkronJobMatch.com to WacoJob Match.com.
The public face of Monster, and architect of its $150 million marketing campaign, has been its founder, Jeffrey C. Taylor. He water-skied with Sir Richard Branson, founder of the Virgin Group, behind the Monster blimp. And on "Today" on NBC, he showed Katie Couric around a giant snow maze in Salt Lake City, where Monster was an Olympics sponsor. A former disc jockey who takes the turntable at Monster parties, Mr. Taylor, 41, is proud that Monster's sprawling headquarters, in a warehouse in Maynard, Mass., had busy foosball tables before they became an icon of dot-com excess.
But the power at Monster, and much of the reason for its success, emanates from the 39th floor of an icy black office building off Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, in Midtown Manhattan, where TMP's chief executive, Andrew J. McKelvey, 67, plots new businesses and acquisitions. TMP, which Mr. McKelvey founded in 1968 as Telephone Marketing Programs, an agency to sell Yellow Pages ads, still largely operates like an impetuous private business rather than the 11,000-person corporation, with $1.45 billion in revenue, that it has become. 
Still, TMP's peculiar environment is most likely why Monster rose above 30,000 other job sites, besting those backed by venture capitalists and newspapers. Mr. McKelvey was willing to make big investments in Monster, like buying Super Bowl ads, starting in 1999. But he also saw to it that the company made money early.
TMP's current troubles, however, also stem from Mr. McKelvey's penchant for risk-taking. Essentially, he took the gains from Monster and doubled down on the strategy of filling all jobs from "intern to C.E.O.," a bet that so far has not worked out.
Mr. McKelvey is unconcerned. "Don't get me started on vision," he said, leaning back in a burgundy leather chair in his vast office, which is dominated by a pair of red boxing gloves hanging next to a giant globe.
"What you do in business is, you follow your nose," he said. "The secret of success is being at the right place at the right time."
Last fall, Mr. McKelvey responded to the tough times by appointing James J. Treacy, a longtime financial executive, as president. Since joining TMP seven years ago, Mr. Treacy has been a voice of restraint, whose calls for financial discipline and intracompany cooperation were largely ignored by Mr. McKelvey and other entrepreneurial sorts like Mr. Taylor. Now that Mr. Treacy has been given operating control, he is paring the recruiting unit, which he never liked, cutting costs and forcing divisions to work together.
At other companies, this might be a moment for the chief executive to retire gracefully. Not so Mr. McKelvey, though he has cut back his work day to 8 hours from 16. Mr. McKelvey is worth $920 million, according to Forbes; that is down from $2.1 billion in 2000, but it still affords him opportunity for enjoyment. He has a Gulfstream jet, a mansion in the Dominican Republic and a 115-foot yacht in the Bahamas. He has also started two charities -- one to lobby for gun safety, another to give college scholarships to mediocre students in poor neighborhoods who have entrepreneurial zeal. That one is run by Dena, his sixth wife.
"I'm willing to take risks," he said. "Or maybe I have a short attention span." But Mr. McKelvey is firm: the only way he will leave his corner office is "in a pine box."
In the early 1990's, Mr. McKelvey decided to expand beyond the Yellow Pages and to start buying help-wanted agencies. One was Adion, run by Mr. Taylor. But when Mr. McKelvey met him in Boston, all Mr. Taylor wanted to talk about was his new Web site, the Monster Board.
Mr. McKelvey had never heard of the Internet, but he was intrigued. He bought the agency for $930,000, then secretly bought the Online Career Center, Monster's larger rival. Even Mr. Taylor did not find out until TMP went public the next year. "Andy likes to control what you eat for breakfast," Mr. Treacy explained.
TMP powered Monster's growth right away. Because TMP's agencies already had hundreds of sales representatives talking to employers about help-wanted ads, it started suggesting that they divert some spending toward Monster. (Unlike newspapers, TMP was not afraid of cannibalizing its existing business.)
WHILE other types of online advertising have yet to prove themselves, online classified ads -- whether junk auctions on eBay or job listings on Monster -- are a thriving business.
Sites like Monster let people browse through jobs as if they were books on Amazon.com and then zap off applications at the click of a mouse. Similarly, employers have endless aisles of prospective employees, both from responses to postings and databases of resumes.
They are hardly a panacea. Job seekers complain of outdated jobs, and listings that are ruses to get resumes by employment agencies. Employers grumble they are often deluged with irrelevant applications from halfway across the world.
But for employers, what has been most important is that online job sites can be much cheaper than newspaper ads. Posting a job on Monster costs $305 for 60 days. Access to the resume database costs more. The average ad for a professional job in a major newspaper costs about $1,000 a day.
For big companies, this has made a compelling proposition. Nestle wants to put all its hiring online. At Sprint, which hires 25,000 people a year, 21.5 percent of total hires in January and February came from the Internet, versus 8 percent for all of 2001. Few big companies plan to return to newspaper ads.
When TMP said last summer that it would buy HotJobs, the No. 2 site, Careerbuilder felt that it would benefit by moving up to the second spot. But last fall, Yahoo stepped in and outbid TMP for HotJobs.
There are also myriad smaller job sites, many offering free listings on trade association sites. And William O. Warren, Monster's former president, has created a nonprofit group backed by companies like I.B.M. and Cisco Systems to run a site called DirectEmployers.com.
Peter Weddle, chief executive of Weddle's Publications, which covers the recruitment industry, says this service has the potential to exploit concern that Monster has taken advantage of its position by raising job-posting prices. "DirectEmployers .com is a response to the perception among recruiters that Monster has taken them for granted, their prices are too high and customer service too low," he said. Mr. Taylor, however, says Monster offers good value and has improved its service.
So far, Monster dominates every measure -- numbers of job seekers, resumes and job postings, as well as revenue and profits. In January, 13.9 million people in the United States visited Monster at least once, according to Jupiter Media Metrix, the technology research firm. Monster now has 15 million resumes on file, double the number a year ago.
"With everything they have done to create the market, Monster stands head and shoulders above everyone else," said Michael Roberts, a first vice president at Bank One.
The revenue from TMP's search business, however, fell 39 percent last year, a bigger drop than at any other big search firm, according to Hunt-Scanlon, a Stamford, Conn., consulting firm. Last summer, TMP negotiated to combine its search operation with Heidrick & Struggles International, the No. 2 search firm, but no agreement could be reached, people close to the talks said. Then, in October, Steven B. Potter, head of the search unit, left.
All this is worth the bother, Mr. McKelvey says, because ultimately even chief executives will be found online. (The company did set up such a system, called Chief Monster, but it has been disappointing.)
"Will a C.F.O. from a Fortune 500 company put his resume up on Monster?" Mr. McKelvey asked. "No way, in the world today. But tomorrow, you bet." The job of keeping the company in order until that day now falls to Mr. Treacy. 
"This company has been run by entrepreneurs, and they can't do the same thing the same way twice," said Mr. Treacy, who was once a treasurer at the WPP Group. "I'm a big-company guy, and I understand that big companies need process."
Mr. Treacy also says he was not keen on some of Mr. McKelvey's acquisitions, especially in the executive-search area. As he has received more power, the search division has been scaled back sharply to focus on the lucrative market for the "C-suite" -- chief whatever officers.
All units have been told that an important mission is to drive business to the Internet, or, as Mr. Treacy puts it, "feed the Monster."
SO far, TMP has few customers that choose to buy a bundle that includes recruiting interns and chief executives. Indeed, some clients who had relationships with multiple TMP units say there is little coordination.
That will come, Mr. Treacy said. There are synergies, he added, that are not obvious. "If you are a recruiter who can use Monster's database for free, your business model is a lot better than someone who has to pay for the same thing," Mr. Treacy said.
That is a real sore spot, because TMP's rivals worry that they will see resumes for the best candidates on Monster only after TMP has picked over them. TMP says it plays fairly, but the risks are high: one-third of Monster's revenue comes from temporary-help agencies.
TMP is approaching other papers. But Mr. Treacy acknowledged that Monster had been rebuffed many times as it tried to form alliances with newspapers, many of which are controlled by founding families.
"Every time they contemplated sharing revenue with us, someone's grandfather would turn over in his grave," Mr. Treacy said, but some newspapers are weary of losing money on Internet operations and would rather switch than fight.
"For newspapers to work with Monster would be goofy," said Timothy J. Landon, president of the classified advertising division of the Tribune Company. "At the end of the day, Monster is all about sucking the value of classifieds back to TMP."

HEADLINE: Absolute Fabulosity 

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
IT'S been a rough six months, and many sacrifices have been made, especially by the English language. With all the sonorous talk of in-the-wake-of, the-events-of and axis-of, there's been a long parade of ominous aheming. 
 Now comes news that President Bush has a thing for fabulous. The man cannot stop using the f-word. From his days as candidate, when he warned doubters not to misunderestimate him, Mr. Bush has gone his own way, word-wise. Now, in the hour of crisis, he is letting his fab flag fly. 
 Fabulous, of course, has a noble pedigree, and is useful for describing the writings of Aesop or the S.E.C. filings of Enron. But in its broader usage, fabulous belongs to the world of fashion, where it is the verbal equivalent of a double air kiss. As captured in the fashion sit-com "Absolutely Fabulous," it means: I will reserve judgment until you are not around. "Giorgio, those chiffon streamers are fabulous," means "You and I will not let those chiffon streamers come between us just now."
As such, it seems hardly the stuff of global diplomacy. Washington has its own, highly evolved doublespeak; why borrow from fashion? 
With tough elections coming up, perhaps it's a subtle shout-out to the fashion vote. Soccer moms are a constituency; why not the fabulous? Fabulous may also have untapped military potential. One of its virtues is that it is always full-throttle, like evil. One is never almost fabulous, or on the verge. Fabulous is absolute. Even our tetchiest allies would surely join an axis of fabulous. 
But there may be a broader linguistic agenda at work: a vast fab-wing conspiracy, if you will. After the gloom of the last six months, the president is sending a message that it is O.K. to get giddy again, whether or not the circumstances merit it. Addressing a crowd in a depressed part of Oregon earlier this year, he trumpeted, "I believe 2002 is going to be a fabulous year for America." Enough of dowdy stoicism; fabulous offers stoicism with brio and better shoes. 
Though there is debate about this, fabulous appears to have a supply-side effect. The president's remarks trickle down, creating a rising tide that flatters all boats. Sober economic policy may rebuild public confidence, but fabulous can reinflate the all-important big-spending public egomania.
Or perhaps the president has sounded the American character and found that the duplicity of fabulousness is a bedrock national value that distinguishes us from our adversaries. Our native social hypocrisy is a first line of defense. It is the lubricant of American industry, the enabler of democratic compromise, the smile of multicultural cooperation. It merits a little presidential smoke blown its way.
Not surprisingly, the mercurial fashion world has moved on to other words. "Fabulous was big two or three years ago," said Linda Wells, editor in chief of Allure magazine. "Now it's 'gorge,' " as in gorgeous.
Of course, maybe Mr. Bush just has a thing for the word. In which case all this other jazz is felicitous accident. How fabulous.

HEADLINE: Forging the Monterrey Consensus 

 BODY:
Half the world's population lives on $2 a day or less. Can prosperous nations best help them by spending significantly more on foreign aid, or by better targeting their assistance and making it more efficient? Both, is the sensible answer that came out of the United Nations' International Conference on Financing for Development, held last week in Monterrey, Mexico. But even though rich nations have pledged to reverse recent declines in assistance, it is not clear that they are prepared to invest enough. 
 The United Nations estimates that it will take a doubling of the nearly $50 billion spent globally each year in foreign aid to meet its ambitious goal of cutting poverty in half by 2015. Developed countries have long been asked to contribute 0.7 percent of their gross national product in foreign aid, but only a handful of Northern European countries do so. America's foreign aid budget currently amounts to barely a tenth of a percentage point. 
 Before President Bush announced earlier this month that he would seek a 50 percent increase in America's aid spending by 2006, it appeared as if the White House might hide behind the more-versus-better debate on foreign aid to avoid heeding the United Nations' call for a greater commitment. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill has been particularly critical of the World Bank and other international development bodies, claiming that they had "precious little" to show for their trillion-dollar effort over the decades. 
Much of his criticism is valid. Too often, the World Bank's low-interest loans have been funneled to corrupt governments that have not been held accountable. Critics like Mr. O'Neill rightly want to see more grants, instead of loans, earmarked for the poorest countries, and not necessarily for their governments.
America's own track record has been far from stellar. Throughout the cold war, aid was funneled to key allies that were not always the most deserving humanitarian cases. Helping countries escape poverty has also proved more complicated than anyone imagined more than a half-century ago, when the United Nations and its development agencies were established. Trade, private investment and good governance have proved far more influential than charity in lifting living standards. 
Yet the recent experience of African countries like Mozambique, Uganda and Senegal, where foreign aid has provided sound reformist governments with seed money to great effect, is the latest reminder that assistance can play a pivotal role in alleviating misery and encouraging growth. Foreign aid does not always produce results, but the chances of success almost always rise when aid is delivered to countries that have adopted policies that promote social welfare and economic growth. President Bush eloquently made that point in Monterrey on Friday. 
It is encouraging that an administration so critical of past foreign aid recognizes that it must reform how the money is spent and then invest even more. The war on terrorism has undoubtedly helped the president reach that conclusion. The European Union has also announced substantial increases in its aid spending.
Development agencies like the World Bank and poor nations themselves are acknowledging the lessons from the past. Much of the talk in Monterrey was about the need to condition aid on a recipient nation's willingness to embrace and promote free markets, human rights, the rule of law, education, women's rights and property rights.
There is still a significant gap between the aid pledged by rich countries and what is needed. The imperative now, as aid dollars are invested more wisely, is to close that gap.

HEADLINE: Frail Offer; 
Arab States Eye a Way Forward

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAIRO 

 BODY:
IN the turbulent bazaar of Middle East peace negotiations, the Palestinians never had much to barter.
 They boasted little credible military force, no land and fickle friends -- the Arab nations next door -- who tended to offer flowery lip service at most. But there was one thing the Israelis sought through the Palestinians: acceptance. Once their hostility eased, the Israelis sensed, the rest of the neighborhood would come along. 
 That is the essence of the Saudi initiative that Crown Prince Abdullah is expected to unveil to his fellow Arab leaders at their summit meeting this week in Beirut: If Israel ends its conflict with the Palestinians, the Arab world will reciprocate by accepting Israel. In other words, there can be normal relations -- not necessarily warm, but without the threat to drive the Israelis into the sea. That is what Israelis have said they have sought most since the state was founded in 1948. 
But what exactly is propelling this new Arab suggestion about ending the conflict? Certainly, as they gather in Beirut, Arab leaders who propose peace face opposition in some quarters back home, from many intellectuals and from a public that applauds the Palestinians' sudden willingness to stand up militarily and their ability to score psychological victories against Israel. Opponents cling to the old notion that accepting Israel is tantamount to surrender and welcome reports of mounting Israeli casualties as a sign that the other side's morale is finally being worn down.
But the leaders of some of the most influential Arab nations believe the conflict has moved to a point where it risks causing trouble at home. First, they want to reduce the appalling human toll. Second, a United States newly bloodied by suicide terrorism is identifying Palestinian violence as terrorism and supporters of those tactics as fellow-travelers. That means regimes that are close to Washington risk getting caught between their patron and their own disgruntled populations.
Third, anger over the Palestinian issue is the most likely spark for domestic unrest during trying economic times, and it could help the recruitment efforts of the those, like Osama bin Laden, who attract recruits by denouncing Israel as they seek the violent overthrow of their own Arab governments. 
Finally, until recently the United States has pointedly stayed aloof from the conflict, a stance that has given Israel great freedom to do what it wants in the occupied territories. But the Bush administration, suddenly conscious that it needs Arab support if it wants to carry its war on terrorism into Iraq, is showing renewed interest in becoming an intermediary, giving Arab regimes a window of opportunity to appeal for American intervention. 
There remain mountainous obstacles on the road to Arab-Israeli peace, of course -- one of the biggest questions is how forcefully the Bush administration will tempt and prod the adversaries to first quell the violence and then make peace -- and the Saudi initiative is in no way a plan to resolve the complexities of a final settlement. Rather, it's a vision of what can come after the Israelis, Syrians, Palestinians and Lebanese finally reach a deal.
THE basic proposition as outlined by the Saudis so far is not new. Prince Abdullah is likely to put it this way to his fellow Arabs, assuming violence doesn't preclude any talk of peace in Beirut this week: Let's get Israel to redraw the lines where they were just before the 1967 war, get the Palestinians a state with a chunk of eastern Jerusalem for its capital and send back into Israel a reasonable number of refugees from the 1948 war. In exchange, the rest of the Arab countries will roll out some form of welcome wagon.
"You have to give the Israelis something in an Arab currency," said Abdel Monem Said, director of the Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies in Cairo. 
The Arab world does not lack for nay-sayers. Iraq and Libya, to start, both oppose the idea, although Iraq has kept largely silent, hoping to persuade the Arab summit to express the idea that America should not attack it.
Last week, a few thousand Lebanese marched in protest against the Saudi proposal, and a columnist in the Saudi daily Al-Watan decried the very idea of a peace initiative at a time of such intense violence between Israel and the Palestinians. After his paper reported the March 8 Palestinian death toll at 50 (other reports varied from 40 to 60), he wrote: "Fifty martyrs, two every hour, and you ask us to give Sharon a chance! Fifty martyrs, O champions of the 'new Middle East' and supporters of 'compromise'! "
Critics in Jordan and Egypt include professional organizations, trade unions and political opposition groups that have long campaigned against contacts with Israelis even though their two countries have peace treaties with Israel. 
"The proposed normalization now is one way of surrendering, and it helps get the Israeli leadership and Sharon out of the crisis that he got himself into," Ali Abu Sukkar, the president of the Committee Against Normalization in Jordan, a group formed to oppose its 1994 treaty with Israel, said on Al-Jazeera television.
BUT senior Arab officials argue that there has never been a stronger consensus among them, nor a stronger reason to push forward with an initiative that will appeal to both sides. "We have to let the Israelis know that we want to live in peace with them as long as they do their part," said Marwan Muasher, the Jordanian foreign minister. "And we have to give Palestinians hope that there is an end to the occupation, that there will be a Palestinian state."
Arab officials and analysts do not consider the Saudi proposal a concrete prescription to be followed by all 22 Arab League members, but a general formula. But they believe that if Israeli settlements were being dismantled and Palestinians were celebrating their state, it would make an Israeli embassy palatable in almost every capital and would dry up support for extreme groups that seek to destroy Israel.
"We are not talking only about the end of belligerency, we are talking about relations," said Mr. Muasher, the Jordanian foreign minister. "There will be an overall declaration that everybody agrees to, but you can't expect every single Arab country to have the same relations with Israel. Will every country have an exchange of theater groups, for example? I don't know; that is up to negotiation."
Some sense of the likely outcome of a final peace deal can be gleaned from the aftermath of the 1993 Oslo accords between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Morocco and Tunisia, which have Jewish communities of their own, established low-level diplomatic relations and welcomed Israeli tourists. Oman and Qatar exchanged trade offices, while Mauritania opted for full diplomatic relations. (Geographic distance seems to abet relations.)
When Egypt became the first country to sign a peace treaty with Israel, the men flogging camel rides at the Pyramids beckoned Israeli customers just like everyone else, as did tour operators in Jordan when it too made peace. But relations overall were never more than chilly. 
Analysts note that events quickly soured both nations on their peace treaties. Egypt's was followed by the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Fierce fighting erupted there again right after Jordan signed in 1994. Now, since the outbreak of new Palestinian-Israeli violence 18 months ago, all Arab states have frozen their ties with the Israelis. But the experience of Egypt and Jordan, which were accused by fellow Arabs of being Quislings, is not likely to be an issue again if everyone goes along with the Abdullah proposal and makes peace this time.
Still, many analysts believe that Israeli hopes for the level of relations they will achieve are much too high. These analysts point out that even among themselves the Arabs don't always get along well. For example, relations between Iraq and Saudi Arabia have not been particularly warm since Iraq killed off its monarchs in 1958, even though the two share a lengthy border.
Perhaps the most intriguing relationship would be one between Israel and Saudi Arabia. The late King Faisal vowed that his country would be the last to recognize Israel. Predictions of the reception that Israelis would receive range from strong anti-Semitism by hardcore Islamists to a kind of benign acceptance based on the fact that the Arab-Israeli dispute would have ended. "You can accept them as a neighbor, but that doesn't mean you have to invite them to dinner," said Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi newspaper editor.
In past dealings with Israel, Syrian negotiators have concentrated on things like where the armies will be deployed, while the Israelis are hoping for the kind of open borders that will allow visits to historic sites in Damascus.
The past 18 months of violence have thrown into question, more than ever, how long it will take to establish anything remotely resembling normal relations. Arab analysts and officials believe that this generation of Arab youths seems to harbor more hatred for Israelis than ever.
"Every child watching television in Egypt, in Lebanon, wherever, they can all watch Palestinians being killed," said Mohammed Sobeih, the Palestinian ambassador to the Arab League. "Kids see it on television every day, and they will never forget this."
BUT Arab governments worry that anger about the Palestinian-Israeli dispute could ignite the simmering frustrations over their own domestic problems -- unemployment, corruption and the sense that dictatorial leaders care more about maintaining power than improving the lot of their citizens.
Many area analysts believe that for the sake of stability at home, Arab governments must do something. Tackling social problems will be less fraught with danger once the scenes of dying Palestinians are gone, they say. 
"All the terrorists in the region, the fundamentalists, anyone who wants to undermine the regimes in the Middle East uses the inability of the regimes to face the Israelis," said Mr. Said, director of the Ahram Center in Cairo. "The Arab-Israeli conflict is one of the main reasons for instability. There are other social problems, but nothing stirs passions like that."

HEADLINE: More Aid, More Need: Pledges Still Falling Short 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 23 

 BODY:
After years of resisting, the United States is enlisting in a global war on poverty, but only if it can choose the rules of engagement, the fields of battle and the ultimate cost.
 Its promises -- and they are only promises at the moment -- are a post-cold-war watershed. Still, they fall far short of what is needed to change one hard fact: half the world's people are have-nots. 
 Ten days ago, it appeared that the Monterrey conference on development aid, convened by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, might prove an empty exercise. The world's nations had already agreed to the goal of halving the number of people in poverty by 2015. But there was no money on the table. 
Now, prodded and pulled and shamed by Mr. Annan, challenged by presidents and prime ministers from nations rich and poor, the United States and Europe have pledged tens of billions of dollars to ease the misery of 2.5 billion poor people.
The change in American policy came in part because President Bush made a direct connection between poverty and terrorism, an idea that the United States had been reluctant to embrace.
"We fight against poverty," he said Friday in Monterrey, "because hope is an answer to terror."
Specifically, Mr. Bush, making his pledge bigger and more urgent than he did at first, said he would ask Congress to increase American aid to poor nations by 50 percent over the next three years, to $15 billion in 2006, and to try to start the money flowing within months, not a year or two.
A great gap remains between what most of the rest of the world wants and what the United States is willing to do, and there are cracks in the framework the United States is proposing for the rest of the world.
The Europeans pressed the United States hard for more. "What can be done against terrorism can surely be done against poverty, in the name of a more human, manageable globalization," said President Jacques Chirac of France.
But the United States' list of deserving nations will be much shorter than the list of needy ones, American officials in Monterrey said.
Few argue with the American position that corrupt governments should not receive aid. But Mr. Bush spent most of his time in Monterrey talking about trade, not aid, which has been the American mantra for a decade. He laid down conditions: If the United States is to open its wallet, poor nations must open their markets. If they undertake political, legal and economic reforms, Washington will help them trade their way to prosperity.
"To be serious about fighting poverty, we must be serious about expanding trade," he said. "Greater access to the markets of wealthy countries has a direct and immediate impact on the economies of developing nations."
But hundreds of millions of people in poor countries who grow food for a living are frozen out of rich countries' markets by "the greatest trade barriers" in the world, the ones imposed by rich nations, the World Bank says in a new report.
No less a globalist than Mike Moore, the director general of the World Trade Organization, said in Monterrey that the agricultural subsidies paid out by the United States and the European Union cost the developing nations more than $250 billion a year in lost markets -- more than five times the sum of all the aid they receive.
The United States today spends twice as much directly subsidizing American agribusiness than it does aiding needy nations. All told, subsidies and other support fertilizing the fields of wealthy nations run about $1 billion a day, or roughly six times the amount spent on aid.
This means that corn from Iowa floods Mexico's markets, onions from France swamp Senegal and farmers from the poorer countries are shut out. "It is no good helping dairy farmers in a country, if at the same time you are exporting subsidized milk powder to it," as Mr. Annan put it.
The new aid the United States promised to provide is a fraction of what other nations think it should give. It represents an increase to 0.13 percent of the national economy, from 0.10 percent. The European Union is to increase its spending to 0.39 percent from 0.33 percent, adding $20 billion by 2006.
The mark Mr. Annan has set for rich nations is 0.70 percent; five European nations exceed that, but the United States drags the average down to 0.22 percent. 
Together with the pledges from Europe, the increased American contribution represents less than one-fourth of Mr. Annan's goal, which was an additional $50 billion a year. Moreover, the new aid proposed by Mr. Bush would still leave the United States as "the benchmark at the bottom of world donors," said Jeffrey D. Sachs, a development specialist at Harvard and a special adviser to Mr. Annan.
The debate in Monterrey may sound arcane. But at root, the many advocates of increased assistance argue, it is very simple.
If Mr. Annan's goals are not met by 2015, Oxfam, the British aid group, contends, death by starvation and preventable diseases will claim an additional 56 million children in that period. One billion people will still be struggling to survive on less than $1 a day, just as they are today.
