HEADLINE: Tourists to the Rescue Of a Wounded City; 
New York Finds Sympathy a Powerful Draw

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The destruction of the World Trade Center has emerged as a powerful selling point for New York City, invoked again and again over the last six months to make the case that big events like the Super Bowl, the Grammy Awards ceremony and a proposed joint meeting of Congress all belong in New York.
 It was used to attract the World Economic Forum to Manhattan. Coca-Cola Company shareholders will meet here next month for the first time. On Tuesday, a major national technology association announced that it would hold its annual awards ceremony here in July. The events of Sept. 11 have inspired trial lawyers, travel agents, television station managers and others to plan conventions and conferences in New York. 
 The argument goes like this: Bringing an event like the Super Bowl to New York City will stimulate tourism and help the city and the country recover; it will be an expression of solidarity with New Yorkers; it will strike a blow against terrorism; it will enable visitors to share in the New York spirit. 
The case being made is striking in its appeal, in part, to sympathy for the purpose of drumming up tourist business. It appears to link notions of patriotism and civic duty to things like hotel bookings. It centers for once not on the glamour of New York, but on its most tragic moment.
"They are using the tragedy implicitly and explicitly to lure people," said Marshall Blonsky, who teaches semiotics at New York University and Parsons School of Design. "And I think that it's going to work. Especially inasmuch as there hasn't been a second strike."
It is not easy to find a clear precedent. After the 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah building in Oklahoma City, tourism officials there said they went out of their way not to appear to market or promote what had happened, out of sensitivity to the feelings of survivors and victims' families.
But that bombing did not have the economic impact of the trade center attack. In New York City, where the tourism and convention industry is said to have supported 282,000 jobs in 2000, tourism officials estimate that several billion dollars in revenues and 30,000 industry jobs have been lost.
The most visible spokesman for bringing big events to New York has been Charles E. Schumer, the state's senior senator, who has made the argument for New York in pursuit of the Super Bowl, the World Economic Forum, the Grammys and the annual meeting of the Democratic Policy Committee.
"I talk to them about our need for their help, in our time of need," Senator Schumer said, describing his conversations with various organizers. "The whole world wants to show that they are at one with New York. This is a tangible way to do it. With benefits for the visitees and the visitors."
United States Representative Vito J. Fossella, who represents Staten Island, said he had repeatedly urged House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to consider holding a joint meeting of Congress in New York as a gesture of support.
This month, Mr. Hastert announced that he favored the idea. On Friday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tentatively set the date for Sept. 6.
NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, has put together a spreadsheet to track what one bureau official called the "new patriotic meetings" -- at last count, two dozen conventions and conferences said to have been channeled to New York City at least in part because of Sept. 11.
The list includes a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors held this past January; and gatherings of magazine publishers, engineers, pharmaceutical company executives, trial lawyers, a labor union, meeting planners and others, all of whom tourism officials say opted spontaneously to meet in New York.
On Tuesday, the World Technology Network announced that it would hold its annual World Technology Summit and World Technology Awards here. The event, which will take place in July at the Millennium Broadway hotel and the United Nations, is expected to bring hundreds of visitors to New York. "New York was the obvious choice for holding this year's summit, for many reasons," said James Clark, the founder and chairman of the World Technology Network, based in London.
William A. Maloney, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the American Society of Travel Agents, said his board voted unanimously in late September to move the society's meeting to New York from Seville, Spain. The meeting, held in November, drew 4,000 people.
"New York is a metaphor for our industry," Mr. Maloney said, listing the curiously commingled motives behind the choice. "It was the symbolism of helping our compatriots in New York, but also the symbolism that travel agents must lead the way to travel. Travel is an inherent right, and we cannot let it be taken away."
NYC & Company actively pursued another event, the International Pow Wow, a gigantic international travel-industry trade show organized by the Travel Industry Association of America. Though host cities are usually picked years in advance, the city that was chosen for 2005, Houston, dropped out last fall.
"We immediately called T.I.A.," Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, recalled. "We said we really want to be in the running for Pow Wow for 2005. We said we think that this would help with the recovery."
The 2005 Pow Wow is now set for New York.
One of the biggest events that some New Yorkers have their eye on is the 2012 Summer Olympics; New York is one of four American cities competing to be the host city. But Sept. 11 and its aftermath have not generally been raised as an argument in New York's favor.
"We have specifically not invoked it with respect to the Olympics," said Daniel Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, who previously led the group in charge of the bid. "In fact, we have expressly avoided even the appearance that we are attempting to benefit in any way from Sept. 11."
Asked to elaborate, he said, "Because somehow we think that to court favor based on a tragedy is wrong." Specifically he said, it would be inconsistent with the spirit of the Olympic Games.
Some have questioned the validity of the 9/11 argument in the case of other major events. Mike Bayham, a councilman in St. Bernard Parish, a suburb of New Orleans, strongly objected to Senator Schumer's push to bring the Super Bowl to New York last January when plans to hold it in New Orleans briefly hit a snag.
Tourism is suffering everywhere, Mr. Bayham said recently; cities like New Orleans also need help. He argued that the country had "really stepped up to the plate already" for New York.
"New York was where the people died, but everyone felt the impact of 9/11," he said.
But others say the 9/11 argument is simply smart marketing. "I don't think there is anything inherently immoral or unethical about what they're doing," said Lauren Schlau, who owns a Los Angeles consulting firm that does market research for convention and visitors bureaus and state travel offices. "Frankly, I think it's savvy."
She added: "I think it strikes a chord with a lot of people. I think people in the United States feel they want to help New York. Not out of guilt and not out of obligation, but out of maybe conviction, too, that if they help New York now and something else happens somewhere else, there may be a similar response. So it's an investment."
How long the argument will work remains to be seen. Representative Fossella suggested it would certainly remain appropriate within the first year after the attack. 
Meryl Mayo, whose husband, Robert, died in the trade center attack, said she had mixed feelings about many of the ways in which Sept. 11 was being used. She said families were having difficulty healing because Sept. 11 was ubiquitous and inescapable; yet it is also crucial to keep it in the public eye.
"I think New York City is the center of the world," said Mrs. Mayo, who said she personally knows many people who have lost jobs in the last six months. "I think it has to get back on its feet. And if it has to be on the back of 9/11, then so be it."

HEADLINE: Silver-Screen Studies 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA GRANDJEAN 

 BODY:
TALKING about movies. That's never more of a pleasure than when with Jeanine Basinger, chairwoman of the film studies program at Wesleyan University in Middletown. 
 She said she feels "A Beautiful Mind" is likely to win the Oscar for best picture at tonight's Academy Awards. 
 "Director Ron Howard places us subjectively in the experience of schizophrenia without letting us know that's what he's doing," she said. "You don't see that kind of intelligent use of the medium much anymore. It's the kind of uplifting film that the Academy likes to give the Oscar to." 
But the voters have other movies to consider: "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring" ("Very cinematic," she said. "An old-fashioned, high-quality piece of filmmaking.") or "Gosford Park" ("Beautiful looking and intelligent, but it's the kind of film that lulls you to sleep.") or "Moulin Rouge" ("Really nothing new, and what's the point of making a musical when your stars can't sing?").
You would think Mrs. Basinger, 66, would have been exhausted on a recent day, her nerves frayed. She had spent most of the day holding office hours, a weekly ritual during which her film students often line up 20-deep at her door for academic advice. 
"I have a sign-up list; it's like a pick-a-number thing," she said. In another couple of hours she would meet with architects concerning the development of a new campus Center for Film Studies. Construction on the building is to begin in September.
Also awaiting her attention were any number of the 100 or so requests she receives via e-mail messages every week: for print interviews and broadcasts requiring her film expertise, from anxious parents wanting help getting their children into Wesleyan and from Hollywood directors and screenwriters looking for advice on their latest projects.
Instead, in conversation, she is at ease, passionate and down to earth, as respectful of another film fan's opinion as she is eager to express her own. 
These are qualities that have long endeared her to the Time magazine film critic Richard Schickel, a fellow movie enthusiast, film historian and producer of television documentaries on film. Mr. Schickel said he has "endless" chats with her four or five times a year.
"She calls us 'movie bozos,' " he said, laughing, and pointed out that Mrs. Basinger's nine books and countless articles on film have served to elevate discourse while avoiding pretension. 
"Nine-tenths of what comes out of academia is unreadable," he said. "So I think of Jeanine as a lonely voice, a writer whose work satisfies all the standards of scholarship, but at the same time can be read with pleasure by people who have a general interest in the movies. I've never seen her teach, but I suspect she can do something very important, which is bring film history to life for her students. She can talk about the pleasures and absurdities of all movies in a way that would be appealing to kids."
Mrs. Basinger's 10th book, "Stardom," is under way. In it, she said, she will examine the erstwhile Hollywood studio practice of grooming young actors for fame.
From the late 1970's up until last year, when Wesleyan hired two new tenure-track film professors, Mrs. Basinger occupied the demanding position of being the only full-time faculty member in the discipline. Film courses have been taught since the early 1960's, but usually by members of the English, foreign languages, anthropology and American studies departments. It was Mrs. Basinger who, having joined the staff as a teaching assistant in 1969, acted as a key guiding force in designing the fully developed film studies major that was finally established in the 1980's. 
To this day, she said, she believes the interdisciplinary nature of Wesleyan's program is one of its greatest strengths.
"Wesleyan represents the old-fashioned liberal arts tradition," she said. "Our film students know music and literature, take science courses, study economics. About 60 percent of our more than 70 film students are double majors, two of whom are studying film and physics." 
Unlike other college film programs, majors are not polarized into separate "theory vs. practice" camps. "Students here have to analyze films and study their history, but they also have to make them," Mrs. Basinger said.
She calls herself a "old-fashioned, rigid" teacher. 
"I don't give incompletes, don't permit absences, don't let anyone come late," she said.
At the same time, she never assigns her students a writing project that she also doesn't complete herself. Nor does she hand back any paper without a single-spaced, full page of comments. 
"Mine is a profession in which every day, you go into a room and give away absolutely everything you've got," she said. "Since film is still not often taken seriously as an academic discipline, those who teach it bring an extra jolt of passion to the process, and students respond to that."
Former Wesleyan film students praise the richness of their training. However, Joss Whedon, class of '87 -- creator of the TV series "Buffy, the Vampire Slayer" and "Angel" -- acknowledged that, "Jeanine inspires fear, big fear." 
He also said that the hallmark of her teaching style is its interactivity. "She would give lectures so dense with information and insight that I could barely follow them," Mr. Whedon said. "But she's also there to learn from her students, and I've worked with brilliant teachers who aren't, who are only there to spew what they've brilliantly figured out." 
Graduates of the film program who have gone on to success in Hollywood careers are known as the "Wesleyan mob." 
In addition to Mr. Whedon, their ranks include Larry Mark (producer of "Jerry Maguire" and "As Good As It Gets"), Jeffrey Lane (creator of the TV series "Mad About You"), Michael Bay (director of "Pearl Harbor" and "Armageddon"), actors Dana Delany and Brad Whitford, Miguel Arteta (director of the Independent Spirit Award-winning film "Chuck and Buck" and the soon-to-be-released "The Good Girl") and Ric Nicita (head of Creative Artists Agency).
"I would say that roughly three-quarters of the people who have taken Jeanine's classes are working successfully in the business," said Mr. Arteta, class of '89.
"That's really astounding," he said. "We're all good friends and we all help each other, and we have to give her the credit for instilling a confidence in us that has made us less competitive." 
Her students stay closely in touch with Mrs. Basinger long after they leave Wesleyan, and continue to actively seek her input on projects. "To this day, I haven't shot a foot of film without asking her opinion," Mr. Arteta said. 
In the 1980's, Mrs. Basinger conceived the idea of developing a cinema archive to complement the film program. She sought a distinctive space to house three significant film and television collections already acquired by Wesleyan: those of Robert Saudek, executive producer of the groundbreaking 1952-61 TV series "Omnibus," and the directors Elia Kazan and Frank Capra, a close friend of Mrs. Basinger. 
Ultimately, the archive's repository became a three-story, gray Victorian house near the university's Center for the Arts. It officially opened as the Wesleyan Cinema Archives in May 1986. 
Over the next decade, the archive added the assorted collections of John Waters, John Sayles, Jonathan Demme, Martin Scorsese, Clint Eastwood and Ingrid Bergman. Bergman's daughter, Isabella Rossellini, looked into several archives following the actress's death in 1982, but was ultimately won over by the intimacy of Wesleyan's operation. 
"It seemed better organized than any other I'd seen," she said. "The building is like a Swedish house, simple, practical and direct, as my mother would have liked. And it's warm in spirit, not a mausoleum."
These days, the operation remains small-scale, and the archive's holdings are open by appointment to scholars and researchers only, despite offering a number of objects that are catnip to nonacademic film buffs. (For example, Ingrid Bergman's childhood diaries, letters exchanged by Capra and Alfred Hitchcock and costumes from the 1988 John Waters film "Hairspray.")
Clint Eastwood, who gave his collection of cinema material to the archive, said: "It could not be in better hands than those of Jeanine Basinger. I've known her for years and have the utmost respect for her skills as an author and curator and getting me back East as often as she wishes."
The new Center for Film Studies will have a community gallery space for special archive collections. Due to open in 2003, it will also house central offices for film faculty (currently scattered around campus), a state-of-the-art screening room, enhanced film production facilities, more space for archive storage and a winter garden, or glassed-in lounge, where students can congregate. 
"The film program has never really had any place of its own, with its own identity," Mrs. Basinger said. "Having this is going to be something wonderful."

HEADLINE: How Quickly a City Can Grow 

BYLINE:  By Witold Rybczynski; Witold Rybczynski is a professor of urbanism at the University of Pennsylvania. His latest book is "The Look of Architecture."

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
A plan is needed for the World Trade Center site but not a big plan. There are times for building Central Park, and there are times for remedial gardening. Lower Manhattan should not be remade according to some new grand vision. A framework needs to be put in place and some principles agreed on, and city life will take its course. 
 "There's no rush" is a phrase often heard in discussions of the site. Actually, there is a rush, because there is a reason why most cities struck by disaster -- natural or man-made -- generally end up rebuilding more or less what was there before. The reason is not a lack of imagination or will. Rather, while the planners and architects are thoughtfully discussing the options, decisions are being made on the ground. There's infrastructure to be repaired, fire hydrants to be reconnected, materials to be transported, neighborhoods to be knitted back together. In the absence of a new plan, the old street pattern emerges by default. 
 And soon it's too late: the blank slate is no longer blank.
Yes, the World Trade Center site offers a rare opportunity, as many have pointed out, but the window of opportunity will not stay open long. There is no immediate pressure to build a lot of office space, since it's as yet unclear how strong the demand will be and how the current economic upswing will affect New York.
But other things cannot wait. Subway tunnels will be rebuilt, stations will be reopened. Damaged infrastructure will be repaired. The destroyed electrical substation will have to be put back into operation.
But doesn't planning take time? Not as much as many people believe. Urban design is not rocket science. People have been building cities for thousands of years, and while technologies have evolved and changed, the principles of good city building are remarkably durable. We got it right a long time ago, which is why an old city, like London, Rome or Istanbul, often remains a delight.
There appears to be agreement among most architects and planners about what should be done on the World Trade Center site. To begin with, New York should not simply replace the destroyed towers with new ones, even if they are lower. The 16-acre site is a so-called superblock, the result of a misbegotten theory of 1960's city planning that replacing streets and sidewalks with windswept plazas was a sign of progress. We have since learned -- rather, relearned -- that urban life thrives on streets and sidewalks.
So we should put them back. Not that we need to recreate the pre-trade-center street grid in its entirety, but a north-south street would be useful, and so would at least one crosstown road. Fulton Street, for example, could be extended to Battery Park City. There is also an opportunity here to unravel some of the knotted transit issues that bedevil this part of Manhattan.
Turning one big block into four smaller blocks also raises the possibility of incorporating mixed uses on the site. Again, past experience has taught that neighborhoods composed of large chunks of single-use real estate are dull and unattractive and empty at too many times of day. Lower Manhattan, before Sept. 11, was slowly being transformed into a place where people live as well as work, and any new development on the World Trade Center site should encourage this trend.
So a plan then, but a simple one and soon.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Many start-ups have survived but will need infusions of venture capital.

BYLINE:  By Amy Cortese 

 BODY:
JUST when you thought the dot-com boom and bust had been safely put behind us, new studies suggest that more carnage lies ahead. 
 Separate studies, by the market research firm VentureOne and the consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, portray an industry still working through the excesses of the late 20th century. Sure, valuations have come down to earth, innovative ideas are percolating again and venture investment is picking up, but the cycle has a few last turns left before it is spent. 
 There is some encouraging news: a surprising number of start-ups survived the punishing market conditions of the last year. However, many of them will need fresh infusions of capital soon, testing the resolve of their skittish venture investors. 
The VentureOne study provides perhaps the best snapshot to date of the investment frenzy inspired by the dot-coms. The research firm identified 7,235 companies at the beginning of 2001 that had previously raised some venture capital. Most were high-technology related and had raised only their seed or first rounds of financing.
Of the 7,235, roughly 11 percent have gone out of business. A small portion (6 percent) were either acquired or went public, but the great majority, 83 percent, are still alive, albeit with varying levels of vigor. Twenty-eight percent even managed to obtain financing in the difficult market conditions of 2001.
The PricewaterhouseCoopers study, which looked at a smaller sample of companies, also concluded that more start-ups than had been expected made it through the bust, thanks to a return to more conservative business basics.
Behind the rosy numbers, though, lies a harsh reality. A large portion of the start-ups tracked by VentureOne -- about 3,400 companies -- last raised money before conditions severely deteriorated in early 2001, suggesting that they will be back in the market for financing soon. Yet venture capital firms continue to be extremely picky when it comes to doling out the piles of cash they are sitting on: at last count, at least $40 billion or $50 billion in United States venture capital has been raised but not yet invested.
What's more, a high portion of the start-ups are considered early stage (read risky) and are in areas like consumer and business services that are not attracting much investment these days. "It's pretty clear that all of those 3,400 companies won't get financed," said Dave Witherow, the chief executive of VentureOne, based in San Francisco. 
Venture investments have been sliding steadily, to 610 deals worth $6 billion in the fourth quarter of 2001, where they seem to have stabilized, from 1,711 worth $27 billion in the first quarter of 2000. At the same time, the interval between financings has stretched.
As the whims of the market change, so do a start-up's chances of being financed. Categories that were hot in 2000 -- e-tailing, online information and technology consulting, for example -- are about as enticing to venture capitalists today as WorldCom bonds are. In contrast, biotechnology -- considered dead just a few years ago -- is one of the hottest areas, along with semiconductors, communications and software.
Taking a slightly different tack, the PricewaterhouseCoopers study interviewed 350 venture-based start-ups in the United States and abroad, trying to analyze the strategies and characteristics common to successful start-ups.
Not surprisingly, the study found differences in the approaches taken by start-ups before the Internet bubble and during the bubble, which the study dated as beginning in the fourth quarter of 1999 and extending through the second quarter of 2000. During that frenetic period, companies attracted strong management teams when they were little more than ideas but typically had little to show in the way of customers or solid business models by the time they received their first round of venture financing. They were able to raise large amounts of money as investors bestowed lofty valuations on their budding companies. Those valuations were typically lowered in subsequent financing.
In contrast, companies that were started before the bubble developed more slowly but had more customers by the initial round of financing and increased steadily in value.
One factor that distinguished successful start-ups from the less successful ones was a narrow and manageable definition of the markets they were going after. "Companies that said they were going to conquer the world were likely to fail for lack of focus," said Michael Katz, managing director and chief operating officer at PricewaterhouseCoopers's global technology center in Menlo Park, Calif.
Venture capitalists have taken much of the blame for fueling the Internet bubble by backing so many ill-conceived ideas at inflated prices and then, when the market for initial public stock offerings slammed shut, ruthlessly pulling the plug on their hopeful entrepreneurs. But the PricewaterhouseCoopers study found that venture investors played an instrumental role in developing successful companies and brought valuable assistance to start-ups beyond financing. The start-ups interviewed said that venture investors were particularly helpful in recruiting, developing strategy and making introductions to potential partners and customers.
And there's the rub. The best venture capitalists have always provided a lot of hands-on guidance to their fledgling charges, and that has been a main source of their appeal. But during the bubble, so much money was thrown at so many companies -- investments in 1999 and 2000 accounted for 70 percent of all venture capital invested in the last two decades -- that even after winnowing their portfolios over the last year, many general partners are stretched thin across too many companies. The slack is picked up by less experienced junior partners, or not at all. With dim hopes of a quick initial public offering or acquisition these days, venture capitalists are facing the prospect of supporting their portfolio companies through several rounds of financing.
That math concerns many in the industry. Arthur J. Marks, a longtime venture capitalist, put together a study of his own, concluding that the flood of money into the venture business the last few years had created an imbalance of capital and the capacity of venture capitalists to manage it. The study noted that the amount of money invested by each experienced general partner had increased more than tenfold the last 10 years. "A lot of firms are trying to come to grips with this," said Mr. Marks, who was a general partner for 18 years at New Enterprise Associates before starting Valhalla Partners, his own venture firm, in Tysons Corner, Va., earlier this year.
One response has been to shrink the size of megafunds. Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the prominent Silicon Valley venture firm, told its limited partner investors it probably would not need all of the capital they had committed for a $650 million fund.
Venture capitalists may be cheered by other findings in the Pricewaterhouse study. Over all, the companies surveyed seemed satisfied with their venture investors, with 84 percent saying they would use them again. 
That is, if they ever get the chance.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Coming soon: advance selling of blocks of movie theater screens for pre-show advertising.

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
THEY run the gamut from snack promotions on slides to full-blown filmed extravaganzas. Now appearing on roughly two-thirds of America's 34,000 odd screens, they are movie theater ads and, like television commercials before them, they are well on their way to becoming a staple of American life.
 Now, taking a page from the television industry, Screenvision, a New York-based concern that acts as a broker for companies controlling about 12,000 movie screens nationwide, including those of the Loews Cineplex and Carmike Cinemas chains, has decided to try to sell its inventory of screens on a competitive, advance-purchase basis. And it is calling its efforts in this so-called upfront market the first in motion picture advertising. 
 It began with a number of recent presentations for advertisers in movie theaters nationwide, with Todd Siegel, senior vice president for sales and marketing for Screenvision, serving as host.
In a way, the movie industry's move into the upfront market was probably inevitable. People who sell movie advertising even say that it already surpasses its small-screen cousin in terms of viewer impact. They cite many reasons, including the physical size of cinema screens, the fragmentation of the television audience, movie audience demographics that skew young and affluent, the availability of complementary promotions on things like popcorn bags and lobby displays and, most important, the fact that the audience is captive and undistracted and unable to zap commercials the way people can with television.
All of that may be true. Still, in terms of media spending, movie advertising captures just a fraction of the television market, with revenue last year of about $250 million, Mr. Siegel said. That compares with roughly $45 billion in ad spending on television last year, according to CMR, an ad tracking firm that is a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.
Jointly owned by Britain's Carlton Communications and the Technicolor division of Thomson Multimedia of France, Screenvision is one of three major players in movie advertising in the United States. The others are National Cinema Network, which represents some 10,000 screens, and Regal Entertainment, which owns nearly 6,000 screens, including those of the Regal, United Artists and Edwards chains.
In its version of upfront market, Screenvision is offering "pre-buys" on its roster of screens to those willing to bid nationally for four- or five-week blocks over the next several months. Buyers have the option of commercials of various lengths, all of which are presented within a three-minute block that is shown after the house lights go down and before coming attractions are presented. Exclusives are being offered in various product categories, with rates and guarantees based on attendance numbers only, without specific links to the particular films that may be playing.
That is because historical patterns already exist to predict how many people will be in movie theaters during every season, Mr. Siegel said, including the summer and end-of-year holidays, when attendance peaks. Studios know how to fill the theaters by producing the right kinds of films at specific times of year, he said, and have reliable track records.
"Regardless of the actual films," Mr. Siegel said, "we know in July, for example, that our network will deliver 85 million tickets." 
Mr. Siegel said Screenvision's rate card -- the "official" price of ads during the upfront period -- was lower than it would be for piecemeal or regional buys, reflecting a cost per thousand viewers of about $35 during the peak summer months. But rate cards are commonly discounted, and Screenvision's are no exception.
"Do we sell at 10 or 20 percent off? Yes," he said. "But not at 30 to 40 percent." That would put Screenvision's cost per thousand viewers in the high $20's to $30 range, which compares favorably with television. According to a report last year by Media Edge, a media services agency that is part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group that is now known as Mediaedge:CIA, television's "peak time" cost per thousand viewers for young adults was more than $94 during the 2000-2001 season. 
Will the advance bidding work? It's too early to know, Mr. Siegel said, adding that a number of advertisers had already expressed interest but had yet to commit. It would appear that the other chains are not engaging in competitive bidding of their own, at least not yet.
Still, the president of National Cinema Network, Chuck Battey, said he was taking a wait-and-see approach, watching Screenvision's efforts with interest.
"I sincerely hope they succeed in enlarging the market for cinema advertising," he said.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
J. Crew reaches a milestone as its sales over the Web exceed sales from its catalog.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
WHEN J. Crew announced its results for February recently, the company highlighted its growing Internet sales as the one bright spot in an otherwise forgettable month. Surprisingly, what it did not say was that it had crossed a threshold that few apparel and general merchandise catalog businesses have crossed: for the first time, J. Crew's Web sales eclipsed its catalog sales. 
 J. Crew began life as a catalog retailer but now gets the bulk of its sales from a growing chain of stores -- $26 million in February. But the $13.1 million worth of goods the company sold online surpassed catalog sales of $10.7 million. 
 The milestone points to the continuing online progress of the biggest catalog marketers, which started their e-commerce efforts with obvious advantages over traditional retailers and Internet start-ups -- expertise in selling to customers remotely -- and which have continued to refine their online selling approach over the last three years. 
Catalog companies previously "did the Web with training wheels," said Kate Delhagen, a retail analyst with Forrester Research, a technology consulting company. "Now they are riding the bike -- they're optimizing." Those companies have also managed to attract new customers through the Web, she said, not simply shift the catalog shoppers over to a new medium with unproven long-term economics.
"There has been some cannibalization, but I'd estimate that between 20 and 40 percent of the catalog companies' sales come from new customers," Ms. Delhagen said. "So the bottom line is, they are acquiring lots and lots of new people through the Web."
But even if the cannibalization exists, that is not necessarily cause for alarm, analysts and executives said. Online shoppers cost less to serve than catalog shoppers, they said. And when customers buy from the same company through different means, they tend to spend more than if they buy exclusively through the company's catalog, store or Web site, industry executives said. 
Certainly, the catalog companies are getting their customers to spend more money online now than in years past. Take J. Crew, which is based in New York, and is 60 percent owned by the Texas Pacific Group. Without citing specific figures, David Towers, the company's vice president for e-commerce, said the average J. Crew order size was bigger on the Web than through the catalog, "mostly because we're able to do things online that we can't do with the catalog."
The best example, Mr. Towers said, involves so-called up-selling -- a technique epitomized in the offline world by the phrase "Do you want fries with that?" Since a site redesign in October, J. Crew has put more emphasis on this selling technique, showing photos of a matching T-shirt or belt, maybe, when a customer places a pair of jeans into her shopping cart. 
Notably, the company has been able to slightly reduce its reliance on printed catalogs as Web sales have increased. Mr. Towers said the company had reduced its catalog mailings in the last 18 months -- although by less than 10 percent. J. Crew does not disclose how many millions of catalogs it mails each year, but given the industry standard of about $1 per catalog to prepare and ship, even a small percentage dip in mailings could produce substantial savings. 
The topic of reduced catalog mailings is a sensitive one for direct marketers. Lands' End made headlines in 2000 after it cut its holiday 1999 catalog mailing by 9 percent, in hopes that customers would simply go to the Web site to view goods and place orders. The result -- 17 percent fewer sales for the company -- seemed to teach the entire direct marketing industry that the Web was a solid adjunct to a catalog business, not a replacement for it. 
And yet, Land's End and other companies with strong catalog and online businesses, like Recreational Equipment International, are still considering changes in their mailing practices, now that so many of their customers shop online. (About $327 million, or 27 percent of 2001 revenues at Lands' End, came from the online division.) 
Bill Bass, vice president for e-commerce and international sales at Lands' End, said the company was testing various approaches -- like mailing smaller catalogs to customers who also shop on the Web. With postal rates rising and the price of paper unsteady, Mr. Bass said, "print is becoming a more expensive way to interact with people."
The Web, meanwhile, is becoming a less expensive way to interact with people. The sizable technology investments that Lands' End and other catalog retailers made several years ago when they began using transactional Web sites "are fixed costs," Mr. Bass said. He added that the online division's profit margins surpassed the catalog division three years ago, "and we're becoming more efficient every year." 
Such efficiency is likely to increase, as catalog companies continue to learn more about the nuances of selling online, said Evan Guillemin, chief operating officer at Delia's, which started as a catalog retailer of apparel and accessories to teenage girls and now operates a Web site and stores, as well. In the past, he said, catalog companies could never change the mix or prices of merchandise once a catalog shipped, "so that's a new flexibility that catalogers have had to learn." 
Two years ago, Mr. Guillemin said, the company would mail its catalogs, then "put the inventory online and leave it there until we mailed the next one." Now, as soon as the company mails its catalogs, "we start reacting," Mr. Guillemin said, adding: "We shift inventory that's selling well to the front of the site. We'll take inventory that's not selling well and adjust the prices." 
The catalog operation also benefits from the online division, Mr. Guillemin said. The Web team can test items that may or may not work in the catalog, rather than placing a large inventory bet on certain catalog items without much empirical data on how they will sell. The company was able to feature more trendy shoes in its January catalog, for instance, thanks to testing the company conducted online over the holidays. 
The sales data gleaned by the catalog companies is coming in handy offline, too. In a year of retrenchment for many traditional retailers, stores bearing the names of Delia's, J. Crew, and other direct marketers are appearing in more places. Although some companies, like Recreational Equipment, are relying more on demographic information to decide where to place stores, others are poring over Internet and catalog sales data to help see where their best offline customers might be. 
Mr. Towers of J. Crew said that along with factors like population density and demographics, J. Crew's direct marketing data has led to recent openings in St. Paul, Durham, N.C., and Yale University. 
Other direct marketers will not be far behind, said Ms. Delhagen, at Forrester. "That light bulb is just starting to go on with the early leaders," she said. "If you've got a cluster of people out there in a certain ZIP code, and you know that when you open a store they go from being $100 per year customers to $300 per year customers, why wait?"

HEADLINE: Broadcasters' Woes Spill Into the Worldof Soccer 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 24 

 BODY:
When the World Cup soccer championships begin in May, the primary television broadcaster will be Premiere, the pay-television company owned by the Kirch Group.
 But while the matches will be played in South Korea and Japan, most of Premiere's play-by-play commentators will be thousands of miles away. All but two of the commentators will report by watching monitors in a studio outside Munich. 
 "Nobody has ever tried to broadcast the World Cup like this before," said Rainer Franzke, editor of Kicker, a German soccer magazine. 
Then again, few broadcasters have been in as much trouble as Kirch.
Kirch, a media conglomerate based in Munich, has been in a slow-motion spiral toward financial collapse. It lost nearly $900 million last year on Premiere and is groaning under at least $6 billion in debt and several billion dollars in other obligations to other media companies.
Kirch has been negotiating feverishly for relief from Germany's biggest banks and investors, and talks continued this weekend in Munich. According to German media reports, many banks want the founder, Leo Kirch, to surrender majority control. The company is trying to sell its controlling stake in Formula One racing, which it acquired less than two years ago for more than $1 billion. It is selling off foreign broadcast rights to World Cup games -- including those for the United States, where the Major League Soccer organization bought the rights from Kirch and will show the games on ESPN and ABC.
Here in Germany, the Kirch crisis threatens to upset the very structure of professional soccer. Kirch owns the television rights to German professional soccer, and the licensing fees it pays account for about one-quarter of the teams' $1 billion in combined revenue. Weaker teams, which get less money from other sources, are so dependent on television money that many would go bankrupt if Kirch were to collapse.
Kirch is not the only media company in Europe affected by having paid extravagantly for broadcast rights to sporting events. ITV Digital, the British pay-television venture owned by Granada and Carlton Communications, is threatening to shut down if Britain's second-tier soccer league refuses to accept deep cuts in its current contract.
Kirch executives are already demanding to renegotiate their existing $1.5 billion contract, which expires in 2004, with the German soccer league. Team owners are resisting, but they are increasingly worried that Kirch might actually go bankrupt.
No matter what happens, soccer executives expect to get far less money from the next contract.
"Anyone who thinks that things will continue like this after 2004 is either more optimistic than I am or knows more than I do," said Christian Schickhardt, a lawyer who represents players and teams in financial dealings.
The pattern is similar in Britain and Germany. Huge television deals prompted soccer teams to pay ever higher salaries, leaving many teams in deeper financial trouble. As the television broadcasters stumble, scores of small teams are in danger of becoming insolvent.
The expansion of satellite and cable television has turned a handful of European teams into pan-European marketing juggernauts: Manchester United, Real Madrid, A.C. Milan and Bayern Munich. Corporate advertisers have concentrated more of their spending on the big teams and increasingly ignore smaller ones.
In Germany, Borussia Dortmund is a publicly traded company with revenue last year of $93 million. Only about 18 percent of that came from television rights; most was from advertising and sales of tickets and merchandise.
By contrast, the Hansa Rostock team in eastern Germany had revenue of less than $25 million. About half came from television license fees, which are negotiated by the German national soccer league.
"Television money is extremely important to us and to all of the smaller clubs," said Dirk Grabow, Hansa Rostock's director of finance. 
Premiere has already served notice that it wants to renegotiate the current deal. "We must talk soon with the league in order to find a sensible solution for both sides," Georg Kofler, Premiere's chief executive, said on Thursday.
Some league executives have floated the idea of starting their own television channel. But many team owners consider that unrealistic. 
Executives of the big teams say they are confident that Kirch will fulfill its existing contract and that professional soccer will still thrive.
"Kirch has been a very good partner," said Michael Meier, president of Borussia Dortmund. But even optimists agree that nobody will pay as much for television rights when the next contracts expire, and that means teams are already scaling back star players' salaries.
Kirch has invested more than $4 billion in Premiere, yet the pay-television service has yet to attract more than 2.4 million subscribers and is said to be losing about $2 million a day. BSkyB, the satellite broadcaster in which the News Corporation is the largest shareholder, which holds a 22 percent stake in Premiere and has an option to sell that stake back for $1.5 billion, has said it would write off its investment and try to get back as much as it can.
Mr. Kirch was convinced that holding exclusive rights to German soccer and the World Cup would give Premiere the edge it needed. But he ran afoul of politicians, furious that people might have to pay to watch soccer on television. Under pressure, the Kirch Group agreed to let free over-the-air broadcasters carry games several hours after their being shown on Premiere. Kirch also agreed to let them broadcast 24 of the 64 games being played in the World Cup championship.
That severely diluted the value of Premiere to sports fans. Making matters worse, most German homes receive nearly 30 channels of television by cable at low or no cost.
Industry experts say at least half a dozen smaller German teams would go bankrupt if Premiere suddenly stopped paying. But it is clear that neither Kirch nor a rival will pay current rates for much longer.
"Football has been living for years on subsidies and infusions," Mr. Franzke wrote in a recent issue of Kicker magazine. "Leo Kirch financed TV rights with debt, and he cannot refinance that debt with the football product."

HEADLINE: Hollywood Watches Ovitz Star In Tale ofThwarted Ambition 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB and ANITA M. BUSCH 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 24 

 BODY:
Four years ago, Michael S. Ovitz promised to reshape the entertainment business by creating a management company that would leverage movie, music and sports stars into film, television and Internet projects.
 Mr. Ovitz, who had been one of Hollywood's highest fliers, was struggling to restore his power and prestige after Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, ousted him as president in January 1997, after a turbulent 14 months in the job. Within Disney, Mr. Ovitz's management style had created an aura of intimidation that clashed with the company's culture and made it difficult for him to define a role as Mr. Eisner's No. 2. 
 Now Mr. Ovitz's own company, Artists Management Group -- which he underwrote with some of his $100 million severance package from Disney -- is in financial turmoil. Over the weekend, Vivendi Universal, the major investor in the film unit, withdrew from their joint venture, leaving Mr. Ovitz in the unenviable position of having to seek new money in an economy still trying to recover from the recession. 
Once referred to as the most powerful man in Hollywood by the reporters and editors he courted so assiduously, Mr. Ovitz, at 55, remains a subject of fascination in this town, even as he struggles in his current job. An internal audit of the film unit that Vivendi conducted before ending the partnership has cast a shadow, and Mr. Ovitz's company faces a threat of legal action by at least a half-dozen employees who have been dismissed and say they are owed back pay. 
Mr. Ovitz was once the city's top talent agent, exerting leverage over studios and networks in the 1980's and early 90's as chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, but he has had trouble realizing his grander ambition: to be not just a handler of stars, but an entertainment mogul in his own right.
One word has been repeatedly used in recent days by numerous entertainment industry executives to describe Mr. Ovitz's current travails. The word is "Shakespearean."
In pursuing his ambitions, Mr. Ovitz, who declined to be interviewed for this article, has left behind a trail of enemies, a surprising number of them former friends and colleagues. That includes the leaders at his former firm, Creative Artists Agency, who were incensed that as soon as Mr. Ovitz set up his new firm four years ago, he sought to lure away many of Creative Artists' actors and directors. Creative Artists now refuses to serve as talent agents for anyone who seeks the managerial help of Mr. Ovitz's company. The agents also felt betrayed when Mr. Ovitz promised them that he had absolutely no plans to leave the agency -- three days before he announced his departure for Disney.
"We've gotten over the anger," one of the top partners at Creative Artists said on Friday. "We were hurt by him. Now we just sort of stare at him and feel sad. He's become what none of us want to be."
Similarly, Mr. Ovitz, at a retreat for the entire staff of Artists Management Group last summer, announced that he had no plans to disband the television unit, even though he and top executives had already talked about shutting down the unit. Weeks later, the television unit, Artists Television Group, was dead.
In an industry in which relationships are everything, Mr. Ovitz is struggling under the handicap of being at odds with many powerful people. Mr. Eisner, at Disney, is one. Others include David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, two DreamWorks SKG owners who have long had hostile relations with Mr. Ovitz. And Mr. Ovitz is estranged from Ron Meyer, one of his former partners at Creative Artists, who is now president and chief operating officer of Universal Studios -- a unit of Vivendi Universal, which has just severed its film partnership with Mr. Ovitz. Another longtime Ovitz loyalist, Barry Hirsch, who was his attorney, is now in a dispute with Mr. Ovitz over money.
One top manager who left the company last year said he had found it a hindrance to represent clients while working for a leader who was such a lightning rod all over Hollywood.
It is true that Mr. Ovitz has had success with some parts of the Artists Management Group. He is widely acknowledged as one of the entertainment industry's best negotiators on behalf of clients. 
The firm's management division, which helps line up projects for the people it represents, has lucrative clients, like the directors Martin Scorsese, Sydney Pollack and Richard Donner, as well as performers like Robin Williams. Yet many of the firm's younger stars, including Cameron Diaz and Leonardo DiCaprio, have been brought into the company by Mr. Ovitz's partners, Rick Yorn and his sister-in-law, Julie Silverman-Yorn, whose contracts expire next year. Their departure would be devastating for Mr. Ovitz's company.
The other divisions of Mr. Ovitz's company have fared less well. The television unit, designed to serve as a major money-maker for Mr. Ovitz, lost as much as $60 million, even though it had deals with top writer-producers like Darren Starr, Barry Levinson and Tom Fontana. Mr. Ovitz gambled on finding one big hit early, essentially to pay the bills. But at least a half-dozen costly bets did not pay off.
Last August, the television production unit was dismantled -- a serious setback for Mr. Ovitz, who was unable to use his persuasive powers to find an investor. Virtually every film studio and network turned him down, as did AT&T, Yahoo, Hughes Electronics and Enron.
The music and sports units of Artists Management group, meanwhile, have seen an exodus of executives and clients. The tennis players Pete Sampras and Pam Shriver, and the Los Angeles Lakers basketball star Rick Fox, for example, have moved with their manager, Jill Smoller, to the William Morris Agency. 
And last October, Alan Berger, a prominent manager of writers and of television newscasters, including Katie Couric and Connie Chung, quit Artists Management Group to join the Creative Artists Agency. Two months later, Ms. Couric signed a new contract with NBC for a salary of $15 million to $16 million year -- and potentially millions of dollars in agent's fees for Mr. Berger. 
Agents and managers play different roles for clients, and many stars retain both. But the lines between them are often fuzzy. Agents are allowed to take only 10 percent of a client's earnings, and their job is to solicit employment and negotiate deals. Managers, on the other hand, can earn 15 percent or more of a client's fees, and their tasks are to find projects and devote as much attention as possible to the individual career needs of their stars. They are also allowed to produce films and television shows with their stars and others, but agents are legally barred from doing that.
When Mr. Ovitz left Creative Artists to join Disney in October 1995 -- after turning down the top job at Universal because he deemed the compensation package insufficient -- he made it evident to his staff that he was tired of working as an agent. A reporter wrote at the time that as agents got older, they grew impatient when temperamental actors like Sylvester Stallone or Sean Connery called them at 3 a.m. to voice complaints. Mr. Ovitz phoned the reporter to say it was absolutely true.
Even Mr. Ovitz's critics give him credit for daring to start a management company and putting up a substantial share of his own money. But he might have miscalculated how long it would take to succeed. He began with 80 employees and soon had more than 200. That was far more than the number employed by Brillstein-Grey, which has been one of the most successful and enduring management companies, representing clients like Brad Pitt and Adam Sandler and producing successful television shows like "The Sopranos." 
Since the closing of Artists Management Group's television unit and the departure of many executives, Mr. Ovitz's firm now has fewer than 200 employees.
In any case, the rupturing of the Vivendi Universal relationship has put a new strain on the firm. After Vivendi made a deal in December to acquire the film and television units of Barry Diller's USA Networks and put Mr. Diller in charge of the Universal operations, it was understood that Vivendi would consolidate its film companies. The film venture with Artists Management Group was set up in July 1999 by Canal Plus, a French entertainment company that is part of the Vivendi empire.
Last week, Vivendi found its opportunity to end the arrangement with Artists Management Group, 16 months before the contract's expiration, by raising hard questions that arose from a recent routine audit of the Ovitz film venture.
Executives at Mr. Ovitz's company say that the audit was a low-level one, focusing on marginal issues like Christmas gifts, money spent on sweatshirts at a company retreat and the amount of staff time devoted to certain film projects.
But those at Vivendi Universal involved in the audit called it far more serious, involving more than $2 million and focusing on the possible misuse of money meant for film development and overhead. Such costs were paid by a joint venture with Canal Plus's production arm, StudioCanal, which Vivendi Universal is expected to close. 
Artists Management Group has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing. And officials at Mr. Ovitz's company said that an executive at StudioCanal had disputed the amount in a letter to Vivendi Universal. 
As part of the settlement agreement ending the relationship, Mr. Ovitz's company and Vivendi Universal issued a statement over the weekend saying that "statements in the press regarding improprieties were uncorroborated by any of the parties." People close to the discussions say that sentence was included at the insistence of the Artists Management Group and became the major bone of contention in the settlement of the deal.
Vivendi Universal, however, was able to use the audit as a lever to end the relationship early. A settlement was reached because neither side wanted a court battle. "There is no pending litigation," the joint statement said.
Whatever the final impact of the audit, Mr. Ovitz is now under more financial pressure as he pursues his dream of being something more than a talent agent. By some accounts, it is an increasingly lonely pursuit.
A top Hollywood agent who once worked with Mr. Ovitz recalled seeing him standing alone one night about two weeks ago outside the dressing room of the comedian Robin Williams at the Universal Amphitheater in Universal City. Mr. Williams -- who has been an Ovitz client at Artists Management Group for about three years -- had completed a sold-out performance. As in his old days as an agent, Mr. Ovitz was essentially hanging around to pay fealty to a star client.
After taking in this scene, the agent went to his car, took out his cellphone and called another former Ovitz colleague.
"It was really a horrific sight -- Ovitz waiting for Robin," the agent recalled. "I got scared. I said, 'We've got to pack it in.' I don't want to do that at 55."

HEADLINE: WRITERS ON WRITING; 
A Woman Pushed Into Heroism in the Times That Tried Men's Souls

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGRATH 

 BODY:
Some years ago, having written several novels in succession about insanity and obsessive sexual love, I decided that the next would be a story about the American Revolution. Instead of wild delusions, ungovernable passions, bad decisions and flawed perceptions there would be horses and muskets and sailing ships and thunderstorms. There would be sacrifice, treachery and bloodshed. Tyranny would be overthrown, a nation born. It was a chancy venture, but every author will recognize the impulse to travel down strange roads, if only for one book.
 Why the Revolution? There was of course its sheer romanticism, this band of farmers challenging the greatest army in the world, with the wilderness landscapes of colonial America as a backdrop and the idea of Liberty shimmering at the heart of it all. But there was a more personal motive involved. I had grown up in England, and after various rebellions and failures fled the place, eventually settling in New York, where I became a writer. That was 20 years ago. My feelings for this country are like those of many immigrants: powerful, affectionate, grateful but somehow never easy to articulate without resort to large vague abstractions. 
 Virginia Woolf, contrasting the English and American peoples, wrote that "while we have shadows that stalk behind us, they have a light that dances in front of them. That is what makes them the most interesting people in the world -- they face the future, not the past." It occurred to me that if I turned the other way, and faced America's past -- in particular, her overthrow of British imperial power and the invention of a new form of republican government -- then I might discover in an early, legible form just what it is about this country that inspires such patriotic fervor in its people, including uprooted Europeans like myself.
It is not a project for the faint of heart, the writing of a historical novel. The research alone absorbed years of my life, and there were no shortcuts possible: one has to be able to feel, breathe and even smell the air of the period being portrayed, and when that period is the 18th century those smells can be pretty ripe. This turned out to be a large part of the joy of the thing, however, and during the endless trawling through the history and fiction of the time, I read no prose more pungent -- perhaps with the exception of Smollett's -- than that of Thomas Paine, the best-selling author of the 18th century and also the man who saved the republic with a pamphlet.
Some novels declare their design and intentions to their author only gradually, as characters and themes emerge through the creative process. The writer of such a book will be wise to hold only lightly to his first ideas, so as to abandon them without a pang when seemingly of its own accord the story veers off in a new direction. Other novels require certain firm commitments to be made up front. My novel of the Revolution seemed to be of this second type. It was clear to me it would have to address the themes of, first, history and its claims to truth; then of power, both personal and political; and thirdly of parenting, inasmuch as the relation of a king to his colony was in those days often represented as that of a parent to a child.
Tom Paine was helpful here. He loathed kings with a passion, and none more so than George III, whom he called "a sottish, stupid, stubborn, worthless, brutish man." He described him as a pimp who prostituted his own children. He compared him to Saturn, who ate his own children. He wrote that "even brutes do not devour their young, nor savages make war upon their families." In short, to quote a French revolutionary sentiment from the National Convention of 1792, "kings are in the moral order what monsters are in the physical."
What I required, then, was a monster, who was also a father, to stand for imperial Britain and her king; and a child, grown strong enough to claim her independence, to stand for the colonies. The child defies her monstrous parent and achieves autonomy, and there we have it. But that of course is absurdly simplistic. Plans for novels generally turn out to be inadequate, and my crude schematic equations soon became the faintest part of the design: characters outgrow their function if they have any vitality at all. But as my story came to life, so, oddly, in its growing complexity, did the human dimension come to mirror the political.
The child in question, an English girl called Martha Peake, loves her father dearly, and it is only when he begins to behave badly, having become besotted with cheap gin, that she is forced to distance herself from him. She attempts a reconciliation, but he is too far gone. Nothing will do but that they separate, and in the fall of 1774 she takes ship for Boston. It grieves her bitterly to do this, for she and her father have lived together happily for many years. But he gives her no choice. So did the colonies, more in sadness, at first, than in anger, recognize that they could no longer tolerate the imperial relationship; their father the king insisted on imposing unjust taxes and stifling their ability to trade.
But having decided they must fight, the colonists did so with dogged courage, and also, it became apparent, with a canny eye to the public relations aspect of the conflict. As early as 1770 the use of propaganda had proved effective for the patriot cause. The Boston Massacre -- when British soldiers occupying the town fired into an angry crowd, killing five -- won international sympathy for the people of Massachusetts largely because, with the help of an engraving by Paul Revere, they got their account of the event across the Atlantic first.
Viewed from this perspective -- that is, in terms not merely of how the war was fought but also of how it was perceived -- the significance for the Revolution of Tom Paine's writings comes into sharp focus. He it was who, when the Americans were filled with despair and irresolution in the winter of 1776, rallied them so successfully with his pamphlet "The Crisis" that the revolutionary cause did not collapse but was, rather, reinvigorated. His closing battle cry, as one historian put it, "might almost have startled slain patriots from their new graves under the frozen clods."
The struggle, then, was not merely one of arms, but of meanings -- and it seemed to me vital that this idea be woven into the fabric of the novel. So it was arranged that Martha Peake, an English girl adrift in war-torn Massachusetts, pregnant and unwed to boot, is riven by conflicting loyalties, not only nationalistic but filial and sexual as well. And that as a result of these conflicts she is provoked into an action that will turn her into a heroine, and her story into a legend, despite the fact that she feels none of the elevated sentiments attributed to her when she performs the heroic deed, being driven by quite other emotions.
The cause is served not by truth but rather by the rhetorical inflation of an event whose meaning is fiercely contested. My own first naively romantic image of the Revolution had come to seem similarly distorted -- and unreliable historical narration became a central feature of the novel's design. As for the project helping me understand why I love America, I still find that difficult to articulate properly, although hating kings has a lot to do with it.
But I do know now why I love Tom Paine. He may have been smelly and not always sober, but by the power of his fiery prose he kept the Revolution alive and with it the fledgling republic. I have done what I can for him, even giving him a small cameo late in the novel, where he terrifies a child just by looking at it. I would propose him as the patron saint of writers everywhere, had he not been a godless atheist.

Writers on Writing

This article is part of a series in which writers explore literary themes. Previous contributions can be found at The New York Times on the Web:
nytimes.com/books/columns

HEADLINE: Big Mexican Breadwinner: The Migrant Worker 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 19 

 BODY:
Three construction workers who gathered outside a Western Union office on the west side of this city seemed too tired to drag themselves home, much less help lift their homeland, Mexico, out of poverty.
 But each time they go to the money transfer counter to send cash to their parents and siblings, the workers fortify a multibillion-dollar network that has made Mexico one of the leading recipients of immigrant remittances in the world. 
 Quick electronic transactions turn the workers, who barely make enough money to support themselves in the United States, into breadwinners for their nation.
Millions of monthly money orders, averaging $200 each, generate more than $9.3 billion a year for Mexico, almost half of the $23 billion sent to all of Latin America and the Caribbean. Mexico, a nation of 100 million people, earns almost as much from remittances as India, with a population of one billion. 
Remittances are Mexico's third-largest source of income, after oil exports and tourism. In much of rural Mexico remittances exceed local and state budgets. 
Across Latin America, the flow of remittances to the region's poorest countries tops all international development assistance and is increasing by an average 11 percent a year.
So while world governments and financial leaders gathered at a United Nations conference in Monterrey, Mexico, to ponder what rich countries could do to help poor ones, Mexican workers like Ricardo Morales were already leading by example.
The brawny 26-year-old roofer is from the central Mexican state of Zacatecas, which has one of the highest migration rates. He said that after four years of work in Chicago he has turned his parents' tin shack near the village of Susticacan into a three-bedroom concrete house.
He has a savings account of some $3,000 back home that he intends to use to help a younger brother go to college. He recently bought an acre of land, where he will build a small home for himself.
Meanwhile he lives with four other men in a one-bedroom apartment not far off West 26th Street, a bustling commercial strip of taco stands, dollar stores and money-sending offices that, according to the Chicago comptroller's office, is close behind upscale Michigan Avenue in the sales taxes it raises for the city.
Mr. Morales says he earns about $500 a week and sends about $400 home each month. "Our thinking," he said, "is that we will make sacrifices now so that our families can live better and so that one day we will live better back home."
Mexico has begun to take heed of how these simple dreams fuel real progress. Abandoning the attitudes of past governments who viewed immigrants as an embarrassment, Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, has hailed them as "national heroes." 
In speeches at home and abroad, he has boasted that the economic output of some 23 million Mexicans and Mexican-Americans who live in the United States is an estimated $450 billion. Mexico's output is a little less than $600 billion.
Mr. Fox has moved ahead of other Latin American leaders in trying to attract more "migradolares," or migrants' dollars, and in carrying out programs aimed at harnessing the power of the southward flood of money for development.
"These guys are potentially, and into the foreseeable future, the most important economic partner of Mexico," said Deputy Foreign Minister Enrique Berruga. "It's good that we have investment from Finland and from Singapore and what have you. But more important is to get these guys engaged."
In an interview, President Fox echoed concerns expressed in recent forums organized by the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank, lamenting that an overwhelming majority of immigrant dollars sent to Mexico were used to provide for the day-to-day survival of the poorest families. Little is saved. Even less is invested in projects that could stimulate economic growth.
"The families that receive the money," he said, "use it to buy shoes or beans, clothes or books for their children. Now we want to channel part of that money for production, for projects that generate jobs."
Mr. Fox has expanded government programs that match, peso for peso, the money that immigrants send for public works projects in their home communities.
Mexican officials have also negotiated with banks and wire transfer agencies in the United States to make it easier and cheaper for immigrants to send money home. Beginning in December some 15 banking institutions with branches from Los Angeles to Delaware agreed to allow immigrants from Mexico, whether in this country legally or not, to use identification cards they receive from Mexican consulates to open bank accounts.
The accounts will allow immigrants to send A.T.M. cards to relatives back home, so rather than spending $25 to send $200 at a typical money transfer counter, immigrants can give their families access to funds in the United States for about $3 per transaction.
In the wake of the attacks on the United States last September, the Mexican government has begun to distribute new digitally coded consular identification cards, which check an applicant's information against computerized census and voter rolls in Mexico. The first cards were distributed here last week.
Mexican officials said that during three weeks in December in Oxnard, Calif., some 12,000 new accounts were opened, averaging about $3,500 each. Officials at Bank of America estimated that new accounts had generated $50 million for financial institutions across California.
The Mexican consul in Chicago, Carlos Sada, reported that his staff could barely keep up with the demand for the new identification cards. Hortensia Martinez, 30, a hotel maid and the single mother of a 2-year-old, said she had heard about the possibility of using the ID cards to open bank accounts, and she thought that having an account might inspire her to save a portion of her $300 weekly income. "I want to open a restaurant in Mexico," she said. "That way my son will never have to work for anyone but himself."
Recognizing their own potential, Mexican immigrants across the United States have organized themselves in the last decade into powerful hometown clubs that finance public works projects and small businesses in Mexican communities that would otherwise languish. 
They raise money among themselves to build roads, install water and sewage systems, erect schools and distribute scholarships.
Officials at the United Federation of Zacatecas Clubs in Illinois said they expected to provide nearly one-quarter of the $2.5 million to be spent in Zacatecas this year for baseball parks, highway construction, computer centers and community meeting halls.
On a day when the Archdiocese of Chicago announced the closing of several black Catholic churches, Jose Luis Gutierrez, president of an Illinois federation of clubs from the state of Michoacan, boasted that his member organizations had financed the construction or renovation of dozens of churches across that state in central Mexico.
The money comes as a mixed blessing to communities across rural Mexico. Ricardo Morales's hometown, Susticacan, population 1,350, has been transformed from a tumbledown village into a well-manicured but empty town.
Many of its 400 homes have American-style facades. But most of them are empty, because their owners live in the United States. Enrollment at the elementary and junior high school, built partly with money from immigrants, steadily declines.
"All the progress you see here comes thanks to the United States," said Anacleto Santiago, 77, who raised six sons while working in Chicago. They all work in Chicago now, and he receives help from them.
But Mr. Santiago also acknowledged that as more pretty houses go up in Susicacan, more and more people go north. "If it weren't for God," he said, "this place would be completely abandoned."

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary 

BYLINE:  By Enid Nemy

 BODY:
DEAR DIARY: 
I was traveling by plane between California and Kennedy with my small dog in a sherpa bag under the seat in front of me. The dog is not a good traveler and was scratching at the mesh part of the bag, trying to get out. Afraid she would rip a hole in it, I spent the better part of the trip with my head lowered, alternately admonishing her to stop and gently telling her to relax, neither of which worked. When the plane landed and the seat belt light went out, I took her out and put her in a pouch on my chest. The man in the row next to me was surprised. "I can't believe you had a dog this whole trip," he said. "Didn't you hear her scratching?" I asked. "No," he said. "Didn't you see me talking to the dog?" I asked. "Yah, but I just figured you were from New York," he said. Sandi Schiffman

Dear Diary:
 During a recent shopping trip to an upscale boutique, I was waiting for my items to be rung up when I heard a dialogue between a saleswoman and the customer next to me. The saleswoman leaned across the counter and opened a case of Gucci wraparound sunglasses. "This is the hottest style right now," she said. After noting a skeptical look on the customer's face, she said: "Look, it's Gucci. It's the hottest thing -- even if you don't like it." At that, the customer actually said, "Really? O.K.," and paid $268 for them right there. I guess it was all in the delivery. Charity Curley

Dear Diary:
I joined my sister one Saturday morning to help her look for a couch for her living room, and after several hours, we decided to make Bloomingdale's our last stop. We were in the furniture department testing a couch when we noticed a man with a camera on a tripod taking pictures of an attractive woman posing in front of a hutch, then stretched out on a lovely bed and curled up in a club chair and finally, seated at a beautifully set dining room table.
We assumed that the pictures were for a magazine layout. So I approached the man and asked him about it. He smiled mischievously and said the woman he was photographing was his bride from Germany and they wanted to show her family how well they had furnished their apartment. Julie Glassberg

Dear Diary:
After a late night out with friends, I rushed to Pennsylvania Station to try to catch the last train to Princeton. Missing it by minutes, I found myself with three long hours to kill before the next train at 5.30 a.m. I decided to get something to eat, but made a stop in the men's room first. When I entered, I was greeted by a homeless man who told me he was hungry and asked if I could help. Inspired by several reasons, including the nightcap I had just finished at a jazz club, I invited the man to join me for breakfast. Before I knew it, Lewis and I were soaring down Seventh Avenue in a cab to a diner that he recommended and said would be open. We spent the next hour enjoying steak and eggs and cake for dessert, and we talked about growing up, our lives and some of the reasons behind his homelessness.
After I had paid the bill, Lewis politely asked if he could have some money to get him through the next day, and I handed him a $10 bill from the change I had received. He thanked me and we hailed a return cab. When we were back at Penn Station, I reached for my wallet to pay the cabby. Lewis stopped me. "Hold on, Mark, this one's on me," he said. He reached into his wallet, pulled out the ten-spot I had given him and paid the fare. Mark A. Sanders

PERENNIAL
The darkness still clung to morning
And the flowers stayed curled in their embraces.
The cool night air lingered
And they huddled and hid their faces.
Memories of sunshine days
Keep them strong and fearless.
They're sure to tilt their heads again
And sway to those warm smooth breezes.
As the sun burns through the haze
Some wake and shade their eyes.
Others squint and clear the foggy pane
To see the flowers, arms outstretched
Welcoming another day.
 Jiuliana Malfatti

Dear Diary:
With my Westie, Maisie Glover, in tow, I was trying to hail a cab. An elderly woman crossed the street toward me, glaring. Suddenly she asked me, "which way are you going?" I pointed in the direction of Central Park and then wondered why I had done so.
"You're never going to get a cab with that dog," she said. I ignored her and thought to myself, "I always get a cab and why do you care?" Just when I thought she was going to walk away, still glaring, she said, "You stand there and hide your dog -- I'll get you a cab and then you can jump in." I was baffled, but if she had nothing better to do, I didn't mind if she hailed a cab for me.
To my surprise, she did and followed through with "the act" to the end. She opened the door for me and said in a perky voice, "So I'll see you later, O.K?" Kathy Park
