HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: OKLAHOMA CITY BOMBING; 
Advice on the Task of Rebuilding, From a Mayor Who Knows Terror's Toll

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Standing in the pit and looking up at damage done by the worst terrorist attack in American history, Oklahoma City Mayor Kirk Humphreys could not help but think of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building.
 Ground zero was one of the few things about New York City that reminded him of home. The twisted metal beams. The chunks of rubble. The scores of rescue workers and firefighters sifting through debris. The weeping widows. 
 Mr. Humphreys was in Lower Manhattan on Friday with his wife, Danna, and his 15-year-old daughter, Annie. This was a personal trip, and they were looking up from the bottom of the pit, a place visited by few people outside of rescue workers. He wanted to come here so that Danna, and especially Annie, could see it.
During his visit, Mr. Humphreys offered some advice for New Yorkers -- some ideas about the anguish, the bickering, the rebuilding that lies ahead. At that moment, he was staring up at the torn-open subway tunnels, the exposed sub-basements, the firefighters using sticks to sift through debris for personal effects: a wallet, a badge, a shred of clothing.
The differences between the events of Sept. 11 and what happened in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995 -- the day a truck packed with ammonium nitrate fertilizer ripped through the Murrah Building -- are clear: in Oklahoma City, 168 people were killed in the fall of the Murrah Building; in New York, the death toll is more than 2,800. In Oklahoma City, one rescue worker was lost; in New York, it was more than 400. But the differences are in size and statistics. Not in anguish and suffering. Not in what each event meant to America. "The area of ground zero, 12 blocks or so, is about the size of our entire downtown," Mr. Humphreys said. "I tell people that what happened on 9/11 would have wiped out something the size of downtown. But the World Trade Center was an attack on America, and so was Oklahoma City."
"Shared Experience" is the theme of an exhibit scheduled to open April 19 at the Oklahoma City National Memorial, the former site of the Murrah Building. There will be a tribute to the seven New York City firefighters and two police officers who died on Sept. 11 and who had helped in search-and-rescue efforts at the Murrah Building.
One of those men, Deputy Chief Ray Downey, the leader of the special operations command in New York, has been credited with saving dozens of lives in Oklahoma City. He disappeared on Sept. 11 while leading a team of firefighters into the south tower. He was wearing a Catholic rosary that had been given to him by Oklahoma Gov. Frank Keating.
The exhibit will also include tributes to New York Battalion Chief John J. Fanning; Capt. Terence S. Hatton; Lts. Kevin C. Dowdell, Michael A. Esposito and Peter C. Martin; Firefighter William D.Lake; Police Sgt. Michael S. Curtin; and Officer Thomas Langone.
"They were good men," Mr. Humphreys said. "They helped us in our time of need."
New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, both consulted Mr. Humphreys -- whose job pays about $24,000 a year and whose city has about 500,000 people, some 7.5 million fewer than New York City -- on economic development, tourism, memorials and recovery.
Mr. Humphreys, who was elected in 1998 and won a second term this month, has been credited with rebuilding Oklahoma City, as well as attracting tourists and businesses downtown by making it more of a cultural center. (Mr. Humphreys did this without anything like the $21.5 billion in federal money that has been promised to New York; Oklahoma City received $54 million.)
In Oklahoma City, victims of what was at that time the worst terrorist attack on American soil received no federal compensation, something that was done in New York, he said, to keep them from suing the airlines. "We think victims' compensation is opening Pandora's box," Mr. Humphreys explained over breakfast at the W Times Square hotel. "Once you go there, where do you stop? What's the value of a life, whether it is a bond trader in the World Trade Center or a sergeant in Afghanistan?"
He added: "I think throwing money at victims is like a wealthy father whose kid is in trouble and his father hands him $100. And the kid says, 'I don't want your money, I need you.' "
He does not believe that the owner of 7 World Trade Center, Larry A. Silverstein, should begin rebuilding before victims' families have been consulted and city officials have looked at all their options.
"My advice here is just to commit to finding that consensus, whatever that is," Mr. Humphreys said. "It's just going to be extremely difficult here because you are so diverse, and religious, cultural and other issues come into play. Ours was tough, but ours was a piece of cake compared to this one."
He said the emotional response would be the hardest, and he emphasized the need to make long-term counseling available. "The physical is the easiest part," he said, "and right when you think it is over, you realize that you need to address those other needs."
He believes New York will do well, but the effects of Sept. 11 are not over. "On the morning of April 19, 1995, there were some people who woke up with their lives spinning out of control -- and then the bomb went off," he said. "You are going to have many people struggling for a long time. More substance abuse. More divorce. More emotional burnout. More suicides."
Focus on hearts and minds, not wallets, he said.
Seven stories below ground, in the pit, Mr. Humphreys stared up as he talked with a friend, Capt. Al Navaretta of the New York Fire Department. Captain Navaretta's wife, Rita, was standing nearby. 
Just the day before, workers had found the wallet of a friend of theirs who had died on Sept. 11, making it an emotional time for the couple.
About two months ago, the Navarettas visited Oklahoma City. "I felt like I was reliving New York again," Mrs. Navaretta said. "The same exact thing, just on a smaller scale."
Annie Humphreys was in the second grade when the bombing struck Oklahoma City. She can tell how it changed life, and how this will forever change New York.
"It's just something you do not get over," she said, riding in a Fire Department truck, the trade center site fading in the background. "It's not something you just get over."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At ground zero with Fire Capt. Al Navaretta, left, Mayor Kirk Humphreys of Oklahoma City recalled his hometown's experience with terror. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wishing for a Velvet Rope To Keep Nightclubs Out 

BYLINE:  By COLIN MOYNIHAN 

 BODY:
It was a recent Friday night on the Lower East Side, and at the nightclub Mint, on the corner of East Houston and Essex Streets, business was being conducted much as usual. Groups of people in their 20's sipped $7 bottles of beer or $11 mixed drinks. As colored lights flashed and dance music blared, partyers bobbed and shimmied. A woman wearing maroon velvet pants cuddled up on a couch next to a man dressed head to toe in black.
 This velvet-rope nightclub, known until November as Chaos, draws crowds from the five boroughs and beyond, but it is less popular with local residents and officials. Last year patrons at this former bank building were reported to be involved in 26 criminal incidents, more than double the number attributed to patrons of any other bar in the area, according to a police report. The offenses included grand larceny, assault, robbery, menacing, harassment and sexual abuse. 
 Underlying some residents' anger is a frustration that their neighborhood is in danger of becoming something akin to a theme park for nightlife.
Community Board 3, which represents the Lower East Side, recommended in May 2001 that Chaos's liquor license be revoked, citing arrests for gun possession and assault with a weapon. The State Liquor Authority allowed the club to continue selling liquor. But on March 11, a community board committee opposed renewing the license. 
"We didn't think they should be granted permission to renew," said Alexandra Militano, the chairwoman of Community Board 3's State Liquor Authority committee. "They don't appear to be capable of controlling their crowd."
Tony Theodore, president of the Old Banque Corporation, which owns Mint and its previous incarnation, Chaos, defended his company's management. 
"We have an incredibly good record of controlling the crowd, considering the fact that it is a nightclub, not a tea-and-crumpet stand," he said. "Every time we've attended a community board meeting, they have refused to listen to us." Mr. Theodore added that the police figures reflect only complaints, not convictions. 
A spokesman for the State Liquor Authority, Mark Anderson, said that the agency held two hearings on criminal incidents involving club patrons and that both times an administrative judge ruled that the charges were not sustained. Although the State Liquor Authority considers suggestions from community boards, it is not bound to follow recommendations.
Loud or rowdy nightclubs that antagonize neighbors are a fact of life in New York City, and some have been the target of strong actions. In 1990, for example, the Department of Consumer Affairs sought to revoke the liquor license of the Underground, a Union Square nightclub cited by the police in five killings involving patrons. In 1989, the State Liquor Authority revoked a license for the World, a club at East Second Street near Avenue C with a reputation of violence. That same year, a large discotheque at 10th Avenue and 18th Street, called 1018, where the police said least 20 shootings and stabbings had occurred in the previous year, closed after the city filed a civil suit seeking to shut it down. 
Orderliness aside, the increase in the number of bars has residents worried. There are 99 businesses licensed to sell beer, wine or liquor for consumption on their premises within the 10002 ZIP code, an area bordered by the East River, the Bowery and East Houston Street. Sixty-one licenses were granted in 2000 or 2001. In its neighboring ZIP code, 10009, which extends north from East Houston Street up to 20th Street, 153 businesses have liquor licenses, many issued within the past few years.
Although Community Board 3 has recommended a moratorium on bars for certain blocks, its chairwoman, Lisa Kaplan said their influence is limited.
"The S.L.A. does not find it in their heart to be responsive to the Community Board and appears at times to completely disregard the actions of the Community Board." she said.
Mr. Anderson said that he regretted that perception and termed it unfair. "We place a great deal of weight and value on community board decisions," he said.
Regulations forbid liquor licenses to be granted within 200 feet of a school or place of worship, or within 500 feet of three existing licensed establishments -- unless, after consulting with a community board, the State Liquor Authority decides a license is in the public interest. But local people say those rules are not always observed. 
"When you have a dozen bars close together, you attract big crowds who literally bar-hop, create noise problems and urinate in public," said State Senator Martin Connor, who recently wrote a letter objecting to the issuance of a liquor license on Ludlow Street, where there are already 12 bars within 500 feet of one another. "Creating an entertainment district in the middle of a residential neighborhood is not appropriate," he said. 
Nevertheless, Lower East Side streets teem with drinkers, many of them from other neighborhoods. Residents often encounter shattered glass and piles of refuse discarded by night-time revelers. But those who oppose new liquor licenses in the neighborhood cite economic concerns as well as public safety issues.
Though they agree that some peaceful bars are fine, they complain that the newest bars have raised the market rental rate for local storefronts to an unreasonable level.
"Bodegas, bakeries, dry cleaners and mom-and-pop stores on the Lower East Side pay between $1,000 and $1,500 per month in rent," said Susan Howard, president of the Norfolk Street Block Association. "Bar rents are estimated between $5,000 and $7,500 per month. As a result, the smaller stores are often evicted to make way for the high-end rents, which only bars can pay." It has hastened the gentrification of the neighborhood, she said, where residential rents have increased steeply over the last decade.
Although the bars affect their leases, some local shop owners say that they welcome the visitors, perhaps for the money they bring. But others say they have come to distrust throngs of young people out drinking.
Nazim Uddin, the owner of the Banga Bazar, a bodega on Essex Street that is close to Mint, said that particularly turbulent crowds gather at the club on Sunday nights.
He said that bands of youths had stormed into his store, then fled after stealing food and knocking over shelves.
And a few months ago, Mr. Uddin said, a drunken man urinated on the floor of the Banga Bazar, brandished a knife and beat up an elderly man who was drinking tea inside the bodega. "It was very bad," he recalled. "I was scared."

(Photographs by Edwine Seymour for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Analysis of Stimulus Package Has City Losing $300 Million 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
A new analysis of the economic stimulus package that Congress passed earlier this month -- which was conceived as strong medicine to create jobs and spur investment -- points out that it may have some unwanted side effects in New York City.
 The measure could cost the city, which is already struggling financially, almost $300 million in lost tax revenue over the next two years, according to an analysis by the Independent Budget Office, the city's nonpartisan budget watchdog. The lost revenue would make it harder for the city to close the $4.76 billion deficit it faces in the fiscal year beginning on July 1. 
 The trouble, city officials say, is that the stimulus package seeks to jump-start the economy by cutting federal taxes. But since the city's business and income taxes are calculated based on the corresponding federal taxes, the stimulus package will effectively grant businesses cuts in their city taxes as well.
Ronnie Lowenstein, the director of the Independent Budget Office, said that while in the long term the stimulus package was expected to spur economic growth and allow the city to collect more in taxes, it would reduce revenues in the short term.
The budget office calculated that the city stood to lose $93 million in revenues this year, and an additional $204 million in the next fiscal year.
City Councilman Bill Perkins, a Democrat who represents Harlem and the Upper West Side, asked the budget office to analyze the stimulus measure. "We are all looking for solutions right now," he said, "but some of the solutions are opening up new problems."
The analysis by the budget office said that to avoid the revenue losses, the city would have to either persuade Congress to amend the newly enacted measure or lobby the New York State Legislature to allow the city to calculate its taxes differently.
New York City is hardly alone in worrying about revenue losses. The National Governors Association estimated that the stimulus package would cost state governments $14.7 billion in lost revenues over the next three years.
New York City and New York State have severed the link with federal taxes in the past. In 1982, after a large federal tax cut threatened to cost the city and state money in lost revenue, the state decoupled the taxes for both, the budget office noted. 
"Given that the state is also facing a revenue loss from the stimulus bill, the governor and the Legislature may move to decouple the state system as well," Ms. Lowenstein wrote in her analysis.
Gov. George E. Pataki's office did not return a call seeking comment yesterday.

HEADLINE: Kentucky Foals Appear Well a Year After Plague 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., Mar.20 

 BODY:
Spring is sweeping as bountifully as ever across the bluegrass pastures of the thoroughbred horse farms. The season's early foals are tottering upright in the barns and prancing forward from the starting gate of life.
 The newborns' gamboling is a sight more precious than ever as the Kentucky thoroughbred industry anxiously watches for any return of the mysterious illness that ravaged breeding farms a year ago, taking the lives of an estimated 3,000 or more foals and fetuses at the height of spring. 
 "We don't know that there wasn't a Secretariat in those mares," said Ric Waldman, the breeding consultant at Overbrook Farm. He evoked the historic competitor in pondering last year's decimation of the foal crop and what would have been its progeny. 
The loss on the hoof is estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. But even more dear is the incalculable effect on the breeding industry of Kentucky, the world's leader. This state's horses account for three of every four winners of the Kentucky Derby and countless championship performances in the finest circles of thoroughbred racing. 
"We're deep into the breeding and foaling season, and there have been no apparent problems from last year's onslaught," Mr. Waldman carefully summarized. He echoed the cautious optimism gripping the industry as it headed toward the spring round of fresh racing and horse auctions at Keeneland Race Course, the world's leading marketplace for thoroughbred sales. 
"The mares that aborted last year are back in foal," said David Switzer, executive director of the Kentucky Thoroughbred Association, thankful that one major concern had been laid to rest. "Now we're looking toward April and the Keeneland race meet. That's what tells us winter is gone and we're ready for spring." 
At the Overbrook barns, Mr. Waldman counted 49 healthy foals. More are on the way, with no sign of last spring's lethal illness, a continuing mystery called Mare Reproductive Loss Syndrome. It swept the thoroughbred pastures like a scythe, with a rate of abortion and dead foals 700 percent higher than normal. 
The prime suspects include combinations of unusual factors, from tent caterpillars to wild cherry trees to a microscopic fungus. Most critical, in the consensus view, was an unusual pattern of hot dry spring weather followed by a hard freeze that left the pasture grasses stressed. 
So far, there has been no similar weather pattern. Confidence is gently rising with each healthy new foal. 
"Spring is special around here," Mr. Waldman said. "The 2-year-olds are just starting their breezes," he said of the local racetrack workouts in which youngsters are tested against time. "The 3-year-olds are developing before our eyes into Derby material. There is excitement and hope." 
To help life recycle, Overbrook is wielding the mighty Storm Cat, the sire of sires among thoroughbreds, the highest earning stallion, with a stud fee of $500,000 for each foal delivered. 
Storm Cat dutifully treks from paddock to breeding shed undaunted by last spring's debacle. He has been doing his bit for the recovery of his kind, with well over 100 mares booked for this year and his conception rate as strong as ever. 
Darkly handsome and resurgent, the stallion seems just the sort of royal symbol of renewal Kentucky needs right now. 
A legendary producer of champions at 19, Storm Cat has sired 93 stakes winners in the last decade, and his progeny lately have been winning about $10 million a year in prizes. Last year, 20 of Storm Cat's offspring attracted an average price of $1.74 million at major yearling sales as owners bid strong to repair their damage and bolster the breed into the future. 
"Even though Storm Cat is arguably the best stallion in the world right now, he still doesn't have the following from people who may have remembered him as a racehorse," Mr. Waldman said as the horse stood grandly oblivious to the fickleness of fame. 
Breeders, not bettors, come by to visit and wonder at him. It could have been different; the colt just missed being the star 2-year-old thoroughbred of his time, losing at the wire in the Breeders Cup Juvenile.
"He was injured soon after and was a forgotten name," Mr. Waldman said. "But Storm Cat would not allow success to escape him." 
Neither would the Overbrook owner, William T. Young, who sensed his breeding possibilities. After some lean early years, Storm Cat's offspring began running noticeably in the money and his stud fee rocketed. Storm Cat has compounded his value by having sired stallions that themselves proved to be effective studs. 
"He had his share of loss from in-foal mares last year," Mr. Waldman said. "Who's to guess the full economic impact of taking 17 Storm Cats out of circulation," he said, counting the lost fetuses and foals from mares of this champion sire, each of which would have been worth more than $1 million if it had survived. 
The losses of last year will linger into the future, thinning out successive generations of competitors and breeding stock, Mr. Waldman said, describing last spring as the most disastrous in his 28 years in thoroughbred breeding. 
"But time is a great tonic," he said, counting on the resilience of the bluegrass stallions and brood mares of Kentucky. "We'll get over this, but it won't be immediate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Storm Cat, a champion sire, will help rejuvenate the Kentucky thoroughbred industry. He is led by a groom, Kevin Stevens, at Overbrook Farm. (Stewart Bowman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Brazil's Prized Exports Rely On Slaves and Scorched Land 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: XINGUARA, Brazil 

 BODY:
The recruiters gather at the bus station here in this grimy Amazon frontier town, waiting for the weary and the desperate to disembark. When they spot a target, they promise him a steady job, good pay, free housing and plenty of food. A quick handshake seals the deal.
 But for thousands of peasants, that handshake ensures a slide into slavery. No sooner do they board the battered trucks that take them to work felling trees and tending cattle deep in the jungle than they find themselves mired in debt, under armed guard and unable to leave their new workplace. 
 "It was 12 years before I was finally able to escape and make my way back home," said Bernardo Gomes da Silva, 42. "We were forced to start work at 6 in the morning and to continue sometimes until 11 at night, but I was never paid during that entire time because they always claimed that I owed them money." 
Interviewed recently in his hometown, Barras, about 600 miles east of here, Mr. Gomes da Silva said particularly troublesome workers, especially those who kept asking for their wages, were sometimes simply killed.
"I can't read, so maybe a half-dozen different times I was ordered to burn the identity cards and work documents of workers who I had last seen walking down the road, supposedly on their way out," he said. "We also found heaps of bones out in the jungle, but none of us ever talked about it."
Brazil was the last country in the Americas to abolish slavery, in 1888, and forced labor for both blacks and whites continued throughout the 20th century in some rural areas. But government authorities admit that despite a federal crackdown announced seven years ago, "contemporary forms of slavery" in which workers are held in unpaid, coerced labor continue to flourish. The reasons range from ranchers in cahoots with corrupt local authorities to ineffective land reform policies and high unemployment. 
Perhaps most important, though, is the growing pressure to exploit and develop the Amazon's vast agricultural frontier, in part to supply foreign markets with two prized goods: timber and beef.
In the jungle west of here, fortunes are being made clearing the forest and harvesting mahogany and other tropical hardwoods, including jatoba and ipe. The United States is the main importer of Brazilian mahogany, and though logging has been permitted only in 13 designated areas, Greenpeace, the advocacy group, has listed nearly 100 companies it says deal in illegal mahogany to meet a growing demand from American furniture makers.
Furniture companies like Ethan Allen and L. & J. G. Stickley say their mahogany comes only from "suppliers that advise us that they comply with responsible forest practices," as Ethan Allen Interiors Inc. of Danbury, Conn., put it in a statement. But the companies also acknowledge that they do not have independent monitors and do not believe that they should have to determine the origin of imported wood.
"We cannot do the job of the Brazilian government," said Aminy Audi, an owner of Stickley, a big buyer of Brazilian mahogany in Manlius, N.Y., for its own stores and a manufacturer for other brands. "We have to believe the certification, and we have had no reason to believe otherwise."
Brazilian government statistics indicate that Aljoma Lumber of Medley, Fla., near Miami, was the largest importer of Brazilian mahogany in the United States in 2000. Asked about slave labor in the Amazon, the company's vice president for hardwoods, Romel Bezerra, said that "there is no such thing these days," and insisted that his company's mahogany came from legal sources.
"Brazil has put in place many, many regulations, with export licenses and stamps all over the place," he said. "They have established strict controls on logging and cutting and transportation and export, so it is impossible to ship mahogany illegally."
But the Brazilian government has estimated that as much as 80 percent of Amazon timber comes from illegal sources, according to a confidential 1997 report. In booming mill towns like this one, dealers openly resell, copy or simply counterfeit the government certificates needed to export timber. 
When a shipment of mahogany reaches the port of Belem for shipment to the United States, government inspectors have no way to determine its origin.
As the trees have fallen, there has also been a huge expansion in cattle ranches that raise grass-fed "green beef." Brazil's commercial cattle herd, the largest in the world, generally does not eat manufactured feed or synthetic supplements.
That makes Brazilian beef especially attractive in Europe and the Middle East, where fears of mad cow disease are still strong. Exports of Brazilian beef, fresh and processed, grew 30 percent in 2001, to $1 billion, according to government statistics.
"Slave labor in Brazil is directly linked to deforestation," Claudio Secchin, director of the Ministry of Labor's special antislavery Mobile Enforcement Team, said in an interview in Brasilia. "There are more and more cattle ranchers who want to increase the size of their herds, but to do that they need more space, so the clearing of land is a constant."
In 1995, the first year that Mr. Secchin's team operated, 288 farmworkers were freed from what was officially described as slavery, a total which rose to 583 in 2000. Last year, however, the government freed more than 1,400 slave laborers.
Mr. Secchin attributed the increase to "the growth both of slave labor and of our efficiency in combating it." But he acknowledged that most cases probably go undetected.
A national survey conducted in 2000 by the Pastoral Land Commission, a Roman Catholic Church group, estimated that there were more than 25,000 forced workers. A decade ago, there were less than 5,000.

Desperation and Coercion
Mr. Gomes da Silva, a slight, bearded man, said he had been forced to work on four ranches over a dozen years and had met hundreds of other slave laborers. Recent interviews with more than a score of other former victims produced similar accounts of forced labor, nonpayment for work and threats or use of violence.
The task of felling trees, some so tall they block out sunlight, is dangerous and exhausting work. The unrelenting heat bathes workers in sweat that causes chainsaws and axes to slip from their grip and draws mosquitoes, flies and chiggers that bite incessantly and transmit diseases. The dense smoke from incinerated tree trunks stings the eyes, and predators like leopards and cougars are often close by.
Still, many of the workers, desperate for any work, had journeyed hundreds of miles to Amazon towns like this one and accepted employment at ranches even deeper in the jungle. Once on the job, however, they discovered that their pay would be less than promised, and that they would be charged for transportation and forced to pay inflated prices for the food, lodging, medicine and tools.
"We were obliged to make our purchases at the ranch's cantina, since we couldn't go to town and the foreman forced everyone to remain in the area," said Gilvan Gomes da Silva, 22. "But everything at the cantina was more than double the price it would have been in town."
In addition, former slave laborers describe living and working conditions as abysmal. Mr. Gomes da Silva recalled the time he spent on a ranch with 48,000 head of cattle as particularly difficult. Forced to spray chemicals to clear pastureland but deprived of protective gloves and masks, he became ill and was plunged deeper into debt when a foreman charged him for the medicines used to treat him.
"The cattle were treated better than we were, since they were at least fattened up in buildings with concrete floors, while we had to sleep out in the jungle," he said.
"The only time we ever ate meat," he added "was when they had rotten beef they were desperate to get rid of, and so there were men who didn't have enough to eat and became weaker and weaker until they just got sick and died."
The peons, as they are called here, were often told they would not be paid and threatened with violence to keep them from complaining or leaving. "When I asked to receive my wages, the foreman told me 'Kid, your salary is right here,' and pointed to his revolver," said Gilvan Rodrigues Freitas, 29.
Workers fall into the trap of slave labor in different ways. But the most common is to be recruited by the "gatos," or "cats," who go to towns deep in Brazil's two poorest states, Piaui and Maranhao, to hire laborers.
"They talk a good game, sweet-talking you and promising you everything when they want you to sign up with them," said Francisco Souza de Santos, 54, a former slave laborer. "But they change their tune just as soon as they have you in their clutches."
Onboard the bus, a fiery sugarcane liquor called cachaca starts flowing. 
Days later, over bumpy, remote roads, the workers arrive in a compliant mood.
"Our trip lasted five days, but we only had three meals," said Onatan Alves da Silva, 53, one of 170 recruited workers who traveled on four buses to a ranch west of here. "Two young guys named Fernando and Severino wanted to go back, but the contractor," who was heavily armed, "hit and threatened them, saying he could fill them full of holes if he wanted to."
Going to the local police for help, however, is often futile.
Sworn statements by workers fleeing slavery are on file at the local office of the Pastoral Land Commission here, reporting incidents in which they went to the police in Maraba to complain of being held as slaves and were promptly returned by the police to the ranch from which they came.
"On the ranch where I was held, the cops were really tight with the foreman, who walked around with a .38 pistol in his belt," said Reinaldo Carvalho da Silva, 23. "They'd come around to his house to have coffee and gossip, so there was no way I could go to them."
But it is also common for ranchers and contractors to decide that a worker is no longer needed and to tell him that they will "forgive" his debt. The worker can then leave, but must find his way through the trackless jungle to a settlement usually at one of the many shabby "pioneer hotels," that take lodgers on credit.
In reality, these boarding houses are essential to perpetuating the system. Cut off from their families and unable to find anyone to help them, escapees and fired workers find themselves once again becoming prey for the gato.
Outside one pioneer hotel in Sao Felix do Xingu stood Baltazar Ribeiro dos Santos. The government's enforcement team had freed him in a raid last August, but a few weeks later he owed about $44 to his landlady and risked being sold to the next recruiter who would pay the tab.
"I'm so ashamed," he said. "Nothing like this has ever happened to me before in the 24 years that I have spent as a roving laborer. How did I let myself get ripped off like that? I feel like slitting my throat. How can I go home to face my wife and kids? I left with nothing, but I can't go back with nothing."
Benta Borges, the owner of the hotel, first claimed not to know what a gato was. But eventually she acknowledged her relationship with the labor recruiters.
"There's corruption in the whole world," she said when pressed about her business. "Whatever arrangements the ranchers or contractors make with the peons is their business, not ours. We just give them lodging. We don't ask questions."

Toothless Enforcement
Many ranchers are influential businessmen or powerful politicians. Last summer, for instance, the enforcement team, acting on a tip, raided a ranch west of Sao Felix do Xingu owned by Francisco Nonato de Araujo, from Piaui, where he is a member of the state Legislature, a prominent official in the ruling party and, until recently, the state secretary of agriculture.
The raid freed Baltazar Ribeiro dos Santos and 59 other workers, some of them ill with malaria, from what was categorized as slavery.
Mr. Araujo did not respond to telephone messages left for him at his offices and on his cellular phone. But he has at various times told local newspapers and radio stations that the ranch belongs not to him but to his father, blamed the ranch foreman for withholding the workers' wages and argued that "this type of hiring is standard practice in the region."
The enforcement team cannot arrest or prosecute offenders itself, and must rely on the local state's attorneys and courts, many of which are either indifferent to slavery or openly sympathetic to ranchers.
In addition, the Labor Ministry unit is chronically short of money and resources.
At least part of the vacuum has been filled by the Catholic Church, whose Pastoral Land Commission distributes a pamphlet to potential recruits warning them to keep their "Eyes Open So As Not to End Up A Slave." Many of the workers, however, are illiterate.
"Alerting workers to the danger is not enough to stop them," said the Rev. Ricardo Rezende, who works with former slave laborers. "Their thinking is that 'If I am hungry enough, I will run the risk and hope that this contractor is better than the other ones, because it's better to take that chance than let my family die of hunger.' "
But Mr. Bezerra, the timber company executive in Florida, dismisses talk of slave labor as "lies and politics," propagated by ambitious officials "who want to run for office and want the green banner behind them."
He, too, is a Brazilian, once lived in the Amazon and still travels to the region four times a year. He says he has never seen even a single sign of slave labor.
Both the Catholic Church and the environmental movement, he continued, are infiltrated by "watermelons, people who are green on the outside and red on the inside."
"That's right," Mr. Bezerra said. "They are a bunch of Communists who think that all businesses are bad."
But Brazil's most prominent antislavery crusader, Pureza Lopes Loyola, a peasant woman from Maranhao, tells a very different story. Her brother, Ataide, went to work on an Amazon ranch in 1974 and was never heard from again. When the same fate befell her teenaged son, Abel, eight years ago, she set off on a three-year odyssey until he was finally found.
"Everywhere I went," she said, "I saw the same scenes of workers suffering from malaria, hepatitis other dreadful diseases, prevented from leaving by armed guards. Now I have a grandson, and I fear for him.
"I pray to God every day for the government to go after this whole structure of slavery so that he too doesn't fall into this terrible trap," she added.
"But I don't think they will."

HEADLINE: Oscar's Home Is Smaller, but the Night Still Thrills Fans 

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, March 24 

 BODY:
The nature of adulation demands extraordinary sacrifices. People who revere Hollywood stars will go to the ends of the earth, or across the country at least, to catch a glimpse of the objects of their obsessions.
 "We drove all the way from Miami," said Elizabeth Birch, 28, a physician's assistant who traveled with her friend Lori Raskin, 33, a hospital administrator, after applying for bleacher seats on the Academy Awards' Web site. "We arranged our entire trip around this event. It's the American way, if you're into Hollywood." 
 Early this morning, as workers wrapped up last-minute hammering and assembling of bleachers and podiums on Hollywood Boulevard outside the Kodak Theater in anticipation of the 74th annual Academy Awards ceremony, the event's 400 least-heralded guests, chattering like excited children, began taking their places in the open-air seats that framed the burgundy-carpeted walkway leading to the auditorium.
In this era of all-encompassing security, fans for the first time were issued photo identification cards and were promised food, refreshments and disposable cameras for the almost daylong wait until the stars were to arrive. Once the celebrities appeared, the fans squealed and yelled, demanding a glance, a moment of reflected glory. Even the drizzle that began to fall about an hour before the ceremony did not dampen the giddiness, although women with meticulous coifs cast apprehensive eyes skyward.
There is no greater arena for celebrity than Hollywood, and no more alluring event for movie fans than the Oscars, the culmination of a three-month season in which the film industry celebrates itself, again and again. No matter how much other awards-granting organizations tout their significance, none come close to the sheer bombast of the Oscars, which throw this town into a tizzy and have far-reaching economic ramifications. Thousands of people -- caterers, chauffeurs, waiters, publicists, hairdressers and security guards -- are pressed into service. 
This year there were added complications, not least the event's new location, built to the specifications of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, sponsors of the awards. The Kodak Theater is considerably smaller than the Shrine Auditorium, the award ceremony's most frequent site in recent years, and even the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. With just 3,100 seats in the Kodak, many of the academy's own members, as well as studio executives who normally consider themselves a shoo-in, were locked out, leading to dark mutterings and wounded feelings.
The upset over the lockouts -- as well as complaints that the acoustics in the Kodak Theater are so poor that some concert promoters have canceled events there -- prompted the administrator of the 76-year-old Shrine Auditorium to predict last week that the academy would opt out of its 20-year lease at the Kodak and return to the Shrine, with its 6,300 seats. As part of the enticement, the Shrine plans a $3 million renovation.
"Who knows until the show's over?" replied John Pavlik, an academy spokesman. "We might decide we couldn't do it from here after all. A lot of people have been complaining, but I think that's simply because it's a new venue and people just aren't used to it. It's hard to change something when you've been doing it in the same place for 10 or 12 years, but we're trying to do it as best we can. We know we'll have glitches. Monday will be a better day to look at that, although no one will be awake."
To make sure the Kodak was as ready as it could be, workers applied fresh paint to exterior walls this morning, as florists arranged towering arrangements along the path to the theater. On the football field at Hollywood High School two blocks to the south, a contingent of Los Angeles police officers, several hundred strong, massed for a briefing at midday before taking their places to augment a heavy security force already deployed.
For some of the Hollywood crowd, however, part of the modus operandi of the Oscars is to act as though the event is not such a big deal. On Saturday, at the Independent Spirit Awards in Santa Monica, Calif. -- held every year just before the Academy Awards to celebrate independent filmmakers -- several of the high-profile attendees made light of today's prizes, not-so-gently suggesting that the real quality is in the world of small-budget pictures rather than in the mainstream studio pictures that the Oscars usually focus on. At the same time, some pointed out, no award is worth getting all worked up about.
"Everyone wants to win, but no one will be slitting their wrists if they don't," said John Waters, director of "Cecil B. Demented" and "Hairspray." Mr. Waters said that, in any event, the gap between independents and studio pictures "is getting closer and closer," citing as evidence the fact that two pictures that did well at the Spirit awards -- "Memento," which pulled in four prizes on Saturday, and "In the Bedroom," with three -- were also Oscar contenders.
"Oh, for heaven's sake, who cares how big your trailer is, or even if you have one?" exclaimed Sissy Spacek, as she carried away the best-actress Spirit award for "Bedroom." "I want all independent filmmakers to remember, it's not the size of the dog in the fight, but the size of the fight in the dog."
The show, as in past years, was filled with funny lines. In her opening monologue, Whoopi Goldberg described "Iris," the story of the author Iris Murdoch's mental disintegration, as "a movie that even Ingmar Bergman found depressing."
Then Ms. Goldberg only briefly referred to the "national tragedy" of Sept. 11. "But we've recovered," she said. "Mariah Carey's already made another movie."
Woody Allen, in his first appearance at an Oscar show, came onstage to introduce a segment of clips about New York, assembled by Nora Ephron. Acknowledging a standing ovation, he said: "Thank you very much. That makes up for the strip search." He pointed out that, when the academy called a few weeks ago to ask him to participate, "I thought they wanted their Oscars back."
Nathan Lane, presenting the best animated feature Oscar, the first time it has been presented, said, "Up to now I thought 'Monsters, Inc.' was a documentary on the Weinsteins," a reference to the brothers who run Miramax Films, Bob and Harvey Weinstein.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Aims to Extend a Lead

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 

 BODY:
In federal court, Sun Microsystems has portrayed Microsoft's Internet services software effort -- known as .Net -- as a virtually unstoppable monopoly. On Monday, Sun will try to cast itself as a Microsoft beater. 
 Sun, a major producer of software and hardware, plans to announce an ambitious effort for the wireless Internet -- a market in which Sun's Java programming language is already widely used and Microsoft's .Net is barely an also-ran. 
 At its annual JavaOne conference, which opens here on Monday, Sun will roll out a new set of Web services standards intended as an alternative to Microsoft's .Net. Sun will also announce a wide range of alliances with a global lineup of wireless carriers and handset makers.
At stake is the potentially huge market for interactive mobile services. Those services include messaging, games and so-called location-based electronic commerce. Sun's Java software has been adopted by the United States' five major wireless carriers, three leading European wireless carriers and the three leaders in Japan. 
"If you compare the phones with Java installed to Microsoft's Smart Phone software, there's a tremendous disparity," said Alan Reiter, publisher of Wireless Internet and Mobile Computing, in Chevy Chase, Md.
Industry executives and analysts say Microsoft is being hampered by its continued PC-centric view of the world, as well as by persistent fear that the company will try to dominate the software portion of the wireless communications industry.
"Microsoft still has the philosophy that you take the PC desktop and put it in the wireless handset," said Andrew Seybold, publisher of Andrew Seybold's Outlook 4Mobility newsletter. "Their bigger problem is that the wireless industry hates Microsoft."
Last week, Microsoft quietly replaced the executive in charge of its wireless initiative, Ben Waldman, who has taken personal leave. He was succeeded by Kevin Shields, a longtime executive in the company's hand-held computing division. 
Microsoft has recently made pacts with Deutsche Telekom and its United States wireless subsidiary, Voicestream, to support Microsoft's .Net initiative. But industry analysts said Microsoft was still lagging badly in the wireless world. There are currently more than 12 million Java-based phones in the Japanese market, and European handset makers like Nokia, Seimens and Ericsson plan to ship tens of millions of Java phones this year.
In the United States, analysts have been predicting that wireless data services will be slow in coming because the nation's cellular carriers have drastically limited their network-technology spending in the sluggish economy.
But Sun's chairman and chief executive, Scott G. McNealy, predicts that wireless data services will arrive more quickly than the skeptics say they will. "People are communicating more and traveling less," he said.
Moreover, telecommunications companies are looking to new wireless data services, which include messaging and games, as a lucrative way out of the increasingly competitive voice market.
Carriers see advanced services as "the silver bullet to ward off collapsing fees" from wireless voice communications, said David Readerman, a partner at Thomas Weisel Partners, a San Francisco investment firm.
Sun's Java-based wireless initiative is expected to receive endorsements on Monday from Sprint Communications, Research in Motion, Nextel, Motorola, Nokia, Ericsson and Vodaphone, among others. 
Research in Motion is the Canadian maker of the popular Blackberry hand-held electronic mail communication system used by 13,000 corporations. The company, which recently announced a new version of its device that includes a cellular telephone, plans at JavaOne to introduce a software development kit that will make it possible for corporations and cellular carriers to produce custom software applications to run on the Blackberry.
"We think the game changer is how these wireless devices will become platforms for software developers," said Jim Balsillie, chairman and co-chief executive of Research in Motion of Waterloo, Ontario.
Examples of cellular software applications for wireless data services include programs being developed by companies like the Mapinfo Corporation, a Troy, N.Y., developer of location-based software, which is intended to let cellular phone users select restaurants, hotels or other businesses and then immediately see maps of their locations on their phone displays.
At JavaOne, Sun plans to announce a set of standards for delivering Web services that have been tailored to the version of Java that is designed to run on cellular phones, palmtop organizers, set-top boxes and cars.

HEADLINE: Broadview-Warburg Deal May Be Near 

BYLINE:  ByPATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Broadview International, an investment bank that specializes in technology company mergers, is in serious discussions to sell itself to UBS Warburg, several Wall Street executives said over the weekend.
 Warburg, the investment banking arm of the Swiss bank UBS, could announce a deal to buy Broadview, a private partnership, as soon as this week. But an agreement is not certain because the firms were still negotiating some terms of the sale over the weekend, these people said, and the talks could fall apart. 
 Exact terms of the transaction could not be determined. People close to the firms said the price could be as low as $100 million, a fraction of what Broadview could have sold for just two years ago, an example of how far the technology sector has fallen.
"We get approached all the time by other firms, which does lead to speculation," said Brian Hickey, a Broadview spokesman. "It is our firm policy not to comment on rumors and speculation." 
A spokesman for UBS, which also owns the PaineWebber brokerage firm, declined to comment.
While most big firms on Wall Street have been cutting back, UBS has been spending money to hire veteran investment bankers. Buying Broadview could enhance Warburg's stature in the technology sector in time for a rebound in deal-making activity there.
Broadview, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., and has offices in Silicon Valley, Boston and London, grew rapidly during the technology boom of the late 1990's as it advised technology companies on dozens of acquisitions, most paid for with inflated stock. After giant banks gobbled up several tech-focused investment banks including Hambrecht & Quist, Broadview became the biggest independent firm of its kind. Among its coups was the sale of the chip maker Burr-Brown to Texas Instruments for more than $7.6 billion in June 2000.
But Broadview has been struggling through a deal drought since the technology stock bubble two years ago. The firm eliminated about 150 jobs last year and now has a staff of about 200 people. Some of its senior executives, including Victor Basta, the executive chairman of its international business, have left the firm in the last few months. Late last year, Broadview hired another mergers specialist, Lazard, to help find a buyer.
UBS is not the first big bank to consider buying Broadview. The Goldman Sachs Group discussed an acquisition of Broadview last year but backed off, people close to the firms said.

HEADLINE: In El Salvador, Bush Talks of Trade and Criticizes Democrats 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, March 24 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would push hard for a trade accord between the United States and Central America, but he also took time to criticize the Democrats back home for calling his four-day trip to Latin America an excuse to pander for Latino votes.
 "Sometimes in Washington, D.C., people cannot get rid of old habits," Mr. Bush said at a 30-minute news conference with President Francisco Flores. "Which is petty politics, Mr. President. But that's just what happens." 
 On Saturday, Antonio Villaraigosa, the former speaker of the California State Assembly who ran for mayor of Los Angeles last year, said in a nationwide American radio address that the president's trip to Mexico, Peru and El Salvador was "part of an orchestrated strategy to curry favor with Latino voters in the United States."
Mr. Villaraigosa added that "our community knows the difference between rhetoric and results" and that it also knew the difference between "pandering and producing."
Mr. Villaraigosa was chosen to respond to the president's weekly radio address, broadcast in the United States on Saturday, in which Mr. Bush extolled his activities on a trip that has promoted trade, immigration policies, American foreign aid and the United States commitment to fight drug trafficking in the Andes.
Trade was the primary item on the agenda during Mr. Bush's six-hour stop in San Salvador, the last of his trip, where he met for half an hour with President Flores, held the news conference, then had a 90-minute lunch with Mr. Flores and the leaders of Nicaragua, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Honduras, Belize and Panama.
Mr. Bush called El Salvador, which a decade ago was mired in a violent civil war, "one of the really great stories of economic and political transformation of our time." He praised Mr. Flores, 42, as a democratic reformer and said that "it's an honor to call him friend."
Mr. Flores responded, "I have had some honors in my life, but never had I had such a high honor as President Bush calling me his friend."
Despite the extravagant expressions of warmth between the two leaders, the trade agreement is far from becoming reality. Mr. Bush first proposed it in Washington in January at speech at the headquarters of the Organization of American States that was intended to show that he had not turned away from Latin America despite his commitment to fighting terrorism.
Since then his administration has conceded that it has much work to do on pushing other proposed trade agreements through Congress before turning its attention to any deal with Central America.
"I just think that as we move forward with our other trade agreements, we have to realize that there are some on Capitol Hill that are not favorably disposed toward these kinds of agreements," Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told reporters on Air Force One this morning. "But these kinds of agreements have been shown over the years to benefit the countries who enter into the agreements with us."
As far away as any trade deal is, Central American leaders nonetheless eagerly welcomed Mr. Bush's arrival and said it signaled Washington's acknowledgment that the region had made a successful transition to peacetime democracy. 
At the news conference, Mr. Bush called El Salvador, which has emerged from the 1980's conflicts better off financially and politically than Nicaragua or Guatemala, "one of the really bright lights in Latin America."
But many Latin American analysts said that Mr. Bush's stopover here amounted to little more than a photo opportunity, and that his administration had not provided enough money or follow-through to make sure that democracy took root.
"One of the real dangers of trumpeting democracy, as we have around all of Central America, and then not backing it up with an effective aid program is that we are building a cynicism about democracy that could turn ugly," said Robert White, a former United States ambassador to El Salvador.
After the news conference, Mr. Bush posed for a picture with Prime Minister Said Musa of Belize, President Ricardo Maduro of Honduras, President Mireya Moscoso of Panama, President Enrique Bolanos of Nicaragua, President Miguel Angel Rodriguez of Costa Rica and President Alfonso Portillo of Guatemala as well as President Flores.
In his briefing to reporters on Air Force One, Secretary Powell also said that in Peru, Mr. Bush had raised the issue of Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year sentence in a Peruvian jail for helping rebels from the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement plan a 1995 attempt to capture the country's Congress. Ms. Berenson, who was tried twice, has maintained her innocence.
Mr. Powell said that Mr. Bush had brought up the issue directly with President Alejandro Toledo of Peru on Saturday, but that Mr. Bush had not made an appeal for a pardon of Ms. Berenson. The president is waiting, Mr. Powell said, for a review of the case by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights.
"We took note of the fact that the second trial, by our standards, followed the kind of due process we'd like to see," Mr. Powell said. "And the appellate process within Peru is finished."
When the commission completes its review, Mr. Powell said, "perhaps that may offer an opportunity for President Toledo to examine the whole case and take another look at what might be possible." At that point, Mr. Powell added, "we'll see what we might want to say."

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Diplomatic Two-Steps In Latin America Trip

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, March 24 

 BODY:
Was President Bush's four-day trip to Mexico, Peru and El Salvador one he never wanted to make? The White House says no, Mr. Bush had a fine time meeting with more than a dozen Latin American heads of state, speaking his own brand of Spanglish ("Mexico es a grand amigo de los Estados Unidos and we're equal partners") and promoting trade in Lima's baroque Presidential Palace after a 21-gun salute.
 But consider the facts, which were not that pretty even before the Democrats accused Mr. Bush of taking the trip merely to troll for Latino votes. A car bomb exploded in Lima, killing nine, just 72 hours ahead of the president's arrival. 
 From the beginning, Mr. Bush committed to attending the last day of a United Nations conference on global aid to the poor in Monterrey, Mexico -- the initial reason for his trip -- only after his friend, President Vicente Fox of Mexico, called and asked. Only the two leaders know for sure how much pressure Mr. Fox put on Mr. Bush, but no one disputes that Mr. Bush's attendance was crucial to Mr. Fox's stature as president and host of the conference and that Mr. Bush owed something to his fellow big-hat rancher, whom he had neglected after the Sept. 11 attacks.
"He was my friend prior to September the 11th, he was my friend after September the 11th, he'll be my friend for a long period of time," Mr. Bush said in a typical I-love-Vicente remark before embarking on the trip.
But Mr. Bush's attendance at the conference immediately created another problem, development experts say. The United States had not increased its $10 billion foreign aid budget in a decade, a source of enormous criticism from nations rich and poor. As the clamor grew, the White House assembled a foreign aid package, a $5 billion increase over three years, which Mr. Bush announced in Washington with Bono, the attention-getting Irish rock star and advocate for the poor, at his side.
The nations already gathering in Monterrey, however, were underwhelmed, and pronounced the offer cheap. Soon enough, Mr. Bush pulled another $5 billion out of his Stetson, as the White House made the bizarre announcement that it had gotten the original math wrong.
"We didn't want to go out there with essentially false or phony numbers," said Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser. Skeptics said the White House was just adding on billions to make sure that the president was a hit in Monterrey.
He was at the conference, but seemed irritable at a news briefing with Mr. Fox at the government palace, where Mr. Bush blamed the Senate for holding up an immigration bill he had hoped to present to the Mexican president. Mexican reporters demanded to know if Fidel Castro of Cuba had stalked out of the conference early because of pressure from the United States.
"I don't know what you're talking about, about pressuring anybody," Mr. Bush replied testily. When another Mexican reporter persisted, asking, "Who is lying, Mr. President Bush?" Mr. Bush responded, "I thought I just answered that question. Maybe I missed it -- or you did."
In Lima, which had been turned into a military encampment by the car bomb, Mr. Bush blamed the Senate once again, this time for holding up an Andean trade agreement that he had hoped to deliver to President Alejandro Toledo. But Mr. Bush announced that the Peace Corps would return to Peru after an absence of nearly three decades.
A Peruvian reporter was not impressed. "President Bush, you are in a region now that's been devastated by terrorism and subversion and drug trafficking for over three decades," he said. "You're offering us the Peace Corps."
Mr. Bush replied, "I think I said more than just the Peace Corps, if I'm not mistaken, in my opening comments." Then he threatened, "I'll repeat if you'd like me to, go through the litany of things I just said."
In San Salvador today, Mr. Bush once again had nothing specific to deliver to President Francisco Flores and six other Central American leaders, at least beyond a display of support for the region. A Central American trade bill that Mr. Bush proposed in January is still that, a proposal, with no one in Congress to blame. At a news conference, American reporters resorted to asking Mr. Bush whether he would sign the campaign finance reform bill passed last week by the Senate reluctantly or whole-heartedly.
Mr. Bush, displaying some evidence that it had been a long four days, replied that he would not hesitate, and said, "I have a kind of firm, semifirm signature as it moves across the page." He added that "it will probably take about -- you know, about three seconds to get to the W, I may hesitate on the period, and then rip through the Bush."
But there were some high moments for Mr. Bush. "This morning in our hotel room when we woke up, I loved looking out the windows and seeing the mountains," Laura Bush told a group of Mexican children in Monterrey, describing the couple's view of the Sierra Madres. 
In the end, Mrs. Bush probably said it best. "A trip like this for me is very fun and relaxing," she told the children. "The president has to work."

HEADLINE: In Awful Year for Industry, 2 Airlines Make Strides 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, March 25 

 BODY:
In a year when the aviation industry suffered $15 billion in losses worldwide and two venerable European flag carriers went bankrupt, Turkish Airlines defied the odds by earning a slim profit, the company reported today.
 Though it is state-controlled, Turkish Airlines did without the government support that kept some airlines in other countries afloat. Its efforts to make itself more responsive to the market were reflected in its $6.7 million profit for 2001, compared with a loss of $103 million in 2000. 
 "This move into the black is sustainable because we have restructured ourselves and because the government has liberated us from intervention," Cem M. Kozlu, the chairman, said in an interview. 
Some of the measures it took were familiar. Unprofitable flights were reduced, excess aircraft sold, orders for new planes canceled or delayed. In-flight meals were pared , and the airline stopped giving passengers free newspapers on domestic flights.
Other steps were innovative. Labor unions accepted a 10 percent wage cut for three months in exchange for a freeze on layoffs. Such agreements are rare both in the aviation industry and among Turkey's state-owned enterprises, where political sensibilities usually outweigh market considerations. 
Deep discounts on tickets for members of Parliament and the news media were eliminated in January and service to unprofitable airports was discontinued, two riskier steps that are still drawing protests but were deemed essential to long-term profitability.
To be sure, the picture is not completely rosy. Only 10.4 million passengers used it last year, down from 12 million in 2000. When business starts to grow again, new capital will be needed to expand the fleet, which was trimmed to 68 aircraft last year from 74 in 2000. Indeed, gains from the sale of six Airbus aircraft to Iranian Airlines helped Turkish make a profit.
"The company needs to increase the operating profitability and promote domestic flights heavily until international flights resume to a certain point," said Oner Ayan, head of the Turkey desk at Raymond James & Associates in New York.
Still, in a year when Sabena and Swissair went bankrupt and United Airlines lost a record $2.1 billion, Turkish Airlines turned a profit for the first time since 1998.
In a sense, the Turks had a head start on the industry when it came to dealing with the havoc created by the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. A plunge by the Turkish currency in February 2001 created an economic crisis that knocked domestic passenger loads down almost one-third, followed by a 10 percent drop in international traffic.
The airline responded by winning new flexibility from the government, which owns 98.2 percent of its stock. Most significantly, Parliament passed legislation allowing it to set its own fares for the first time. In the past, the government often blocked fare increases to curry public favor, executives said.
Simple steps also led to substantial savings. Eliminating boxes for meals on domestic flights saved $3 million; adjusting crew schedules to reduce overnight stays saved $1 million.
Many steps were under way when the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington caused deep cutbacks in air travel worldwide. Turkey was hit hard because of its proximity to the Middle East. 
"After Sept. 11, we realized the measures we had taken were not enough, so we started a further cost-saving program," said Sertac Haybat, executive vice president for finance. 
In the fourth quarter, the airline eliminated about 1,500 jobs, half through voluntary and forced retirements, cutting the staff to 11,000. The deal with the union to freeze layoffs and cut pay temporarily came in November.
One of the toughest steps was dropping money-losing routes within the country, where it has a virtual monopoly. With no service, five airports closed last year and a sixth closed this month.
Some sizable cities were suddenly isolated, and angry. For Sivas, a city of 250,000 in central Turkey, the nearest airport is now two hours away by car, and Istanbul, the commercial capital, is a day's drive.
"The closure is unfortunate for Sivas, because we want to develop our business community," said Osman Yildirim, head of the city's chamber of commerce. "We understand the global crisis that followed Sept. 11, but our airport had been functioning since 1957."
Airline executives said passenger levels were climbing again, particularly on international routes. Mr. Kozlu said the airline's management sees promise in Istanbul's location as a hub for Asia and the Middle East, in the prospects for improved tourism in Turkey and in a two-year-old code-sharing alliance with American Airlines that has increased access to the United States market.
Most important, he said, is the new freedom from government intervention. "We can plan our future ourselves," Mr. Kozlu said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Passengers buy tickets for domestic flights on Turkish Airlines at Ataturk International Airport in Istanbul. Through efficiency measures, the carrier made a profit, countering the trend at most other airlines. (Staton R. Winter/Getty Images, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Standards Mean Korean Air Is ComingOff Many 'Shun' Lists 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, March 25 

 BODY:
When Korean Air brought in David Greenberg, a retired Delta Air Lines vice president, to run its operations two years ago, he was given a tall order: rescuing the airline from international disgrace.
 Among major international carriers, Korean Air -- 13th largest in the world -- had become a pariah after a string of disasters that began in 1983 when Flight 007 strayed over Russian territory and was shot down with 269 people aboard. 
 One accident after another seemed to strike the airline after that. By late 1999, when two of its cargo jets crashed within weeks of each other at Shanghai and at Stansted Airport near London, a total of 750 people had been killed in accidents. The airline was also plagued with smaller mishaps on domestic flights that cost no lives but heightened worries about the company and its future. 
Against this background, Mr. Greenberg started with the airline's flight crews. He introduced rigorous new training and testing standards, as well as some "cockpit culture" changes for Korean Air's 1,700 pilots. On the ground, he began basing promotions and transfers in the company's ranks on merit rather than connections and friendships.
These efforts have been paying off with a steady rehabilitation of the airline's reputation, capped last month when Delta and Air France, after separately scrutinizing Korean Air's safety standards, approved the resumption of its membership in their code-sharing alliance, known as SkyTeam. Korean Air's access to the alliance, whose member airlines offer one another's flights to their passengers, had been suspended after the Shanghai and Stansted crashes.
This month, Delta and Korean Air jointly applied for an antitrust exemption in the United States that will permit them to coordinate marketing, pricing and promotions as well; approval is expected.
The airline has also won the lifting of a ban by the United States Department of Defense on its employees' flying on Korean Air planes. And last fall, the Federal Aviation Administration restored its rating of South Korean air safety to the top classification. For the four months the country was rated in a lower category, neither Korean Air nor its smaller rival, Asiana, could expand service to the United States or share codes with American carriers.
"It's kind of a turnaround story," said Richard Samuelson, chief of UBS Warburg Securities' Seoul office. "We have lifted our estimate for Korean Air," he said, citing improvements in its safety record and the vote of confidence from the code-sharing partners. 
Along with safety, Korean Air's finances have improved. After reporting losses of $450 million in 2001 and $352 million in 2000, the airline forecasts a $77 million profit this year. Traffic is returning to normal on trans-Pacific routes after slumping in the wake of the Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States, Korean Air officials say. Its flights to Japan, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia are more packed than ever. The airline has a new hub airport at Inchon, near Seoul, and has high hopes for the World Cup soccer tournament, which will be jointly held in South Korea and Japan, beginning in May.
Investors have taken note, and the company's stock has more than doubled so far this year, outperforming even Korea's rising stock price index by a healthy margin. Lee Chan Ho, general manager for investor relations for the airline, attributed the rise to "our operating performance," and said the airline was focused for now on profitability, not expansion.
Mr. Greenberg, 60, who was hired in January 2000 as Korean Air's executive vice president for operations, said he was looking forward to turning the reins back to a Korean executive next year and returning to retirement. The remainder of his tenure, he said, will largely be spent training a successor -- not yet named -- and inveighing against complacency and the temptation to cut corners if the economy slumps again.
Even with all the improvements, the airline remains under the overall control of the Hanjin Group, a conglomerate dominated by a powerful, close-knit family, as many large Korean companies are. And Hanjin has drawn criticism in the past for placing profits above safety, notably after the Shanghai crash, which the country's president, Kim Dae Jung, publicly attributed to mismanagement by the owners. An executive shake-up after that crash led to Mr. Greenberg's hiring.
"What's necessary is to keep the focus, keep the concentration, whether times are good or bad," Mr. Greenberg said. "It takes years to build recognition, and one slip can destroy that. There's this tendency to become complacent, to say, 'We've perfected this thing, let's coast.' "
According to an investigation by a team of Delta executives in 1999, many of Korean Air's woes were rooted in the airline's rapid expansion in the 1980's, when pressure to hire pilots quickly brought in many with minimal qualifications.
Making matters worse, most of its pilots were Korean Air Force veterans with a strong authoritarian streak. Senior pilots tended to ignore warnings or advice from copilots, especially those who had been their subordinates in the air force, and junior pilots were discouraged from speaking up.
The harm done by this dynamic was made clear in a 1997 crash in Guam that killed 228 people. An inquiry found that the co-pilot had failed to warn the pilot that the plane was descending onto a ridge as it approached the airport. 
The airline's partners say it is putting such problems behind it. "Korean Air has made a major commitment to creating a culture of operational excellence," said Paul Matsen, Delta's senior vice president for alliances. "They have gone through a significant process."

HEADLINE: What Yemen Needs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nicholas D. Kristof is right that the Bush administration's decision to train Yemen's military to fight Al Qaeda is well intentioned but problematic (column, March 19). I worked in Yemen promoting democracy for an American organization and visited some of the villages mentioned. 
The people have little hope, a product of poverty and powerlessness.
 Mr. Kristof says many people have more loyalty to local leaders than to the central government. That is because local leaders are often the only ones providing basic necessities. 
 Many of these governments need greater legitimacy before the war on terror can be won. That legitimacy cannot be won through more military might. It will require economic growth and democracy. 

DAVID NASSAR
Arlington, Va., March 19, 2002

HEADLINE: Europe Is Ready to Impose Broad Limits onSteel Imports 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, March 25 

 BODY:
Moving to head off a feared deluge of steel diverted from the United States, the European Union is preparing to impose tight limits on imported steel products, officials of the union said today.
 "This is not a tit-for-tat response to the United States import restrictions," Pascal Lamy, the union's top trade official, said in an interview, referring to new American tariffs of up to 30 percent on certain steel imports. 
 Rather, Mr. Lamy said, the danger for the union was that steel excluded from the United States would swamp the European market and drive down prices. Last year the union imported 26.5 million tons of steel, a bit less than the United States; officials here estimate that another 15 million tons may come this year, worth $4 billion at current prices, because of the American tariffs. 
"Safeguard measures are precisely designed to respond to trade diversion," Mr. Lamy said. For that reason, the Bush administration's tariffs were unwarranted, he said, because "there is no trade diversion to the U.S."
By the union's reckoning, American steel imports have fallen by a third since 1998, while European steel imports have grown. World Trade Organization rules allow safeguard measures only when there is evidence of a surge in imports.
 In Washington, Richard Mills, a spokesman for the United States trade representative, called the union's move toward applying safeguard measures "odd," given that it had criticized the American tariffs so loudly. The United States move followed nine months of study, Mr. Mills said in a statement, but the union acted "without an investigation or even time for ships to have reached European docks." He said a challenge to the European measures before the World Trade Organization would be considered. 
The European Commission, the union's executive body, is expected to discuss the draft measures at its weekly meeting on Wednesday and approve them to apply for six months, beginning April 3. Among the measures are regulations known as tariff quotas, covering 15 steel products that comprise 40 percent of all steel imports, a European Union official said; the American tariffs apply to the same categories and six others.
Imports of the 15 products, including items like stainless steel wire and nonalloy hot-rolled narrow strip steel, would continue to enter the union uninhibited by the new tariffs until they reach current import levels. Once that quota is exceeded, tariffs of 14.9 percent to 26 percent would take hold. 
United States steel makers will not be directly affected because they ship hardly any steel to the European Union, the official said. Developing countries that account for less than 3 percent of the union's imports in any category will be exempted, he said, and because of a separate tariff arrangement, the safeguards do not apply to steel from Russia, Ukraine or Kazakhstan.
Countries that apparently would be affected by the measures include China in three product categories, and India, Brazil and Egypt in two categories each, the official said.
