PERSON: Ernest van den Haag 

HEADLINE: E. van den Haag, 87, Educator And Backer of Death Penalty 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Ernest van den Haag, a conservative commentator on social issues, especially crime, and a leading advocate of the death penalty, died on Thursday in Mendham, N.J. He was 87 and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
 He died at a nursing home, succumbing "to the myriad attenuations of old age," William F. Buckley Jr. said in an obituary of Dr. van den Haag that is to appear in National Review, to which Dr. van den Haag was a consultant and occasional contributor for more than four decades. 
 Dr. van den Haag, who was also an educator and psychoanalyst, was John M. Olin professor of jurisprudence and public policy at Fordham from 1982 to 1988 and held many other teaching posts. 
Dr. van den Haag wrote in 1983 in an Op-Ed article in The New York Times: "Common sense, lately bolstered by statistics, tells us that the death penalty will deter murder, if anything can. People fear nothing more than death. Therefore, nothing will deter a criminal more than the fear of death. Death is final. But where there is life there is hope. 
"Wherefore, life in prison is less feared. Murderers clearly prefer it to execution -- otherwise, they would not try to be sentenced to life in prison instead of death. (Only an infinitesimal percentage of murderers are suicidal.) Therefore, a life sentence must be less deterrent than a death sentence. And we must execute murderers as long as it is merely possible that their execution protects citizens from future murder."
Dr. van den Haag was comfortable taking strong and often controversial stands on a wide range of other issues. He was a critic of the 1954 Supreme Court desegregation decision in the case of Brown v. Board of Education. 
He also advocated abolition of the child labor laws, saying that the evils they were intended to guard against had long passed.
After he stopped teaching at Fordham, he continued to lecture, mainly about criminology, and to write. 
He was born in The Hague. The National Review obituary says he was interned by the Nazis as a teenager, escaped and left the Netherlands. He came to the United States in 1940. He was a propaganda analyst with the United States Office of War Information in World War II.
After studying at the Sorbonne and elsewhere, he received a master's degree in 1942 from the University of Iowa and a doctorate in economics in 1952 from New York University. His other teaching posts included adjunct professor of social policy at N.Y.U. and lecturer in psychology at the New School for Social Research. He practiced psychoanalysis in New York City from 1955 to 1982.
He leaves no immediate survivors.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 30, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Wednesday about Ernest van den Haag, a Dutch-born conservative commentator on social issues, misidentified the regime by which he told friends he had been detained in the 1930's. It was the Fascist regime in Italy, not the Nazis in the Netherlands.
The obituary also gave an incomplete version of Dr. van den Haag's account of his escapes from internment and misstated the sequence of events. In the account, supplied by National Review from his coming obituary, Dr. van den Haag said he escaped from the Fascists at 19 and fled to France. He also said that the French interned him as an enemy alien after the start of World War II, but that he escaped to Portugal and then to the United States. He did not tell of having reached the United States directly from the Netherlands.

HEADLINE: In Mild Winter, The Northeast Sees a Windfall 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 

 BODY:
A relatively mild winter in the Northeast has helped cities and states save hundreds of thousands of dollars in snow-removal costs, a welcome respite in a tough economic climate.
 In Pittsburgh, domes of rock salt are still filled to the top. The Pennsylvania Department of Transportation expects to save $25 million statewide. 
 "That's actual cash savings that we can redirect to repairs this spring and summer," an agency spokesman, Steve Chizmer, said.
In the Washington suburb of Rockville, Md., the Public Works Department will save a third of its snow-removal budget, possibly enough to buy a new piece of equipment, said Hal Cranor, the department's director.
"It will stay in the Public Works Department as long as I can spend it," Mr. Cranor said.
A snowstorm coated several communities in the region today, but forecasters said it would have little impact on average snowfall amounts.
"Northern New York, New England, western Pennsylvania and down through the Appalachians have seen very little snow this year, generally well below normal, especially southern New England," said a National Weather Service forecaster, Dave Martin.
Dave Krisanda, a Transportation Department spokesman for four northeastern Pennsylvania counties, said 50 to 120 inches of snow typically fell on his region in a year, but not this winter.
"We have a lot of extra salt and antiskid in hand." Mr. Krisanda said. "That means we won't have to buy as much in the fall."
Many municipalities in Massachusetts, which allows cities to fold any overspending into the following year's budget, are looking forward to smaller deficits than usual.
Robert Moylan, a commissioner of Public Works in Worcester, Mass., said the city budgeted $1.1 million on snow removal this year and had spent about $1.3 million. Last winter, his city overspent by $2 million.
John Dourgarian, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Transportation, said his state budgeted $12.7 million and spent $6.9 million as of the beginning of March.

HEADLINE: U.S. Consumers Are Positive. So Are Orders For Durables. 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence soared in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday, offering more evidence that the optimistic resilience of the American shopper is pulling the nation back from recession.
 In the daily flow of economic data, that was the latest headline, and it sent stock prices smartly higher for a while. A second report -- new orders last month for computers, machinery, trucks, planes and other durable goods -- was also positive. But it failed to provide convincing evidence that companies were once again expanding. Without that turnaround in capital spending, the consumer-led recovery could lose steam. 
 "The message in these latest numbers is that consumers are doing surprisingly well, but companies are still struggling with investment and production," said James W. Paulsen, senior economist at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "That has been the story for nearly six months."
Positive economic data -- and the data has been much more positive than negative in recent weeks -- raises concerns, particularly on Wall Street, that the Federal Reserve may push up interest rates to slow growth and thus restrain inflation. Although the Fed's policy makers have stopped cutting rates, they have been less optimistic about the economy than have most private forecasters. And one policy maker, Robert McTeer, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, reflected that caution in an interview yesterday.
"Sooner or later, as the economy gathers momentum and gets stronger, an adjustment will have to be made" in rates, he said. "But I'm in no hurry," Mr. McTeer told Bloomberg News while attending a forum in Prague.
The surge in consumer confidence this month reflected a growing impression among Americans that unemployment had stopped rising and layoffs were less of a threat, said Lynn Franco, director of the consumer research center at the Conference Board, a private research firm. After dipping slightly, to 95, in February, the confidence index jumped to 110.2, its highest level since last August.
A similar surge in confidence, for roughly the same reasons, showed up in preliminary data for March released earlier this month by the University of Michigan. 
New orders for manufactured durable goods rose in February by $2.7 billion, or 1.5 percent, to $179.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported. This was the third consecutive monthly increase. But in analyzing these numbers, most economists exclude aircraft and ships; because of their huge cost, they can make durable goods orders vary sharply month to month.
Excluding transportation, new orders fell 1.3 percent, to $124.1 billion, and the increase in January turned out to be considerably smaller than originally announced. The greatest strength last month was in orders for military equipment, a big item in increased government spending. A surge in government spending, from the federal level on down, explains, along with consumer spending, why the economy has performed so much better in recent months than forecasters had expected. 
When it comes to capital spending by business, no category serves as more significant a barometer than the category of orders for computers and electronic equipment.
Investment in such equipment was a huge source of economic growth in the late 1990's. It then plunged, helping to produce the recession. Now economists, awaiting a turnaround, drew some encouragement from the February numbers.
"While investment in electronic gear is not yet a source of strength, adding to economic growth, it is no longer a constraint on the economy, as it was all of last year," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy .com, a forecasting and data gathering service.
Orders for electronic gear fell slightly in February, to $33.62 billion from $34.44 billion in January. But in fits and starts, these orders have risen steadily from the September low of $29.31 billion, and many economists have concluded that capital spending, having passed its worst days, is showing signs of revival.
The durable goods report also shed light on inventories. For months, companies have been selling from their stockpiles, and their reluctance to reorder merchandise helped cause the recession that started last March. The hope is that a rush to replenish inventories will produce a surge in economic growth this spring, after which growth will settle back to a moderate pace.
Business inventories are tracked in the durable goods report, and they declined 0.5 percent in February after falling 0.9 percent in January. The slowing decline suggests that reordering is taking place, said James Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, "but the reordering is not yet keeping pace with consumer spending."

HEADLINE: Pricing the Poor Out of College 

 BODY:
Tens of millions of Americans have used college to propel themselves out of poverty. This road to upward mobility has been, unfortunately, narrowed in recent years by changes in aid programs that focus more on middle- and upper-income students. Poor and working-class students have considerably more access to college today than 30 years ago, thanks in particular to federal Pell grants, which provide up to $4,000 a year in tuition aid. Even so, enrollment data show startling differences in college attendance rates for high-income and low-income students with roughly comparable academic abilities. 
 In a recent report, the economists Michael S. McPherson and Morton Owen Schapiro pointed out that only about 5 percent of high-achievement, high-income students fail to enroll in college. The non-entry rate for high-achievement, low-income students is about 25 percent. 
 Most low-income students attend high schools that lack a sophisticated guidance program to help students apply to college. Poorer students tend to get scared off by the price of college, particularly if they are unaware of aid programs. But even savvier students are often shocked by the tuition at state and private colleges, which has soared over the last 10 years.
The Pell grant program has failed to keep pace with rising costs. At the same time, federal and state tax credit and scholarship programs have begun to be directed at higher-income students, whose parents are more politically powerful. By some estimates, the federal government over the last decade has spent $10 in college aid for upper-income students for every dollar spent on low-income families. The two federal college tax credit programs passed during the Clinton years apply to families that earn up to $100,000 a year. In addition, many colleges now use "merit" scholarships -- offering aid based on grades and test scores rather than need -- that further skew the picture. 
The issue of student need came into the news recently when Brown University became the last Ivy League school to adopt a "need-blind" admissions policy, meaning that it accepts students without taking into account their ability to pay and then provides them with a combination of loans and scholarships. The move was welcome, but in truth it affects only a small number of students. 
In addition, a recent study found that schools with need-blind policies actually have fewer poor and working-class students. The private liberal arts colleges that have the most students with incomes low enough to qualify for Pell grants are Mount Holyoke and Smith. Neither has a need-blind admission policy, but both have historically taken it upon themselves to seek out first-generation college students as well as women who are returning to school after motherhood or careers.
These examples show that elite schools can preserve broad access if they wish to. But nothing that happens in the Ivy League can compensate for a national college system that is directing more and more of its resources at middle- and upper-income students. If this pattern is not arrested -- and quickly -- the country will find itself back at that unpleasant juncture in history when colleges were mainly the preserve of a well-heeled elite. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: GROUND ZERO; 
Years of Work Underground Before Steel Reaches Skyward

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Nothing will be built above ground for several years at the site of the World Trade Center because of the extensive underground construction that must be completed first, the chairman of the group overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan said yesterday. 
 John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the joint city-state agency in charge of planning and coordinating the redevelopment projects, also said that while a conceptual outline of the effort would be released within about a month, an overall master plan for rebuilding the trade center site and redeveloping parts of the rest of Lower Manhattan would not emerge for some time. 
 Rather than publish a single master plan, the development corporation will lay out details of major components of its building proposals in a yearlong series of publications beginning in May, corporation officials said yesterday. Those publications will focus on individual subjects, like transportation, residential and commercial development, and the attraction of arts and cultural institutions. 
With work on the recovery of victims and the cleanup of the site nearing an end, Mr. Whitehead cautioned against expecting that evidence of the rebuilding effort would be as tangible as the rapidly diminishing pile of rubble and the deepening pit that have been hallmarks of the recovery effort.
"People will have to be patient about that, because nothing can be built yet on the surface of the site itself, the 16 acres, for several years," he said.
When building begins, work must first be completed below ground. This will include rebuilding not only the subway and PATH train systems that will be part of a new transportation network, but whatever retail or other commercial space will exist in the six stories of underground space.
Only after that work is completed will any structural steel appear above ground, Mr. Whitehead said. 
"You have to know what is going to be in the six floors of the 16-acre site underground before you can plan what is going to be above ground," he said, addressing a crowd of more than 900 people at a breakfast meeting sponsored by Crain's New York Business, a weekly magazine. "And yet people are very eager to know what is above ground because it's what they're going to see."
Near the area known as ground zero, however, construction is likely to be visible on the replacement of 7 World Trade Center later this year. 
Mr. Whitehead played down previous reports of a disagreement between the development corporation and Gov. George E. Pataki or Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over how quickly Larry A. Silverstein, the developer with rights to the ground zero site, should be allowed to begin construction on that building.
Mr. Silverstein, who hopes to begin building by midyear, has completed a plan for an office tower with 1.5 million square feet of commercial space, Mr. Whitehead said.
Other details are likely to be contained in the rebuilding plans that will begin to emerge from the development corporation in the coming weeks, agency officials said.
The guiding principles to be released next month will be based on comments that have come from the advisory committees set up by the corporation. Those committees, organized according to constituencies including victims' families, downtown residents, small businesses and large companies, have been meeting over the last two months.
After the corporation's board adopts the guiding principles, its planners will develop its yearlong series of publications.
The first publication, scheduled for May, will look at the current state of the site and what actions are needed to restore essential services like mass transit and utilities, officials said. The second, set for June, will focus on a regional transportation center, including subway and commuter rail lines, and will include cost estimates for those projects. 
One publication will deal specifically with the selection of a site for a permanent memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.
The public will be asked to comment on the proposals before they are approved.

HEADLINE: City Where Visitors Never Sleep; 
Trenton's New Hotel May Wake Up Its Downtown

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 26 

 BODY:
The Quaker Oats Company in Chicago asked about having a shareholders meeting here a few years ago, and Sally Lane was the one who had to answer with the truth: that would not be possible. Trenton had no hotel.
 A few days later, she recalled, "They called back, and they said, 'the C.E.O. wants to make sure he heard this right.' " 
 Ms. Lane, director of the hopefully named Trenton Convention and Visitors Bureau, has had to explain to people for years that they cannot actually have conventions here. Mayor Douglas H. Palmer, embarrassed when his friends in the United States Conference of Mayors asked about visiting, simply told them that they would have a hard time finding a room. 
But those days are over. Next week, Trenton, like the other 49 state capitals, will have a hotel, its first in 16 years, and not just a hotel but a Marriott. And not just a Marriott, but an anchor for a downtown that yearns for the return of private enterprise and a little respect.
"It'll change the entire image of our city," said Shelley M. Zeiger, a Trenton businessman who courted hotel investors for years. Mr. Zeiger plans to be the second to register when the hotel opens Tuesday. Mayor Palmer will be the first.
Trenton is a small city, 85,000 people in eight square miles engulfed by a landscape of the new and the outsized: McMansions, S.U.V.'s and malls and big-box clusters that sponge up the area's considerable disposable income.
Trenton has been left with no movie theater, no general bookstore, and no department store. The downtown Dunkin Donuts closes by 4. That's 4 in the afternoon.
But Trenton is still a city, loved as no agglomeration of office parks can be. It has a past, a certain tattered chic and a smattering of new restaurants and cafes. Since the Capitol and government offices employing more than 20,000 people are housed here, Trenton's leaders have long been sure that some visitors must want to stay overnight.
A result of years of plans, negotiations and precarious bond-floating is the 197-room Lafayette Yard Marriott Conference Hotel. It is shouting distance from the streets where American and British troops clashed in 1776 and next to the War Memorial, an ornate auditorium restored in a recent wave of refurbishing of public buildings near the State House.
"People still don't believe it," said Mr. Zeiger, who runs an import-export business. "I'm getting calls now from developers and people from chain stores. Once they see the crowds and the enthusiasm, they'll come."
As he spoke, he was stepping around workmen in the hotel lobby, which was already outfitted with beige-on-beige striped wallpaper and awaiting its dark-wood molding. He added, brightly, that the Russian ambassador was coming to the opening.
"It was very awkward for me to bring in high-ranking business people from other countries," he said, "and put them in Princeton or Pennsylvania."
The nearest hotel, a Holiday Inn Express, is in Morrisville, Pa., across the bridge with the neon announcement "Trenton Makes the World Takes." Route 1 north of Trenton has miles of hotels. And 35 miles down I-95, Philadelphia has 15,400 hotel rooms.
Trenton did have a motel, a few blocks from the State House, until recently, though it was used mostly by longer-term residents, many of whom left their doors open and smoked marijuana while watching daytime television. Another motel survives on the city's fringes.
At the new Marriott, John F. Yake, the sales manager, said there had been a relative clamor of bookings for reunions, weddings and bar mitzvahs. 
It is apparent that those who ask for Trenton truly want Trenton. The general manager, Dwane Martin, puts it in terms of the "capture ratio," or the percentage of people making inquiries who end up booking events or rooms. While the national average is 45 to 50 percent, he said, here it is 85 to 90 percent.
The city's last hotel was a businesslike 15-story building, the Capitol Plaza, once a Holiday Inn, down the street from the State House, which closed in 1986. But the hotels of fondest memory were the Stacy-Trent and the Hotel Hildebrecht, grand in the 1920's and 1930's and victims of a modernization campaign after the urban riots of the 1960's.
As the state remade the downtown, it razed town houses and elegant if faded commercial buildings, replacing them with government-issue cement architecture. Each building was used by hundreds of workers, but each would empty by dark.
Stores emptied, too. Mr. Yake, 41, remembers being taken as a child to Sears, where he was allowed to play on the escalators. Sears was displaced by the Department of Motor Vehicles.
Mayor Palmer, elected in 1990, viewed the hotel as the third point in a triangle that included a minor-league ballpark, opened in 1994, and an arena built five years later. Both have "Mercer County," not "Trenton," in their names.
Mr. Palmer maintains a workable but tepid relationship with state government.
"The state workers, well, God bless 'em," he said, "but their incomes and attitudes are a little different from people who work in the private sector. People in the private sector work in the evenings and on weekends. They tend not to go home at 4:30. That's what you need."
Jamie Griswold, the owner of a downtown business, Cafe Ole, who recently started a monthly newspaper called The Downtowner, is the sort of person Mr. Palmer was referring to.
Mr. Griswold opened his cafe here five years ago because it was the only place he could afford. But by last fall he was not only publishing The Downtowner but helping organize First Fridays, the first Friday evening of each month, when restaurants stay open and vendors and artists set up on the street.
Mr. Griswold said he was tired of waiting for people who said they were waiting for the hotel to open. 
"Some people think you have to have your best clothes on before you go to the party," he said. "Well, sometimes you've just got to go to the party."
Mr. Griswold says houses in Trenton's leafier neighborhoods are hard to come by -- and he should know, because he is looking for one -- but economically, the city is far behind its suburbs. In the 1990 census, the last available measure, the city's median household income was $25,719. In neighboring Lawrence Township it was $51,035, and in Princeton Township, $62,288.
Given the perverse relationship of wealth to property taxes, Trenton residents pay $3.76 per $100 of assessed valuation, while in Princeton the rate is $2.16.
James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, said Trenton's recent public developments -- the arena, the ballpark, all the state buildings -- meant that the city "has been lagging farther and farther behind because it hasn't been securing any taxable new development."
As for expectations invested in one hotel, Mr. Hughes said, "It's kind of unfair to put that level of burden on one little property."
Still, Trenton is taking a step toward normalcy, toward acting like the other state capitals. Even the smallest, Montpelier, Vt. (population 8,300), has three downtown hotels. Dover, Del. (32,000), has about 15. Jefferson City, Mo. (37,000), has 13.
Beth Carmichael, the director of the Convention and Visitors Bureau in Jefferson City, found it hard to believe, when told during a telephone interview, that Trenton was only now getting its own hotel. But after a pause, Ms. Carmichael wished the city well: "Well, congratulations to Trenton, New Jersey. Jefferson City sends its congratulations."

HEADLINE: Whether It's State or Local, Somebody Has to Raise Taxes 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 26 

 BODY:
The biggest applause line in Gov. James E. McGreevey's budget address today was a kind of New Jersey cheer: "I will not raise our income taxes. I will not raise our sales taxes."
 But the applause and the debate that will follow about how to slice up $23.6 billion are, to many taxpayers, beside the point. The 566 towns and cities in New Jersey will see plenty of tax increases. 
 New Jersey has the highest property taxes per capita in the nation. (The state with the second highest, New Hampshire, which has no income tax or sales tax, isn't even close.)
Local government in New Jersey is hugely expensive. And wherever the state refuses to provide -- by freezing state aid to school districts, for example -- someone else must.
Republicans protest that Mr. McGreevey's proposed freeze on municipal aid will force an increase in local property taxes, just as Democrats complained in the 1990's that Gov. Christie Whitman's popular cuts in the income tax did. 
"He said he didn't want to balance the budget on the backs of middle-class families," John O. Bennett, the Republican Senate president, said of Mr. McGreevey. "But that's exactly what he's doing. He's shifting the cost to local taxpayers."
Senator Anthony Bucco, a Republican leader in the Senate, said, "We're trying to get money into the schools," and promised that his half of the evenly divided State Senate would back an increase in state aid for 2003. 
The governor had already told local officials not to expect any increase in state aid. 
"They're not going to be surprised," said William G. Dressel Jr., the director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. "But they're going to be taking the political heat." 
Many other states are taking Mr. McGreevey's approach, said Arturo Perez, a budget analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures -- going to great lengths to avoid raising income taxes for the sake of keeping "no-new-taxes" pledges made before the recession embarrassed them.
But other states do not rely so heavily already on property taxes. In New Jersey, local taxes account for almost half of the state's total revenue. The national average, Mr. Perez said, is 29 percent. 
And because a property tax is more regressive than an income tax, the state's tax system as a whole becomes more regressive as the local share of the burden grows.
New Jersey taxpayers, like taxpayers in general, do not seem to be more accepting of progressive than regressive taxes. The income tax was so hated that it nearly cost Gov. Brendan T. Byrne his office when he initiated it, and it did cost Gov. Jim Florio his office when he increased it. 
So while income taxes have risen -- at $856 per capita, New Jersey ranks 13th among the states -- property taxes have risen faster. From 1993, when Governor Whitman took office, to 2000, they rose by 28 percent. 
New Jersey's average property tax burden per capita was $1,744 in 1998, the last year for which figures are available. It was followed by New Hampshire, at $1,545; Connecticut, at $1,533; and New York, at $1,345. The national average was $851. 
The cost of schools, which accounts for about 70 percent of the property tax burden, is also growing faster than inflation. And the freeze in state aid is distressing at all levels: the poorer urban districts depend heavily on the aid, and many suburban districts have seen huge enrollment increases in the last few years. 
Reducing New Jersey's reliance on property taxes is a goal recited regularly by good-government groups and politicians of all philosophical views. But it would require raising some other taxes, at the least, and possibly overhauling the state tax or school-finance system. 
Senator Bucco said this morning that that fight is "for another day." And clearly most legislators agreed today, as they were concentrated on threats to their own districts and favored budget lines. 
But in Trenton, fundamental problems in the tax system are always for another day -- so much so that many legislators, conceding that rewriting the tax laws is politically too dangerous for them, are proposing a constitutional convention to take on property tax reform.
"I don't see the political will here," Mr. Dressel, of the state league of municipalities, said in the din of the Assembly chamber, just after Mr. McGreevey's speech. 
The governor had just invoked, in a list of citizens he met while campaigning, a "grandfather in Gloucester County" who "worries about how he will pay his property taxes" if his wife's illness wipes out their savings. 
Mr. McGreevey did not otherwise discuss rising property taxes. That is a fight for another day.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Budget Plan Cuts Aid To Avert Worst Shortfall in U.S. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 26 

 BODY:
After warning for months that New Jersey faces the worst budget crisis in the nation, Gov. James E. McGreevey unveiled a $23.6 billion spending plan today that sought to avert a $5 billion budget shortfall by cutting aid to parks and universities, increasing cigarette taxes and using some one-time measures to increase revenues.
 Mr. McGreevey, who was elected after pledging not to raise taxes and to reduce state borrowing, is proposing to sell $1.1 billion in bonds against the state's portion of the tobacco settlement and to cancel an increase in the property tax rebate that would have cost the state more than $149 million. He has also ordered the treasury to revise the state's corporate tax code, which will result in major companies' paying $500 million a year more to the state. 
 While Mr. McGreevey said the lagging economy had forced him to sacrifice many of the spending plans he had espoused during his campaign last fall, he expressed relief that he had not had to resort to large-scale layoffs or increases in the broad-based taxes on sales and income. 
But Republicans and many local government officials warned today that Mr. McGreevey's budget for the 2003 fiscal year, which begins July 1, only delayed the pain, and would lead to increases in New Jersey's already high property taxes.
Like many other states, New Jersey is reeling from the recession, but its problems have been compounded by the Sept. 11 attack and a last-minute spending spree last year by the acting governor and legislative leaders. Mr. McGreevey said that without his proposed spending cuts and tax increases, New Jersey would be facing a $5.3 billion shortfall for 2003, more than 20 percent of the total budget. No state has ever had a deficit as high on a percentage basis.
"It is my job to say to the citizens, 'This is what we can do with the resources we have,' " Mr. McGreevey said. "I cannot tell you that this budget meets every need or solves every problem. But I believe it will put us on the right path, because I believe it was driven by the right priorities."
Mr. McGreevey's budget plan calls for an across-the-board 5 percent cut for all state departments and reduces $133 million in financing for capital projects involving roads, buildings and dams. It also eliminates $10 million for maintenance in state parks and reduces aid to universities by $64.3 million. 
Mr. McGreevey's proposal would merely freeze aid to municipalities and local school districts. But local officials, and Republicans in the State Legislature, warn that the freeze is likely to have a substantial impact on homeowners by spurring property tax increases, according to Senator Joseph Kyrillos Jr., the state Republican chairman. 
Others predicted that the change in the corporate business taxes could hurt the state's economy. The governor cast the issue as a matter of tax equity, asserting that 30 of the state's 50 largest corporations paid only $200 a year each in taxes. But business leaders said Mr. McGreevey's attempt to squeeze more tax money out of businesses could drive some employers out of New Jersey.
"People are going to lose their jobs because of this," said Philip Kirschner, executive vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. "People are going to get their hours cut." 
In shaping his budget plan, Mr. McGreevey was mindful that the $2.8 billion tax increase imposed in 1990 by the budget of the state's last Democratic governor, Jim Florio, angered voters so much that it cost Democrats control of the governor's office and both houses of the Legislature. Even Republicans praise the way the governor has managed expectations by incessantly reminding the public of the depth of the budget problem, and that he inherited the deficit from his predecessors. 
Senator Barbara Buono, a Democrat from Edison, praised the spending restraint in Mr. McGreevey's plan, saying it would allow Democrats to portray themselves as the party of fiscal responsibility. Mr. McGreevey's budget plan calls for a 1.5 percent increase in spending; the state's 2002 budget included 8.4 percent more spending than in the previous year. 
"During the past eight years, the average increase in spending was 7 percent," Senator Buono said. "So I think it's very positive that the governor is trying to make the state live within its means again." 
But Republicans said it was hypocritical of Mr. McGreevey, who had repeatedly criticized his Republican predecessors for tripling the state's debt during the 1990's, to try to balance his budget by borrowing against the tobacco settlement. 
"Jim McGreevey promised he would change the process New Jersey uses to come up with its budgets," said Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican of Hunterdon. "But by borrowing against the tobacco money, he's unfortunately doing the same thing he himself has criticized." 
In addition to the tobacco bonds, the budget also depends on several mechanisms likely to draw criticism. Mr. McGreevey wants to tap a $25 million surplus in the medical malpractice insurance fund, and he projects an extra $400 million in revenue by changing the way the state handles unclaimed property and reformulating its retirees' medical benefits fund. 
The budget would also divert $325 million in unemployment insurance contributions to pay for charity care, a move that would require legislative approval.
Mr. McGreevey's spending plan also assumes that the federal government will provide nearly $500 million for Medicaid and prescription plans for the elderly -- money that has not yet been committed. 
Mr. McGreevey said he tried to find savings by making state government more efficient. His plan calls for merging the authorities that operate the New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway and Atlantic City Expressway, which will probably save several million dollars a year. 
He also cut financing to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to $5 million from $11 million, calling it "a first step toward getting our state out of the sports business."
Other reductions were based Mr. McGreevey's assessment of his constituents' economic needs. Mr. McGreevey would save $48 million by removing families with incomes of more than $200,000 a year from the New Jersey Saver property tax rebate program.
But he preserved the tax cuts for low- and middle-income families, and expanded the Homestead rebate plan, which provides property tax rebates to the elderly. 
 The governor's plan also includes several new spending efforts: $66 million for antiterrorism measures, $100 million for a new state police headquarters and training site and $28 million for a new cancer research center.
 "This is not the budget I wanted to submit," Mr. McGreevey said. "It does not and unfortunately cannot reflect all of my priorities. But as governor it is my job to hold the line."

HEADLINE: Report on Social Security Adds 3 Years to Fund's Life 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
The financial outlook for Social Security and Medicare improved in the last year, despite the recession, the Bush administration said today.
 The main reason for the improvement, it said, was an increase in the anticipated growth in the productivity of American workers in the coming decade and in the next 75 years. 
 Still, the administration said Congress ought to shore up both programs before baby boomers reach retirement age. Baby boomers, the 76 million people born from 1946 to 1964, will reach 65 in the years from 2011 to 2029. 
With no change in current law, the government now estimates that the Social Security trust fund will run out of money in 2041, three years later than estimated in last year's report.
Likewise, assuming a continuation of current law, the government said today that Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund would run out of money in 2030, one year later than predicted in 2001.
"The projected near-term financial conditions of the trust funds have improved slightly since last year's reports," said Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. But he insisted, "This reprieve provides little comfort, as the programs continue to face substantial financial challenges in the not-too-distant future that need to be addressed at the earliest opportunity."
President Bush has proposed fundamental changes in Social Security and Medicare, but politicians said it would be difficult to muster a sense of urgency when the problem seemed, for now, to be receding.
Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security, said the report on that program showed it was facing a challenge, but not a crisis. The problem, he said, is that after the trust fund is exhausted in 2041, four decades from now, Social Security will be able to pay only three-fourths of the promised benefits.
"Those who claim that the system is collapsing are misleading the public," Mr. Matsui said. "They are promoting privatization plans that would actually create a crisis by draining trillions of dollars from the trust fund."
Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a liberal research organization, said: "There's certainly no imminent problem here. People have to ask if there is any reason Congress should trouble itself with restructuring the program when it's sounder than it's ever been in five decades."
But Dick Armey, the Texas Republican who is majority leader of the House, said: "Today's report offers little comfort to those who argue that Social Security is structurally sound and needs only minor adjustments. While the short-term outlook has improved a little, the long-term outlook is the same. Social Security is in serious financial trouble."
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who is chairman of the Social Security subcommittee, said Congress and the public must not be complacent. In 2017, he said, "the Social Security program will begin running a cash deficit" as income falls short of spending. 
Today's reports were issued by the six trustees of Social Security and Medicare: Mr. O'Neill, the secretaries of labor and health and human services, the Social Security commissioner and two university economists who represent the public.
The reports are widely viewed as an authoritative assessment of the financial condition of Social Security and Medicare, a reference point for all debate on the programs in Congress and in political campaigns.
While President Bush has proposed changes in Social Security and Medicare, he has not put much pressure on Congress to act on his proposals.
Mr. Bush wants to let younger workers invest some of their Social Security payroll taxes in the stock market, and he wants to give private health plans a larger role in Medicare, in the belief that they could help control costs. 
Republican members of Congress have embraced the concept of individual investment accounts, but mindful of the political risks and technical complexity of such changes, they have not rushed to pass legislation. For their part, Democrats say they want to avoid major changes in the structure of Social Security, and they would use some of the expected federal budget surplus if more money is needed to help pay benefits in future years.
Lawmakers of both parties have said they want to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare and increase payments to doctors and other health care providers. But they do not claim any popular mandate for changes that would slow the growth of Medicare.
Secretary O'Neill enthusiastically endorsed the slight increase in the trustees' estimate of future productivity, which measures the amount of output for each hour of work. He said the trustees might "have reason to raise productivity assumptions again" in a couple of years. 
Mr. O'Neill said he was amazed that productivity grew at an annual rate of 5.2 percent from October to December of last year, "in the midst of an economic slowdown." But he said that productivity growth alone could not solve the problems of Social Security and Medicare.
The report on Medicare said the hospital insurance trust spent $143.4 billion last year, up 9.4 percent from the previous year. But it took in $174.6 billion, so the balance grew by more than $31 billion "despite a slowing economy," the report said.
Spending from a separate trust fund that pays doctors and laboratories rose last year by 12 percent, to $101.4 billion. The trustees foresee smaller increases averaging less than 5 percent a year from 2001 to 2004, in part because, under current law, Medicare is reducing the fees paid for each physician service.
The administration predicts that Medicare costs will grow much faster than the economy in coming years, and it says this trend is cause for "great concern." The increased costs may require beneficiaries to pay higher premiums and co-payments, the report said.

HEADLINE: HIGHLIGHTS; 
McGreevey's Plan

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following are highlights of Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposed $23.6 billion budget for the 2002-03 fiscal year, which starts on July 1: 
 *Appropriates $23.6 billion, an increase of 1.5 percent from the $23.3 billion expected to be spent in the fiscal year ending June 30. 
 *Includes $1.9 billion from the corporate business tax, a 66 percent increase generated from changing the tax's structure.
*Plans for $6.2 billion in sales tax revenues, up 4.6 percent from the previous fiscal year.
*Includes $7.8 billion in income tax revenues, a 6.7 percent increase from the previous year.
*Proposes borrowing $1.1 billion against New Jersey's share of the national tobacco settlement.
*Diverts $325 million from a fund that the state holds in reserve to cover unemployment insurance costs.
*Includes a 50-cent increase in the cigarette tax, to $1.30 a pack from 80 cents, estimated to generate $200 million.
*Provides for $76 million in savings generated by an early retirement program for state employees and salary freezes for managers and cabinet employees.
*Caps eligibility for the New Jersey Saver tax rebate program to applicants with incomes of less than $200,000. The estimated $48 million in saving will go toward reducing state debt.

HEADLINE: Answering '800' Calls, Extra Income but NoSecurity 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE 

 BODY:
For all her skill in designing Web sites, Alicia Suarez made only $5,000 last year from 10 clients. So she did what many women here do to make ends meet -- she took a job in a call center, on the answering end of the "800" numbers that Americans dial so often to deal with the companies that sell to them.
 "This may not be the best job, but in Albuquerque, it is better than the last job I had, waitressing tables," said Ms. Suarez, who is 21 and earns $9.50 an hour helping frustrated callers from around the country use Earthlink, an Internet service. 
 Call centers like the one that employs Ms. Suarez are proliferating, adding jobs at a faster pace than any other major occupation. At least 3.5 million people and perhaps as many as 6 million work in call centers, which are increasingly concentrated in lower-wage cities like Albuquerque, making this work force roughly as numerous as the nation's truck drivers, assembly line workers or public-school teachers. 
The centers offer fresh opportunity and flexibility. They draw employees mainly from the 30 million women who, like Ms. Suarez, have a high school degree and a year or two of college. Many are second earners in their families, helping to anchor their households in the middle class despite the middling pay.
But the centers also exemplify a trend in today's service economy that has held down wages of many middle- and lower-income workers. Unlike factories, the centers can be relocated easily to lower-wage cities, or even overseas. All it takes is to ship the computers and communications gear somewhere else. So even as the economy boomed in the late 1990's, surveys show that pay scales held steady at $7 to $14 an hour at most of the nation's 60,000 or more call centers. And the people in the jobs can never feel secure.
Most centers "make a priority of holding down labor costs, and as these jobs multiply, a large mass of women has become more vulnerable to layoffs and to what I would call plant closings," Rose Batt, a labor economist at Cornell University, said.
In part because of the growth of call centers, total employment of women has resisted the recession, declining less since 2000 than for men, who were particularly hard hit by the slump in manufacturing. Still, if the surge in call center jobs has helped to sustain total employment, the women filling the jobs change frequently as the centers are relocated, or shrunk in one city and expanded in another. Contracting out the work has also become increasingly popular.
That is what Earthlink has done, shrinking its call center staff and outsourcing the work to ClientLogic, which hired Ms. Suarez a year ago. In part because of brisk Earthlink business, ClientLogic is expanding here to 780 workers from 600.
"We don't have any shortage of job applicants," said Caroline Jones, director of ClientLogic's operation here. As she spoke, five people in the lobby were filling out job applications and returning them to a security guard at a reception desk. Through the day, the lobby was rarely without applicants.
Albuquerque, population 722,000, is high on the list of cities benefiting from the call center migration. Eighteen companies have opened centers here since 1993, bringing the total to 22, not counting 2 that closed recently, laying off 530 people. Despite the surge, the pay scale, matching the national range, has barely risen since the mid-1990's.
Employment has climbed to 12,730 people, mostly in the last four years. That is 3.3 percent of Albuquerque's work force, up from under 1 percent in 1993. Most are like Ms. Suarez, in need of income but unable to find better-paying alternatives as bank tellers, teachers, office managers or government clerks.
Many operators at call centers are single mothers, but the largest percentage, according to surveys, are married women seeking a second income for the household. They are drawn from local job pools like the thousands of families here attached to Kirtland Air Force Base, Sandia National Laboratory and a big Intel computer chip factory.
"A lot of times, dependent spouses do not show up in labor force data, but quite frankly they are a hidden treasure," said James Beatty, owner of NCS International, which scouts sites for the constantly migrating call centers. "The centers quite consciously locate" near these dependent spouses.
Across the nation, call centers are similarly organized. Equipped with telephone headsets and computers and seated in partitioned cubicles in huge rooms, the operators handle every manner of customer request, not only in American cities but increasingly abroad. New Yorkers calling an "800" number with a question about the Road Runner Internet service of Time Warner Cable are as likely to get an operator in Canada as in the United States. E-mail and Internet communications are gradually adding new twists at call centers.
Despite the growing presence of call center workers, the Labor Department has counted only some of them: 1.9 million customer service agents in 2000 and 462,000 telemarketers, the people who call during dinner with sales pitches. The rest are hidden in other classifications, as technical support personnel (Ms. Suarez), reservation clerks, temporary workers, bill collectors, mortgage brokers, 401(k) administrators or catalog order takers. According to industry estimates at least 3.5 million people work at call centers; three out of four are women. 
The 3.5 million represents 2.6 percent of the nation's work force. The total is probably higher, perhaps as many as 6 million, according to estimates cited by Call Center Magazine, including one estimate from Datamonitor, a research firm. In contrast, the nation has 4.2 million production workers and 5.5 million teachers from preschool through high school. The only clearly larger job categories are retail sales and food preparation. 
As manufacturing jobs decline, call centers are rising -- and borrowing industrial practices from the factories. Professor Batt described the process as the "mechanization of the service sector."
"Companies have tried to routinize these jobs, making them as similar as possible to the old assembly line work where you left your mind at home and tightened bolts all day," she said. The typical call center operator averages 100 calls a day, or one every 4.8 minutes over eight hours. 
Advances in technology also push them toward an assembly line pace. Responding to questions about credit card balances or payment plans or alternative rates to fly from New York to San Francisco, the operators pull up information that can often be read like a script.
But in another sense, the work escapes routine. "The social skills of call center operators have to be polished to absorb constant complaints from customers without a peep," Professor Batt said, "and their knowledge of the product or service they are handling has to be fairly sophisticated."
The tensions from this mix are evident at Citibank's two-story call center built five years ago on the city's outskirts. The sandstone-colored concrete blends with the desert that stretches behind the building toward the mountains. Inside, the huge room in which 1,350 operators work is colorful and homey. 
Stuffed animals, family photos, flowers, flags, even an ivy vine draped over a computer, decorate the work areas. The goal, in the words of Edward J. Consroe, who runs the call center, is to make the cubicles seem like home for the women who make up 75 percent of the work force. Still, the turnover rate, while low by call center standards, is 25 percent annually.
June Fuentes, 33, a mother of five, with two years of community college, has been a call center operator for Citibank for two years, after leaving a lower-paying teaching job. "I wanted a different sort of work," she said, "and I saw Citi's ad."
Her wage has risen to $11.23 an hour, which adds $23,000 a year to the $58,000 salary of her husband, John, an engineer's assistant at Sandia. He gets the children off to school in the morning, Ms. Fuentes says, and she cares for them in the afternoon, having been assigned to a 6:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. shift by an employer eager to accommodate the dual role of motherhood and work for employees, married and single.
Rather than raise wages, managers lure workers with flexible hours and other benefits, what Mr. Consroe calls soft labor costs. Citi, for example, offers health insurance, limited child care support, tuition reimbursement for post-high school study, a librarylike learning center and a well-equipped exercise room that Mr. Consroe describes as a "wellness center used by 40 percent of the staff."
But the price for receiving these benefits is accepting an effective cap on wages and an unrelenting work routine. Ms. Fuentes is able to handle each caller in an average of three minutes, the company standard. She keeps up this pace for two-hour stretches, punctuated by 10-minute breaks and 30 minutes for lunch. For emergencies -- an ill child, for example -- there is 48 hours a year of "unplanned" time off. Beyond that, pay is docked. 
Reflecting a nationwide marketing trend, there is also pressure to sell, and small commissions for doing so. On one recent shift, Ms. Fuentes received a commission for persuading a woman calling about a credit card balance to let Citi debit her checking account -- for a fee -- in lieu of a mailed check. And by late morning, Ms. Fuentes had persuaded three customers to transfer a total of $16,233 in balances from other credit cards to their Citi account for the lure of a lower rate. 
At the call center here for Southwest Airlines, where employee turnover is a very low 4 percent, Michelle Romero, 29, an operator, credits in part a scheduling option that she describes as particularly friendly to mothers. Southwest, operating one of the few unionized centers, permits its 418 agents to "sell" hours among themselves. Ms. Romero, who had been a bank teller before coming to the call center in 1993, earns $13.09 an hour, or $27,000 annually. But she took home only $22,000 last year.
"I give away shifts to be home with my daughter," she said. "My mom usually takes care of her, but she'll be out of town next week, so I am selling that week." 
ClientLogic has the only call center in Albuquerque where the men outnumber the women, 6 to 4. That is typical of call centers that provide technical support for computers and software. But even here, the ratio is shifting. Among supervisors, women now outnumber men.
Ms. Suarez, who says her father, an industrial engineer, kindled her enthusiasm for computers, aspires to become a supervisor. Salary and bonuses would push her pay above $25,000 from less than $20,000 now.
"In New Mexico," she said, "that represents opportunity for women."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michelle Romero earns $13.09 an hour as a call center operator in Albuquerque for Southwest Airlines. She said a scheduling option at the center allows her to "sell" hours, making it easier to take care of her daughter. (Cary Herz for The New York Times)(pg. C5)

HEADLINE: Towns With Odd Jobs Galore Turn to Inmates 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: ZACHARY, La. 

 BODY:
For generations, convicts have made license plates or gone out, sometimes in chains, to clean roads and clear ditches. But in recent years struggling rural communities like this one have relied more and more on inmates to do jobs that public employees once did: tending cemeteries, cleaning courthouse restrooms, moving furniture, renovating municipal buildings and even running errands for the police. 
 In flat and timeworn Louisiana towns near the Mississippi around Zachary, crews from the Dixon Correctional Institute in nearby Jackson set up tables and tents for fairs and charity events, groom the grounds of Lions Clubs, make repairs at museums and string up Christmas lights on Main Street. In nearby Slaughter, they have replaced the metal roof on the municipal building and stripped and waxed floors at the First Baptist Church. At the elementary school, they dug a goldfish pond and planted azaleas. 
 Here in Zachary, a swampy town of 11,275 people, a group of inmates come into town with an unarmed guard about 20 days a month. They mow the baseball field and cemetery, and they have restored two historic Victorian homes. Now, a dozen inmates, called Crew 12, are laying a sidewalk for a museum that was once the town hall. 
In the last few years, the use of prisoners for manual labor has increased around the country, particularly in the South and Southwest where it not only fills the desperate demand for inexpensive laborers, but also helps prisons relieve overcrowding and supplement their budgets. 
A Justice Department survey showed that 124,000 inmates in state prisons, or 10.4 percent of the total state prison population, and 45,000 local inmates, or about 7 percent of those in jails nationally, were working off the premises in 2000, the most recent year for which figures were available. 
"There's more and more of it," said Carl Wicklund, executive director of the American Probation and Parole Association in Lexington, Ky. "The offender needs to be doing something to prepare himself for release and be seen repairing something broken in the community." 
Officials in California, Mississippi, Texas and Virginia, for example, say they are putting more inmates to work outside prison walls. Georgia, said Mike Light, spokesman for the State Department of Corrections, plans to double the number of prisoners doing community work. 
In Minnesota last year, 17,073 inmates in state prisons, almost twice the number of six years ago, were enrolled in "sentencing to service" programs in which they live in county jails and do local jobs. 
Oklahoma has more than 1,000 inmates assigned to local work centers around the state, mostly in western towns with waning populations. The Legislature is considering raising the 100-bed limit on the centers and letting drug offenders join the program. 
Not everyone agrees that the rise in inmate workers is an entirely positive trend.
"It's a way to get nasty work done for free," said Malcolm C. Young, executive director of the Sentencing Project, a research group in Washington.
But as a form of restorative justice, Mr. Young said, "it's doing something constructive and it gives something back to the community." 
In some state capitals, including Baton Rouge, La., prisoners maintain governors' mansions and do most of the cleaning and heavy lifting chores in state offices and museums. But it is in hundreds of small towns where they stand out most. 
In Louisiana, the economic downturn's effect on state and local budgets has been the driving force behind the use of prison labor. By employing inmates that the state pays 4 cents to 20 cents an hour, towns like Zachary can deliver many public services they would otherwise do without. 
In this part of the state, most workers come from Dixon, a medium security prison with 1,470 inmates. 
"I love it out here," said Timothy Holland, 27, a member of Crew 12 who was working on the sidewalk project.
Mr. Holland said he was sent to prison at age 20 for selling cocaine, was sentenced to 15 years and should be eligible for parole in two. 
"It's hard work," he said, "but you get a better peace of mind. You get adjusted back to society." 
The men have become a familiar part of Zachary, working from 8 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. about five days a week. 
Fears are few, largely because townspeople know that the inmates chosen for the assignments are nearing the ends of their sentences and are unlikely to do anything to jeopardize their release. The workers are carefully screened. Sex offenders are automatically ruled out. Instead of the meager wages, many take payment in "good time" reductions in their sentences. 
People gain satisfaction seeing inmates clean up their towns.
"Politically, people want to see inmates work," said John A. Womack, the mayor of Zachary. 
Corrections officials also argue that the programs help prepare inmates for life and work after they serve their time. "I think we have to accept the fact that people are going to be released," said James M. LeBlanc, the warden of Dixon. 
Nationwide, inmate labor sometimes arouses resentment from unions and local contractors. Towns around Dixon pay only for Crew 12's guard and for its transportation, which works out to $2.50 an hour for each man, or less than half the minimum wage, which is $5.15 an hour. In Slaughter, population 1,011, Mayor Barbara Bourgeois pays the state $2,500 a year for weekly visits from Crew 12. 
Mayor Womack of Zachary said that competent workers willing to do menial labor were hard to find. His most likely alternative to Crew 12, he said, would be Mexican migrants. 
Last year in Clinton, La., Sheriff Talmadge Bunch began a work-release program for state prisoners with six months to two years left in their jail time. Sheriff Bunch finds them jobs in private businesses that pay them $6 to $10 an hour. Participants live at the jail, but they wear whatever they want and pay taxes. Though they are driven to and from their jobs, they are left to work on their own, without a guard. 
Each inmate pays the sheriff half his wages up to $120 a week for room, board and transportation, and the state pays the sheriff $18.25 a day to keep him.
"It generates $600,000 a year for us," said Paul Perkins, the deputy sheriff -- more than twice what the East Feliciana Parish budget provides the Sheriff's Department. 
Officials of these towns cannot cite many cases of inmates' causing trouble, Mayor Womack said. The only unsettling episode occurred a year or two ago when a newly released work crew member asked a city employee for a ride home. The employee refused, so the former inmate found a solution in a city parking lot. Later, someone in New Orleans called the mayor's office. 
"They wanted to know if we were missing a city truck," Mr. Womack said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dixon Correctional Institute prisoners dig around a drainage structure for the Old Town Hall in Zachary, La. (Mark Saltz for The New York Times)(pg. A1); Dixon Correctional Institute inmates do plumbing work in Zachary, La. (Mark Saltz for The New York Times)(pg. A19)

HEADLINE: The Free-Speech Bind 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
So here's an interesting moral dilemma: I got e-mails last week from Saudi and Egyptian friends encouraging me to write a column about the Saudi poet who had been thrown in jail for writing a fiery poem attacking Saudi judges as corrupt.
 The Saudi poet, Abdul Mohsen Musalam, in his poem "The Corrupt on Earth," published March 10 in the newspaper Al-Madina, wrote: "It is sad that in the Muslim world, justice is suffering from a few judges who care for nothing but their bank accounts and their status with the rulers." He then added with amazing bluntness about the judges: "Your beards are smeared with blood. You indulge a thousand tyrants and only the tyrant do you obey." 
 Not only did the Saudi interior minister throw Mr. Musalam in jail for this poem, but his editor, Mokhtar al-Fal, was fired. So what's my dilemma? I should be all for free speech -- right? -- especially in Saudi Arabia.
Not so fast. By accident, I met this poet on a recent trip to Saudi Arabia and I tasted some other free speech he has in him. Readers may recall that I noted in an earlier column that at one newspaper I visited in Saudi Arabia, I walked out after being told that the source of all the problems today was that "the Jews control America." The newspaper was Al-Madina, and the person who said that to me, during a discussion, was Mr. Musalam. (His editor, who apologized for him, was a good person, and I hope he gets his job back.) 
So what to do?
The only thing to do is to call on the Saudis to release Mr. Musalam -- not for his sake, but because a government that is afraid of a poem only shows itself to be insecure and as tyrannical as the poet charged. His charges should be answered -- but don't throw him in jail.
This incident, though, actually highlights a larger dilemma: At the Arab summit meeting now being held in Beirut, not one of the 22 Arab leaders represented has been elected in a free and fair balloting.
But some experts ask: Why would we want to foster democracy and a free press in that part of the world when we know that many of those who would be elected or free to write would be incredibly hostile to us? After all, we may not like everything that Egypt's Hosni Mubarak or the al-Saud ruling family in Saudi Arabia do -- but they are more liberal and pro-American than many of their people. 
That's true, but Sept. 11 demonstrates how dangerous it is for us to rely on that. Because the pro-Americanism of these Arab leaders is being bought at a price of keeping their own people so angry, so without voice and so frustrated by corruption that they are enraged at both their regimes and us. Stability in these countries is achieved by these regimes' letting their people have free speech only to attack America and Israel.
After all, the Al-Riyadh newspaper recently published an article by a Saudi "professor" who alleged that Jews make a holiday pastry that requires them to "drain the blood" from a young Christian or Muslim, but the editor of Al-Riyadh was not fired. Right now the only way you get a free voice in most of the Arab press is by denouncing Israel and America or praising your regime. That distorts the whole political discourse.
"There is no way out of the dilemmas of the Arab world without some political opening," says the Stanford University democracy expert Larry Diamond. "But it doesn't start by holding elections now. What is needed is a managed political opening, coincident with economic reform, that can generate a middle class with respect for the rule of law and institutions. It requires a gradual process, with a vision from the top, that introduces pluralism into the political life. The objective is to create a body of people who can one day contest for power in a responsible way, with the regimes keeping some reserve of power for themselves as insurance." 
Yes, when you open up such closed societies, crazy things do fly out, like bats from a dungeon. Look at Poland and Russia, where two of the first bats out were rabid ultra-nationalist presidential candidates, Stanislaw Tyminski and Vladimir Zhirinovsky. But after a few seasons of democracy both are now long gone. When given a real choice, people usually don't want to be ruled by jerks.
Sure, these transitions are tricky. They can go wrong. See Serbia. But it's a worthwhile risk. Because context matters. Change the context of how people live and you change everything. And the current Arab context sure isn't working in our favor.

HEADLINE: Waste Management Executives Are Named in S.E.C. Accusation 

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint yesterday against six former officers of Waste Management Inc., providing new details of the accounting fraud case that has become a driving force behind the government's criminal action against Arthur Andersen.
 The 138-page complaint provides an anatomy of an accounting scandal that is far more than just a financial history lesson. In light of Enron's collapse, with members of Congress and other officials asking how an apparent scheme to manipulate reported finances could have gone undetected, the government's new details in the Waste Management case, if true, provide evidence of the limited protections that exist for investors if a company's senior executives and its accountants decide to hide the truth. 
 The complaint portrays a multiyear effort to inflate reported profits at Waste Management using accounting tricks that allowed the company to hide about $1.7 billion in expenses from 1992 through part of 1997. And, year after year, the complaint says, Arthur Andersen accountants complained about the efforts but still approved the company's financial statements when their objections were effectively ignored. 
"The complaint is a catalog of ways to cook the books," said Thomas Newkirk, associate director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, adding that certain of the actions involved were "unlike anything that I've ever seen investigating financial fraud cases."
Arthur Andersen, which the complaint contends played a central role in allowing the accounting fraud to continue, paid a $7 million fine last year and accepted an injunction against future misdeeds as part of a settlement of its role in the Waste Management case. A belief by prosecutors that Andersen violated that injunction by destroying documents in the Enron investigation played a significant role in their decision to indict the firm two weeks ago on a charge of obstruction of justice. 
The complaint named the most senior officers at the company during most of the 1990's, including Dean L. Buntrock, Waste Management's founder and former chairman; Phillip B. Rooney, who served as president, chief operating officer and later chief executive during part of the relevant period; and James E. Koenig, the former chief financial officer. The others named are Thomas C. Hau, the former chief accounting officer; Herbert A. Getz, the former general counsel; and Bruce D. Tobecksen, the former vice president for finance.
The complaint contends they received tens of millions of dollars -- through stock options and bonuses -- that they would never have received if the accounting fraud had not taken place. The suit seeks to force them to pay fines and return money they received unjustly. It also seeks to bar them from serving as officers or directors of public companies.
Through their lawyers and in written statements, the named executives vehemently denied any improprieties, saying they had never taken any accounting actions that were not appropriate and approved. In a statement, Mr. Buntrock also said that he thought that the decision to bring the S.E.C. case was in part a result of conflicts of interest because chief accountants at the agency formerly helped Waste Management in its restatement of earnings that led to the investigation.
"I firmly believe that, while under my watch, all of Waste Management's financials were fairly reported and in compliance with" generally accepted accounting principles, Mr. Buntrock said in the statement. "I was never told otherwise, either by our internal accountants or our outside auditors."
While technical, the scheme described in the complaint was surprisingly simple: numbers for expenses at Waste Management became almost magical things, appearing and disappearing at will for the purpose of reaching preset earnings goals. For example, the complaint says, the company avoided depreciation expenses for its garbage trucks by extending their estimated life while simultaneously making unsupported increases in their salvage value. 
"In other words," the complaint says, "the more the trucks were used, and the older they became, the more the defendants said they were worth."
When a preliminary internal study was conducted showing that the salvage values -- which can be used to offset depreciation costs -- had been inflated, company officers ordered that the study be halted, the complaint contends. Afterward, efforts were made to destroy copies of the memorandum describing the study, and the original document was deleted from the author's computer. 
But the primary mechanism to manipulate earnings, the complaint says, were through accounting changes known as "top-level adjustments." In essence, subsidiaries would report their results to corporate headquarters relying on a series of financial assumptions; senior management then arbitrarily changed those assumptions, the complaint says, keeping the revisions hidden from the subsidiaries.
"Keeping the process secret and centralizing it at corporate made it especially easy for top management to falsify the financial statements by plugging in the additional income needed (by way of reduced expense) to achieve the desired earnings for each quarter," the complaint says. 
The complaint lists other bogus accounting practices, including failing to record expenses for the decreases in the value of landfills as they filled with waste and failing to establish sufficient reserves to pay for expenses like income taxes. The company also engaged in a practice known as netting, in which a one-time gain -- like the sale of an asset -- was used improperly to eliminate unrelated current expenses or accounting misstatements from past periods. 
Throughout these efforts, the complaint says, Andersen fully understood the extent of the accounting misrepresentations and repeatedly tried to press Waste Management executives to change their practices or correct errors, with little success. Eventually, the complaint says, Andersen typed up an agreement that laid out 32 changes in practices that Waste Management would have to undertake over time to make its finances more truthful. But in truth, if such material misrepresentations were taking place, the company would have been obligated under the law to disclose them and immediately restate earnings, not try to adjust the problems over many years.
"The action steps thus constituted an agreement between the company and its outside auditor to cover up past frauds by committing additional frauds in the future," the complaint says. 
The agency believes that Andersen's willingness to bend on such issues was a result of the fees it was receiving from Waste Management. According to the complaint, Waste Management put a cap on the amount Andersen could be paid for accounting work -- a total of $7.5 million over the years in question. But its nonaudit consulting fees were $17.8 million, including a $3.7 million "strategic review" that was virtually ignored by Waste Management. 
"A board member who had approved and reviewed the strategic review later described it as a 'boondoggle' " the complaint says.
