HEADLINE: Polish Priests Press Vatican on Case Against Bishop 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: POZNAN, Poland, March 21 

 BODY:
Here in western Poland, in what residents boast is the oldest diocese of a fervently Roman Catholic country, it was the priests who reported the many whispers of homosexual advances by the local archbishop -- and the priests who got the Vatican to take some action.
 In the United States, action against priests accused of sexual molestation has been a result of lawsuits by parents, family members or the victims themselves. In Europe, and particularly in countries as conservative as Poland, such scandals have been handled more discreetly. 
 But by late 1999, the rumors that Archbishop Juliusz Paetz of Poznan had made advances on teenage seminarians had become so intense that the director of the seminary confronted the archbishop, who denied the reports. In 2000 a respected local layman from the diocese drew the same response from the archbishop. 
So the priests decided to act.
Their action led not only to a Vatican investigation but also to detailed publication of the charges in a generally cautious Polish daily, Rzeczpospolita, which departed from its usual political and economic news on a February weekend to emblazon the story on its front page.
Last year a sizable number of priests of Poznan wrote to the Vatican, which -- apparently without informing the Polish pope, John Paul II -- asked the papal nuncio in Poland, Bishop Jozef Kowalczyk, to investigate the accusations. (Last year, Archbishop Paetz removed the publisher of the diocesan magazine, the Rev. Jacek Stepczak, after he refused to print a letter signed by priests who support the archbishop.) 
In May four affidavits signed by seminarians and detailing the archbishop's behavior were sent to the nuncio, who forwarded them to Archbishop Paetz with a recommendation that the matter be forgotten, according to journalists who saw copies of the document.
Further letters by leading priests and laymen to Polish bishops followed, to no effect, so a personal messenger -- whose identity no one in Poznan, Warsaw or Rome will disclose -- was finally dispatched to Pope John Paul.
In November two Vatican emissaries arrived in Poznan to question dozens of priests and seminarians, many of whom confirmed the reports, church officials familiar with the mission said. 
The Rev. Adam Schulz, spokesman for the Polish bishops, said a Vatican decision was expected soon, though he would not disclose its nature. Until then, he said, the bishops urged silence.
When Archbishop Paetz, who is 67, became archbishop of this grimy industrial city in 1996, it seemed like a crown on a fruitful career. The archbishop had studied at papal universities in Rome, held a prestigious position at the Vatican and been bishop of a diocese in eastern Poland. Poznan was a homecoming; his family had migrated here from southern Germany in the 17th century, like many settlers to what was once a mixed German-Polish region.
Now the local church is deeply torn, and Polish Catholics are dismayed by the first case in which such a high-ranking cleric has been accused of sexually abusing teenagers. To date, Poles have read of such priests abroad, most notably in the United States, or heard of lower-ranking priests at home accused of fathering children or sexually abusing youngsters.
The Polish church remains highly authoritarian, with a hierarchical order that culminates in the Vatican. No victims of sexual abuse have sought legal regress or -- until the Rzeczpospolita article, which masked identities while giving shocking details -- spoken publicly about their suffering.
Rzeczpospolita quoted a father of a seminarian as describing his distraught son coming home and telling his parents, "I did not know our archbishop was a homosexual." The paper said the boy ultimately left the seminary to finish his studies for the priesthood abroad. Another cleric from the seminary described how Archbishop Paetz touched seminarians to test their willingness to be approached. 
One priest told the paper that the archbishop warmly embraced him with a big kiss. He later called the archbishop, he said, to tell him he was cutting short his studies at the Poznan seminary.
After a fruitless meeting with the archbishop in late 1999, the seminary rector, the Rev. Tadeusz Karkosz, barred the archbishop from entering the seminary without a prior announcement. "I'm only interested in the good of the boys under my care," Father Karkosz told Rzeczpospolita. He refused to be interviewed for this article, as did seminarians and their intermediaries.
The archbishop has steadfastly denied all accusations that he acted inappropriately with seminarians, some of whom are as young as 18. In a letter he ordered read in churches on March 17, he accused the news media of "an unprecedented, massive and one-sided campaign against my person."
While he was deprived of the right to anonymity, he said, "indiscriminate and mendacious attacks and accusations on the part of a few have loosed an avalanche of accusations and rumors, without family names or Christian names or faces behind them."
Some pastors refused to read the letter, though they are unwilling to discuss why, saying they fear retribution. Local journalists fear that the attack on the media means that Archbishop Paetz could be dismissed, but present himself as a victim of media rancor.
Wlodzimierz Bogaczyk, the bureau chief in Poznan for Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest newspaper, said: "We see a real shift. What is said is that it's not certain whether the archbishop is guilty, but it is certain that the media are guilty." 
Many here believe a solution will be found that will permit the archbishop to avoid not only disgrace but even prosecution. For example, a compromise could redraw diocesan boundaries to make his retirement appear to be a consequence of reorganization rather than of reprehensible behavior.
Indeed, Vatican officials familiar with the case say that evidence of homosexual activity appears to be lacking, and that Archbishop Paetz will most likely only be chided for injudicious words and actions to seminarians.
Marek Ziolkowski, a sociologist at Poznan University who studies Poles' religious behavior, said the slowness of the official reaction and the silence were not surprising because action could come only from John Paul. "Some thought, 'We do not want to bother the czar,' " he said, referring playfully to the pope. "They felt disclosure would be linked with enormous pain" for John Paul, who is 81 and visibly infirm. "It was about sparing him the pain."
But the silence, some say, came at the price of a fear more familiar during Communism, when the Polish church was a rallying point of national identity and played a part in toppling the system.
A parish priest who refused to read the archbishop's letter from the pulpit on March 17 also declined to comment for this article, saying he had been threatened with transfer. An employee of a diocesan organization, also seeking anonymity for fear of jeopardizing his job, noted how the silence recalled Communist times, "when people could not talk publicly for fear of the consequences." 
Professor Ziolkowski noted that in general, Poles tend not to play up the misdeeds of individual bishops, believing as they do in the permanence of the Roman Catholic Church.
By way of illustration, he paraphrased words of the 19th-century Polish novelist Henryk Sienkiewicz that have become a common adage: "The monastery will long outlive the abbot."

HEADLINE: Albany Will Preserve Its Streak: For the 18th Year, a Late Budget 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 26 

 BODY:
For the 18th year in a row, New York State will not have a budget enacted by the start of the fiscal year, a fact the Legislature acknowledged today by passing an emergency spending bill to keep the government running past April 1.
 Legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki sounded optimistic as they emerged from the latest in a series of lengthy budget negotiations. 
 Only the governor tried to dampen expectations of an easy resolution. "I think there was a productive exchange of ideas," he told reporters, "and I think there were some concepts and proposals advanced by everybody that allow us to move the process forward, but it's still a very, very difficult year."
Despite the dreary milestone of yet another late budget, there is greater promise for a relatively early conclusion to the budget drama this year than in any recent year. The Assembly Democrats' estimate of available revenues is just $600 million more than Mr. Pataki's; in some recent years they have been as much as $2 billion apart. And the mere fact that the three leaders have held several budget meetings in March is an improvement over recent years, when the governor often refused to negotiate for months.
All sides are eager to avoid a repeat of last year, when budget negotiations dragged into October, by far the latest in history; when the Legislature, trying to put pressure on the governor, passed a stripped-down budget that left many programs with no money at all; and when the economic downturn and the Sept. 11 attack forced everyone to lower expectations of how much money would be available.
The Legislature passed a $4.66 billion spending bill today to keep the state operating until the second week of April, and Mr. Pataki said he would sign it. In recent budget impasses, the state has functioned for as long as four months on a series of such two- and three-week emergency bills.
As a practical matter, it became clear weeks ago that lawmakers would miss the April 1 deadline, but it became official today, the last day the Legislature was scheduled to meet during the 2001-2002 fiscal year. Legislators will take the first week of April off.

HEADLINE: If We Care About City Schools . . . 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert's concern about the lack of money for New York City schools (column, March 25) is understated, a reality that will become even more clear when this year's high school graduation rates, and the accompanying dropout rate data, are published.
 New York State's academic intervention services regulations are woefully underbudgeted. 
Without an infusion of services for students who are not prepared to succeed on the five required Regents exams or who don't pass them on their first attempt, a large number of students will have no recourse but to enter the ranks of the perennial unemployed. 
 Regardless of whom should be blamed, it's the students who will suffer.

MARC F. BERNSTEIN
Chief Academic Officer
Kaplan K12 Learning Services
New York, March 26, 2002

HEADLINE: Rebuild Downtown, And Remember 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Witold Rybczynski ("How Quickly a City Can Grow," Op-Ed, March 25) speaks for the architects and planners who have always hated the twin towers, while most everyone else loved them. 
Rebuilding the twin towers, with improved technology and infrastructure, is our only real hope for a solution that can be "a simple one and soon," with a proven track record to boot. 
 The World Trade Center succeeded magnificently as a business and transportation hub, as a tourist site and as an icon for the city. It was already a part of a combined commercial and residential neighborhood resurgence, and its future value as a memorial is unsurpassed.

LUTHER S. HARRIS
New York, March 26, 2002

HEADLINE: In Year of Attacks, Passover Preparations Are Somber 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Tamar Warburg wanted to be reunited with family members who did not feel safe making their annual Passover trip to Israel. So, at the last minute, she decided to leave her yearlong studies in Jerusalem for a quick return home to Englewood, N.J.
 Judy Goldring, a Brooklyn jeweler, wanted to have a Seder with her entire family, too. But her American-born, Columbia-educated son, Mordechai David Goldring, will not be able to make it: he joined the Israeli Army last year, just as the violence in the Mideast was cresting, because "he just felt this was his responsibility as a Jew," she said. 
 Judy Weil, a resident of Armonk, N.Y., would have liked to sit down at the Seder table with her daughter Joanne, just as the family had done for more than 30 years. But Joanne died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, so this year, the Weils are going elsewhere to observe the holiday. Staying home would be too painful.
As Jews in New York and across America prepare for Passover, which begins at sundown tonight, many have an inescapable sense that this year it will be impossible to avoid talking about how much life has been altered by two calamitous events: the recent high level of violence in the Middle East and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
After all, some say, it was all too easy in previous years to mark the holiday with a sometimes perfunctory ritual of reciting passages from the Haggadah, an ancient text, without dwelling on the meaning of the words. Some said it was the equivalent of reciting the Pledge of Allegiance or the lyrics to a favorite song for the thousandth time without necessarily thinking about those words.
"We say in the Haggadah that there are those who seek to destroy us, and quite often, when we said it, we didn't pay attention to it," said Rabbi Joseph Potasnik, president of the New York Board of Rabbis and the Jewish chaplain of the Fire Department. "But this year, when we have people who lost loved ones at the World Trade Center, in Israel, we see the fragility of life."
Indeed, Rabbi Potasnik plans to spend one of the first nights of Passover at ground zero, comforting a firefighter who will be looking for the remains of a friend.
Meanwhile, the Orthodox Union, on its Web site, is urging all Jews to "add a special prayer on behalf of our brethren in Israel during the Seder." 
And Rabbi Michael Lerner, the editor of Tikkun, a liberal magazine on Jewish issues, took out a full-page advertisement in The New York Times last week encouraging people to "turn part of your Passover Seder" into a discussion about the violence in Israel.
One should also not forget the Jews in Argentina who have been reeling from the economic crisis there, said Rabbi Marc Schneier, president of the North American Board of Rabbis, who recently returned from a trip to Buenos Aires. In Argentina, thousands of people are lining up at two dozen soup kitchens that have been set up at synagogues, he said.
This is not to say, of course, that before this year, people did not think about world issues during Passover. But for many people, the extrapolation of the Haggadah, which recounts the ancient Israelites' liberation from slavery and exodus from Egypt, often applied to personal struggles.
"In the past, you'd think about your own personal mitzrayim," said Marcia Stein, executive director of City Meals on Wheels, using the Hebrew word for Egypt, which has come to symbolize bondage. "It could be an addition to drinking, smoking; it could be an inability to overcome a hatred in your own family. I might have thought about a chocolate bar as my personal mitzrayim."
For Ms. Warburg, the student from New Jersey, the hardest decision of the last few weeks is one that many Jewish families have confronted: whether to celebrate Passover in Israel or in America.
"I felt very torn," said Ms. Warburg, 18, who is the granddaughter of Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University. "I am strongly Zionistic, but if my family came with my 7-year-old sister and three other sisters, and God forbid something happened. . . ." She paused.
Ultimately, she agreed on a compromise: she would return home for a week or two, but then return to complete her year abroad, unlike some of her classmates, who have left Israel and are afraid to return.
And yet she knows that come tonight, when her family ends its Seder by reciting the Hebrew for "Next year in Jerusalem," those words will possess a special meaning. Next year, she said, her family really does want to celebrate Passover in Jerusalem again.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Bartow Community Center kitchen in the Bronx, which serves over 450 kosher meals a day, Rabbi Solomon Berl pours scalding water to eliminate traces of leavening to prepare for serving matzo at Passover. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BOISE CASCADE EXPECTSLARGER FIRST-QUARTER LOSS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Boise Cascade Corporation, the paper and lumber maker, said an expected loss in the first quarter would be wider than analysts' forecasts because of falling paper prices and expenses from production cuts. The loss will be 15 cents to 20 cents a share, the company said. 
Boise Cascade, which is based in Boise, Idaho, was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call, to lose 3 cents a share. Boise's average price for products like newsprint and copier paper fell about $15 a ton from the fourth quarter, the company said. Paper makers slowed production and closed plants as demand slowed with the economy. Boise cut paper output by 60,000 tons, or 2 percent, in the quarter.

HEADLINE: FAILING MORTGAGES SOAR IN NEW YORK 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
The number of low- and moderate-income families in the New York metropolitan region who are seriously behind on their mortgage payments is soaring, according to new federal and city data and housing experts, who say they have seen a surge in mortgage troubles since Sept. 11.
 Among homeowners holding federally insured loans in a popular mortgage program intended to help low- and moderate-income people and minorities buy their first homes, the percentage of families who bought during the housing and economic booms of the 1990's but are now in default on their loans has skyrocketed, according to data from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 The increase in the number of homeowners in default on federally insured loans for one- to four-family homes -- defined as 90 days behind on their monthly mortgage payments -- is occurring across the nation, the federal data show, with the rate more than doubling in the last decade. 
But for a variety of reasons, including the soaring prices of New York City real estate in the last five years, and changes in lending practices and job losses in the aftermath of Sept. 11, the New York area default rates are well ahead of those in the rest of the country -- three times higher than the national average so far this year. 
The vast majority of the roughly 50,000 homeowners in the New York region with Federal Housing Administration mortgages -- 75 percent -- live in Brooklyn and Queens. Foreclosures on these loans have also risen sharply in the past few years, almost doubling between 1999 and 2000, according to HUD, which administers the loan program. Further, a new analysis by a New York City economic development group shows that in the last six months, the number of foreclosures -- actions by lenders to repossess the homes -- on all types of home loans in Brooklyn and Queens increased sharply over the same period last year.
What has emerged in New York City is a kind of default and foreclosure belt, snaking through predominantly black neighborhoods of southeast Queens and central Brooklyn, where experts say a combination of rising unemployment, economic losses resulting from the events of Sept. 11 and fraudulent lending practices that lured first-time home buyers into untenable situations, has given rise to unprecedented mortgage troubles.
"It looks to me like the American dream is, for some people, becoming the American nightmare," said Dolores Martin, a homeownership counselor for Jamaica Housing Improvement Inc., a nonprofit agency in Queens whose offices have been flooded in recent months with clients who are behind on their mortgages or attempting to stave off foreclosure on their loans. 
In 1991, the percentage of New York homeowners in default on their Federal Housing Authority loans was 2.4 percent. In the first months of 2002, the rate was 11.7 percent, compared with 4.9 percent nationally. 
The trouble making mortgage payments appears to be centered on the government-guaranteed loans, which along with federal loans for veterans, account for 10 to 14 percent of the overall mortgage market. Another recent national survey suggests that the problem is not as pronounced with other types of loans.
That survey, by the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade group that tracks delinquent payments and foreclosures on conventional and government loans quarterly, shows a slight increase nationally and in New York State in foreclosures over the last year but a decrease since last summer in late payments.
Many of the moderate-income New York City families who obtained the federal loans and bought houses during the flush economic times of the late 1990's were swept up, experts said, by a feeling that the good times would never end and that it was time to buy -- or forever be priced out of owning a home. However, when the economy stalled, they found themselves with more debt then they could handle, and things have only gotten worse since Sept. 11.
Among Ms. Martin's clients are a flight attendant who lost her job after Sept. 11 and who is married to a taxi driver whose income plunged after the terrorist attack, and a woman who lost her weekend job at a car dealership in October, as sales there began to plummet. 
And Ms. Martin, who as a real estate broker in the 1990's sold homes at a furious pace in many of the same neighborhoods where she travels now, trying to rescue her clients from foreclosure, is one of several counselors across the city who said they were seeing an overwhelming number of people in neighborhoods like Jamaica, Queens, and Bedford Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, facing the loss of their homes.
"I'm finding that people just aren't able to hold it together," said Pamela Sah, a lawyer with the Foreclosure Prevention Project of South Brooklyn Legal Services. "Beginning late last year, we started getting slammed," she said, referring to her caseload, which she said had doubled among clients holding F.H.A. loans.
Default rates are only somewhat lower in Staten Island and the Bronx, but there are far fewer federally insured loans in those boroughs: 3,370 in Staten Island and 6,788 in the Bronx, compared with 15,807 in Brooklyn and 22,472 in Queens. In Manhattan, there are only 429 such loans, 158 of which are in default, mostly due to a mortgage scandal last year that led to hundreds of defaults in low-income neighborhoods, housing officials said.
Federal housing officials declined to discuss the default rates. But Diane L. Tomb, a HUD spokeswoman, explained in a statement that the inventory of older housing in New York City presents the risk of unexpected repairs, and that in New York City, the F.H.A. program tends to attract a higher concentration of people who buy multifamily homes and rely on rental income to meet the mortgage.
Ms. Tomb said that another reason for the high default rate was the mortgage scandal, which involved real estate speculators working with mortgage lenders and appraisers to buy properties from private owners and quickly resell them to nonprofit groups at hugely inflated prices.
But the scandal mostly involved properties in Harlem and Brooklyn and would account for only a fraction of the defaults in the last few years, not the last 10 years. 
However, advocates for the poor say there have been instances in other boroughs where unscrupulous lenders have arranged F.H.A. mortgages for inflated amounts, then profited when the buyers of those properties defaulted.
Besides the demographics of a city that has a higher proportion of low- and moderate-income homeowners than most other areas of the country, several experts said that another likely cause of the higher New York region default rates had to do with a wave of refinancing in the 1990's that left the government mortgage program with the lenders most at risk of defaulting. 
As private lenders began to compete with the government for the business of moderate-income home buyers -- offering lower down payments and interest rates -- some homeowners with good credit left the F.H.A. program.
And, as real estate values increased sharply during the 1990's, some homeowners refinanced because they qualified for more attractive private mortgages.
Still, the number of homeowners holding the federal loans has steadily increased in the last decade, suggesting that more people with spottier credit records and perhaps shakier financing are taking out the loans, said Paul Muolo, executive director of National Mortgage News, published in Washington.
Even though foreclosures on F.H.A. loans in most of the New York region -- including the five boroughs and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties -- has increased sharply in the past decade, the latest federal data shows a slight decrease in the New York region in the past few months. Still, an analysis by the Neighborhood Economic Development Advocacy Project, which is based in Manhattan and obtains data on foreclosures, shows that in the last six months there was a surge in claims filed by lenders against borrowers in Brooklyn and Queens.
Between Oct. 1, 2001, and March 11, 2002, lenders filed 1,207 claims against owners of one- to four-family homes in Brooklyn, compared with 869 during roughly the same period a year earlier, the analysis shows. In Queens, 1,116 claims were filed between Oct. 1, 2001, and March 11, 2002, compared with 976 filed during the same period the year before.
Behind all the statistics are people like Gina Lundy, a media representative at a medical company who is facing foreclosure. She earns $37,000 annually and bought her first home, in Springfield Gardens, Queens, in July 2000. After having to pay for unexpected repairs to the plumbing and heating systems, Ms. Lundy lost her second job, at a car dealership in Brooklyn, soon after Sept. 11, and the $14,000 a year in extra income she had counted on when she applied for her $1,531 monthly mortgage. 
Ms. Lundy, 38, who is raising three sons, has borrowed $5,000 from her retirement account and is trying to work out a payment plan with her lender. "I'm going to hope for the best," she said. "I wanted to buy the first house I could afford, and I need to keep the house. If I pass away, my kids will have this to fall back on."

HEADLINE: U.S. Grant to Gazprom Partner Is Questioned 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 26 

 BODY:
Why was the United States government subsidizing Itera Holding, a mysterious company in Jacksonville, Fla., at the center of accusations of corruption swirling around Gazprom, the Russian gas giant?
 That is what minority shareholders in Gazprom demanded to know about an $868,000 grant announced by the United States Trade and Development Agency in late February. The agency provides grants to American companies to help them gain contracts overseas. 
 The grant was intended to pay for an American engineering company to conduct a feasibility study of a gas field in northern Russia that Itera owns with Gazprom. But Gazprom shareholders complained that the grant gave a stamp of approval from the American government to a company they say has benefited improperly from asset-stripping at Gazprom, a charge that Itera denies. 
The Trade and Development Agency suspended the grant last week, apparently because of the complaints. Leocadia Zak, the agency's general counsel, said that additional information was needed before the money could be disbursed.
Itera Holding started in the mid-1990's as a small gas trading company and rapidly grew into the No. 2 gas producer in Russia, behind Gazprom. But the transactions with Gazprom that brought about that growth are shrouded in mystery. Gazprom extended more than $600 million in loan guarantees to Itera, and some analysts and shareholders have said that they think Gazprom managers secretly enriched themselves or their relatives by transferring Gazprom assets to Itera.
The managers who ran Gazprom through the 1990's were removed last year by the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who said that enormous sums of money had leaked out of the company. The Russian government is Gazprom's largest shareholder with 38 percent.
Since then, Gazprom's new management has been struggling to regain control of lost assets, generally by exercising buyback options or forcing bankruptcy proceedings for affiliated companies like Sibur and Purgaz. 
Itera and former managers of Gazprom said that there were no improper links between the two companies or their executives. 
At the heart of the controversy is the question of who owns the Achimovskoye gas field, with estimated reserves of 354 billion cubic meters of gas. An Itera spokesman, Nikolai Semanenko, said that Itera and Gazprom, after creating a joint venture in 2000, applied to the Russian government for the development rights, and that Itera had invested in the field since then. 
But a study last year by the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers found that Gazprom had sole ownership rights to the field that dated from before the joint venture, raising questions about how Itera gained its 49 percent interest.
An American official involved in the process said the grant to Itera "made sense because of U.S. exports -- we want to give U.S. firms a leg up in the development of this field -- and because Itera has become a major player in Eurasian gas."
The American engineering company that was to conduct the study on the gas field, BSI Industries of Columbus, Ohio, is owned and run principally by Vladimir Gokun, 56, a Russian-born American citizen, who had worked in the Soviet gas industry designing transport systems. Mr. Gokun said he met Itera's chief executive, Igor Makarov, at a conference in Houston in 1994. 
Mr. Gokun said the grant would give American companies, which sold gas turbines to the Soviet Union before the 1979 invasion of Afghanistan and subsequent embargo, an opportunity to return to the market.
But Ian Hague, a partner at Firebird Management, an equity fund in New York that holds Gazprom shares, called the grant "an endorsement of what we minority shareholders regard as something that could turn out to be a criminal organization," referring to Itera.
Mr. Semanenko dismissed the criticism. "Itera and Gazprom are two independent companies with no relation to each other," he said. Referring to critics, he said, "They've talked about a connection a million times, but not once has anything been proven."
James Fenker, strategist at Troika Dialog, an investment bank in Moscow, said: "It was a closed deal between former Gazprom management and Itera. It just doesn't seem like something the U.S. government should be involved in."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
A Suit Says WorldCom Deals Obscured Millions in Bad Debt

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
A lawsuit quietly moving forward against the telecommunications giant WorldCom accuses the company of using concealed transactions and sham contracts to avoid reporting an uncollectible debt of $165 million. 
 WorldCom says the suit, brought by shareholders of a company, now bankrupt, in which WorldCom was an investor, has no merit. But a San Francisco judge ruled that the accusations were detailed enough for the case to proceed. The two sides are now disputing whether WorldCom's chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, and chief financial officer, Scott D. Sullivan, must submit to pretrial questions and cross-examination, according to the plaintiffs' lawyer. 
 The suit is unfolding at an awkward time for WorldCom, which has disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating its accounting practices. 
The suit grows out of WorldCom's relations with Cherry Communications and World Access, two small long-distance companies that went bankrupt after extensive dealings with WorldCom and each other.
According to a suit filed last June in San Francisco Superior Court, Cherry and World Access were pawns in an intricate and deceptive plan that began in 1997 as an effort by WorldCom to avoid writing off as uncollectible a $165 million debt that Cherry owed WorldCom. 
The suit contends that WorldCom helped engineer a bankruptcy filing by Cherry and arranged for Cherry's subsequent merger into World Access in 1998. According to the suit, WorldCom then took part in transactions that misleadingly inflated the value of World Access, a publicly traded long-distance company based in Atlanta. The goal, the suit says, was to help World Access use its high-priced stock to buy numerous small companies that had sprung up to offer phone services in Europe as telecommunications there were being deregulated. WorldCom and World Access executives viewed the strategy as an efficient way to build an enterprise that WorldCom itself would eventually buy, the suit says.
A WorldCom spokesman, Bradford Burns, said, "We believe the claims are without merit and will certainly be contesting them vigorously." He declined to comment further on the suit.
The plaintiffs are Roger B. Abbott and other former shareholders of Communications Telesystems International, a phone and data services company based in San Diego that operated under the name WorldxChange. Communications Telesystems was acquired in April 2000 by World Access in a stock swap. A year later, World Access filed for bankruptcy protection, and the stock that Mr. Abbott and others received in the deal became worthless.
The defendants, which include World Access and its executives and directors, are expected to argue that the plaintiffs' losses had nothing to do with accounting tactics, but resulted from competition and recession in the telecommunications industry. John D. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of World Access, called the suit "an attempt to shake down our insurance company." 
WorldCom's main accuser, Mr. Abbott, has a track record of entrepreneurial flair and illegal hustle. He spent three years in prison after conviction on cocaine trafficking in 1983. After his release, he set up a telemarketing company that attracted regulatory scrutiny for its tactics in selling precious metals investments. 
In 1991, Mr. Abbott founded Communications Telesystems, which became known for slamming, the practice of switching customers from one long-distance service to another without their permission. After tens of thousands of complaints, the California Public Utilities Commission revoked the company's permission to operate most services in the state.
Neil A. Goteiner, Mr. Abbott's lawyer, said his client's past had nothing to do with the charges or Mr. Abbott's credibility, and was unlikely to become evidence in the case.
The lawsuit contends that Mr. Ebbers and Mr. Sullivan became worried in 1997 that the $165 million Cherry owed WorldCom for use of WorldCom's network might be uncollectible. WorldCom, then still a telecommunications upstart, wanted to avoid writing off the debt while it was pursuing an audacious takeover of MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, the suit says.
Enter Mr. Phillips, a friend and business associate of Mr. Ebbers who was a World Access director. The suit says the defendants worked together to help Mr. Phillips gain control of Cherry and merge it with World Access. The plans for the merger -- announced in February 1998, a few weeks before MCI shareholders voted to approve WorldCom's takeover of their company -- allowed WorldCom to transform Cherry's debt into a 14 percent stake in World Access, the suit says.
A crucial element in the transactions, according to the suit, was the business relationship Mr. Phillips negotiated with WorldCom. The suit says that Mr. Phillips portrayed the arrangement as a commitment from WorldCom to buy $25 million a month in services from World Access. In fact, the suit contends, the contract was "a sham" and WorldCom paid only the amount needed to help World Access meet its quarterly earnings projections. 
The combination of apparently reliable earnings and ties to WorldCom misled investors, analysts and Mr. Abbott, according to the suit. 
Mr. Phillips's version of the story, which has yet to be presented in court, is that WorldCom was not the force behind his interest in gaining control of Cherry or his move to merge it with World Access.
Mr. Phillips said that WorldCom wound up with an interest in helping World Access after the merger because it held stock in the company. But it was clear that WorldCom's commitment was to conduct $25 million a month in business with World Access only if the World Access prices and service were competitive and if WorldCom actually needed the capacity, Mr. Phillips said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Airlines and hotel chains are spending plenty to revive travel, especially business travel.

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
BUSINESS travel has shown definite signs of life since the double shock of Sept. 11 and a slumping economy, but it is still limping. So airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced campaigns in recent weeks to try to get things going at a brisk pace again.
 The problem is clear. Domestic airlines will lose $3.5 billion this year, Samuel C. Buttrick, an analyst with UBS Warburg, forecast recently. And while that is far less than the more than $6 billion loss in 2001, it is still the second-largest loss in industry history. 
 Scott Berman, a partner who follows the hotel industry at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said, "Full recovery is difficult to pinpoint, and is very likely to come some time in 2003."
Many new campaigns are directed at business travelers.
American Airlines introduced several television spots during the February Olympic Games; these will run through the end of this month on broadcasts of the National Collegiate Athletic Association games.
The ads, by Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, feature American employees working at various jobs, and conclude by saying, "We are an airline that is proud to bear the name of American."
According to Michael Gunn, the airline's executive vice president for marketing and planning, the ads are aimed mainly at frequent business travelers and airline employees.
"Traffic is there, but business traffic just simply is not there," Mr. Gunn said. He declined to specify American's budget for the advertising, describing it as "well short of $10 million."
United Airlines also has new commercials by Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, a unit of the Publicis Groupe, that are running nationally on N.C.A.A. broadcasts, and on prime-time programming in Chicago. Its campaign also includes ads running through April 30 in The Wall Street Journal, USA Today and other newspapers, and on radio in select markets through the middle of next month.
Jerry Dow, United's director for worldwide marketing communications, said the new ads were meant to "give people reasons to believe United is bigger, better, different and should be their choice."
Six TV spots feature employees discussing their work, and three depict United customers. Print advertising focuses on specific selling points, like the age of United's fleet.
The campaign is aimed "primarily at business travelers," Mr. Dow said. "Our customers are coming back at a slow but very steady pace. We need to accelerate that curve if we want to get back to the point of profitability."
He also said United was allocating most of its 2002 advertising budget to the first half of the year, spending more than it has in this period in the last five years. According to CMR, United's largest ad expenditures in the first six months of the last five years came in 2000, when it spent $42 million.
Several hotel companies are also wooing business travelers.
Last month, Choice Hotels International began a $10 million print, TV, radio and online campaign by the Washington office of Arnold Worldwide, part of Havas Advertising; it will run through the end of April.
The campaign promotes the company's new loyalty program partnerships with American, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and US Airways, as well as a triple mileage offer.
"We're starting to see the economy come back and business travelers getting back on the road," said Wayne W. Wielgus, Choice's senior vice president for marketing. "We see a lot of opportunity as companies look at their travel expenses and trade into the midscale and economy market."
Earlier this month Marriott International introduced four TV spots by the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, a unit of Interpublic, that promote its Marriott, Courtyard, Residence Inn and Fairfield Inn brands. Each spot features a famous sports coach giving tips on getting a competitive edge; in the Courtyard ad, Phil Jackson, head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, dispenses advice as he drives several business travelers around in a taxi.
The ads, which will run through mid-April on cable and broadcast TV, are intended to "capture the business travel demand that's out there, not generate demand," said Deborah Fell, Marriott's senior vice president for marketing. She declined to disclose the company's budget.
Several other campaigns are geared more toward the leisure market, or the travel market in general. Orbitz, the online travel company, is running a magazine and cable TV campaign, through Memorial Day, by Fusion Idea Lab in Chicago. The theme, "The most low fares to planet earth," lets "customers know we have a great value proposition," said Mike Sands, chief marketing officer.
Finally, the American Society of Travel Agents, Association of Retail Travel Agents and the Airlines Reporting Corporation, which processes airline sales by travel agents, earlier this month introduced a public service television commercial featuring the astronaut Jim Lovell, commander of the Apollo 13 space mission. In the spot, he explains air travel security measures instituted after Sept. 11 and urges Americans to travel.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
YES Says No to Cablevision Proposal

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Cablevision, which has resisted carrying the Yankees' new cable channel as part of its basic package, proposed a compromise of sorts yesterday. Cablevision said it would carry the Yankees' channel, the YES Network, on its systems but would allow YES to set the price and keep all the revenues.
 YES rejected the idea, labeling it undemocratic and unfair. 
 The proposal essentially dared YES to demonstrate how many of Cablevision's three million subscribers actually want it. And it maintained Cablevision's opposition to carrying YES as a basic channel and requiring all of its customers, even those who are not fans of baseball, to absorb some of YES's monthly fee, $2 a subscriber. 
"It's a fair way for the Yankees to find out what their value is in the marketplace rather than make the retailer shove it down everybody's throat," James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision, said. 
But Leo F. Hindery Jr., YES's chairman, rejected Dolan's argument and insisted that YES should be a basic channel available to the widest possible audience.
"There is nothing about my service that differentiates it from the myriad other services that belong in basic," he said. "The discriminatory aspect of it is simply unacceptable."
He said Dolan's offer ignored the reality that programmers like YES do not sell themselves directly to cable subscribers but use the cable systems as intermediaries.
"This is an attempt to shift blame back in my direction, and that's disappointing," Hindery said.
The impasse leaves Cablevision's subscribers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut without access to some or all of the network's 130 Yankees games -- opening day in Baltimore is Monday -- or seeking an alternative with a satellite dish.
YES and Cablevision have staked out rigid positions, and until now, YES has been more successful in appealing to fan sentiment. It has successfully pursued agreements to be carried as a basic channel with Time Warner, Comcast, RCN and DirecTV, the satellite service. And in doing so, it has cast Cablevision as the villain.
Cablevision's offer was its first major effort to deflect criticism from itself.
"What a clever move," John Mansell, an analyst for Kagan World Media, said. "It's really designed for the media, to turn around public sentiment, and I think it does."
The company, which has historically been willing to withstand subscriber anger, has been buffeted by advertising from YES that portrayed it as unnecessarily depriving Yankees fans of their games, and advertising from DirecTV to switch to satellite to receive YES.
Had YES accepted Cablevision's offer, it would have had to redo its existing deals, which would have most likely reduced its revenues.
Without Cablevision's subscribers, YES will be unable to sustain its advertising rates for Yankees games or deliver the expected financial return to its investors, including Goldman Sachs, which owns 40 percent of the network.
Dolan said he was motivated to make his offer because of the absence of negotiations.
"This is a tough issue for us," he said. "I'm not really that interested in going up against DirecTV without the Yankees. We're going to lose some subscribers."
Dolan said he had heard the loud objections of customers demanding that he put YES on basic, but he was also listening to subscribers who do not want their bills to increase because of YES.
"As the C.E.O. of the company, I have to balance the screaming with the fact that there are three million customers out there," he said. "How much of that screaming actually represents the true feelings of the customer base?"
Cablevision said it had experienced a minimal number of disconnects from its service; DirecTV said only that caller volume to its local distributor, American Satellite, had grown 80 percent above normal volume since its YES advertising campaign began on March 11.
Dolan said his company's refusal to carry YES under the Yankee network's terms is based on the network's economics. He said that the valuation of YES at more than $800 million required that it charge cable systems the monthly $2 subscriber fee. The fee is the highest ever for a startup cable network, according to Kagan World Media. (Cablevision customers pay the most in the nation, with average bills of $59.93 a month.)
Regional sports networks are the most expensive on cable, while well-known basic channels like CNN and Lifetime are much cheaper. CNN's monthly fee is 37 cents a subscriber, while Lifetime's is 15 cents, Margo Black of Kagan said.
YES's valuation, Dolan said, "was a fantasy in somebody's mind, with assumptions that weren't grounded in any other valuation we've ever seen."
He added, "The valuation was born during the dot-com fever days when everything was valued at incredibly high numbers."
Hindery derided Dolan's analysis and noted that with 130 Yankees games, YES has more baseball games than Cablevision's MSG and Fox Sports New York services combined. It will also show 75 Nets games next season, as well as minor league Yankees games, taped Manchester United soccer games and college sports.
"It is absurd to suggest that the quality of YES isn't in excess of what anyone has seen in this market," Hindery said.
If, indeed, YES does not appear on Cablevision, it will remind local cable customers of Cablevision's refusal to carry MSG in 1988 and 1989; that dispute was also over whether MSG should be sold as a basic or premium service. Subscribers missed the 1988-89 Knicks and Rangers seasons and half of the Yankees' 1989 season.
Last season, the Time Warner cable system in Southern California blacked out 34 Los Angeles Dodgers games on the Fox Sports West 2 channel and 15 Anaheim Angels games on the Fox Sports West channel because it refused to pay an increased surcharge for the games.

HEADLINE: Europe's Trade Chief Trains Cross Hairson U.S. Tariffs 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, March 26 

 BODY:
The Bush administration has a new bogeyman in Brussels to contend with.
 Last year it was Mario Monti, the European Union commissioner in charge of competition issues, who effectively vetoed the proposed merger of General Electric and Honeywell over antitrust issues. 
 Now it is the turn of Pascal Lamy, the trade commissioner, to lock horns with his American counterparts, in particular over President Bush's decision earlier this month to protect the American steel industry from some imports.
Like Mr. Monti, Mr. Lamy finds himself reacting to a problem thrown at him from across the Atlantic. And like Mr. Monti, he is attacking it with strict application of legal and economic principles. 
But this time around, the stakes are far higher. If the United States and the European Union, the two largest forces in world trade, allow their bilateral problems to escalate into all-out trade war, flows of goods and services worth billions of dollars will be disrupted. But more ominously, the long hard hard work Mr. Lamy and Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, put in to get a new round of global trade liberalization talks under way may be undone, and according to European diplomats and trade lawyers, the World Trade Organization itself could easily become a casualty.
Europe is rapidly running out of patience with America. At the end of last week, Mr. Lamy's department circulated a list of United States export products that it wants to submit to the World Trade Organization as targets for possible retaliatory sanctions if the United States does not agree to pay compensation for the steel tariffs, or better still, scrap them altogether. The list goes into great detail: steel doors, 800-cc motorbikes, grapefruit juice, long-grain brown rice, pantyhose, ballpoint pens and toothbrushes are some of the items that would be hit with punitive 100 percent duties.
Mr. Lamy is quick to acknowledge that the list has been tailored for maximum impact on American domestic politics. The products all come from important battleground states in the coming midterm elections, like Florida. "We have got to be as clever as we can," he said in an interview. "It is a question of efficiency, in order to leverage a change of position in the U.S.
"We want this decision to be reversed. For President Bush the pros for imposing the tariffs outweigh the cons. We have to rebalance this."
Mr. Lamy said he was using the same tactics the United States adopted in an earlier dispute, now resolved, over European restrictions on banana imports. French cheese was included in a list of European products to be hit by United States sanctions because France was thought to have backed a hard line on bananas by the union.
"If Roquefort was taken hostage in the case of bananas, it's not because of the huge importance of Roquefort to the macroeconomic situation in the U.S.," he said.
Mr. Lamy must now decide whether to impose sanctions on the $2.1 billion worth of American exports on his list, which could take effect as early as May. The union has until May 19 to submit the list to the trade organization as part of the group's arbitration process, which generally takes 18 months, but under certain of the trade group's rules he can move much faster than that. A stickler for process and principles, Mr. Lamy said he was still examining the legal basis for such a move.
"There is an option there," he said. "I'm considering it, and I'll take a decision according to my own sense of whether it fits with our strategy, which is abiding by rules. The name of the game is rules, disciplines."
Mr. Lamy's approach has surprised many people since he took up his post in 1999. "When he arrived, people thought, 'Oh no, a French Socialist -- he'll be a protectionist with a hidden agenda to pursue the interests of France,' " one Brussels diplomat said. 
But he has shown little sign of chauvinism. "He has fired some of his most vitriolic comments at his countrymen, including the minister of foreign affairs, Hubert Vedrine," the diplomat said.
As for being a protectionist, his fighting talk in the steel dispute has laid that idea to rest for many. In fact, he is more often criticized for being the opposite, an overzealous crusader for globalization and the free markets, a notion he finds rather amusing given his political allegiance.
Neither does his fierce criticism of American protectionism arise from any instinct toward anti-Anglo-Saxonism, a fashionable attitude in France. "There are lots of things about the U.S. that I admire because of their creativity and productivity," he said in the interview, speaking English fluently. "Steel may be an exception."
Mr. Lamy is well thought of by his opposite number in Washington. "I've known and respected Pascal for some 13 years," Mr. Zoellick said in a telephone interview. "He leads the pack both in the effective representation of E.U. interests and in reasoning through differences skillfully."
Mr. Lamy gives the impression of a man of few passions -- a workaholic and ascetic who favors bread and lentils for lunch and spends leisure time jogging and cycling. "He does come across as frighteningly dry, but a man totally in command of his brief," the diplomat said.
Passion only shows when he talks of his work. "Trade is an advanced continent of world governance, and I think we should nurture it and care for it," Mr. Lamy said in the interview. Whether he gets a chance to do so will depend largely on how he fields the latest problem thrown at him from across the Atlantic.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Enron Cure Is in Market,Not Regulation 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the solutions to weaknesses in corporate governance exposed by Enron's collapse rested more with market forces than with new legislation or regulation.
 In his most comprehensive comments to date on the issues raised by the Enron debacle, Mr. Greenspan focused on the consolidation of corporate power in the hands of chief executives, overly optimistic earnings forecasts by stock analysts, a lack of independence among outside directors and efforts by executives to puff up earnings reports. 
 He said some issues were ripe for legislative or regulatory action, especially the accounting rules that allow companies to issue stock options as compensation without counting them as an expense. 
But Mr. Greenspan defended the current approach to corporate governance, with its reliance on trust in the chief executive, as the best available. And he suggested that the market was already disciplining corporations by penalizing the stock and bonds of those that try to deceive investors. 
"After considerable soul-searching and many Congressional hearings, the current C.E.O.-dominant paradigm, with all its faults, will likely to continue to be viewed as the most viable form of governance for today's world," Mr. Greenspan said in remarks prepared for delivery at the Stern School of Business of New York University. 
His comments were consistent with previous statements about the lessons of Enron's downfall and a long-held ideological position that economic and financial problems are often best left to the free market. They seemed directed in part at calls from members of Congress, especially Democrats, for tougher rules on corporate oversight. 
Senate Democrats have proposed legislation that would increase criminal penalties for some kinds of corporate wrongdoing and give state attorneys general additional power to sue companies. Some Democrats have said that a naive reliance on free-market checks and balances of the sort advocated by Mr. Greenspan was at the heart of Enron's collapse.
But the Fed chief suggested that the market was working as it should, if after the fact. He said investors seemed to be awarding higher relative values to companies whose earnings reports were not exaggerated or misleading, and that the reliability of financial statements was being reflected in corporate bond prices.
"Corporate governance has doubtless already measurably improved as a result of this greater market discipline in the wake of recent events," Mr. Greenspan said. 
Noting that "Congress is clearly signaling that more needs to be done," he added that the government should be careful "not to look to a significant expansion of regulation as the solution to current problems."
Regulation, he said, has "proven only partially successful in dissuading individuals from playing with the rules of accounting."
The Fed chairman endorsed President Bush's call for chief executives to be held more directly accountable for corporate financial statements' accuracy. The president's call to define "more clearly the duties of C.E.O.'s with respect to accounting and disclosure appears appropriate," Mr. Greenspan said. The Bush position was largely based on recommendations from the President's Working Group on Financial Markets, a senior economic policy group including Mr. Greenspan.
Addressing the matter of relentlessly upbeat recommendations by stock analysts, he noted "the proclivity of firms that sell securities to retain and promote analysts with an optimistic inclination," especially when the brokerage firm also acts as an investment banker for the company whose stock it is recommending.
But he said Wall Street was responding on its own to deal with the problem through initiatives like a requirement that brokerage firms include in research reports the distribution of their ratings among buy, sell and hold recommendations.
In time, he said, earnings projections by analysts will be more closely scrutinized by investors after the fact, allowing them to judge more accurately which analysts are worth listening to. "I venture to say that with such transparency, the current upward bias of analysts' earnings projections would diminish rather rapidly," Mr. Greenspan said, "because investment firms are well aware that security analysis without credibility has no market value."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Fed chief, Alan Greenspan, discussing corporate governance at New York University last night. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bush Energy Paper Followed Industry Push 

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
As he helped the Bush administration write its national energy report last year, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham heard from more than 100 energy industry executives, trade association leaders and lobbyists, according to documents released by the Energy Department.
 Mr. Abraham did not meet with any representatives of environmental organizations or consumer groups, the documents show. 
 In a press release on Monday night, the Energy Department summarized the secretary's calendar by saying that Mr. Abraham met with 36 industry representatives on task force matters. Most news organizations reported that figure today. 
But Mr. Abraham actually met with 109 representatives of energy industry companies and trade associations, according to a comprehensive review of his daily calendar from late January 2001 to May 17, 2001, the day the White House released its national energy report. Many of the executives were leaders of corporations that were among the most generous financial supporters of President Bush's presidential campaign and the Republican Party.
Among the individuals and groups that met with Mr. Abraham, 18 contributed a total of $16.6 million to the Republican Party since 1999, nearly three times what they gave to the Democratic Party, according to an analysis of data compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics.
Jill Schroeder, spokeswoman for the Energy Department, said the department came up with its figure of 36 industry representatives meeting with Mr. Abraham based on executives who had asked to discuss the work of the task force with Mr. Abraham, who was an influential task force member. But many of the other meetings not counted by the Energy Department also dealt with the executives' interest in topics covered by the national energy policy.
"He's the energy secretary, he meets with these folks about energy issues," Ms. Schroeder said. "It's his job."
Energy Department officials also pointed out that Mr. Abraham occasionally rebuffed energy industry executives. Officials said 23 requests for meetings from industry leaders were denied. Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former top executives of the Enron Corporation, were among the executives who were turned away, officials said. But on March 29, 2001, Mr. Abraham met with two other Enron executives, Joe Hartsoe and Linda Robertson.
And Mr. Lay met with Vice President Dick Cheney, who headed the task force, on April 17, 2001, to discuss energy policy and the California energy crisis. David Addington, counsel to Mr. Cheney, has said that altogether, Enron executives had six meetings with task force staff members in 2001.
A coalition of nearly 30 environmental groups asked to meet with Mr. Abraham to discuss the energy policy on Feb. 20, 2001. Energy Department officials declined the request, citing Mr. Abraham's "busy schedule," department officials said.
But in the days following, Mr. Abraham met with numerous industry representatives, including a top executive of the American Coal Company; the chairman of UtiliCorp United, a power company now known as Aquila Inc.; executives from a half-dozen utility companies; executives from a half-dozen nuclear power corporations and the corporate leaders of ExxonMobil, BP/Amoco, Shell, ChevronTexaco, Anadarko Petroleum and Ashland Inc.
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said today: "News flash -- no surprise to anybody, the secretary of energy meets with energy-related groups."
Over three days in late February 2001, Mr. Abraham met with six petroleum executives, a railroad executive and the leader of a coal producing company. On Feb. 21, he met with executives of five oil companies, including David O'Reilly, the president of ChevronTexaco, and Steven Miller, the president and chief executive of Shell Oil Company.
The next day, Feb. 22, Mr. Abraham met with John W. Snow, the chief executive of the CSX Corporation, one of the nation's largest railroad companies. According to Mr. Abraham's calendar, the meeting's topics included "the role coal plays in electric utility generation, mountaintop mining and the National Energy and Environmental Technology Act."
Mr. Abraham also met with a number of energy industry lobbyists, including Haley Barbour, who represents utility companies, and Tom Kuhn, the executive director of the utility industry trade group, the Edison Electric Institute.
Mr. Abraham's calendar was among the 11,000 pages of documents that Democratic lawmakers and environmental groups said today demonstrated that the administration sought the advice of utility companies, oil companies and the producers of natural gas, coal and nuclear energy in developing its energy policy.
Congressional Democrats and environmental groups have long argued that the administration relied on advice from industry leaders while spurning environmentalists who were arguing for conservation, renewable energy sources and energy efficiency measures. Today, the groups said that Mr. Abraham's calendar has proved that suspicion.
"The documents indicate that great deference was given to energy industry executives and lobbyists and almost none was given to the environmental industry and the concerns of consumer groups," said Larry Klayman, chairman and general counsel of Judicial Watch, the legal watchdog group and one of several groups that sued executive branch agencies for the documents' release.
The boxes of documents released by the Energy Department include hundreds of internal e-mail messages that are heavily edited. Other apparently benign e-mail messages are entirely blank; some blank pages have tantalizing titles like, "Importance: High." The Energy Department also failed to print out e-mail attachments; one was titled "proposed energy policy language."
Energy officials cited an array of exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act, including internal deliberations about policy and personnel matters.
Leaders of the two groups that sued to get the documents said today that they would ask federal judges to review the full texts of the edited documents and press for their complete release. They also complained that the Energy Department refused to release an additional 15,000 pages of documents.
"There is a lot missing," said Sharon Buccino, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, another organization that sued to get the records. "We have 11,000 pages of scrubbed, purged and sanitized documents. Even despite those efforts to hide the documents, they are littered with evidence of industry access."
Ms. Schroeder said that all outside documents submitted to the Energy Department were made public. "What we have withheld is not any kind of communication between D.O.E. and anyone on the outside but discussions inside the administration about what the report should say," she said. "It is standard practice not to produce information about such discussions."
The documents include papers from industry representatives about the relationship between gasoline consumption and air pollution. The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers noted in a report to the Energy Department on March 22, 2001, that "fuel economy standards are an ineffective energy policy."
The federal task force essentially accepted that argument. Instead of calling for new fuel efficiency standards, it recommended only that new standards receive further study.
And the energy policy report warned that increases in fuel efficiency had to be done "without negatively impacting the U.S. automotive industry."
The Energy Department noted that the National Mining Association asked for an overhaul of the New Source Review program, an Environmental Protection Agency regulation that requires power plants, oil refineries and other industrial plants to meet new emissions standards when they undertake a major upgrade of operations. The energy industry has fought the regulation for years, claiming it lacks clarity.
The Bush administration is now trying to overhaul the rule, a move that has touched off debate between the Energy Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, and within the agency itself.
Ms. Schroeder said that other Energy Department officials met five environmental and consumer groups -- the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, the Sierra Club, Environmental Defense, Resources for the Future and the American Wind Energy Association. And she said five other groups did not respond to a request for comments, including the World Wildlife Fund and Greenpeace.
Gary Skulnik, a Greenpeace spokesman, said yesterday that "a low-level staffer called us on March 22, 2001, and gave us 24 hours to provide any input we had on energy policy." The organization decided not to scramble to meet the tight deadline. 
"If they were serious about getting input," Mr. Skulnik said, "that was certainly not the way to go about it."

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER; 
Dream Car, Dream Colors? A Dream Indeed

BYLINE:  By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ONCE I owned the cutest car in America: a sporty red 1989 Honda Civic, fun to drive with a peppy four-speed manual transmission. 
But buying it was a nightmare after the dealership's "closer," whose name sounded like Shanker, tried to browbeat us into a sunroof and rustproofing. So when we needed another car a few months later, we bought the ugliest car in America, figuring the dealer would be too relieved to get rid of it to give me a hard time. It was a milky beige Honda Civic similar in color to chipped-beef gravy. This car was such a leftover that even Shanker did not push for a floor-mat upgrade. 
 Over the years, it picked up dents in long-term parking at LaGuardia. The dents rusted. Then a speaker cover fell off, causing tangled wires to spill out like uncoiled intestines when you opened the driver's door. 
 That car is still in my driveway, a testament to how much I dread the car-buying process. 
But against my will, I must get a second car this spring to replace a leased Audi station wagon. And I know nothing can eliminate the stress of the confusing, high-pressure negotiation between a smooth car dealer and an amateur buyer struggling to understand the nuances of "the XC AWD Trim Line" or the hidden costs of add-ons like the "Touring Package With Interior Air Quality System." 
So last week I joined the 62 percent of American new-car buyers who, according to a recent study by J. D. Power and Associates, turn to the Internet for information. In fact, people who buy their vehicles through an online buying service save an average of $500, according to Chris Denove, the senior director of automotive research at J. D. Power. 
First I visited two pricing and comparison sites, MSN Carpoint (www.carpoint.com) and Edmunds .com, to compare station wagon models. Both sites gave me identical blow-by-blow comparisons of the invoice prices the dealer pays, the sticker prices the dealer posts on the cars, and vehicle equipment and options. In addition, Edmunds.com offered a True Market Value price, the average national selling price for any particular model. 
At both sites, I also requested referrals to local dealers, who within 24 hours sent me e-mail or phoned to try to get me to visit their showrooms. Their phone manners ranged from pleasant (an Audi seller) to shifty (a Volkswagen seller who, when I phoned a few days later, was "no longer with this company"). 
Then I headed to the ConsumerReports.org site to purchase New Car Price Reports for three models ($12 for the first report, $10 for each subsequent report). The crucial bit of information is the dealer's true cost for the vehicle, the "wholesale price" that takes into account any financial incentives from the maker. 
Based on ConsumerReports.org's reviews, I decided to buy a Volkswagen Passat wagon, rated on the site as the top family car. 
Next I went to Volkswagen's site, at vw.com, to create my own car. With a few clicks, I had "built" a handsome indigo blue GLX wagon with beige leather and a peppy five-speed manual transmission. The buggy VW site then crashed my computer. I ignored that. When I returned to figure out how much this car would really cost, the site's payment calculator told me $57.91 a month. I disregarded that as well. 
Then I went to CarsDirect.com, the only direct seller online, to get a price quote. CarsDirect.com assigns a sales specialist to each customer who requests a car. From among the site's more than 3,800 partner dealers nationwide, the specialist searches for the vehicle a customer wants. Unlike a dealership, which is structured to move the cars on its lot, CarsDirect.com is happy to sell any car, regardless of make. 
My goal, based on advice from my Consumer Reports price report, was a five-speed GLX wagon for less than $28,940. Edmunds.com set the market value slightly lower, at $27,871. 
After a few clicks, CarsDirect.com delivered a firm quote: $28,304. With a few more clicks, I applied for a loan (revealing information like my name, address, phone number and Social Security number). 
That same day, a helpful, polite CarsDirect.com sales specialist phoned to confirm my order, which would not become binding unless I authorized a deposit. My loan application had been approved, for a 6.19 percent, 36-month loan from one of CarsDirect.com's partner lenders. 
"That's it?" I asked. "I'm approved?" 
"That's it," he said. 
To complete the transaction, he said, all I would have to do would be to visit a partner dealer once, sign papers, hand over my money and drive away in the indigo-blue-with-beige-leather vehicle. 
I was feeling empowered. Thanks to the Internet, I knew exactly which car I wanted and exactly how much it should cost and had even arranged the loan. 
The only hitch? The car didn't actually exist. Instead, the CarsDirect .com representative offered me three choices: 
1. A blue, automatic-transmission wagon with gray leather instead of beige, which I could get from a partner dealer in New Jersey. 
2. A blue automatic wagon with beige leather, which I could go to Boston to get from a partner dealer who had located that car at another, unnamed dealership. "But that car may have up to 300 miles on it, from being driven to Boston," I was warned. 
3. A factory order for the five-speed I wanted, which might take 12 or more weeks to arrive at the New Jersey dealership. By then, the lease on my other wagon would have expired. 
Was I getting the runaround? I phoned Volkswagen headquarters and found out that CarsDirect.com was right: no blue-beige GLX five-speeds were available. Anywhere. Last week, only 54 five-speed GLX wagons were on dealers' lots in the entire United States, a spokesman said. And none was blue. There were, however, two blue-beige five-speed GLX's on boats, coming to customers who had placed special orders. 
Where did this leave me? Disappointed. I felt betrayed by the Internet for raising my expectations without being able to deliver, thanks to the ease with which I had gotten specs and prices, applied for and been accepted for a loan and built a specific car. 
Reality, however, was far colder. The man from CarsDirect.com (who listened sympathetically for 30 minutes as I explained my situation to him) agreed that I shouldn't order a five-speed unless I first took one for a test drive; but there was no five-speed to test drive anywhere near my house. 
This brings me back to the ugliest car in America. According to the Kelley Blue Book site, it's worth only $2,275. But sitting in my driveway? It's priceless.
