HEADLINE: Virtual Game Weapons Bought With Real Money 

BYLINE:  By MARC WEINGARTEN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
KEN SELDEN is having a red-letter month selling goods on the Internet. He has unloaded about 400 million pieces of silver, a sanctified claymore and a lot of women's clothing, among other things. His total take is about $9,000. But the merchandise is strictly digital, nothing more than words written on a computer screen.
 Mr. Selden is a mighty financial force for the roughly 20,000 players of GemStone III, an online swords-and-sabers role-playing game in which thousands of people gather daily to interact in a medieval domain. The goal is to advance your character, or avatar, accumulating virtual wealth and new armor by hunting monsters, raising the dead or opening boxes of treasure. 
 Players can advance more quickly by using potent weapons that make their avatars stronger. And for those who lack the time or patience to acquire the goods within the game's confines, Mr. Selden provides an answer in the material universe. 
Buying up merchandise and virtual currency from those abandoning the game, Mr. Selden resells the goods to eager players, often for a handsome profit. In doing so, he has established an exchange rate between game currency and the dollar, emerging within the GemStone subculture as equal parts Alan Greenspan and J. P. Morgan.
"Half the people thought I was ruining the game," he said, "and the other half thought it was the coolest thing they'd ever seen."
Mr. Selden is not the only entrepreneur capitalizing on Web gamers' lust for hard-to-obtain virtual merchandise. Bustling real-money markets thrive on bulletin boards and sites including playerauctions .com, devoted to popular role-playing games like Dark Age of Camelot and EverQuest. 
What makes GemStone III unusual is that unlike the new generation of role-playing games like EverQuest, with their elaborately matrixed 3-D renderings of virtual worlds, GemStone is a low-tech, text-only game whose merchandise exists only as descriptions, along with the coding that makes them functional -- not images. (The game, which costs $12.95 a month, is at www.play.net.) Everything -- a "4X blessable ax with extra silvery cobwebs across the blade," a "6X exceptional padded breastplate" -- is an imaginary construct. Still, game players are willing to spend hundreds of dollars, even thousands, for vestigial goods. And more often than not, the seller is Mr. Selden. 
Mr. Selden, a 43-year-old father of three boys who lives in Studio City in the San Fernando Valley, said his profit from selling items on GemStone III had allowed him to take a sabbatical from his career as the writer and director of such films as "White Lies," starring Rosanna Arquette, and network movies-of-the-week. A Cleveland native and Yale graduate, Mr. Selden said he had made close to $100,000 last year selling goods to fellow GemStone III players, and that this year looks promising as well. 
Mr. Selden's customers tend to be older professionals who lack the time to play for 10 hours at a stretch and who use their real-money acquisitions as a shortcut to keep up with the hard-core contingent. 
GemStone, one of the first multiplayer online games, was introduced in 1988 as a feature of General Electric's online service, Genie. Players paid $2.95 an hour at night and $11.95 an hour during the day. "At that point about 30 people, including me, were playing the game," Mr. Selden said. "When people left the game for good, usually to sign on to EverQuest, they would try to recoup the money they spent by selling the items they had accumulated." Mr. Selden, an armchair economist whose first job out of college was building economic forecasting models for a company called Data Resources, kept a close watch on those auctions, looking for trends. 
When Mr. Selden observed a bidding war for a piece of armor in which the asking price quickly ballooned from $500 to $9,000, he realized that the prices were arbitrary. So in 1998 he decided to buy a "dead account" -- one left dormant after someone permanently logs off the game -- for $2,500. Using the items acquired from the account, Mr. Selden held two auctions: one inside the game, where players could bid with silvers, the virtual currency, and another outside the game, for cash. 
"I discovered that people tended to pay the same amounts inside the game as they did out of it," Mr. Selden said. This was a crucial revelation, as it allowed him to determine an exchange rate, which he estimated at $65 per million silvers. The rate quickly became the lingua franca of GemStone III's marketplace. Using this rate, he sold all of the items from the dead account and made a $5,500 profit. 
Mr. Selden kept acquiring dead accounts and selling the items individually until he had become the wealthiest player in the game. Now he functions as a kind of high-end warehouse for GemStone III players. Because GemStone III is a vintage game, some items have become rarities, and Mr. Selden has just about all of them. He also has three sales representatives who hawk some of this merchandise within the game for commissions. 
Simutronics, the Missouri-based company that runs GemStone III, is aware of Mr. Selden's thriving business. But the company, which advocates a level playing field for the game, holds that selling fake goods for real cash distorts the spirit of fair play. "We don't in any way support this sort of thing," said the company's executive vice president, Neil Harris. But Simutronics does not try to prevent players from buying items. "It's a simple case of supply and demand," Mr. Harris said. "We do our best to maximize the skill element, but you can't legislate it away. If players really want something, they're going to get it." 
Other game companies have been less permissive. In January of last year, Sony Online Entertainment, which runs EverQuest, prevailed on eBay and Yahoo to cancel all auctions of EverQuest items, asserting that the transactions were a violation of the game's end-user licensing agreement, which states that Verant Interactive, a Sony subsidiary, "shall retain ownership of all intellectual property rights." 
"From the player's standpoint, I can understand that there's an eminent domain issue, which is basically, 'I produced the goods, so I can do what I want,' " said Edward Castronova, an associate professor of economics at California State University at Fullerton who has written a paper on EverQuest called "Virtual Worlds: A Firsthand Account of Market and Society on the Cyberian Frontier." "But the game runners have a public-goods argument. They need to create an atmosphere of play for the collective good, and if they allow the buying and selling of items, that collective good could be ruined." 
Meanwhile, Mr. Selden dreams of the day when he can become the Federal Reserve of all Internet games. "I want to create a cross-game currency exchange," he said. "I'm actually working on a site now with a few people. But I don't know the other games as well as GemStone. Guess I'll have to start playing them." EverQuest players, lock up your safe-deposit boxes. 

Going, Going, Gone
The price tags on a few coveted GemStone III commodities sold online recently by Ken Selden:
$1,100 -- A long knife for use against evil undead creatures in perpetuity.
$900 -- A large, meaty bone used to summon wolves to do the player's bidding. 
$700 -- Extremely supple black leather body armor that protects against certain spells. 
$150 -- A talisman that casts advantageous spells when rubbed.

HEADLINE: Making a New Home Where Darkness Fell 

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
ANTHONY RICCI was drawn by the ruin and the recovery. In March, he let the lease expire on his apartment on East 54th Street and moved to Battery Park City, where he looks out on the empty sky where the World Trade Center towers used to be. "I wanted to be part of the resurrection," said Mr. Ricci, 36.
Samir Merghoub and Rachelle Maouchi wanted to stay uptown. But the co-ops they looked at were too small, too expensive or both. Finally a real estate agent pushed them to bid on a one-bedroom on Rector Street, just southwest of the site of the attacks. "I thought I was in a strong bargaining position," said Mr. Merghoub, 31, sitting among cardboard boxes in his new living room. "Then I ended up paying $1,000 over the asking price."
 Patricia Rockmore said she was drawn to the sadness. In January, after living most of her adult life on Park Avenue, Mrs. Rockmore, 65, moved to a studio apartment on John Street, four short blocks from ground zero. "It was a new beginning," she said. "I felt drawn here. Is that crazy?" 
 Just six months ago, residents of the area surrounding the World Trade Center fled their homes on foot, evacuating apartments that were without water, electricity or telephone service, and streets buried under dust and rubble. Many swore they would never go back. The occupancy rate in the Battery Park City complex, which has 6,400 apartments, fell to 60 percent, from near capacity. Projections for the neighborhood were dire.
But now a new cohort of New Yorkers is starting to move in. Some are drawn by the promise of bargain apartments, others by the gaping wound left by the attacks.
Private developers and government agencies have offered incentives to attract new residents and keep old ones. The Battery Park City Authority has offered $15.6 million in incentives to residents living there or moving in by June. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency created by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to oversee the recovery of downtown, has proposed grants of up to $12,000 for residents who commit to living below Chambers Street and west of Broadway for at least two years. (The proposal is subject to approval by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.)
The newcomers have helped revive the downtown real estate market, which had been falling even before Sept. 11, several agents said. In Battery Park City the occupancy rate has risen to about 75 percent. Though co-op and condominium prices are still below pre-Sept. 11 levels, they have been inching back since the new year. "Now downtown is not acting differently than the rest of the market," said Pamela Liebman, chief executive of the Corcoran Group, who added that her company had handled 48 sales below Canal Street since mid-November, at prices of $450,000 to $2.375 million. Ms. Liebman noted the return of bidding wars in several recent sales.
The newcomers recall the neighborhood's earlier settlers, who followed a sense of adventure and the scent of a bargain to a cityscape others found forbidding. As Mr. Merghoub said, one week into life among his new neighbors, "When I saw the attitudes of the people in the neighborhood, they were like, 'We're not going to leave -- we're going to rebuild this better than before.' "

'Like Going to Church'
In her new home on John Street last week, Patricia Rockmore pulled a street map of Manhattan from her handbag. Though she has lived in the city since college, Mrs. Rockmore, who is a partner in a SoHo advertising firm called Patty & Toshi, is still learning her way around the irregular maze of her new downtown neighborhood.
On the morning of Sept. 11, Mrs. Rockmore was in her temporary home in the Hotel Wales on Madison Avenue when she received a call from her daughter Sicily, who told her to turn on the television. Her daughter lived on 120 Greenwich Street, opposite the World Trade Center. Debris was flying by her window, she told her mother. She was terrified. Then the line went dead.
Over the next few weeks, as a cathartic exercise, Mrs. Rockmore drew arrows on a city map, marking the route by which her daughter fled uptown, shaken but unharmed. She went with her daughter to look at her daughter's old building, which is still uninhabitable. Against the enormity of the destruction, a smaller detail nagged at her: the shuttered windows of the small businesses, ruined not by the attack but by the economic exodus that followed.
Mrs. Rockmore, who has been separated from her husband for five years, was then dividing her time between Southampton and the Wales. She loved the Upper East Side; the shopkeepers reminded her of Italy. But as she started to look at apartments there, she felt something was missing. In December her daughter suggested she look downtown.
"I used to come down here for Century 21," she said, referring to the popular discount store. "When I started looking around, it just felt right." She looked at 100 John Street, not far from the arrows she had drawn on her map. She offered her deposit the next day. The rent was $1,795 for about 600 square feet plus a terrace. She did not try to haggle. "Maybe I should have pushed, but I didn't feel like it," she said.
Moving downtown has helped her to make sense of the event. "It's selfish to say, but it's a healing process for me," she said. "Just to go into a candy store and make a contribution to the neighborhood, I'm happy to do it."
In her small, modern living area, she keeps a copy of "When Every Moment Counts: What You Need to Know About Bioterrorism From the Senate's Only Doctor," by Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee. She said she goes to ground zero once a week, "almost like going to church."
Mrs. Rockmore said this reminder felt humbling but right. "I needed to be in reality," she said. "This is reality down here, because you're in it every day."

'Don't Want to Live Downtown'
Samir Merghoub and Rachelle Maouchi were talking on the telephone when the first plane hit the World Trade Center. She was living in Metz, France, looking forward to joining him; he was just blocks away from ground zero in his office at Goldman Sachs, where he is a senior analyst in global operations. He remembers feeling the impact as the plane hit the second tower, the sky outside his window turning black, the walk through a neighborhood in ruin.
The couple had looked for apartments over the summer, mostly uptown or in Midtown. But the prices were so high, the square footage so low. When they resumed their search in late fall, a real estate agent suggested they look downtown.
"We were both very apprehensive," said Ms. Maouchi, 29, who works at Dexia Credit Local in Midtown. Mr. Merghoub saw the destruction in the neighborhood every day, going to and from work. "This place was horrible," he said. "You could smell it for the first three months." Ms. Maouchi suffers from allergies to dust, acute enough that she carries an inhaler. "I told my real estate agent, no, no, I don't want to live downtown," Mr. Merghoub said.
But as the couple hunted uptown, Mr. Merghoub watched daily the remarkable pace of transformation around the financial district. Streets that were closed or covered in debris one week were clean the next. The dust and odor cleared from the air.
When they saw the condominium on Rector Street, the agent urged them to bid right away. It was bigger than what they had seen uptown, and less expensive: $275,000 for about 600 square feet. They bought it for $1,000 more.
After a week in the apartment, the two are surprised by the angles from which their emotions buffet them. One night last week, they spotted a line of ambulances outside their window. They had to wonder if the work crews had come across a cache of human remains.
"I'm still shocked," Ms. Maouchi said. The health club in the building looks over the excavation site, and she said she has mixed feelings when she goes up there. "I would feel guilty if our apartment looked over ground zero, taking advantage of what happened."
Mr. Merghoub moved gently beside her. "I think the opposite," he said. "We should feel good. We're contributing to the community."
It felt like a conversation the two had had before, and would have again. It belonged to the push-and-pull of their new life near ground zero.

'I Wanted to Be Around It'
In the back of his mind, Anthony Ricci is still "mildly concerned" about the air quality around his new home in Gateway Plaza, the six-building complex in Battery Park City most damaged by the explosions and smoke. "I'm leaning toward OSHA's announcements that the air is O.K.," said Mr. Ricci, who helps run health and wellness programs for employees at Pfizer. "But I don't want four years down the road to be paying health consequences."
Mr. Ricci said he had wanted to move downtown before Sept. 11. He loved running along the Hudson River; he liked the light and the mood in the area. After the attacks, his commitment grew only stronger. As he saw it, the worst was over; now began the flood of resources, emotional and financial, into the area. "I'm a huge fan of history," he said. "I wanted to be around it. What happened there drew me."
"I prefer not to lose sight of what happened," he added.
When he saw the studio in January, he scrutinized it for signs of dust. Then he went back a week later and checked again. Satisfied, he signed a lease in January on the 450-square-foot apartment, at a rent of $1,313. He committed even before the incentive programs were announced.
Mr. Ricci said the resolve and purpose that swept the city after Sept. 11 were still in evidence among the loyalists downtown.
And though many people fled the horror of history in the neighborhood, he said he felt safe. "I definitely do think something like this could happen again," Mr. Ricci said. "But not there. That's one of the more secure places at present."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
One theory on why itseems easier to buy a house in the nation's 'red' zone.

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; Virginia Postrel is the author of "The Future and Its Enemies" and is writing a book on the increasing importance of aesthetics in the economy and society. E-mail: vpostrel@dynamist.com.

 BODY:
ARE there really two Americas, the "red" conservative heartland and the "blue" liberal coasts? Extrapolating from the 2000 election results, political commentators like to think so. The electoral map has morphed into a mental map, a shorthand for different regional cultures.
 But one of the biggest differences between red and blue America may have less to do with cultural attitudes and more to do with family budgets. Buying a house is a lot easier in "red America," for reasons that reflect politics as much as economics. 
 In most of the country, housing is not especially expensive. The median house value is $120,000, according to the 2000 census, and 63 percent of single-family detached homes are valued at less than $150,000.
"The norm is a world in which people are living in houses that are between 1,500 and 2,000 square feet, and they are paying around $120,000 for them, which is darn close to construction costs," said Edward L. Glaeser, a Harvard economist. "The growing edge cities of America are a world in which land is pretty close to free, and people just build like mad -- economy housing at 60 bucks a square foot. That's the red America world."
Construction costs do not vary that much nationwide. Even in New York City, new construction runs only about $110 a square foot in a typical apartment building of 8 to 24 stories. That would imply a price of $165,000 for a new 1,500-square-foot apartment, something New Yorkers can only dream of.
So why is housing affordable in most places and so expensive in others? Professor Glaeser and Joseph E. Gyourko at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania examined this question in a new working paper for the National Bureau of Economic Research. (The paper can be downloaded at post.economics.harvard.edu/hier/2002papers/HIER1948.pdf.)
The answer obviously has something to do with land prices. One possibility is that land is expensive simply because people really want to live in places like California and New York City. Since the amount of land is fixed, if demand is high, prices will rise.
In test after test, however, the two economists found that demand alone did not explain the difference in prices. For starters, many fast-growing areas did not show skyrocketing house prices.
"There are a lot of high-growth places in North Carolina, Florida, Texas, etc.," Professor Gyourko said. Those places offer amenities like good weather and lots of jobs, he said, but "they don't have high house or land prices."
In their paper, the economists compared two ways of looking at the price of land. Suppose you want to calculate the value of a quarter-acre. One way is to take the difference in price between a house on a quarter-acre lot and the same house on a half-acre lot. A second way is to take the price of a house on a quarter-acre and subtract the construction cost of the building, leaving just the value of the land.
In an unrestricted land market, those two prices should be about the same, since each represents the value of a quarter-acre of land. When the economists did the two land-price calculations using statistical controls and a large set of housing data, however, they found very different results in places where housing is particularly expensive.
In Los Angeles, for instance, going from a quarter-acre to a half-acre lot for the same house costs about $2.60 a square foot, or roughly $28,000. But a quarter-acre lot with a house on it, minus the cost of the house, comes to almost 12 times that -- $30.44 a square foot, or about $331,000.
The difference represents the value of the right to build. Going from a quarter-acre lot to a half-acre lot in Los Angeles does not give you the right to build a second house.
The difference between the land prices is the implicit cost of all the local land-use controls, from zoning to the time it takes to get a permit. Some regulations simply raise the cost of building by slowing down the process. Others limit density, making it illegal to subdivide expensive land.
"If I look around me in Cambridge," Professor Glaeser explained, "there are a large number of $3 million houses on one-half of an acre. Cambridge is also filled with $1 million town houses on a 20th of an acre. If you're an enterprising developer, if you're not stymied by zoning regulations, you tear down the $3 million house, you use the half an acre, and you put up 10 town houses."
Presto: You've made $7 million, minus construction costs, and Cambridge has added nine units to meet the rising demand for housing. If land could be subdivided, that sort of process would happen whenever land prices became high.
But it cannot happen in Cambridge, or most other places in "blue America," because of land-use regulations. The result is soaring prices.
That's fine, of course, with people who already own their homes. "The overwhelming political story is that the majority of homeowners have absolutely no interest in there being affordable housing," Professor Glaeser noted. "The overwhelming reason that we have the web of zoning controls that we have is that local homeowners are powerful over their local areas, and they want to make their housing as expensive as possible."
In undeveloped areas, the political dynamic is different. "There's some farmer named Bob who's very eager to have his land subdivided, and he's the voter," Professor Glaeser said.
On reflection, however, his co-author suggested that perhaps there is more to it than voters acting in their economic self-interest. Places like Charlotte, N.C., and Las Vegas seem able to grow and grow without ever setting off land-use protectionism.
"Outside of the coastal areas of California and the Amtrak Northeast Corridor, you don't see this phenomenon," Professor Gyourko said. "It may be that the civic culture is really different in those areas." Maybe there really are two Americas. "One allows development, and the other puts a lot of restrictions on it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A subdivision in suburban Las Vegas, a fast-growing region of the country. A new study suggests housing is more affordable where there are fewer land-use restrictions. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Military Suppliers and Financial Companies Lead Climb

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Military contractors and financial companies led shares higher yesterday.
 Boeing and United Technologies paced the Dow Jones industrial average after a trade journal reported that the Pentagon would loosen restrictions on the profits its suppliers could earn. 
 "Today is kind of a snapshot of what's occurred in the first quarter," said Rimas M. Milaitis, who manages the $900 million Strong Growth and Income Fund. "Everyone has attempted to anticipate an economic recovery, buying the cyclical stocks." 
The Dow rose 73.55 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,426.91.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 6.09 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,144.58, with financial shares, like the Citigroup stock, accounting for more than one-third of the gain.
The Nasdaq composite index added 2.58 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,826.75.
Three stocks rose for every two that fell on the New York Stock Exchange while advancing and declining shares were about even on the Nasdaq.
Optimism about the economy has surged in recent weeks. That has helped the shares of manufacturers, basic materials companies and energy producers, Mr. Milaitis said.
The Dow has risen 4.1 percent this quarter, led by General Motors' 24 percent rise. Boeing is the second-biggest gainer, adding 22 percent.
The S.& P. 500 has lost 0.3 percent in the quarter, heading toward what would be its sixth losing quarter in the last eight. The Nasdaq has dropped 6.3 percent so far this year.
Boeing, the largest aerospace company, rose $1.54, to $47.33, and United Technologies, which makes Pratt & Whitney jet engines, advanced $1.75, to $73.75. They were the two biggest gainers in the Dow.
Lockheed Martin advanced 92 cents, to $58.15, near a record high.
The trade journal, Defense Daily International, reported that the Defense Department might allow contractors to earn greater profits. The Pentagon currently caps profit margins at 15 percent.
Among the financial stocks that advanced, Citigroup, the biggest financial services company, gained 85 cents, to $50. American Express, the fourth-largest credit card issuer, climbed 59 cents, to $41.19, and the insurer American International Group added 70 cents, to $72.29.
Oil stocks rallied after oil inventories had their biggest decline since October. Exxon Mobil rose 21 cents, to $43.95. United States shares of Royal Dutch Petroleum gained 65 cents, to $54.10, and ChevronTexaco added $1.50, to $90.50.
Home-building stocks declined after a Commerce Department report showed new-home sales rose less than expected in February.
Toll Brothers lost $1.61, to $50.90; Beazer Homes USA fell $2.81, to $79.30; Lennar dropped $2.20, to $53.45; D. R. Horton lost $1.51, to $38.25; and Centex fell $1.49, to $52.98. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 By Reuters
 Treasury bond prices rose for a second session yesterday as recent comments by Federal Reserve officials soothed worries that the central bank might soon raise interest rates.
A $25 billion auction of new two-year notes -- matching the record size of recent months -- met with the best demand in three months. The Treasury auctioned the new two-year note that was priced to yield 3.705 percent, nearly two percentage points above the 1.75 percent federal funds rate. By late in the day, in when-issued trading, the note's price rose enough to lower the yield to 3.655 percent.
The price of a 10-year note was unchanged at 96; its yield was 5.34 percent. The 30-year bond fell 3/32 , to 94 21/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposition direction from the price, rose to 5.76 percent from 5.75 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: PBS Scrambles to Pull Together 'Wall Street Week' 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
For the next few months, "Wall Street Week" without Louis Rukeyser may look more like a reunion of cast members rather than the updated financial talk show that PBS executives have in mind.
 After Maryland Public Television dropped Mr. Rukeyser as the host of the Friday evening program he created 32 years ago, its producers had to scramble to pull together a cast in a hurry. This week's program was scheduled to be taped today instead of tomorrow because of the Good Friday holiday. 
 They could not choose among the 22 analysts and money managers who made regular appearances alongside Mr. Rukeyser. That group, showing allegiance to Mr. Rukeyser, who hopes to have a program elsewhere on television, banded together and decided not to participate, two of them said.
Catherine Wood, a money manager who had been scheduled to be Mr. Rukeyser's featured guest this week, also backed out. Ms. Wood did not return calls seeking comment.
Mr. Rukeyser, 69, balked last week at the station's plan to revamp the program and bring in new co-hosts to attract more and younger viewers. After announcing that he would end his involvement with the program when his contract expired in June, Mr. Rukeyser criticized the station's handling of the change at the start of last week's program, calling it an "ambush."
On Sunday, the station said it had dismissed him for those remarks, saying that he had "violated the journalistic standards of the show."
So, starting Monday, the producers had to replace a host, a guest and find three new panelists who would travel to a studio in Owings Mills, Md., to tape the 30-minute program. In a pinch, they rounded up what may be the oldest cast the program has ever had.
Marshall Loeb, 72, a former managing editor of Fortune and Money magazines who writes for "CBS MarketWatch", will be the host. The three panelists will be Julius Westheimer, 84, a former stockbroker in Baltimore who writes about personal finance; Bernadette Murphy, a longtime technical analyst who said she "was retired" from the show a couple of years ago after appearing on it for 23 years; and James Grant, 55, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
"It seems like a strange way to start the youth movement -- with three dinosaurs," said Mr. Grant, who appeared on the program from 1987 to 1997.
Mr. Grant said that he did not feel the need to pick a side in the breakup between Mr. Rukeyser and Maryland Public Television. "I'm a friend of both the husband and the wife of this divorced couple," he said.
For a featured guest, the station turned to Gus Sauter, who manages indexed stock mutual funds for the Vanguard Group. Mr. Sauter, who at 47 will be the youngest person on the program, eagerly accepted the invitation because he thought the format of "Wall Street Week" would give him time to explain the benefits of indexing, said Brian Mattes, a Vanguard spokesman.
Jeff Hankin, vice president for marketing at Maryland Public Television, said that Ray Brady, a retired economics correspondent for CBS News, had agreed to fill in as a host while the station revamps the program. It was scheduled to have its debut in the fall as "Wall Street Week With Fortune" with Geoffrey Colvin of Fortune magazine as the co-host. But Mr. Hankin said the producers now hoped to have it ready by late June.

HEADLINE: Tbilisi Journal; 
In Post-Soviet Georgia, Sweet Stench of Success

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, March 26 

 BODY:
This town stinks. For that, Giya Khiazaneishvili gives thanks.
 From a second-floor office suffused with the rank, faint fragrance of decaying eggs, Mr. Khiazaneishvili happily counts his blessings: seven days a week of business; 85 customers a day, on average; at least 10 lari, or about $4, per customer -- often twice that. 
 All for the coveted, if difficult-to-explain, pleasure of an hour's soak in a marble tub of steaming, malodorous sulfur water.
"I'm not sorry for it," he said between drags of a long, thin cigarette. "All the city's here."
He exaggerates, but not by much. Having survived near-fatal brushes with Communist engineers and capitalist economics, Tbilisi's famed sulfur baths are enjoying a spirited resurgence. Whereas a decade ago there were perhaps 15 sulfur baths serving the city's 1.4 million or so residents, today there are scores of them, from the sprawling bathing palaces of Tbilisi's ancient center to little two- or three-tubbers in the ticky-tacky suburbs.
One could attribute this to growing wealth (unlikely; the average teacher's monthly paycheck might buy a five-hour soak). Or consider the obvious: since Georgia's economy collapsed in the mid-90's, taking the city's decrepit heating plants with it, most Tbilisi homes have had no hot water. A hot soak is much in demand. 
But Mr. Khiazaneishvili believes otherwise. He argues that Georgians' post-Soviet entrepreneurship and the legendary powers of sulfur have combined to return the city's residents to the centuries-old habit of filling lungs and pores with hot, noxious fumes. 
"It has a curing effect," he said. "It helps all the joint diseases, like rheumatism, and it helps with skin diseases. Some people even drink it. They claim it's good for your stomach." 
Like a lot of Tbilisi's sulfur-bath lore, this may or may not be true. Consider their origin: Tbilisi's warm sulfur springs -- even the city's name comes from the Georgian word for "warm" -- were first noted in chronicles written in the ninth century, by Arabs who then ruled Georgia.
But Georgians cling to a less prosaic tale of their discovery. It seems that the fifth-century Czar Vahtang Gorgasaly was hunting when his falcon dropped a captured bird. Servants later found it in a bubbling spring, boiled and ready to serve.
Deeply impressed, the czar decided to move Georgia's capital there. His 16th-century successor erected a grand bathing complex on the site.
If that seems fanciful, no one disputes the original splendor of the domed bathing complexes, near the Kura River in downtown Tbilisi. "Not since my birth have I witnessed such luxuriousness as at the Tbilisi baths," the great Russian writer Aleksandr S. Pushkin wrote in 1829.
More than two decades later, the French author Alexander Dumas spent six weeks in Tbilisi, most of it, being washed, massaged or dipped in tubs of stinking water.
"My lungs were incapable of inhaling those fumes," he wrote in "Caucasus," his 1853 travel book. "I had to get used to it gradually, having left the door ajar and creating a kind of mixed atmosphere for myself." 
He quickly adjusted. "Why does not Paris, the city of physical pleasures, have such baths?" he lamented.
At their height, there were more than 140 sulfur bathhouses here, big pools for the great unwashed to cozier retreats for the rich.
But in later Soviet days, they began to decline. Mr. Khiazaneishvili said they nearly vanished in the 1970's when teams of engineers, drilling for oil and tunneling for Tbilisi's subway, set off collapses that led Czar Gorgasaly's original springs to dry up altogether.
Workers later drilled wells as deep as 10,000 feet to find the sulfur-water sources that now sustain the original baths. 
Much of the ritual Dumas described remains a part of the Tbilisi bath tradition today. A first-class visit includes a prolonged soak in warm water -- between 85 and 105 degrees -- followed by a rubdown by a "scrubber," a hefty man with a bucket of sulfur water and a coarse loofah with which he reduces a customer's skin to little wads of damp dough.
There follows a soap bath, a coating of thick, silky suds rubbed gently into the newly exfoliated body. A quick, warm shower, and the client is ready for tea -- or, perhaps, another warm bath. 
The czar's baths, since parceled out by the government to private owners, remain the biggest, most famous and most lucrative. Mr. Khiazaneishvili, a bath administrator for Tbilisi's city council in Soviet days, claimed a chunk of them. including a fantastic 500-year-old Arabic-style building that sits above the tubs. 
"It's all the original structure," he said. "Much has been restored, but a lot is still operating."
Alas, much of the grandeur that Dumas celebrated has faded. Ten lari admits one to the public bath, a dreary communal affair. A typical 20-lari bath is a closet-sized room of once-white marble, yellowed by sulfur and age, little changed since Brezhnev's days.
Then again, 60 lari, or about $24, commands a sumptuous, fully restored bath, with an anteroom, a sauna, hot and cold tubs and a marble bed for the scrubber's work. 
In Tbilisi, that is a lot of money. Needless to say, Mr. Khiazaneishvili believes it is worth it. 
"Of course, you can heat water and wash yourself at home. Maybe it is even more convenient. But here," he said, utterly deadpan, "the atmosphere is different."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A "scrubber," Natik Imam-Kuli, pouring hot sulfur water on a marble bed at the Khiazaneishvili baths in Tbilisi, Georgia. The baths are housed in a 500-year-old building elaborately decorated in Persian mosaic. HEADLINE: Judge Moves to Speed Along Lawsuit Over Managed Care 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
A federal judge in Miami has allowed a group of managed care companies that have been accused of fraud to ask an appeals court for an immediate ruling on whether they are open to racketeering claims, a move that lawyers for both sides said could speed a final decision.
 The judge hearing the case, Federico A. Moreno of Federal District Court, ruled last month that the lawyers who represent health plan subscribers could proceed with claims of fraud under the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act against Aetna, Cigna and United Healthcare. Humana is also a RICO defendant under an earlier ruling. 
 The plaintiffs contend that the health maintenance organizations violated the racketeering law by conspiring to withhold medical care and by not telling H.M.O. members that doctors were rewarded financially for doing so.
The insurance company lawyers said the RICO claims, on behalf of millions of health plan subscribers, should be dismissed. That view was upheld two years ago by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia.
In his latest ruling, issued late Tuesday, Judge Moreno agreed with the defendants that the RICO issue raised an important legal question, "whether a managed care subscriber who has not actually been denied care can state a claim under RICO," and said the issue could be sent at once to the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta. By resolving the issue, the appeals court would "permit the parties to avoid unnecessary, protracted and expensive litigation," he said.
For one thing, the defendants might not have to open insurance company records for examination by the plaintiffs' lawyers. Miguel Estrada, a Washington lawyer for Aetna, said that without the racketeering claims, the lawsuits "basically shrivel up."
"There's very little left of the case," he added.
But Stephen Neuwirth, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said that "if there is misrepresentation of the coverage when you buy an insurance policy, you can overpay" and suffer economic damage. He said a ruling by the appeals court could "validate our claim going forward." 
Earlier this month, the appeals court in Atlanta upheld several rulings by Judge Moreno in a separate group of suits on behalf of doctors. Those suits also made RICO claims against the H.M.O.'s. The judge had said some of the claims should be settled by arbitration and others by litigation. 
The judge has not yet ruled on requests by the plaintiffs to have both sets of cases declared class actions.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Rise in Much of the U.S. 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
Good weather motivated people to house hunt and favorable financing moved them to lock in deals, spurring a solid increase in new-home sales in February.
 The Commerce Department reported today that sales of new single-family homes last month came to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 875,000, a 5.3 percent increase over January's level. 
 Buying a house is often followed by significant spending in areas like furniture and appliances. Given that, economists are optimistic that consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States, will hold up fairly well in coming months and speed national economic recovery. 
"There's a tremendous multiplier effect of buying a home," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at Argus Research. "Step 1 is buying a home. Steps 2 through 5 are putting things in it and redecorating."
By region, new-home sales rose 9.9 percent in the South, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 410,000 in February. In the West, sales went up 6.7 percent, to a 240,000 pace. But Northeast sales fell 10.1 percent, to a pace of 62,000, and in the Midwest, sales dipped 0.6 percent, to an annual 163,000.
Economists cited low mortgage rates, good weather, increases in home values and generally good consumer attitudes for helping to lift home sales over all.
The median price of a new home fell 2.4 percent in February from January, to $179,600, but rose about 6 percent from the month a year earlier.
The average interest rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in February was 6.89 percent, down from 7 percent in January, according to Freddie Mac, the mortgage company. But mortgage rates, as tracked by Freddie Mac, have climbed in the last three weeks. The average rate on a 30-year loan rose last week to 7.14 percent.
In January, new-home sales plunged 15.8 percent, a drop that many economists called a fluke and were hard pressed to explain. At the same time, sales of previously owned homes soared to a record. .
Early this week, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of previously owned homes dipped 2.8 percent in February. Still, the annual pace of 5.88 million homes sold was the second-highest monthly level on record.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: BUILDING DESIGN; 
Report Sees Lower Towers That Can Empty Faster

BYLINE:  By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
Whatever is rebuilt on the World Trade Center site must be secure against much more sophisticated bioterrorism attacks than the nation has yet seen and, because of both safety and economics, should be no more than 50 or 60 stories tall, according to a new study by the nation's leading engineering organization.
 The study, by the Construction Institute of the American Society of Civil Engineers, offers a first glimpse of the effect the attacks are likely to have on the physical structure and insurance costs for a renewed trade center and perhaps for other large buildings. 
 The study also recommends that all buildings at the site be designed to accommodate mass evacuations. Until now, the practice has been to assume that just a few floors would be evacuated at a time. 
Any 100-story skyscraper would require extra-wide stairwells to accommodate a mass evacuation, the report says, and the lost floor space would make the buildings unprofitable. The resulting recommendation of shorter heights is sure to be resisted by some architects and others devoted to tall buildings.
The reconstruction of the trade center will be "a kind of primer for the 21st-century engineer," said Robert F. Borg, chairman and founder of the institute's committee on social and environmental concerns and the chief writer of the new study.
"We contractors and engineers are going to be practicing our profession differently now, based on what we've learned at the World Trade Center," said Mr. Borg, who is also chairman of Kreisler Borg Florman, a construction company.
The study, which has been completed but not yet published by the engineering society, presents early indications that the attention to security and safety in anything built on the trade center site will probably be like that in few other existing buildings.
Experts in building construction and design say, however, that those new buildings may not be at all untypical of high rises built anywhere else in the country after Sept. 11. The same experts also say that much of the technology, if not the demand, for making the improvements has been available for years, particularly in the case of protecting against biological and chemical terrorism.
"A lot of these things should be done as a matter of course, should be even mandated," said Bruce Fowle, a partner at Fox & Fowle Architects, the Manhattan firm that built the 48-story high rise at 4 Times Square and is working on the new building for The New York Times on Eighth Avenue.
Expensive as those measures may be at the trade center, they will simply be the cost of doing business, said Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who has rights to the site and wants to rebuild the center. 
"They're going to be buildings which will have a considerably greater factor of life safety built into them than existing buildings," Mr. Silverstein said in an interview Tuesday. The findings of the study are "totally consistent with what one would expect," he said.
Biological and chemical attacks top the list of threats that the new buildings must protect against, according to the report, titled, "Rebuilding the World Trade Center."
The biological attacks of last fall aroused a high level of fear by sending anthrax powder through the mail, but, experts pointed out, it could be more deadly to put the substances directly into a building's ventilation system through an intake vent.
Many buildings are now vulnerable because their intakes are easily accessible and unmonitored, and the filter systems cannot stop the extremely fine particles that carry anthrax and other biological and chemical agents.
"We should think twice about how we bring fresh air into the buildings" built at the trade center site, said Marvin Mass, chairman of Cosentini Associates, a mechanical, electrical and plumbing firm in Manhattan, who was consulted on the report.
Mr. Mass said some buildings near the site, including Stuyvesant High School, had already started installing high-efficiency filters simply to remove fine pollution particles from the indoor air.
It can cost millions of dollars, Mr. Mass said, to fully rework an existing building to filter out all biological and chemical agents, move and monitor intake vents, and keep internal air pressure just high enough to prevent terror agents from being sucked in through the small cracks around windows and doors.
When those measures are woven into the original design, however, the extra costs are far lower, said William Blewett, a mechanical engineer at the United States Army's Edgewood Chemical Biological Center at Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland. Still, some measures, like special charcoal filters to catch certain chemical agents, are likely to be expensive even if they are taken into account in early designs of new trade center buildings, Mr. Blewett said.
The Construction Institute report touches on two dozen other social and environmental issues concerning the rebuilding, from environmental effects of the materials to the construction's effect on regional transportation patterns.
In considering the problems presented by a situation seldom contemplated before last fall -- the sudden need for everyone to leave an extremely tall building at once -- the study says escape stairwells might have to be so wide that there would not be enough real estate left to turn a profit. The report suggests that the solution would be to design lower buildings. 
At the trade center itself, where planners have already declared it unlikely that the reconstruction will involve 110-story towers, that conclusion may cause little controversy. The same may not be true of the report's wider implications.
"We engineers have to think in terms of building heights that may be no longer worth achieving, even though they may be technically feasible," Mr. Borg said.

HEADLINE: Despite Economic Dip, State Needs More Power Plants, Group Says 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 27 

 BODY:
Despite the destruction of the World Trade Center and the economic downturn, New York's appetite for electricity has not slowed significantly, and there is still a dire need for new power plants, the managers of the state's power grid said today.
 The New York Independent System Operator forecast peak demand statewide this summer of 31,475 megawatts, near the high of 31,983 recorded last Aug. 9, when the system was pushed dangerously close to its limits across the Northeast. As in recent years, Long Island will have less breathing room than any other part of the state, followed by New York City. 
 By 2005, New York should build an additional 7,100 megawatts of power supply to ensure reliability, keep prices down and protect air quality, the Independent System Operator projected. That is about 1,000 megawatts less than it said a year ago should be built. The I.S.O. is a nonprofit group formed by the state and power companies to manage the transmission system and hold the auctions in which electricity is bought and sold, daily and hourly. 
William J. Museler, the group's president, said his organization had updated last year's report largely to counter a widespread perception that the Sept. 11 attacks and the slowing economy had put an end to a mounting electric power crisis.
"The reality of the situation is that the energy crisis we talked about last year is still with us," he said. "Things have gotten better in a number of ways, but the fundamental situation which we pointed out is still in front of us."
Power producers and environmentalists, who are often at odds, agreed with the group's conclusion that there remained a strong need to find more sources of power.
"We also believe the energy crisis has not gone away, because it's a long-term thing, not a short-term thing," said Ashok Gupta, an energy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Gavin J. Donohue, executive director of the Independent Power Producers of New York, said, "We need more power plants now."
A major new power plant has not opened in New York for a decade, and a year ago, many people in the industry said the state's creaky process for approving plants was the single biggest obstacle to addressing the supply shortage. That process has since been greatly accelerated, and experts say the biggest problem now is finding financing for new plants in a post-Enron era when power markets are not as attractive to investors.
The state's Siting Board has approved six major projects -- either new plants or significant expansions of existing plants -- that, combined, would increase supply by 3,700 megawatts. Three are in New York City. But none of the six will be completed until next year or later, and at least one is stalled because of financing problems.
Last year, the State Power Authority hurriedly installed 10 miniplants around New York City and one on Long Island, to raise the supply by more than 400 megawatts, and Long Island officials are encouraging installation of more such plants there this year.
During last August's heat wave, the state took a number of steps, like asking big industrial customers to shut down and encouraging hospitals and office buildings to switch to their diesel backup generators, that reduced demand on the grid by up to 1,500 megawatts.
Mr. Museler said the trade center destruction would depress peak demand for power in New York City by 90 megawatts, less than 1 percent of the citywide total, because most of the customers moved elsewhere in the city. That is far less than earlier estimates. 
The I.S.O. also warned that the drought could complicate matters for the power supply this summer, because plants use water for cooling. The agency said that with less melting snow and lower water levels in rivers and lakes, the water would be warmer, and, as a result, more water would be needed to cool the plants.
New York's power plants can deliver up to 36,000 megawatts, more than 4,000 above this year's projected demand. But planners like to have more of a cushion, in case equipment breaks down. Mr. Museler said an additional 7,100 megawatts would also increase competition among suppliers, lowering peak prices by 25 percent.
Environmentalists are also interested in seeing new plants built because they emit a tiny fraction of the pollution created by older plants, are more efficient and might push some of the old ones out of business.

HEADLINE: Short of Money, Boston Drops Lawsuit Against Gun Industry 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 27 

 BODY:
Citing financial concerns, the City of Boston today became the first city in the nation to drop its lawsuit against the gun industry voluntarily.
 The case was scheduled to go to trial in September, but Mayor Thomas M. Menino and the city's health commission called it off today, saying a trial would be too expensive, given the weak economy in the city. 
 The case was expected to be the first to go to trial. The city sued gun manufacturers, distributors and trade groups in June 1999, saying they were responsible for gun violence. 
The suit sought damages for the municipal costs of gun violence. Sixteen similar suits are pending, involving 25 other cities.
"It is a very sad day, but I think Boston is encouraging other cities to carry on, and we think they will," said Dennis Henigan, legal director of the Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence, a Washington organization that helps litigate the suits.
In its suit, Boston cited negligence in marketing and distribution, poor gun design and the failure of the industry to keep guns from criminals. There were 31 defendants, including the manufacturers Taurus International Manufacturing and Glock Inc. Smith & Wesson initially was named, but later settled.
The suit was withdrawn from Suffolk Superior Court, Mr. Menino said, after the sides agreed to a joint resolution that calls for the industry to devote more resources to combating gun violence in Boston.
Gun rights proponents applauded the move.
"It indicates they should have never brought the lawsuit to begin with," said James Baker, the National Rifle Association's chief lobbyist. "It's a lesson that other cities ought to take. Criminals are responsible for their own actions, not manufacturers of legal products."
There have been 21 similar suits in recent years, Mr. Henigan of the Brady Center said, but no city has voluntarily backed out before. Courts have dismissed cases brought by New Orleans, Miami, Bridgeport, Conn., and Camden County, N.J.

HEADLINE: Budget Plan By McGreevey Raises Doubts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 27 

 BODY:
Before presenting his first budget proposal on Tuesday, Gov. James E. McGreevey promised to end the state's bad fiscal habits of excessive borrowing, profligate spending and reliance on one-time measures to increase state revenues.
 But state legislators and Wall Street analysts said today that the $23.66 billion spending plan proposed by Mr. McGreevey included some of the same flaws that have plagued New Jersey's budgets for years: understating the actual amount of state spending, using overly high predictions of state tax revenues and using one-time revenue sources for operating expenses. 
 In political terms, Mr. McGreevey accomplished a difficult balancing act by managing to close a projected $5.3 billion shortfall without resorting to the kind of broad-based sales and income tax increases that led to a taxpayer revolt against a Democrat in 1990. In doing so, however, Mr. McGreevey's plan relies heavily on both borrowing and nonrecurring sources of revenue. Those moves have brought criticism from bond analysts who have been urging the state to take substantive steps to cut spending. 
Officials from the state treasurer's office were scheduled to meet on Thursday with analysts from major bond rating firms to answer questions about the spending plan. While the governor's aides are confident that they can win support for the plan in the State Legislature, where Democrats control the Assembly and the Senate is split 20 to 20, it is not clear whether they can convince bond agencies not to lower the state's bond rating.
At Moody's Investors Service, which downgraded New Jersey's bonds early this month, analysts said Mr. McGreevey deserved credit for promising to close corporate tax loopholes that cost the state more than $500 million in revenue annually.
But Timothy Blake, a municipal analyst for Moody's, said the weakness of Mr. McGreevey's budget plan was that it relied heavily on one-time sources of revenue, from depleting surpluses in several funds for state retirement health benefits to selling bonds against proceeds of a tobacco settlement.
New Jersey's tax revenues have dropped sharply in the last year because of the recession and the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. And its budget deficit ballooned to $3 billion in the fiscal year ending June 30 because of big spending increases by the governor and legislative leaders last year.
"The reason we downgraded was the recognition that in the current political climate, the budget was unlikely to include either a significant tax increase or substantial cuts in spending," Mr. Blake said. "And if you look at this budget, you still have a multiple-year structural budget gap." 
As he described the proposal during his speech before the State Legislature on Tuesday, Mr. McGreevey said he was proud to have presented a balanced budget plan without proposing a major tax increase. He said he had tried to dole out painful cuts to those most able to absorb them: for instance, eliminating property tax rebates for families with annual incomes of more than $200,000 but preserving them for the middle class and expanding them for senior citizens.
"I did not balance this budget on the backs of hard-working families," he said.
The governor also took credit for reining in spending: he made all department heads impose an across-the-board 5 percent budget reduction, froze aid to school districts and municipal governments, and trimmed more than $130 million in capital construction projects.
But budget analysts in Trenton and on Wall street said today that Mr. McGreevey understated the growth in spending, which his budget said rose just 1.5 percent over last year. The actual spending growth proposed in Mr. McGreevey's budget is double that rate, they said, because his proposal does not include $325 million in health care costs that would be paid for by diverting contributions to the unemployment insurance fund. Mr. McGreevey's proposal also compared his proposed spending with last year's budget proposal, rather than the actual expenditures, which were far lower.
Analysts said the budget was also based on several highly optimistic projections. Mr. McGreevey's budget assumes that the state will get $78 million in federal financing for nursing home costs and a senior citizens' prescription drug plan, but no funds have yet been committed. The governor's budget also projects a 6.7 percent rise in personal income taxes, which Colleen Woodell, a managing director of Standard & Poor's, said was among the most optimistic of any state.
Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon, said he was disappointed that Mr. McGreevey had not been able to fulfill his promise to change the state's budgeting process and with its reliance on the tobacco bonds for a one-time infusion of $1 billion. "Our continuing reliance on bonding is, in my opinion, extremely poor governance," he said. "Jim McGreevey did not begin it, but he continues it unabated."
Wall street analysts appeared less troubled by the tobacco bonds than by the state's spending, however. 
Mr. McGreevey's budget does include several measures that will increase revenue in future years. In addition to closing the tax loopholes, he called for $75 million in increased fees for motor vehicle registrations and other state agencies. And his proposal to increase the state cigarette tax to $1.30 a pack, from 80 cents, bringing the average price to $4.50 a pack, will also add $220 million a year to the state treasury.
But New Jersey faces escalating costs for health care, debt service and the state payroll, and it is unlikely that the governor will be able to freeze aid to localities and schools two years in a row. Ms. Woodell said S.&P. had assigned New Jersey a negative outlook early this year but would wait until the final budget was adopted before deciding whether to downgrade the state's bonds.
"In some ways, the tobacco bonds are fine, because it buys them additional time to grow out of its problems or come up with a way to address the issue of long-term spending control," Ms. Woodell said. "But eventually, there is going to have to be more controls on spending."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

Ex-Global Crossing Worker Accused of Making Threats
The F.B.I. arrested a disgruntled former employee of Global Crossing and charged him with using the Internet to post threats to injure or kill company executives and to display personal information, including the Social Security numbers, of nearly 2,000 of the company's employees.
 The arrest ended a five-month investigation into the activities of Steven William Sutcliffe, a 40-year-old former technical support worker at Global Crossing's offices in Beverly Hills, Calif. Federal agents arrested Mr. Sutcliffe in Manchester, N.H. Page C2. 

G.M. to Revive a Muscle Car Icon
General Motors said it was reviving the Pontiac G.T.O., an American muscle car icon, by modifying a sports coupe it sells in Australia. The old G.T.O., whose models spanned from 1964 to 1974, was the first of a string of muscle cars popular in that era that appealed to young men looking for affordable cars with plenty of horsepower. C3.

Mitsubishi Motors is replacing its Japanese president with Rolf Eckrodt, the highest-ranking Mitsubishi executive appointed by DaimlerChrysler, its biggest shareholder. World Business, Section W.

Hospitals Unable to Meet Demand
After years in which they closed beds and laid off workers, many hospitals are struggling to cope with surprising increases in the number of patients. Some are being forced to turn away ambulances. At others, emergency room patients who are admitted wait hours or even days for rooms. A1.

Industry-Tinged Energy Policy
A review of documents released by the Department of Energy showed that several recommendations from energy industry representatives were written into the White House's national energy report and into an executive order signed by President Bush. A18.

Old-Economy Stocks Bolster Dow
Military contractors and financial companies led stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.55 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,426.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 6.09 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,144.58. The Nasdaq composite index added 2.58 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,826.75. C7.

'Wall Street Week' Replacements
For the next few months, "Wall Street Week" without Louis Rukeyser may look more like a reunion of cast members rather than the updated financial talk show that PBS executives have in mind. C7.

Pepsi-Cola has hired Janusz Kaminski, a two-time Oscar winner for photography for "Saving Private Ryan" and "Schindler's List," to direct a commercial for its Sierra Mist lemon-lime soft drink. The spot begins appearing this weekend in theaters. Advertising. C6.

New-Homes Sales Up 5% Last Month
The Commerce Department reported that sales of new single-family homes last month came to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 875,000, a 5.3 percent increase over January's level. Good weather and favorable financing helped buyers lock in deals. The median price of a new home fell 2.4 percent in February from January, to $179,600, but rose about 6 percent from the month a year earlier. C3.

Goldman Appoints Vice Chairmen
The Goldman Sachs Group, one of the biggest and most profitable investment banks on Wall Street, appointed three senior executives to be vice chairmen and promoted other executives to assume their roles. The moves shed light on who might eventually succeed the three men who now run the firm. C7.

Where It's Easier to Buy a Home
A big difference between the "red" conservative heartland and the "blue" liberal coasts may have less to do with cultural attitudes and more to do with family budgets. Buying a house is a lot easier in "red America" for reasons that reflect politics as much as economics. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Not the Best of Times, but Manhattan Hotels See Encouraging Signs 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
At the W Hotel in Times Square one recent evening, Oksana Baiul, the Olympic figure-skating champion from Ukraine, went slinking through the lobby in a short black dress and a pearl necklace. Nearby, John Corbett of HBO's "Sex and the City" was standing close to a real estate developer who was hobknobbing with Elizabeth Jagger, Bridget Hall and other supermodels.
 The hotel staff, decked out in designer clothes, served Champagne and hors d'oeuvres. 
 It did not look like the worst of times.
But few are ready to call it a full rebound. After all, the number of hotel rooms occupied in Manhattan was at its lowest level in seven years this January. But, despite dire predictions after the World Trade Center attack, the frenzied atmosphere at the W Times Square and many other hotels in Manhattan is giving hope to those in the industry. 
The average occupancy rate in February 2002, at 74 percent, was only 1 percentage point lower than it was in February 2001, according to HotelRevMax, a research firm. Other analysts have slightly less rosy numbers, but none suggest the doom-and-gloom scenarios of late last year predicting that occupancy would be down 10 to 15 percentage points.
Analysts and hoteliers say that the increase in business has come at a cost and that the packed hotel rooms mask the lost jobs, deep discounts on room rates and other tough decisions hoteliers have had to make since the attack -- not to mention the coming challenges.
"We are not out of the woods yet," said Guy Hensley, a vice president at Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, which operates the W Times Square. The hotel opened in December and already surprised analysts with a 55 percent occupancy rate in February.
In this environment, it seems the hotels that are a part of larger chains, like the W Hotel in Times Square, are doing much better than their competitors. In bad economic times, industry analysts say, large chains can consolidate certain functions among their hotels to cut costs and use their combined sales resources to grab business from competitors. 
At Grand Hospitality, the owner of the SoHo Grand and the TriBeCa Grand, the owner, Emmanuel Stern, has been able to cut costs by combining corporate sales, reservations, human resources and catering services without eliminating any guest perks. At the Ritz Carlton in Battery Park, which opened in the fall, officials have been able to use its national reservation system to get corporate business travel that seems to be eluding many of its other competitors near ground zero.
At Starwood, which operates five W's in Manhattan and six other hotels, Barry S. Sternlicht, the chairman and chief executive, has personally overseen moves and consolidations intended to cut costs and drive up occupancy without making severe layoffs.
Starwood was able to persuade Lehman Brothers, which was displaced from its offices in the World Financial Center, to take over the entire 655-room Sheraton Manhattan on Seventh Avenue. The 11 Starwood hotels in Manhattan have begun to share human resources and reservations operations. The W Tuscany on East 39th Street even closed for six weeks. As workers took a six-week layoff, Starwood retained many guests by directing them to other W Hotels, where occupancy rates were boosted by the move.
"For us, New York appears to be leading the nation out of the recovery, and there is no question that the scale of the company has helped in the downturn," said Mr. Sternlicht, whose company operates more than 730 hotels in 80 countries.
The W Times Square also hired 400 employees, many of them people who were laid off after the terrorist attack.
According to John Fox, a hotel industry analyst at PFK Consulting, the new demand induced by rate cuts has led to the rehiring of 3,400 of the estimated 5,000 workers laid off after the attack. 
Still, hotels have cut rates so deeply to entice guests that there have been sharp drops in revenues. The average room rate in February 2002 was $202.82 compared with $232.04 last year, according HotelRevMax, and is not expected to recover any time soon. 
The cuts are having the most impact on high-end hotels carrying a lot of debt. At the Bryant Park Hotel, for example, room rates are nowhere near the $550 that it was charging when it opened on Valentine's Day in 2001. Guests can get a room for $199 a night and in some cases less.
"Room rates are basically reset," said Sean Hennessey, director of the hospitality and leisure consulting practice at PriceWaterHouseCoopers. "They are not going to bounce back for a couple of reasons, and those whose business models rely on high room rates to pay off debt and for amenities could be in trouble."
Among the reasons for concern is many companies worked out annual corporate deals in September and October and the city has had trouble attracting international tourists, who tend to spend more money. 
In February, the city's hotels lost an estimated $8 million despite being virtually as full as they were during February 2002.
Mr. Hennessey said that he was troubled by several factors in the coming months and years.
New hotel construction combined with the reopening of establishments shuttered after the attack will add more than 2,200 rooms to the market by November, when a Westin Hotel is scheduled to open at West 43rd Street and Eighth Avenue. Without added demand, this new supply could weaken occupancy rates at other hotels, Mr. Hennessey said.
There is also some concern, particularly downtown, that an estimated to 2 to 2.5 percent of the rooms occupied are being used by Federal Emergency Management Agency workers, displaced residents, volunteers and others connected to the attacks. "There is definitely going to be a be a vacuum at hotels south of 24th Street," Mr. Hennessey added.
Ian Schrager, chairman and chief executive of the Ian Schrager Hotels, which operates the Royalton and the Paramount, said he was most concerned about the fact that room rates had been slashed so deeply and that they were not likely to recover soon. Now he believes that the fear has subsided. "It was unfortunate that everyone had to follow the pack," he said. "Right now, if we had not cut room rates, we would have high occupancy and be able to bring in a lot more money," he said.
But most hotel operators believe that cutting the room rates was the right way to go. They credit the city's convention and visitors bureau, NYC & Company, with pushing discount packages to the regional travelers within 500 miles of the city. The hoteliers also said that the warm weather and lack of snow or rain helped improve the numbers in January and February, two of the toughest months for tourism even in good economic times.
The president of NYC & Company, Cristyne L. Nicholas, who took a three-day trip to Berlin this weekend to promote the city, said she was focusing on getting back international tourists, who tend to spend more money than domestic visitors. Ms. Nicholas cautioned that there was not much money left to spend on tourism-related advertising. 
"Tourism is rebounding quicker than what was forecasted," Ms. Nicholas said. "But we still have a long way to go, and it is not an entirely rosy picture."

HEADLINE: THE SKI REPORT; 
Some Ups and Downs In Winter That Wasn't

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
If anyone needed more evidence that we are living through the most incongruous winter/early spring weather in generations, here are some facts from the last week:
 In urban and suburban areas throughout the country, most golf courses were open and sales for sunscreen and lawn fertilizer were booming. Meanwhile, at Jay Peak in Vermont, there has been four feet of snow in the last three weeks. Oregon's Mount Hood got six feet of snow in 10 days to increase its season total to 526 inches. At Whiteface Mountain in the New York Adirondacks, with recent powder softening the mountain's renowned steep trails, there is a move afoot to change the name to Niceface. 
 For me, this snow-sports season began with a pathetic, largely fruitless search for a single snowy trail during the week after Thanksgiving. Three months later, after plowing my driveway once (and that was only because I was bored), we are having the best snow of the season. Go figure.
There are a few lessons to be learned. To start, regardless of droughts, monsoons or global warming, some of the best skiing and riding of any season will always be in March and April, and the wise and worldly know it. Try, for example, to get a room in Vail, Colo., this weekend.
More significantly, it is clear that nothing about the winter season was what it seemed.
After the Sept. 11 attacks, after the economy soured and after all the warm weather in the Eastern valleys and cities over the winter, most people expected a calamitous season for the ski industry. It will instead turn out to be a decent season, even a good season, for most of the major resorts.
Trade organizations throughout the country, except in the most Western states, are estimating that skier/snowboarder visits will be down 7 to 10 percent from the 2000-1 season. But then that season -- with especially abundant snowfall in the East -- was record-setting. Compared to the 10-year average, last season will probably be above average in terms of skier visits. In some California, Oregon and Washington areas, the season just past may be better than the earlier bonanza.
"It's definitely not been as bad as people probably think," said Dirk Gouwens, president of the Ski Areas of New York State, home to more ski areas (52) than any other state in the nation. "The numbers will be down because a warm December meant a later start, but in some ways costs will go down, too, because they were prepared to make more snow and did not. And it got cold just in time to save the Christmas week business. That was key."
In an interview on Jan. 2, Adam Aron, the chairman and chief executive of the Vail Resorts, was worried that the strong numbers from his resorts during the Christmas/New Year's Day holiday were a mirage. He cautioned that Sept. 11 could have a more lasting effect.
"It turns out that no terrorist is going to stand in the way of people's cherished annual ski trip," Aron said. "Advance bookings were anemic for January and February, and I think Sept. 11 put people in a holding pattern. But in the end, they decided to come."
It is one of the quirks of the ski industry that the largest resorts, the top 20 percent, account for 80 percent of business. So it is these major areas, with their technologically advanced snowmaking, better grooming and savvy marketing, that have had the strongest years. They also have higher elevations. Unquestionably, there have been some sketchy weeks with thin snow cover in the East, but most major areas still got 100 to 200 inches of snow, even if the crocuses have been growing for weeks.
Still, at places like Ski Butternut in Great Barrington, Mass., business was off more than 10 percent. Without question it is the smaller mountains -- Butternut has 22 trails -- that have been hit the hardest. "Visits were down pretty dramatically," Matt Sawyer, Butternut's director of marketing and sales, said.
The ski areas of western Massachusetts, the Hudson Valley of New York and eastern Pennsylvania are much more reliant on consumers driving from nearby cities. "When it's February and 60 degrees in New York City, nobody's thinking about skiing," Sawyer said.
But the plucky, smaller areas have also learned to be resourceful in lean times. They know how to shave costs and are prudent enough to put something extra away after a good year so they can survive the rainy days (no pun intended).
"The community areas are supported by their communities," Greg Sweetser, executive director of the Ski Maine Association, said. "Everyone buys season passes and comes out almost as a matter of civic pride. Even if it's a half a day before taking the kids to basketball practice."
Or, this winter, to the golf course.
But ski areas large and small will endure. It is not easy, like running a farm when the crop is sparse. Both walks of life tend to attract the hardy and hopeful.
"I don't think you're going to see a trend of people closing their doors or anything like that," Sawyer said. "People adjust. We'll be O.K. But we won't be buying new lifts this summer."
As with any sport, the saying applies: wait till next year.
