HEADLINE: Economy's Rock: Homes, Homes, Homes 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Amid the shaky economy of the last couple of years, housing has emerged as the central pillar of support. The market for housing has become less volatile and less prone to oversupply than before; it has also become the Federal Reserve's main lever for reviving the economy.
 "Housing has been a key stabilizer," said Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. 
 From the very beginning of the downturn last year, the housing market has been strong. And that remains true today. In February, sales of new homes grew 5.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 875,000, thanks to good weather and low mortgage rates. Sales of existing homes in February fell only slightly from the record annual pace in January of 6.05 million. 
Housing prices have been increasing faster than general inflation for several years, and they have accelerated in recent months to their fastest real rate of gain in decades.
All this has bolstered consumer spending and helped salve the wounds that the falling stock market inflicted on households.
In trying to explain the resilience of the housing market in the face of rising unemployment, shrinking stock portfolios and a soft economy, economists start with the Federal Reserve. The Fed's sharp cuts in short-term interest rates supported the demand for housing by helping to push mortgage rates down further.
Mortgage rates had already started to fall in late 2000. "The Fed began cutting interest rates aggressively back in January of 2001," said S. Lawrence Yun, a senior economist at the National Association of Realtors in Washington. "The long-term rates pretty much anticipated that move. By that time, mortgage rates had already hit 7 percent."
With help from the Fed all through 2001, rates moved even lower for a time. "Last year mortgage rates were the second lowest on record," Dr. Yun said. According to his calculations, the additional drop in mortgage rates meant that three million more households could afford to pay a mortgage on a new home.
"That's a big cushion" for the housing market, he said, enough to largely allay the effects of more than a million job losses last year.
At the Fed, top officials were clearly aware of the importance of the housing market in countering Wall Street's fall. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told monetary policy experts at a forum in Jackson Hole, Wyo., last summer: "Movements in the prices of some other assets in the economy -- changes in house prices, for example -- have been steadier, less dramatic, but perhaps no less significant."
The strong housing sector supported the economy in two ways. First, it added $2 trillion to $3 trillion to homeowners' wealth, according to calculations by Karl E. Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College and a co-author of "Comparing Wealth Effects: The Stock Market Versus the Housing Market," with John M. Quigley of the University of California at Berkeley and Robert J. Shiller of Yale University. This greater wealth from their real estate holdings encouraged consumers to spend more, Professor Case said.
Second, the rise in housing wealth -- combined with low interest rates -- made last year an especially tempting time to refinance a mortgage and arrange for home-equity loans and lines of credit, which are often priced these days as low as the prime rate.
"People took advantage of the lower rates not just to lower their debt service but to take out equity to support a lifestyle," Mr. DiClemente said.
Was taking on more debt dangerous in the midst of record levels of outstanding consumer credit? Not according to Mr. DiClemente. The debt that is reflected in home equity loans, he said, "is pitted against the most durable type of asset that people have."
As it turned out, the housing market responded so well to the lower rates that it became the main area of the economy where the Fed's actions really gained traction last year. By contrast, business investment continued to shrink despite the decline in interest rates because companies found themselves with so much excess capacity that it made little sense to try to expand.
"The only place where the Fed seems to have had a major impact is in the housing sector," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. And other traditional channels for the effects of monetary policy, like exports and the stock market, did not work much at all. 
In the past, the housing market's strong reaction to changes in interest rates sometimes led to nasty surprises, usually a glut followed by a crash after rates increased or credit dried up. That happened as recently as the late 1980's and the early 1990's. But despite its healthy response to the Fed's rate cuts, the housing market is not as volatile as it once was, economists now say.
"Go back to the 1980's and you can see a case study of excess in real estate," Mr. DiClemente said. "In that case we had major adjustments that held consumers and business back for years."
This time appears to be different, said Dennis R. Capozza, a professor of real estate finance at the University of Michigan. "The experience of the late 80's and early 90's was not wasted on people," he said. "Builders have not responded as aggressively as they have in the past. There hasn't been the oversupply that is typical in this kind of cycle."
Dr. Yun agreed. "The market is much better at anticipating whether or not they are supplying too much," he said.
In addition to lessons of the past, changes in regulations and real estate finance have helped the housing market to achieve greater stability. Among those were the easing of restrictions on the rates banks could pay on deposits and the introduction of flexible mortgage rates to fit consumers' needs.
The securitization of mortgages through the last few decades, which led to bundles of mortgages being traded on financial markets, also made credit for housing easier to attain. These changes have "gradually taken away a major element of cyclicality," in the economy, Mr. DiClemente said.
Even before these changes, the housing market was not like other markets when it came to handling transitory drops in demand.
"The housing market behaves a little differently from other markets on the downside," Professor Case said. "When most markets feel a fall in demand, price falls. The housing market doesn't behave that way, in the short run anyway, because sellers hold out. People won't sell."
Professor Case added that surveys of homeowners show that those who are selling their houses believe they can ride out troubled times in the economy. "If people view it as temporary," he explained, "they're not going to cut their asking prices."
A long-term trend has also been supporting the demand for housing: the growing number of households.
"Average household size has been falling for some time," Professor Capozza said. "The kids move out and get their own apartments. Young college students and new workers, instead of joining up with other similar people and sharing a house, will just get their own when their incomes will support it."
That is contrary to recent anecdotal evidence of hordes of laid-off technology workers moving back in with their parents rather than buying their own homes.
"You can infer what's going on in household formation by the fact that people keep buying the darn things," said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. 
Most economists expect the housing market to stay strong in the coming year, though not as buoyant as in the last five years. Professor Rosen said that rising interest rates, in expectation of credit-tightening by the Fed, could slow the pace of increase in home prices. He expects the level of housing construction and new-home sales to drop about 15 percent by the end of the year and annual gains in house prices to moderate from about 7 percent to roughly 4 percent.
Virtually no one, however, calls the current housing market a bubble, in part because there is very little of the excess supply of unsold homes so common in past economic recessions.
"The rise in housing prices," Mr. DiClemente said, "just pales in terms of what a real housing bubble looks like."

HEADLINE: Patching New Jersey's Budget 

 BODY:
Much like New York's governor, George Pataki, whose proposed budget this year was for a "monsoon," not a mere rainy day, Gov. James McGreevey of New Jersey has used every trick in the book to make his first statewide budget balance. In particular, both governors are using one-time windfalls to fill their financial gaps. In general, it is very bad budgeting to use one-time revenues to pay for expenses that occur every year. But both governors are arguing that because last year was no ordinary year, it required extraordinary remedies. 
 Mr. McGreevey's budget attempts to cope with the bad hand he was dealt on taking over in January. A state that depends heavily on Wall Street was hit not only with the recession but with the devastation on Sept. 11 as well. Moreover, the previous governors and the former legislature went on a last-minute spending spree before they departed their offices. Governor McGreevey's $23.6 billion budget should cut back considerably and ward off what he says is a $5 billion shortfall. 
 Perhaps the most promising aspect of the McGreevey budget is its effort to close loopholes for corporations in the state. He makes the point that 30 of the state's top 50 corporations paid $200 or less in state taxes last year while a few adjustments in the corporate tax code could add $500 million a year to the state's revenues. Some industry leaders in New Jersey howled that jobs would move out of the state as a result of such changes, but it would be hard to find a place nearby where corporations can exist tax-free.
Mr. McGreevey also deferred a plan to increase property tax rebates and canceled those rebates for families with incomes over $200,000, sensible moves that could save the state millions. And he added 50 cents in cigarette taxes, which could increase the state's income by $200 million.
There are still reasons for concern about Mr. McGreevey's budget proposal. He would add $1.1 billion to the state's debt, borrowing against New Jersey's share of the tobacco settlement. And his cutting of state aid to localities would shift more of the tax burden to property owners, even though the state already has the highest property taxes per capita in the nation. But reasonable people will accept his argument that this is an emergency budget, and that the state should allow some financial shortcuts that would be unacceptable in ordinary times.

HEADLINE: Worst Drivers In New York Will Pay More 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
New York state insurance regulators yesterday approved a 19.5 percent rise in auto insurance premiums for people with the worst driving records, but insurance executives said the increase was far less than what was needed.
 The insurers had requested an increase of nearly 80 percent, saying their losses were soaring, mainly because of a steep increase in fraudulent claims. 
 The increase applies to about 350,000 of New York's estimated 8.6 million drivers. But several insurers had increased their rates for most of their customers in New York by an average of 10 to 15 percent around the end of last year, and industry experts said the insurers were likely to ask regulators for additional increases in the coming months. 
New York political leaders look with horror across the Hudson River at New Jersey, for years the most expensive state in the country for auto insurance. Now, industry experts say, New York is threatening to overtake its neighboring state, where premium costs have been a major political issue. Winning that dubious distinction alone would be a stigma for the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki.
Mr. Pataki is seeking re-election this year, and the rising auto insurance costs pose a significant political problem. His administration has to keep premium costs down so as not to offend millions of voters. But the auto insurers say they will either have to raise their prices or consider withdrawing from New York, as they are already doing in New Jersey. 
In New Jersey, several insurers, including State Farm, the biggest auto insurer in the state, say they are pulling out because political leaders will not permit them to raise prices enough to earn profits.
J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said that while fraudulent claims had indeed become a serious problem in New York, the general premium increases seemed "slightly high." He said the request for an increase of 80 percent for drivers with poor records was "incredibly high." Mr. Hunter, a former insurance commissioner in Texas, said that a general increase of 8 to 10 percent was probably sufficient.
He said the administrators of state-organized programs around the country for drivers with poor records "tend to overreach" when requesting price increases. "They ask for 80 percent when 20 percent or 25 percent would do," he said.
The number of drivers in what is known as the assigned risk plan for those with poor records has doubled in two years to the present 350,000 drivers. They pay roughly 50 percent more for their coverage than most drivers, industry experts said. Most drivers in New York State pay about $1,000 a year, but coverage can be much more expensive in New York City. And drivers in the city and in other urban areas account for a disproportionate share of those in the assigned risk plan.
The number of drivers in the plan has been growing because insurers, unable to increase prices as much as they say is necessary, have been tightening their rules for coverage to include only the most profitable customers. Until recently, insurers were willing to sell policies to people with perhaps one or two small accidents. Now they are refusing them coverage, forcing those drivers into the assigned risk plan.
The insurers also want to see prices increased in the assigned risk plan because, under state law, they share the cost of the coverage among themselves. If the plan loses money, as it has for the last few years, the insurers lose money.
Robert P. Hartwig, the chief economist of the Insurance Information Institute, said that insurers push customers into the assigned risk plan, expecting that its higher rates will cover higher losses from the more risky drivers.
But these days, the plan is paying out far more than it is collecting. So the insurers were hoping for more than the 19.5 percent increase approved by the superintendent of insurance, Gregory V. Serio.
Joseph Termini Jr., who is in charge of government affairs in New York for the National Association of Independent Insurers, said, "We're disappointed." But he added: "The alternative of not getting any rate increase would have been disastrous."
The growing number of drivers covered under the plan intensifies the political pressure on the Pataki administration. Hoping to reduce those numbers, the insurance superintendent is increasing the size of the plan's administrative board to 27 members from 15. Until now, insurers have had a one-vote majority over agents on the board. Now they will be equal in number and the swing vote will go to a consumer advocate, who is yet to be named.

HEADLINE: Home Insurers Frown on Many Dogs 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
The big Rottweiler was an awesome sight: glistening black fur, 135 pounds of muscle and nearly 6 feet tall when it rose up on its hind legs. Strangers scattered when they saw it coming.
 But Carleton Giles and his wife, Christina, always kept the dog, Cezanne, on a leash, and neighbors on their quiet street in Columbia, S.C., say their pet was invariably gentle and even cuddly. 
 "He's a big baby," said Woody Freeman, who lives next door to the Gileses. "The big joke was the worst he could do, as big as he was, would be to step on your foot while you were playing with him. He is a very friendly dog." 
But Nationwide, which for seven years has sold the Gileses insurance on their home and two cars, was taking no chances. It considers Rottweilers, Dobermans, pit bulls, Presa Canarios, chows and wolf hybrids dangerous, and simply refuses to insure homes where they are kept. Some other insurers also have blacklists of breeds, including Akitas and huskies, which they compile on the basis of both reputation and dog-attack statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Without the insurance, it is almost impossible to get or keep a mortgage.
The danger of big, powerful and often aggressive dogs has been underscored by the fatal mauling of a San Francisco woman in the doorway of her apartment by a neighboring couple's 120-pound Presa Canario. Just last week, one of the dog's owners was convicted of murder, the other of involuntary manslaughter. The day before, a Wisconsin couple were charged with homicide because their six Rottweilers had killed a 10-year-old girl who was playing in their home with their daughter.
But insurers began focusing on the problem of dangerous dogs long ago. Since the mid-1990's, with the growing popularity of aggressive breeds as a result of security concerns, dog attacks have become the biggest single cause of home policy claims, with costs running to more than $300 million a year, said Robert P. Hartwig, chief economist of the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group.
State Farm, Allstate and many other insurers do not have blacklists. Instead, their agents make a judgment call on each dog, regardless of breed, as Nationwide and some other insurers do in cases of breeds that are not on their lists. 
"If the dog is growling or aggressive, that's pretty much a tip-off that you could have a problem dog," said Dan Hattaway, a specialist on home insurance at State Farm.
Mr. Hattaway said State Farm did not think blacklisting of breeds was an effective way to screen for danger. "Simply by naming a breed," he said, "people are screening out a fair percentage of good dogs. Just because someone is a Rottweiler fancier doesn't mean they have a dangerous or aggressive dog."
When Nationwide discovered the Gileses' Rottweiler, during a visit to check possible damage to their roof, it issued an ultimatum: get rid of the dog or give up coverage on the three-bedroom ranch-style home.
For the Gileses, the choice was heartbreaking. They considered Cezanne a part of the family, a big brother and playmate for their 4-year-old daughter, Courtney.
For Nationwide, it was a straightforward business decision.
"We believe these breeds are capable of inflicting damage or causing a loss that is far outside the norm," said Scott Mallasee, a specialist in home insurance at Nationwide.
J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said it made sense for insurance companies to deny coverage because of a dangerous dog. "If you had a dynamite factory in your basement, it would be silly for an insurance company to sell you coverage," Mr. Hunter said. "Likewise if you have a dog that is biting everybody or exhibiting menacing behavior."
But he and others said they objected to denial of coverage on the basis of breed alone. 
"Dogs, like people," Mr. Hunter said, "have a wide range of behavioral patterns and personalities."
Sometimes, veterinarians say, the most troublesome dogs are those that might be least suspected. 
"The most vicious dogs I see are Chihuahuas," said Dr. Kevin Blaes, chief of staff at Banfield, the Pet Hospital of Columbia. "They don't do a lot of damage, but some of them just keep gnawing and biting. And Dalmatians are becoming very aggressive. You don't expect that."
Unlikely though it may seem, tiny dogs sometimes kill. A little over a year ago, for example, a Pomeranian, one of the smallest breeds, jumped onto a bed and killed an infant in a home near Los Angeles. 
At Nationwide, Mr. Mallasee defended his company's policy of discriminating by breed.
"We just don't have the luxury of getting to know the dog to the point where we would believe that this dog does not pose the risk that the breed would indicate," he said.
Nationwide and some other companies also refuse to sell or renew coverage when a dog has attacked someone. But State Farm, the largest insurer of homes, and Allstate, the second-largest, say they will consider selling or continuing coverage even after a dog bite.
"We have to look at the situation," said Michael Trevino, a spokesman for Allstate. "Is the dog really vicious? Is he going to bite again? Or was it just an accident?"
Even at companies that do not blacklist, though, individual agents are often wary. Mr. Giles, a graphics designer, said he had tried to change insurance companies. But because of his big dog, he said, he could not find an agent who would sell him coverage. One who offered coverage, he said, wanted to triple his premium.
Finally he gave Cezanne to Sarah Elkin, a local dog groomer. She agreed that if the Gileses could ever find coverage that would include Cezanne, she would give him back. She lives out in the country in a home without a mortgage. She has no insurance on the house. So the views of the insurance companies are of no concern to her.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carleton and Christina Giles and their 4-year-old daughter, Courtney, pay a visit to Cezanne, a Rottweiler they had to give up at the insistence of their insurer, which blacklists certain breeds of dog. (Travis Bell for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: February Computer Chip Sales Off 35% 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 29 

 BODY:
Worldwide sales of computer chips fell 35 percent in February, declining at the slowest pace since June as chip makers outside Japan got more orders from makers of mobile phones and digital cameras, an industry group said. 
 Sales fell to $10.01 billion from $15.48 billion in February 2001 and were unchanged from the previous month, the group said. 
In January, computer chip sales fell 40 percent, to $10 billion. 
 Demand in the second quarter will be "slightly stronger," and the second half will see "accelerating growth," according to the group, the Semiconductor Industry Association of San Jose.
"Strong consumer spending for mobile phones, DVD's and digital cameras continued to move chip sales slightly upward," the association's president, George Scalise, said in the report. "Although business investment has yet to pick up, consumer confidence and inventory replenishing continue to rise, driving the early stages of the overall recovery." 
Revenue from dynamic random access memory chips, the main memory in personal computers, rose almost 24 percent in February from January because prices increased, Mr. Scalise said. 
Sales in North and South America rose 2 percent in February from January, while sales in Asia- Pacific excluding Japan increased 0.3 percent, the association said. Europe had a 1.5 percent month-on-month drop, and Japan's sales fell 1.2 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Argentines Feel Misled By Foreign Banks in Crisis
With Argentina mired in the worst economic crisis in its history, feelings are running strong against United States banks and other foreign banks that aggressively expanded in the 1990's. Many residents said they had deposited money into the foreign banks, believing it would be safe from Argentina's economic unrest.
 Now those depositors -- saying they have been deceived, cheated and lied to -- are threatening legal action. Their accounts have been converted into pesos and have lost more than two-thirds of their value. For their part, bankers say they have been hamstrung by government regulations. Page C3. 

Personal Spending and Income Rise
Two government reports offered additional evidence that the economy was gathering momentum. Consumer spending increased 0.6 percent in February, the Commerce Department said. In addition, personal income rose at its fastest pace since December 2000, also increasing 0.6 percent in February. Both figures surpassed the expectations of analysts. C3.

Plastics Recycling Loses Steam
The plastics recycling industry is caught in a Catch-22. Manufacturers that want to use recycled plastics say they cannot get enough high-quality material at a reasonable price. But companies that recycle the plastic say they cannot guarantee such a stream until sales grow enough to drive down costs. C2.

Study Faults Oil Drilling in Refuge
A federal study said that drilling in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge could harm wildlife in the 19-million acre refuge. The study undercuts the Bush administration's efforts to allow drilling in the refuge; its release comes just days before the Senate is scheduled to begin debate on the matter. A12.

Car Insurance Rises in New York
New York state regulators have approved a 19.5 percent increase in premiums for auto insurance for people with the worst driving records. The increase affects about 350,000 of the state's 8.6 million drivers. B1.

Visa Ordered to Release Records
A federal judge has ordered Visa to turn over information on offshore accounts held by Americans suspected of tax evasion. The order is part of a federal investigation of Americans who hide their incomes in offshore banks and live off credit cards in the United States. C2.

Japanese Stocks Fall as Year Ends
Japanese stocks fell sharply on the last day of trading for Japan's fiscal year. The Nikkei index fell 308.17 points, to 11,024.94, and finished the fiscal year down 15.2 percent. Most markets around the world were closed and will reopen on Monday. C3.

Two large Japanese banks said they would cut the interest rate they pay on savings accounts to 0.001 percent, one-twentieth of the already tiny 0.02 percent they pay now. For the banks, taking in deposits has become less attractive; with the country in a recession, there is little demand for loans. C3.

Kmart's Sales Fell After Court Filing
Providing the first financial details since filing for bankruptcy in January, Kmart said that it had lost $753 million in the five weeks after it sought protection. While its sales dropped 11 percent in February, sales at a rival, Wal-Mart, increased 10 percent. C3.

Baker Hughes Faces Investigations
Baker Hughes, the oil field services company, said the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department were investigating accusations of a kickback involving a contract in Nigeria. C5.

Goldman Warned of Possible Charge
The Securities and Exchange Commission has told the Goldman Sachs Group that it may pursue a complaint against the firm stemming from the early disclosure of the Treasury Department's plans to retire the 30-year bond, a person close to the firm said. C5.

U.S. Takes Over LTV Pensions
The government's pension insurance program will take over three underfinanced retirement plans covering 82,000 workers and retirees of LTV, the troubled steel company. C5.

Chip Sales Fell in February
Computer-chip sales fell 35 percent in February, declining at the slowest pace since June, an industry group said. Sales fell to $10.01 billion, from $15.48 billion in February 2001. C2.

HEADLINE: Between a City and Some Villages, a Proposed Mall, and So Much More 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: PELHAM, N.Y., March 29 

 BODY:
On the surface, the dispute was over a sewer line and whether the Westchester County executive had the power to authorize its relocation without the County Legislature's approval.
 But when a state judge dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that had been brought by seven county legislators, he may have removed one of the last obstacles to a fiercely contested $45 million mall proposal that has pitted the struggling city of Mount Vernon against the more genteel villages of Pelham and Pelham Manor. 
 Mount Vernon has sought for years to develop 15 acres straddling Sandford Boulevard, just a few blocks from the Pelham border, in an effort to inject some much-needed cash into the city's coffers. But Pelham protested, and the dispute has centered on the usual suspects of suburban development battles: traffic and sprawl. 
The struggle has revealed some of the perceived class frictions involved when a big city with a large minority population goes up against its upper-crust neighbors. Because the proposed shopping center is a mere football pass from the Pelham public schools and athletic fields, the tone of the dispute has risen to a virtual wail, with schoolchildren held out as Exhibit A.
"If this geographic boundary was moved a quarter mile down the road," said Terrence F. Martell, the Pelham school board president, "and Pelham High School was Mount Vernon High school instead, I can assure you they wouldn't be putting up a mall a couple of yards away in an area that is already heavily trafficked."
Mount Vernon's mayor, Ernest D. Davis, who calls Pelham a "closed community" because of its scarcity of affordable housing, accused the project's opponents of arrogance and insensitivity.
"How dare they be so arrogant as to try to dictate what another city, a major city, does with its property," he said, referring to a series of lawsuits that failed to stop the project.
"Mount Vernon is not a closed community," Mr. Davis said. "We have special needs here. We have people who can't afford to live in Pelham. We don't have a strong tax base by which to provide the services that our people sorely need."
Last year the Legislature delayed the 285,000-square-foot shopping center by holding up an approval that the developer, G & S Investors of Old Bethpage, N.Y., needed to move the sewer line, which crosses the site. But County Executive Andrew J. Spano secured a permit through the Board of Acquisition and Contracts, which he oversees.
Seven county legislators, complaining that Mr. Spano had done an end run, sued to avoid the permit. They were joined by the town of Pelham, the villages of Pelham and Pelham Manor and the Pelham school district. Judge W. Denis Donovan of State Supreme Court ruled this week that the entire 17-member Legislature would have to challenge the permit approval.
Mr. Davis said today that the city could now move forward, realizing its dream of creating $4 million in annual sales tax revenue and 400 jobs, as well as "establishing Mount Vernon as an economic hub for Westchester County."
But Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democratic county legislator, said he would urge his fellow lawmakers to appeal the ruling. He called the development, which is to include a Best Buy and a Target, "the wrong project in the wrong place," adding that it would lead to the "further deterioration of downtown Mount Vernon and the destruction of the good neighborhoods of the Pelhams."
Today Mr. Davis accused Mr. Abinanti of forming an "unholy alliance" with representatives of the Pelham area. Mr. Abinanti's district includes Greenburgh, which has been waging its own struggle against Yonkers over a big-box development on the Greenburgh border. 
"You have to ask why are they doing this," Mr. Davis said. "I think it's a mass design to try to stop Yonkers from developing and Mount Vernon from developing."
Art L. Scinta, the mayor of the village of Pelham, said the two villages, the town of Pelham and the Pelham Union Free School District, had spent "hundreds of thousands of dollars" trying to ease potential traffic problems from the future project.
Among other things, officials proposed changing the location of exits off the Hutchinson River Parkway, which runs by the site, to keep cars from whizzing past the Pelham schools. "Unfortunately if you don't have cooperation from the other side, none of these will go anywhere," Mr. Scinta said.
Opponents also object to the retail complex on grounds that part of the site is technically listed as parkland on city maps. And they point to the troubled projects G & S has undertaken in the past, like a Home Depot on Long Island that was abandoned because of structural flaws.
But by far the biggest concern is traffic. "We're talking about a project that will draw two million cars a year," Mr. Scinta said. "Most of those cars need to travel on Pelham roads to get to the project, and those Pelham roads go right past our middle school, high school, library and athletic fields."
Mr. Davis said he hoped the shopping center brought more traffic. ("If you don't have traffic, you've got a problem," he said.) But he insisted that the project would actually make the area around the schools safer. "It will compel us to have signals and crosswalks where the children can safely cross," he said.
For their part, Pelham officials seem to resent the mayor's many references to class divisions. "Energy could be better spent trying to work together to find a solution to this problem," Mr. Scinta said, "instead of exchanging words of warfare."

HEADLINE: The Wimps Of War 

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH; E-mail: frankrich@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Here's how bad things are for the Democrats. During the last town meeting of liberals that still convenes on network television -- Hollywood's Oscar ceremony -- no one, not even the tag team of Barbra Streisand and Robert Redford, had so much as a mildly critical word to say about George W. Bush. But Nathan Lane scored one of the night's few laughs when he saluted movie animators for "creating the illusion of life -- something that was never achieved with Al Gore."
 Such is the torpor of the Democrats these days that Mr. Gore's shaving of his beard is what passes for a galvanizing party event worthy of national polls (62 percent were pro-shave) and desperate '04 prognostication on CNN. Even the Democrats' rare legislative victory, the passage of the campaign finance bill, was robbed of its glory when the party chairman, Terry McAuliffe, almost simultaneously announced a record soft-money donation of $7 million from the "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" mogul, not to mention a spring Apollo Theater fund-raiser at which Bill Clinton will be paired with Michael Jackson, fresh from his photo op at Liza Minnelli's wedding. 
 If the Democrats stand for anything in a time of rapidly expanding war, it's not clear what it is. Hours before the Passover massacre in Netanya, President Bush could assert that the latest diplomatic foray by Gen. Anthony Zinni was "making very good progress" with little worry that any Democratic leader would challenge him. The incoherence and indolence of the Bush "policy" in the Middle East, which kept General Zinni out of the region for three months of violent meltdown and ultimately rendered Dick Cheney a supplicant to Yasir Arafat, has been more forcefully dissected by conservatives like George Will than anyone in the administration's opposition. At home, the Democrats can't even offer a serious alternative to the Bush budget for the simple reason that they helped give away the store by abetting the administration's mammoth tax cut last summer and made no legislative push for even partial rollbacks after the fiscal world changed on Sept. 11.
The explanations for this fecklessness start, of course, with the president's poll numbers. Democrats are so intimidated by them that a recent open memo co-written by James Carville found hope that Mr. Bush was "falling back to earth" in a survey showing that his approval rating had tumbled from 82 percent in December to a March low of . . . 75. Compounding the Democrats' fear of a popular president is the Republicans' calculated rollout of a strategy branding anyone who questions the administration as "giving aid and comfort to our enemies" (the phrase actually used by Tom Davis of Virginia, the head of the G.O.P.'s House campaign committee).
This strategy was codified by Karl Rove in a January speech to the Republican National Committee inviting his party to politicize the war in an election year because Americans "trust the Republicans to do a better job" of "protecting America." But the impugning of the opposition's patriotism began only two months after Sept. 11, when the Family Research Council ran ads in South Dakota likening Tom Daschle to Saddam Hussein because the Senate majority leader had opposed oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. In late February, when Mr. Daschle raised a few mild, common-sense cavils about the next stage of the war, Trent Lott fired back, "How dare Senator Daschle criticize President Bush while we are fighting our war on terrorism?" Since then, President Bush's image and voice have graced negative TV and radio ads in which firefighters and flags are used as props and incumbent Senate Democrats are demonized as partisans who will "put their interests ahead of national interests." 
Such tactics are sufficiently ugly that two Republican senators who, unlike Mr. Lott, didn't take deferments during Vietnam, John McCain and Chuck Hagel, were moved to defend Mr. Daschle's right to question war policy after the minority leader's attack. So was another Vietnam vet, Colin Powell. But except for a speech given in New Hampshire by John Kerry, a presidential candidate inoculated against charges of treason by his own Vietnam heroism, no Democrat has articulated a muscular alternative wartime political vision to the president's. As Nicholas Lemann reports this week in his compelling New Yorker account of the White House run-up to a planned removal of Saddam, the administration is now using Sept. 11 "as the occasion to launch a new, aggressive American foreign policy that would represent a broad change in direction rather than a specific war on terrorism." Where is the debate? 
It's an index of the general sheepishness of Democratic leaders that such sporadic tough talk as there is usually emanates by default from either the clownish Mr. McAuliffe or the cranky Senate octogenarians Robert Byrd and Ernest Hollings. It's a measure of how compromised leading Democrats are by their own ties to Enron, Global Crossing and the accounting industry that the heavy lifting in pursuing Mr. Cheney's secret energy task force and the dubious Enron dealings of the secretary of the Army, Thomas White, has often fallen to the House's Henry Waxman, who doesn't have the power to call his own hearings. 
As for Mr. Gore, America's "president in exile," in the hopeful formulation of the best-selling populist Michael Moore, his most pointed remarks are served up to rich paying customers at fund-raisers. Our country has seen more spirited political back-and-forth over the merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq and the factual verisimilitude of "A Beautiful Mind" than it has over a $48 billion defense-budget increase (itself larger than the entire defense budget of any other nation) or our uncertain policy for stabilizing Afghanistan so that the victory by Mr. Bush and our armed forces over the Taliban isn't usurped once more by Al-Qaeda-breeding chaos.
Trent Lott did nail his adversaries correctly on one score. "When you don't have anything substantive to talk about," he said, "you start talking about process or how you need more information." This fits the Democrats' one bold but almost substance-free stand of late -- the threat to subpoena Tom Ridge if he won't formally testify before Congress about what he's up to as director of homeland security. Would Mr. Ridge really have much to say even if he did testify? His biggest function seems to be to supply gags to late-night comics with his color-coded alert system. The man who has by far the most clout over domestic security (and much else) is John Ashcroft, who continues trying to grab authority from other agencies (from the Treasury Department to the Federal Trade Commission), not to mention extra-constitutional power, with even less resistance from Democrats than they mustered against his appointment in the first place. 
Last week, in a typical stroke of grandstanding designed to deflect us from his stalled anthrax investigation and other hapless efforts to find terrorists within our borders, the attorney general announced that he would haul in thousands more men for questioning. He hopes we'll forget that his previous dragnet produced no Sept. 11-related arrests and, according to officials consulted by USA Today, "little usable intelligence about terrorism." 
Mr. Ashcroft couldn't even find half of the nearly 5,000 subjects he intended to interview in that previous roundup, but not until there was universal outrage this month over the I.N.S.'s posthumous granting of visas to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers did he decide "to move up the timetable" for the agency's reform (as a Justice Department official delicately put it). This week Mr. Ashcroft made yet another move that puts his own political posturing ahead of the war on terrorism by seeking the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui. Few legal experts believe that the courts will uphold a death sentence for an indirect participant in the attacks (Mr. Moussaoui was already in jail on Sept. 11), but by overreaching anyway Mr. Ashcroft has given the French government grounds to withhold evidence needed to prosecute the case. 
It isn't treason for a party out of power in wartime to talk about these matters. If anything, it's the Democrats' patriotic responsibility not just to hold up their end of the national dialogue over the war's means and ends, but to say where they want to take the country in peace. Yet now that they've capitulated on issues ranging from fuel-economy standards to gun control, the sum of a Democratic social vision these days often seems to have dwindled down to a prescription drug program for Medicare patients. For the party itself, however, nothing short of a spine transplant may do.

HEADLINE: 3 Months in Office, Bloomberg Has Set New Political Tone 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Three months is not long enough to judge a marriage, a new home or a mayoralty. But within that period, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who unexpectedly took the helm of New York City during one of its most difficult periods in modern history, has in many ways profoundly altered the tenor, if not the substance, of city government.
 He is a mayor who reads e-mail sent personally to him from the public, rides the subway to City Hall and loves nothing more than for a stranger to approach him in a restaurant requesting a photograph. Many days, he walks out to lunch with a security detail smaller than the former mayor still has, and as a result often goes unnoticed on the street. 
 Mr. Bloomberg is also a mayor who places a premium on his personal privacy, saving his few moments of public ire for those who ask him how he spent his weekend. He still speaks far more comfortably before business leaders than before police officers. And in spite of the broad consensus building he has insisted on, he has yet to articulate a wide range of initiatives or goals, preferring a razor focus on three areas: rebuilding Lower Manhattan, school governance and the budget. 
While he has managed to escape the shadow of his predecessor, Mr. Bloomberg is still far less known to New Yorkers than Rudolph W. Giuliani was at this point in his tenure, and in turn, parts of New York are still in many ways an enigma to the mayor. "He is not a blank slate, but there is still not much writing on the chalkboard," said Douglas Muzzio, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College. "He has been parsimonious in dealing out facts about his worldview and his general orientation. Both Dinkins and certainly Giuliani had a political agenda coming in. Bloomberg's agenda, if it is there, is much less clear and much less overtly political, and he is acting on it in a much less dramatic way."
At his first town hall meeting this month, Mr. Bloomberg listed two accomplishments: putting together "the greatest team that any mayor has ever had the privilege to work with" and "second, to set a tone."
Clearly, after eight years of Mr. Giuliani, who micromanaged the city with an ideologically charged vision for how to transform public policy, Mr. Bloomberg has altered the role that key subordinates play in government. Many create and promote their own programs and all feel free to voice their ideas. "The mayor lets commissioners run their agencies," said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the city's health commissioner, echoing several commissioners interviewed in the last few months.
And there is little doubt that there is a new civic vibe. Budget watchdogs, union leaders, civil rights activists, former mayors and others have roundly praised Mr. Bloomberg for fostering an inclusive atmosphere at City Hall, in which all are welcome to share opinions on policy. 
"We had zero contact with the previous administration," said Larry Horowitz, chairman of Community Board 7 on the Upper West Side, who was invited to Gracie Mansion this month for the first time since the Koch administration for a cocktail party. "It was really an encouraging sign." 
That open-door attitude appears to be paying off, at least for now, so much so that Mr. Bloomberg has not been confronted with the usual wrath from various corners of the city -- even after he proposed one of the most austere budgets in decades. 
"I think that myself and others are trying to capitalize on this moment of detente," said Mary Brosnahan Sullivan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless.
Instead of staging regular protests on the steps of City Hall, Ms. Sullivan's organization and others have tried to work directly with this administration. "We feel that there is receptivity on the other side of the door," said Ms. Sullivan, who spent years on the outside of City Hall. "So we are willing to forgo the theatrics for a while to see if there will be any substantial change."
But all the reaching out and hugging has had its downsides. Partly by soliciting so many opinions, and perhaps because of the autonomy he has given so many subordinates, who like any set of humans do not always think in synchronization, the mayor has seen his plan coalesce much more slowly than those of previous administrations.
The mayor or one of his aides will talk one day about setting sliding-scale tolls on bridges and tunnels based on a driver's residency, and then the next day, he will say that is all just a vague notion. His administration is exploring incinerators as an option to the city's colossal garbage problem, but Mr. Bloomberg has vacillated on whether that would ever be a viable alternative.
And his administration has yet to weigh in on one of the most controversial Giuliani policies, the welfare-to-work rules. The only significant clue wafted out of a recent City Council hearing, during which Verna Eggleston, the commissioner of human resources, said the administration would refuse a federal waiver that would allow unemployed, childless adults seeking work to receive food stamps. Even that position is one that Mr. Bloomberg has not talked about publicly, and some members of his administration oppose it and are working to upend it. 
Advocates for the poor and supporters of Mr. Giuliani's policies alike say they are eager for a strong message to emerge. "It is preferable to articulate a philosophy than have the whole administration wait," said Heather MacDonald, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute, an organization that frequently shared Mr. Giuliani's views. "I think he is trying to control his message now."
It is also clear that Mr. Bloomberg's honeymoon is ending. Protesters, particularly those clamoring for tax increases over budget cuts, have resurfaced as part of the foliage in Lower Manhattan. The mayor's recent remark that parents of minority children do not understand how bad the schools are drew fire, as did some of his statements about how to handle garbage. And board members of the Museum of the City of New York were not among those on Mr. Bloomberg's distribution list when he decided to pull their deal to move into the Tweed Courthouse out from under them; the museum's director quit in protest. 
"There is no longer the passion of a honeymoon, but there has not been a filing for divorce," said the Rev. Al Sharpton, whom Mr. Bloomberg met with early in his administration. "I am not disillusioned, but I am watching more carefully, especially on the schools and budget."
One reason there is not a policy-a-week initiative from Mr. Bloomberg's administration is that he has kept his attention almost exclusively on three issues: rebuilding Lower Manhattan, dealing with the budget and pushing to overtake the school system. He pursues rebuilding with vigor via his subordinates, although he is often overshadowed by Gov. George E. Pataki, who has exerted more control over the process and has made it his business to be on hand for almost every news conference related to ground zero.
And while mayoral control of the schools has become a central theme for his tenure, Mr. Bloomberg has become publicly passionate about it only in the last month. On Martin Luther King's Birthday, Mr. Bloomberg went on a show on a black radio station and said merely, "I don't think the Board of Ed does a good job at providing an education." Two months later, he was calling the board a "rinky-dink candy store" and saying that he would not be able to look himself in the mirror unless he could control of the board.
And it may be that Mr. Bloomberg's true ideological leanings and social policy agenda outside of education will emerge as part of the budget process. "It seems as if the budget will drive his policy agenda," Mr. Muzzio said. "Which is the exact opposite of Dinkins and Giuliani." 
In small but noticeable ways, Mr. Bloomberg's on-the-job training at City Hall provides him the chance to show off his new knowledge about, say, how power plants work. 
Left to his own devices, though, he can still display a novice's grasp of government. In a recent speech, he mentioned the city budget's PEG program, saying the acronym stood for "Plug the Economic Gap." (Government wonks be alert: it stands for Program to Eliminate the Gap.)
And asked last week whether he would want a garbage incinerator in his backyard on Park Avenue, Mr. Bloomberg pronounced that a bad idea because it would drive away business. The proper answer, a former city official volunteered, would have been to mention the marine transfer station at Gracie Mansion as a possible site for an incinerator. (The station, once used as a landing dock for waterborne mayors, is on an old list of possible incinerator sites, but Mr. Bloomberg may not know that since he does not live at Gracie Mansion.) 
In some ways, New York City has two mayors: the businessman, whom Mr. Bloomberg insisted after Sept. 11 was what the city desperately needed, and the new politician, who is most visible to average New Yorkers. This was starkly illustrated on Wednesday, when Mr. Bloomberg went from overseeing the graduation of new police officers in the morning to a lunch for construction trade professionals at the Regent hotel on Wall Street.
The graduation was fairly emotional -- the class was the first to join the force since Sept. 11, and a video of those who died in the terrorist attack opened the ceremony. But Mr. Bloomberg's speech began with an anecdote about fingerprinting technology, and his tone barely changed when he described the difficulties this class faced as junior officers on that horrible day last fall. "You are ready to hit the ground running," he said flatly. 
Less than an hour later, as he addressed the construction industry, Mr. Bloomberg was relaxed and jocular as he told one of his favorite standbys. ("People ask me the difference between government and the business world. The business world is a dog-eat-dog world. In government, it is exactly the opposite.") The mayor then outlined specific ideas about how the economy could recover and what the city was doing in the meantime, and gave blunt explanations of what he thought the business world needed to do. 
The mayor has given several such speeches at the Regent and to business leaders elsewhere in the city, leaving his audiences almost always enraptured. "It was a stellar performance," said Omar Javaid, chairman of Mobilocity, a technology consulting firm, who attended the New York Software Summit in early March, where Mr. Bloomberg was a keynote speaker. "His speech was warm and funny. Prior to that, I had only seen him give speeches on television and I didn't find those very engaging."
Some suggest that Mr. Bloomberg's business background has also made him a strong sell to Washington lawmakers who are otherwise cool to New York. "I think it helps to have a businessman and a Republican and someone who walks in in Paul Stuart clothing," one aide said.
To others, though, there is something striking about the juxtaposition of this mayor's style of living with the financial condition of the city. His city agencies are struggling with devastating budget cuts, and council members are beginning to plot strategies to distribute the pain in different ways. Meanwhile, on the weekends, Mr. Bloomberg can escape the week's travails in his private jet to estates in lovely locales. And many New Yorkers are still not accustomed to hearing his Boston twang when they turn on their televisions.
But slowly, this mayor is becoming familiar to his constituents, as he divulges just a few personal glimpses along the way. What does Mr. Bloomberg really care about? His daughters, he has said that much. Other random facts: He owned a dog named Candy growing up that he carried in his coat. He likes hats on women. He very much enjoys peanut butter. And being the mayor is the best job he has ever had, he said. So far.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
 For those who cannot wait for summer, a few spring suggestions.

SHAMU IS YOUR NEIGHBOR: The Renaissance Orlando Resort, across the street from SeaWorld Orlando, has discounts for bookings for stays May 10 to 12. Rates are $109 per room per night. The 778-room resort has a pool, tennis courts, 24-hour health club and spa services. Availability is limited. Call (407) 351-5555 and ask for rate code LLRP; www.renaissancehotels.com. If you can't get away until summer, the same rates are available June 28 through July 5.

NORTH OF THE BORDER: Through April 30, the 294-room Sutton Place Hotel, on Bay Street in central Toronto, offers its Spring Break Escape Package starting at $109 a night, double (at $1.61 Canadian to the United States dollar), up to $174 for a suite. That includes self-parking, full breakfast for two in the hotel restaurant or in your room, and an in-room movie. Amenities include an indoor pool. Taxes are extra, availability is limited and some restrictions apply. For information: (800) 268-3790 or go to www.suttonplace.com.

IVY LEAGUE: The Inn at Harvard, with 113 rooms on Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass., is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a Diamond Anniversary Rate. Overlook how they came up with a diamond anniversary out of 10 years, and you'll find a rate of $99 a night for a double room, plus tax, through April 30. There's also a Diamond Weekend Getaway for $250, double, for one night's accommodations, a four-course dinner for two, valet parking and all taxes and tips (alcoholic beverages extra). Call (617) 491-2222 or visit www.theinnatharvard.com.

MICRO ECONOMICS: Spring Fever Specials, available through May 24 at Microtel Inns and Suites nationwide, start at $32 a night single and $42 double. Rates do not include tax, and there may be blackout dates. There are 128 Microtel properties in 38 states participating in this offer, with most in the South and Southeast. For information: (888) 771-7171 or on the Web at www .microtelinn.com.

NANTUCKET FIX-UP: The Harbor House Village (formerly the Harbor House), a 130-year-old hotel near downtown Nantucket scheduled to reopen next month after a major renovation, is offering three nights for the price of two from April 25 to May 31. Rates start at $170 a night. From June 1 to Sept. 2, there are five nights for the price of four, at $325 a night and up. The 104 rooms have been redone with pine and wicker furniture. Amenities include a heated outdoor pool (open weather permitting). Accommodations are in the 35-room historic Harbor House and in separate town houses. Blackout dates apply; availability is limited. Call (866) 325-9300 or go to the Web at www.harborhousevillage.com. JOSEPH SIANO
