HEADLINE: When Cool Is Not Enough 

BYLINE:  By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO writes frequently for the Travel section.

 BODY:
BOUTIQUE hotels were among the glittering successes of the 1990's. They flouted the hotel-world rules, dressing up small, often oddly shaped rooms with high-tech gadgets and high-concept design, and wooed guests with the downstairs as much or more than the upstairs -- the hip bar, the spare but glamorous lobby and, it was hoped, the cool crowd. The approach worked. In general, boutique hotels charge steeper rates and have enjoyed higher occupancy levels than traditional hotels, particularly on weekends, according to Bjorn Hanson, a managing partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting company.
 But the hotel industry has changed in recent months. Travel dropped sharply following the September terrorist attacks, and the recession has kept a full recovery at bay. And the mood among travelers, especially those doing business, is more conservative than a year ago. 
 "When the economy was booming, people were looking to spend money," Mr. Hanson said. "But now it's out of sync to spend on showy hotels."
Since the fall, guests have shown a preference for proven hotels, whether traditional or boutique, where they can feel safe and secure and experience no unwanted surprises, said Richard L. Brush, dean of The Hospitality College at Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I. The boutique hotels with loyal clienteles, established reputations and familiar names are doing well, although most are charging less for a room than a year ago, industry observers say. But many newcomers are having a hard time, particularly independent hotels in odd locations and with strange room configurations.
"I would have been scared opening a new hotel right now in some of the locations in Manhattan," said Barry Sternlicht, chairman and chief executive officer of Starwood Hotels and Resorts and founder of W Hotels, which opened the W Times Square, a 509-room hotel in the heart of New York's bustling theater and business district, in December. Indeed, the situation of boutique hotels is a particular question mark in New York, where more than a dozen have opened in the last year and a half, many with boldly untraditional locales and designs.
Many of these new hotels were struggling last summer, Mr. Hanson said, "and with rates down and occupancies down, as many as a dozen will fail." Guests may not realize a hotel has failed, since lenders rarely choose to publicize a foreclosure and allow new management to take over quietly.
Because boutique hotels are so individual, some owners have experienced wild fluctuations between properties. "The Mercer has a special clientele and is back to where rates and occupancy levels were," said Ira Drukier, a real estate developer and hotelier whose chic Soho property, at Mercer and Prince, is a favorite with fashion designers and movie stars. But Chambers, his new 77-room luxury boutique at 15 West 56th Street, has had a more difficult time. "We had just opened and had not had time to establish who we are," he said.
Most boutiques, by definition, belong to the hotel category hit hardest by the soft economy -- upscale hotels in large cities. In January, room revenues at luxury hotels in the United States dropped 15.2 percent from the previous year, according to Smith Travel Research, a company that tracks hotel industry performance. Revenues at economy hotels, in contrast, declined 7 percent.
Boutique hotels are particularly vulnerable to drops in room rates because they tend to have higher operating costs than traditional hotels. Maintaining a designer property with a stylish bar and restaurant and a high level of service adds up.
"Occupancy is back, but we've lost money on rates," said Emanuel Stern, co-owner with Leonard Stern of the Soho Grand, on West Broadway between Grand and Canal, and the Tribeca Grand, on Sixth Avenue at Church, Walker and White Streets. While guests may cheer, many hoteliers are concerned that the robust rates charged in 2000, an excellent year for the industry, may not come back for several years.
Indeed, guests have become more budget conscious. Since October, occupancy levels have been well above the city's average at most hotels in the Amsterdam Hospitality Group, in Manhattan. Its five small hotels, which include the Bentley, on 62nd Street at the East River, and the Moderne, on 55th Street between Eighth Avenue and Broadway, are less costly than most boutiques. In January and February, occupancy at the hotels was up 13 percent over 2001, while room rates, averaging $170 a night, declined 7 percent. "The market is coming back, but it's changed from last year," said George Dfouni, chief executive officer for the group.
Cutbacks in high-profile industries, like advertising and high technology, have also had an impact on the boutiques. "We need to rebuild some of our market base," Mr. Sternlicht said. Instead of spending heavily on advertising for the new W Times Square, the company went after business at the cluster of corporations in high rises surrounding the new hotel.
Smart restaurants and bars that attract local people have been a boon for many boutiques, helping offset lower room rates. "But they don't compensate entirely for the loss of room revenues, which are the sweet part of the hotel industry," said the hotelier Ian Schrager, whose boutique hotel properties include the Hudson in New York and the Clift in San Francisco.
But no one expects the boutiques to morph into traditional hotels as the world moves away from the prosperous 90's. "There might be a change in emphasis, with these hotels marketing themselves as more intimate, quiet and private, but there won't be a change in style," Mr. Hanson said. Indeed, D.J.'s still pump up the volume and bring in the crowd at the lounges of the Soho and Tribeca Grand. And guests at the Hudson still shoot pool in the Library into the wee hours. "People may be concerned about appearing more tasteful, but I think everything is going back to where it was," Mr. Schrager said.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Amsterdam

BYLINE:  By CORINNE LaBALME; CORINNE LaBALME writes about cultural events in Europe.

 BODY:
Expect more than tulips when the premier garden exhibition in the Netherlands, Floriade 2002, opens on Saturday on the Haarlemmermeer polder three miles west of Amsterdam's airport. This lavish horticultural extravaganza, held once every 10 years, incorporates flowers, fruit trees, prize vegetables, ornamental shrubbery and national gardens from more than 30 countries, including France, Bulgaria, Egypt, Thailand, Chile, Kenya, China and the United States. 
 The Netherlands is still basking in a honeymoon glow created by the glamorous wedding of Prince Willem-Alexander and his Argentine-born bride, Princess Maxima, in February. Wedding souvenirs are the top collectibles, and the mood in Amsterdam, always oriented toward parties and fun when the weather gets warmer, promises to be more romantic than usual this spring. 
 Amsterdam is one of the most cosmopolitan cities in Europe. Its pioneering sailors and traders brought Indonesian cuisine, Japanese silks and Chinese porcelain to Northern Europe, and these exotic items were eagerly assimilated into Dutch culture. This year the Netherlands commemorates the 400th anniversary of the Dutch East India Company, one of the largest commercial enterprises of the 17th and 18th centuries. A reproduction of the Duyfken (Little Dove), the vessel that, in 1606, made the first map of the north coast of Australia, was built in Australia for the anniversary and will be docked in Amsterdam's harbor from May 2 to 7. Free admission. 
 This spring would also be a good time to visit two major arts landmarks. The Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art will close in late 2002 for a 30-month renovation and addition, although part of the collection should be on view in an undetermined location. The Rijksmuseum, with the city's trove of Rembrandt and Vermeer paintings, will be partly closed for renovation from autumn 2003.

Events
 Floriade occupies a 160-acre fairground that encompasses a lake, adorned with 150 varieties of water lily, and the 19th-century Geniedijk defense wall. To provide panoramic views for the three million visitors expected, landscape architects have built a 130-foot grass-covered hill whose base has the same dimensions as the Pyramid of Cheops in Egypt. Floriade 2002 is open daily from Saturday through Oct. 20 from 9:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. Information: Netherlands Tourist Board, (888) 464-6552 or www.floriade.com 
 Through Oct. 27, the Amsterdam Maritime Museum, Kattenburgerplein 1, Oosterdok, (31-20) 523-2222, www.scheepvaartmuseum, celebrates the Dutch East India Company with an exposition that focuses on the trade with China and India that brought chintz fabric and tea to Holland. Admission: $6. Closed Monday except July to September. Through Sept. 15, a companion show at Rotterdam's Maritime Museum, www .maritiemmuseum.nl, details the commerce with Japan, Ceylon and Indonesia that brought cinnamon and kimonos to the Dutch middle class. Admission $6. 
 The Van Gogh Museum, Paulus Potterstraat 7, (31-20) 570-5200, www .vangoghgauguin.nl, presents "Van Gogh and Gauguin" through June 2. The blockbuster show, which originated at the Art Institute of Chicago, concentrates on the autumn of 1888, when the two volatile artists worked on sunflower paintings in Arles. Open daily. Advance sales, (800) 669-8687, fax (212) 302-4251. A limited number of tickets are on sale at the museum. General admission, $11. 
 On Queen's Day, April 30, the Dutch celebrate by raiding their attics and setting up impromptu flea-market stalls all over town. Many Amsterdam cafes inaugurate the festivities with street parties the night before. 
 On May 3, 5 and 6, Jiri Kylian's Nederlands Dans Theater performs at the 1,600-seat Muziektheater, Amstel 3, (31-20) 625-5455, fax (31-20) 551-8025. The program includes Kylian's 1982 ballet set to Mahler's "Lieder Eines Fahrenden Gesellen" and new works by the house choreographers Paul Lightfoot and Hans van Manen. Tickets: $14.65 to $25.80. 
 Through Sept. 8, the Jewish Historical Museum, J. D. Meijerplein 2-4, (31-20) 626-9945, www.jhm.nl, showcases the vibrant gouache paintings of Charlotte Salomon, the Berlin-born artist who died at Auschwitz in 1943. The autobiographical series, 769 paintings in all, begins with her 1920's bohemian childhood. Open daily. Admission $4.30.
 The soprano Dawn Upshaw sings Purcell, Druckman and Bach on May 24 at the Concertgebouw, Concertgebouwplein 2-6; (31-20) 671-8345, fax (31-20) 573-0460, www.concertgebouw.nl. Tickets: $26 to $29. People with tickets to the bargain-priced Sunday morning recitals ($10.35) can take a backstage tour, in Dutch with an English translation, before the concert ($3).

Sightseeing
 During the 17th and 18th centuries, property on the Herengracht became lined with exclusive real estate. Many of the mansions on this canal have been converted into intimate museums that provide tantalizing glimpses into the domestic life of the Golden Age.
 While the elegant satin upholstery and gilded chandeliers in the Willet Holthuysen Museum, Herengracht 605, (31-20) 523-1822, www.ahm.nl, are French rococo, the house itself dates from 1685. Bequeathed to the city in 1895, this merchant's residence -- with kitchen, salon, bedrooms, ballroom and garden -- is the only fully furnished Amsterdam town house open to the public daily. Admission $3.50. 
 Rembrandt's "Madonna With Cat" etching and 19th-century Japanese netsuke highlight the feline-oriented art and artifacts at the eccentric Kattenkabinet (Cat Gallery), in a well-worn 17th-century town house at 497 Herengracht; (31- 20) 626-5378, www .kattenkabinet.nl. It was founded in 1990 by one Bob Meijer in honor of his beloved tomcat John Pierpont Morgan. Watch out for the litter boxes -- five well-fed cats reside on the premises. They can often be found dozing beneath cat portraits signed by Picasso and Theophile Steinlen. Open daily; admission $3.90. 
 The oldest Bible printed in the Netherlands, dated 1477, is on view at the Bible (Bijbels) Museum, Herengracht 366-368, (31-20) 624-2436; www.bijbelsmuseum.nl. The museum also houses Egyptian antiquities, but anyone whose eyes turn upward will be dazzled by the profane splendor of seminude goddesses and pagan astrological symbols adorning the ceiling murals painted by the 18th-century artist Jacob de Wit. Open daily; admission $4.30.

Where to Stay
 In the museum district near Vondel Park, the Prinsen Hotel, Vondelstraat 36-38, (31-20) 616-2323, fax (31-20) 616-6112, www.prinsenhotel.demon.nl, merges two white-trimmed town houses built around 1870 by P. J. H. Cuijpers, who also designed the Rijksmuseum and Amsterdam's neo-Renaissance Central Station. All 45 rooms have color television, safes and bathrooms with hair dryers. Doubles $98 to $108. 
 Near the 17th-century Amstelkerk church, the Amsterdam Prinsengracht Hotel, Prinsengracht 1015, (31-20) 623-7779, fax (31-20) 623-8926, www.prinsengrachthotel.nl, has 33 comfortable rooms overlooking either the canal or a private garden. The views add a great deal of charm, since the pristine, modern rooms are decorated with Dutch economy. For more privacy, four people can share a two-bedroom bungalow in the garden for $142. Doubles $90 to $116. 
 Budget: Only five minutes' walk from the night life on the bustling Leidseplein, the friendly Euphemia Hotel, Fokke Simonszstraat 1-9, telephone and fax (31-20) 622-9045, fax (31-21) 638-9673 www.euphemia hotel.com, has 30 no-frills rooms that preserve the atmosphere of its former incarnation as a monastery. The building has steep stairs (and no elevator), so guests may want to request rooms on the lower floors. Price per room: $65 to $120. 
 Luxury: The Dutch royal family booked all 468 rooms at the Hotel Krasnapolsky, Dam 9, (31-20) 554-9111, fax (31-20) 622-8607, www.krasnapolsky.nl, for Prince Willem Alexander's wedding guests. The room decor is subdued and businesslike but this sprawling hotel, often described as a self-contained village with a private landing dock for canal boats, has a fitness center, beauty salon and a variety of restaurants. The 19th-century glass-roofed Winter Garden, which serves a popular $28 jazz brunch on Sunday, is one of the most flamboyant dining rooms in town. Doubles from $250. 
 The most stylish transport in Amsterdam is a shiny black bicycle with a license plate from the super-chic Blakes Hotel, Keizersgracht 384, (31-20) 530-2010, fax (31-20) 530-2030, www.blakeshotels.com. The jet-set innkeeper Anouska Hempel remodeled its four 17th-century buildings in 1999. Basic black sets the style in the lobby, bar, restaurant and even the courtyard garden. The 25 elegant rooms may mix old-fashioned herringbone-brick floors or cathedral ceilings with bold textiles and mahogany screens. Doubles $300 to $388.

Where to Eat
 Visitors can snack on a cheese broodje sandwich ($2) or vegetarian lasagna ($9.40) at the stylish Cafe De Jaren, Nieuwe Doelenstraat 20-22, (31-20) 625-5771, fax (31-20) 624-0801, a Tribeca-style duplex restaurant with a panoramic patio where the scenic Kloveniersburgwal canal meets the Amstel in the Old Center. A formal dinner of grilled salmon in the fancier dining room costs $56 for two, with a bottle of Italian Soave. Open daily 10 a.m. to 1 a.m. 
 Moko, Amstelveld 12, (31-20) 626-1199, fax (31-20) 626-6059, a trendy bar and restaurant with a vast canal-side terrace, opened last year in the former stable wing of Amsterdam's only wooden church, the 17th-century Amstelkerk, which is still a house of worship. The steamed sea bass is served in yellow curry and lime sauce, and the tamari beef with shiitake mushrooms, daikon and Hawaiian pesto. From Wednesday to Saturday nights, DJ's spin a seductive lounge beat. Dinner for two with wine, $78. Open daily for lunch and dinner. 
 Amsterdam's only surviving city gate, built in 1488, today houses In De Waag, Nieuwmarkt 4, (31-20) 422-7772, fax (31-20) 422-8641, a low-key cafe with free Internet access. The medieval interior is so murky that candles are needed at noon. The dinner menu includes lentil soup ($5.60) and a beef filet platter ($18), but this is mainly a lunch stop. Dutch ham sandwiches, apple pie and organic fruit juice for two, $15. Open daily for lunch and dinner. 
 The 10-table Tujuh Maret, Utrechtsestraat 73, telephone and fax (31-20) 427-9865, specializes in flavor-intensive Indonesian recipes like coriander-lemongrass beef from the Minahasa region of Sulawesi island. An order of rijsttafel (rice table) allows diners to sample small portions of 23 specialties. Rijsttafel for two, with Indonesian Bintang beer and mango sherbet: $45. Dinner only; closed Monday; no credit cards.
 "Fancy" usually means French in the Netherlands, and the Grand Hotel's glossy Cafe Roux, Oudezijds Voorburgwal 197, (31-20) 555-3111, fax (31-20) 555-3222, is supervised by Albert Roux, the chef who created Le Gavroche in London. In a sleek Art Deco wing of a former 15th-century convent, Cafe Roux serves a three-course, $37 dinner (including wine) that may feature truffled foie gras and tender roast brill with parsnip puree. The Bordeaux selection is awe-inspiring. Dinner for two with a modest wine, about $85. Open daily for lunch and dinner.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADIVSORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Tourism Venture Ends On Midway Atoll Refuge

BYLINE:  By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

 BODY:
THE Bush administration is hoping to create business partnerships with private companies to invest in wildlife refuges and preserves, sometimes with development in mind and sometimes for conservation. The proposal is the highlight of the administration's budget request for the Fish and Wildlife Service, an agency in the Interior Department that runs the sanctuaries. But while the approach meshes nicely with Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton's "new environmentalism," a similar venture by the previous administration has failed.
 Opening Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge to the public was an attempt to blend tourism and wildlife protection in the remote reaches of the Pacific Ocean, more than a thousand miles west of Hawaii. 
 In 1996, Midway Phoenix, a company in Georgia, took over running the island's small station, which the Navy had occupied ever since the World War II battle over a strategic refueling stop, and started receiving tourists there the following year.
Claimed by the United States in 1859 (its guano was valuable as fertilizer), Midway was occupied by 21 marines under President Theodore Roosevelt in 1903. His intent, he said, was to protect the albatross from Japanese hunters. But that same year an oceanic cable was extended through Midway. The 1,500-acre atoll, made up of two small islands and a surrounding reef about five miles in diameter, has been occupied ever since.
Once the Navy left, turning over Midway to the Fish and Wildlife Service after cleaning up the ramshackle base, Midway Phoenix, based in Cartersville, Ga., took over managing the airport, providing power and maintaining buildings, including officers' quarters that it made into a resort.
The arrangement was to cost the government almost nothing; the company, which invested millions, planned to turn a profit by bringing small numbers of tourists to the sanctuary and refueling planes and ships.
But early this year, Phoenix abruptly announced that it was suspending operations, and on March 6 the partners abandoned their cooperative arrangement. Phoenix will keep the power on and the airport running until May 1, and is required to leave Midway in condition that the Federal Aviation Administration can certify as suitable for emergency landings by commercial aircraft. (It is not clear whether the F.A.A. will continue that certification once the company leaves the atoll.)
The wildlife agency, meanwhile, says it will look for a new contractor to run the airport and tourist facilities. But Phoenix doubts any other company can make a similar agreement work, said Robert F. Tracey, its executive vice president.
The company walked out of the deal complaining that the wildlife agency had not been flexible enough in letting tourists use the beaches and reefs. "They are not visitor friendly," Mr. Tracey said of the agency. "They are self-appointed stewards of nature, but if they had to look at a profit and loss statement, as we do, they would have to be flexible." Most beaches were closed, ocean-going tugs were not allowed to visit for refueling, and "we had to fight like hell for a couple of cruise ships to visit," he said.
The agency, for its part, said the company was not meeting some contract conditions, finding them too expensive.
With trips abruptly canceled, Aloha Airlines ended its weekly flight from Hawaii, isolating the atoll's 150 or so permanent residents. About 150 contract employees lost their jobs.
Among the visitors whose plans were scrubbed were more than 250 who had signed up with the Oceanic Society, a nonprofit conservation group, for its eco-tour to Midway this year. Typically, tourists who take the two-hour flight from Hawaii work as paying volunteers in such projects as banding albatrosses that nest by the hundreds of thousands at Midway, where sailors knew them as "gooney birds."
The great frigate bird and the white-tailed tropicbird are other spectacular residents of the atoll. A small colony of rare monk seals breeds there, and big sea turtles forage in the lagoon. To avoid disturbing them, all of Eastern Island, part of the atoll, is off limits to visitors except once a week, when they are allowed ashore in an amphibious craft, under careful supervision by wildlife scientists. Small numbers of tourists are allowed to dive and fish in Midway's waters.
Birgit Winning, president of the Oceanic Society, said that wildlife programs would be harmed by the end of the agreement.
"Not only will the endangered species and habitat recovery process be affected, so will preservation of historic sites and opportunities for long-term biological monitoring and research," she said.
Barbara Maxfield, a spokeswoman for the Interior Department, said it had not been satisfied with the company's performance in maintaining the refuge's property, ensuring the safety of tourists, and protecting the frail resources of the atoll. By law, the wildlife agency's main objective in managing its reserves is conservation. 
Because of its remoteness, the Midway project was challenging economically, and its failure comes as Congress considers the Bush administration's request for $1.3 billion for the agency next year, including a $56.5 million increase in spending at refuges. The budget includes $284 million for programs to give companies incentives to restore wildlife habitats on public lands. But new land purchases would be reduced, the White House says, because the refuge system, with 535 units totaling 95 million acres, has a backlog of more than $660 million in unfinanced maintenance projects.

HEADLINE: The Little Engine That Can 

BYLINE:  By J. D. REED 

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
ON a recent Monday morning, a few dozen commuters scurried along the train platform to get out of a cold rain. Among them were the novelist Peter Benchley; Gregory J. Osberg, executive vice president of Newsweek magazine; and Nicholas Katzenbach, a former attorney general of the United States. They settled into their seats with pleasant nods to the other regular riders whom they recognized, then snapped open their morning papers.
 These notables, along with their less-exalted fellow travelers, regularly shuttle through the flats of New Jersey on what can often seem like a movable green room for some ultimate talk show. 
 Yet this self-propelled car -- commonly known as the Dinky and sometimes as the PJ&B (for Princeton Junction and back) -- though providing only a four-minute ride, is long on history, privilege and notoriety. For generations, it has been celebrated in the literature and the lore of Princeton University. And in a cycle of difficult budget choices, powerful advocates help keep the little engine that not only could -- but insisted upon -- out of harm's way. 
So the single car, operated by New Jersey Transit, plies back and forth about every half hour between the magnolia-budded tranquillity of the university campus and the hard-edged, workday bustle of Princeton Junction a mere 2.7 miles away, making it perhaps the shortest regularly scheduled passenger route in America.
"I have been riding the Dinky for 54 years and find it soothing and reliable," said Freeman Dyson, a renowned physicist and a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study here. "I consider it a great privilege to be living at the one place in the United States that has decent train service."
On a typical weekday, the Dinky, as anachronistic as a pair of cordovan wingtips, moves about 250 daily commuters to trains bound for New York and Philadelphia on the Northeast Corridor line. It ferries university students during vacations, and carries the Matrons Who Lunch and faculty members like Mr. Dyson toward their speaking engagements and theater trips to the city. Altogether, it handles about 850 riders each day.
The Dinky ride itself is as necessary as morning coffee to regulars. Take Jane Silverman, the executive director of the Association of Junior Leagues International, who seems to speak for many of her fellow commuters when she says, "The Dinky is a necessary transition between precious Princeton and the real world." That world begins with the rush hour stampede at Princeton Junction, during which sharp words are exchanged, and an occasional elbow flung, as hundreds of riders compete for too few seats on the hourlong ride to New York City.
Parking spaces spell out the difference between the two stations -- indeed, the two New Jerseys. Princeton Junction station is administered by West Windsor, a community that grew like wildfire in the 1990's, in great part because of its proximity to public transportation. There are more than 3,000 spaces at the Junction, and a four-year waiting list to get a parking sticker. Back in bucolic Princeton, which lies on the other, pricier, side of Route 1 -- that cataract of traffic that bisects central New Jersey -- there are only 125 slots in the university-owned lot -- and no waiting.
"At one time I had parking stickers for both places," said Aline Haynes, a broker of high-end real estate with Manhattan's Stribling & Associates, and who has been a commuter for 19 years. "But I quickly decided on Princeton. I love the sociability of the Dinky. Once you hit the main line, it becomes just another uncomfortable commute."
Over the decades, the Dinky has ferried more famous people than any conveyance except the Queen Elizabeth II. Hundreds of celebrities have made the little journey -- people who would not normally enter the same orbits, much less the same railroad car. The economist John Maynard Keynes, who taught at Princeton, and the actress Margaret Hamilton, better known as the Wicked Witch in "The Wizard of Oz," who appeared at the McCarter Theater, were both once onboard. Nobel Prize winners from Albert Einstein to the novelist Toni Morrison as well as less high-profile laureates have been a common sight. Other fellow travelers include Brooke Shields, John O'Hara, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Bill Bradley, Joyce Carol Oates, Ron Howard, T. S. Eliot, Bill Walton, Paul Robeson, Christopher Reeve, James Taylor and Thomas Mann. 
In the early 1980's, a commuter strolled onto a post-rush hour Dinky to find only three passengers waiting for the ride to the Junction. At one end of the car sat Brendan Byrne, a former governor of New Jersey, reading a legal brief. In the middle of the train, John McPhee, the author and New Yorker writer, was absorbed in a manuscript. And at the far end, Mr. Benchley was engrossed in his morning paper. They seemed oblivious to one another's presence.
By far the most celebrated current regular is the mathematician John F. Nash Jr., who is portrayed in the Academy Award Best Picture, "A Beautiful Mind." Long before he was awarded a Nobel Prize, a chain-smoking Mr. Nash, wearing a wrinkled raincoat and scuffed canvas sneakers, rode from his home near Princeton Junction to the university nearly every day. Almost everyone knew him by sight, though few knew who he was.
"I've been bumping into John Nash for the last 25 to 30 years," said Paul Gray, a book critic and journalist. "One October morning in 1994, while waiting for the 8:51, I saw Nash's picture on the front page of a local paper in a vending machine. My first thought was, 'Oh, how sad, the local character-bagman must have died.' Then I read the headline and realized that the local character-bagman had won a Nobel Prize."
Mr. Nash, who is sometimes joined by his son Johnny, a teacher, is still a regular, off-peak Dinkyite.
"Nash will often ask if we can hold the train while he has a cigarette," said Artie Radford, a Dinky engineer for the past 20 years. "We always say yes. Mostly because he smokes a whole cigarette in about 30 seconds and it never makes us late."
While it may cater to the whims of its notable ridership -- celebrities, the merely famous and the high-profile -- eccentrics on the Dinky are studiously ignored, unless one has served on the same charity board, or has a daughter who also plays traveling hockey.
One commuter sailed awfully close to the wind when he struck up a conversation with Mr. Katzenbach one morning. The commuter had reviewed "Hart's War," a novel by Mr. Katzenbach's son Jonathan, which called on many of the former attorney general's World War II experiences as a prisoner of war.
"I always got on and minded my own business," said Joe Wisnovsky, a 35-year veteran of the commute and editor of science books who now works at the Princeton University Press. "I hardly noticed who was in the seat next to me."
There are exceptions, of course. A conductor, Earl Hagaman, who for the past 16 years has collected the fares (currently $1.65) retrieved lost car keys and once even rescued a baby who had been left onboard, could not resist having some fun when he learned about John Plummer, a renowned expert on medieval illuminated manuscripts who was for many years a commuter.
"Hey, John," Mr. Hagaman would say to Mr. Plummer, an emeritus professor of art history at Princeton and a fellow of New York City's Pierpont Morgan Library. "A buddy of mine has a trailer-load of paintings. They're good ones, on black velvet. You know about art. You can help us sell them."
The kidding still brings a smile to the good-natured Mr. Plummer, who said, "Earl was irresistible."
The feeling is mutual.
"People like John Plummer are always a pleasure to have onboard," said Mr. Hagaman. "So are most of the regulars."
Such familiarity breeds anything but contempt among riders, who have grown into a kind of four-minute community. On main line Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains, the experience is impersonal: conductors change often, one never meets an engineer, and a ticket must always be shown.
But on the Dinky, Mr. Hagaman checks monthly tickets once, and doesn't bother until the first of the next month. William P. Lockwood Jr., who is responsible for most of the artistic programming at McCarter as well as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, has also been a Dinky rider since 1965.
And as Mr. Lockwood put it: "The Dinky is a kind of commutation society. We don't all know each other by name or position, but we recognize each other. And that's important. After all, the first face you see in the morning after you kiss your wife goodbye is the Dinky conductor."
The personalized service extends in some interesting directions. The Dinky schedule is posted backstage at McCarter Theater. As it happens, most members of the theater's permanent acting company live in New York City, which makes them very conscious of show timing. A 10:17 p.m. curtain means they might be able to make the 100-yard dash from the stage door to the door of the 10:22 Dinky, makeup intact.
"We wait for them sometimes," said Mr. Radford. "We don't have much going on at that time of night anyway."
The engineer also serves as information central. Has a friend been missing for a few days? Artie, the engineer, might know. He will know if the person is out sick, on vacation or has retired. Mr. Radford also keeps track of which cars are in the parking lot, and when.
"On the evening of Sept. 11," Mr. Radford said, "there were two cars left in the lot. I was worried, but the next day the people were back. They weren't able to get out of the city. We didn't lose anybody."
Along with the special treatment comes Dinky protocol. Rule 1: Never ask what a fellow commuter does for a living, or what position he holds. One may find seated on a typical morning rush hour trip the chief executives of Fortune 500 companies, $500-an-hour corporate lawyers, small-business owners, journalists, dot-com programmers, adjunct Rutgers University professors, advertising executives and foundation heads.
"I talk to people every morning that I would never even meet elsewhere in life," Mrs. Haynes said. "You know them for years, and you have no idea what they do."
Indeed, certain subjects, including titles, are taboo. Politics are generally off limits, as is any form of business conversation. Most chat concerns the weather, late trains, films recently seen and, of course, golf. Indeed, an Old Boy swathed head to toe in Orvis recently showed a friend his scorecard from the back nine at the Burning Tree Country Club in Bethesda, Md., outside Washington, where presidents often take their hacks. Behavior in the car also has its rules: The urgent bleat of the cellphone, which can drive some commuters to acts of violence, is almost never heard. Conversation is acceptable on the morning run, frowned on in the evening.
Of course, problems in the parking lot are always a topic. Some years ago, the Case of the Crooked Parker bedeviled regulars. An unknown commuter who arrived for a very early train often took up two spaces by sloppy parking. After weeks of fuming, several commuters positioned their cars so the miscreant couldn't get out. That evening, the Crooked Parker's car was still there, but there was no sign of its owner. The problem never happened again.
The parking lot itself is sleek with the products of Stuttgart: Mercedes-Benzes, BMW's and Audis. There are only a few S.U.V.'s, which generally draw an irritable lip-twitch by commuters. They are Just Too Obvious. One Princeton native, Robert Moore, who is managing director of Manhattan's MezzinaBrown Partners advertising agency, is a master of Princeton reverse chic. He drives a grimy, rust-flaking 1989 Toyota.
"It is," said Mr. Moore with quiet dignity and a straight face, "a special edition Samurai model. A classic."
Dinky style is similarly dated. While Armani and DKNY are making inroads, J. Press and Laura Ashley, Brooks Brothers and Talbot's still predominate. If Harry Truman walked onboard, his clothing would not be out of place. The feeling seems to be that a man's commute should be as quiet as his tie. Occasionally an unworldly type will board wearing old, heavy tweeds that smell like a wet dog. It is an olfactory reminder that there are a few commuters who still enjoy the blood sports.
No matter what one's pleasures, calling attention to the Dinky's implicit air of privilege and accomplishment is just not done. During reunion week, a Princeton University spring rite, several thousand alumni swathed in the school colors of orange and black descend on the town, many by way of the Dinky, for social frivolity. A few years ago, Mickey Wolfson, a Miami art collector and former Princetonian, parked his private train car at the Dinky platform during the reunion, inconveniencing regular commuters who had to walk down the platform to board the Dinky and who found the whole thing too ostentatious for words.
For all the Dinky's history, its origin is lost somewhere in the historic mists before 1874. It was operated by the Pennsylvania Railroad, on whose board sat a few patrician Princeton alumni. By the Roaring 20's, the little car was a part of Ivy League lore. Special trains would come down from New Haven and Cambridge for the Yale or Harvard football game with Princeton. The trains were parked on a siding of the main line, and sports fans took the Dinky to the university.
Indeed, the Dinky has been memorialized in two seminal works of literature, testament to the fact that before Princeton became coed in 1973, student dates from Vassar and other girl's schools were imported for the weekend on the train.
For instance, meeting one's date at the Dinky station was a rite of Ivy League passage. F. Scott Fitzgerald, who almost graduated from Princeton, captured the Jazz Age in his first novel, "This Side of Paradise," published in 1920. In one memorable scene, the protagonist, Amory Blaine, meets his weekend date at the Dinky station. More than 30 years later, J. D. Salinger, who vivified his own disaffected generation, wrote of Franny Glass in the classic "Franny and Zooey" who meets her date at what has to be the Dinky station.
Of course, the train has also figured in its share of student high jinks. In the early 1960's, George R. Bunn Jr., of the Bunn coffee maker family, and three fellow students held up the Dinky on horseback.
"We sat up in the woods beside the tracks -- not entirely sober, if I remember right," Mr. Bunn once recalled, "and waited for the 6:14. We had hats and bandannas and rented horses. I had a .38 pistol loaded with blanks. When the train came along, we galloped down and the conductor screeched it to a stop. We all climbed on and I fired off a couple of shots -- it was very loud -- and everybody was yelling and had their hands up and all the businessmen were throwing their wallets at us. We didn't have dates on the train. We just picked the four girls we thought were most likely to play along and told them what was going on. We all took off through the woods."
Not surprisingly, the railroad was not amused, but no charges were filed. 
A prank in 1990 involving the Dinky, however, did end tragically. Bruce J. Miller, a university student who had been to parties at several of Princeton's fraternity-like eating clubs, climbed onto the the top of the Dinky, where he suffered a severe electric shock from the overhead equipment. The injury led to the loss of both legs and an arm, and Mr. Miller sued the university, New Jersey Transit and several clubs. Eventually, the suit was settled for $5.7 million. 
Petite and precious the Dinkyt may be, but its future is not in doubt.
"At one point in its past, the Dinky was sort of an anachronism," said John L. McGoldrick, executive vice president of Bristol-Myers Squibb, a one-time Dinky rider and a current board member of New Jersey Transit. "But with the explosion of population in our area, it is an extremely useful line."
Planners are even considering lengthening Dinky service deeper into Princeton, and perhaps northwest into the towns of Montgomery and Rocky Hill.
Wherever the Dinky may extend, however, its roots will reach back through the haze of history to the platform at the foot of the university. For instance, Richard Preston, the author of "The Hot Zone" and "The Cobra Event," who is also a local resident, recalled his grandfather telling him how he rode the Dinky when he was in the class of '17 -- along with Fitzgerald and the literary critic Edmund (Bunny) Wilson.
"The Dinky would stop running late at night," Mr. Preston said. "So when they'd been in New York, and got back late, they would get off at Princeton Junction and walk the Dinky tracks. Much later, when I was a graduate student at Princeton and rode the Dinky, I sometimes thought of my grandfather and Fitzgerald and Wilson staggering along the tracks, young people with hopes, but no real idea that the world would hear from them one day. I felt the same way myself -- young, ambitious to write, with no way to see into the future or know that one could achieve one's hopes, riding the Dinky to Princeton, and to one's dreams."

HEADLINE: Parents Are Worried As District Struggles 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
FOR years, the Amity Regional School District, which includes 2,400 high school and junior high school students in the affluent New Haven suburbs of Orange, Woodbridge and Bethany, had been one of Connecticut's most respected regional school systems.
 But a report issued earlier this month by a special tri-town investigative committee charged that a budget deficit of $2.8 million was caused by top school administrators and school board members who improperly shifted and commingled money from different accounts and different school years. 
 The report accused the school board of fiscal mismanagement for, among other things, misspending money from a $2.85 million bond issue in 1998 earmarked solely to correct mold and fungus problems at Amity Regional High School. The findings have left the education community concerned, with many students, parents and educators worried about how the problems will affect the quality of education.
The district is in such financial trouble that residents in the three towns voted in a referendum to come to the district's aid by paying a special tax to save as many as 80 teachers' jobs. Now, the district is seeking a $29.5 million budget for next fiscal year and there is concern that voters, angry about how school funds were used in the past, may not approve it, further worsening the economic problem. 
The committee determined there was possible criminal wrongdoing that is being reviewed by the New Haven state's attorney, Michael Dearington. The committee also recommended that nine of the 12 school board members resign.
Michael Lohne, the chairman of the school board, said he had no intention of quitting.
"There isn't anybody at Amity who isn't embarrassed by what has happened, but I believe we can now move forward and learn from the mistakes that have been made," Mr. Lohne said, adding that he "welcomed a criminal investigation. Let them look all they want, I have nothing to hide. We're innocent until proven guilty."
Many teachers are indicating they may leave and many parents are already applying to area private schools for their children because they fear that potential cuts in programs and teacher defections could leave the district in a mess by September.
"It's ironic because when we moved here 11 years ago it was because of the school system, and the local elementary school is still excellent," said Kate O'Brien of Orange, whose 14-year-old son, Liam, attends Amity Regional Junior High in Orange, but would attend the regional high school in September.
Like many other parents at Amity, Ms. O'Brien said she may send her son to a private school in the fall.
"We are seriously considering enrolling our son in a private school and have already submitted applications because we don't see how the debacle at Amity is going to improve any time soon," said Ms. O'Brien, co-chairwoman of Amity Community for Education, a tri-town political action committee.
Karen Shinkman, president of the Amity Education Association, said as many as 20 of the district's 200 teachers are looking for new jobs. 
"Teachers are concerned because we want to just get back to the classroom and concentrate on teaching again," she said. "But if a budget for next year doesn't pass, we don't know whether we will have the supplies and staff to continue to function as a viable school system. At this point there's just a feeling of complete uncertainty about what is going to happen next. That's resulted in a lot of people talking about leaving." 
Some have already left.
Joseph Campbell, hired four years ago as the school system's information technology coordinator, has taken a similar job in the Brookfield school system. 
"I had to get out of there because of the complete lack of stability," Mr. Campbell said. "They have already cut my funding so severely I cannot provide the vision that they hired me to create. I may be the first to leave, but I won't be the last."
Jim Clifford, a social studies teacher, feared he could be out of a job if the board's proposed budget is not approved and the district is forced to make cuts.
"We thought the worst was behind us when the referendum was approved by voters in December, but now everything seems up in the air again," Mr. Clifford said. "I left another school to come here because Amity was always known for its excellence in education. But right now the only thing Amity seems to be known for is this controversy."
School administrators said they are trying to save the school system by placing strict controls on spending and implementing emergency programs that include intervention by a group of financial advisers.
"No purchase order goes through unless I sign off on it, and if there is no money in the account I don't," said Michael Nast, the interim school superintendent who was hired in January to replace the last superintendent, Rolf W. Wenner. 
"We know it's not business as usual any more, and there's no denying the impact this has all been having on students, teachers, parents and the community," Mr. Nast said. "But we still do have students to educate and we are trying to do that in spite of everything that has happened."
After meeting with Theodore Sergi, state commissioner of education, Mr. Nast said he will be taking Mr. Sergi's advice and relying on help from the Connecticut Association of Business Officials to come up with new fiscal procedures for the district. He said he hoped they will both improve fiscal responsibility and gain trust from the community.
But even the strongest education supporters said they believed any budget the school board tries to present will be defeated in referendum, and that would mean reverting to the current year's $28 million budget and no increase in spending, which administrators said would actually mean a decrease because of rising budget obligations.
Critics of the district are vowing to defeat the budget as long as school board members don't resign and are threatening to make the budget vote a referendum on the school board itself.
"It's a sinking ship and there's chaos throughout the district," said Robert C. Sousa, a former first selectman of Orange.
"The only way to save the school system is for this school board to just go away," he said.
Student leaders said it's tough being part of the Amity school system because of the controversy.
"Many students and teachers are very pessimistic and worried because there is a very real possibility voters are never going to approve a budget and nobody knows what that's going to mean to programs and teaching staff next year," said Anthony Monelli, 17, a senior of Bethany. "This entire school year has been like a roller coaster ride, but unfortunately we also know the worst could still be ahead."
Some students said their faith in the adults running the school system has been shattered.
"Kids really feel that the board has let down our school system and has set a bad example for students," said Melissa Zoock, 17, a junior of Orange. "We have always felt this was a great school system, but the school board is dragging us down and dragging down the reputation of the school. Kids are worried about how all this could impact programs next year and whether teachers might leave."
Patricia Varanelli, Amity's director of pupil personnel services, said she "never thought things would ever come to this," but she and other administrators have been meeting every week to prepare for a worst-case scenario that could include massive teacher defections and serious cuts to programs. 
"We began the school year not knowing if we would be able to make up the big deficit discovered last summer and we got a reprieve when voters approved the referendum," she said. "Now it looks like we're going to approach the end of the school year much the same way as we started out -- complete uncertainty about what happens next."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Managing Company Morale

BYLINE:  By JUDITH S. LEDERMAN 

 BODY:
JEFFREY M. SALTZMAN, the chief executive officer of Sirota Consulting and an industrial psychologist, has a tool for navigating the uncertain economy: surveys.
 Mr. Saltzman and his company, which has its offices on Manhattanville Road in Purchase, say that a properly done survey can help corporations manage employee morale and increase customer satisfaction. It can give managers important information with answers to questions about whether employees feel like they are being challenged by their work, treated considerately and compensated fairly. 
 "In a down environment like this one, you make better business decisions with information," Mr. Saltzman said. "It's important to know what to cut back on and what not to cut back on. Are layoffs and cutbacks right or wrong for this company at this time?"
Sirota had very few projects postponed during the latest recession. Over the last two years the privately held company grew to employ 40 full-time and 40 part-time employees, working for many Fortune 100 companies, and other mid-sized and large private companies, organizations from the public and nonprofit sector as well as government agencies. 
Bank of America in Charlotte, N.C., engaged Sirota last year to conduct what has become its annual "Associate Survey" process, a comprehensive survey of all 145,000 employees , from C.E.O. to janitor.
"The recession made it even more important for us to look for better ways of running our business," said Ronald J. Meadows, the bank's senior vice president of leadership development. "Strategically when you're looking for ways to grow your business you have to look at all the elements that affect it. We recognize that if we can find ways of engaging our associates more creatively, then our customers are more likely to do business with us, expand their business with us, and ultimately improve our business." 
Sirota moved to Purchase about four years ago, from the upper East Side of Manhattan. Its employees include industrial organizational psychologists, several statisticians, project managers and Web programmers. The company handles about 130 projects per year.
Sirota isn't the only survey company prospering through the recession, said Dr. Jack Wiley, president and C.E.O. of Ganz Wiley Research, a Minneapolis-based company that is one of Sirota's competitors. Despite some delays and postponements of research projects in early 2001, Dr. Wiley said, things began to rebound in second quarter 2001 and the fourth quarter was the best the company has seen to date.
"Forward-thinking companies see strategic measuring symptoms as a critical management tool," Dr. Wiley explained. "Employee surveys can detect the difference between performance leaders and performance laggers."
When Sirota Consulting was founded in 1972 by David Sirota, who had retired from his position as head of personnel research for I.B.M., its initial goal was to help companies manage their employees. I.B.M. was one of Sirota's first clients. 
Mr. Saltzman began working for the company in 1988, after seeing the company from the client side when he hired Sirota to do a survey for his employer, Timken Corporation, an Ohio-based steel bearings company. Mr. Saltzman, a Queens native and graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton, had studied psychology along with classmates who were pursuing careers in clinical psychology. He said he found that he preferred "organizational neuroses" to "individual neuroses" and, after embarking on his industrial psychology career, was delighted to find that the pay exceeds the pay standards for clinical psychology.
In 1996, he bought Sirota Consulting with a partner, Douglas A. Klein, another industrial organizational psychologist, who is now president of the business.
"Linking employee surveys with customer satisfaction gave Sirota Consulting a unique vantage point," said Mr. Saltzman. "We had the ability to predict that components of employee satisfaction, such as a sense of equity, feeling rewarded, salary satisfaction and advancement opportunities, along with a sense of achievement and enjoyment of the challenge of the work, would lead to increased customer satisfaction."
The correlation between satisfied workers and happy customers is present in nearly all the surveys Sirota Consulting performs. And that, Saltzman said, represents big dollars for the surveying companies. Armed with information from the surveys, companies can make informed decisions. Surveys are conducted by telephone, on the Web, on in-house computer networks and sometimes through focus groups.
The average questionnaire ranges from 75 to 125 questions, although some have been longer. While questions are specifically tailored for the client corporation, questionnaires will include questions like "How would you rate your pay, your benefits, your boss?" "Are you treated with respect and dignity?" "How much direct feedback do you get on performance?" 
All questionnaires have one or two questions that include norms that are tracked by Sirota from one company to the next, to show how companies compare overall. 
Research is used in many different ways. Mr. Saltzman gave some examples: When advertising revenues dried up at a well-known business journal, the journal was wrestling with whether to keep personnel or lay some off. Based on customer surveys that indicated that the advertisers seek stability, known and well-trained contacts, the journal decided not to opt for layoffs. 
When British Petroleum merged with Amoco and Arco, Sirota was called in to perform a study in the refineries. Their findings indicated that employees had fewer accidents on the job when there was better employee satisfaction. In companies where managers were taught how to help employees deal with demands on the job -- prioritizing conflicting demands -- and where supervisors were better trained to deal with employees, there were fewer accidents.
"We look for what's important, but also for what's constant," Mr. Saltzman said. "Given everything that's going on with the economies, traumas in different parts of the world and all the external factors, what are the things that don't change? In looking at a company with hundreds of retail establishments, why does store A do better than store B? It always boils down to the leadership of the organization."
Mr. Saltzman, a 42-year-old resident of Pleasantville, was recently contacted by representatives of a Chinese government agency, he was asked to open an office in China, after its entry into the World Trade Organization to help Chinese organizations become more effective in the global economy in terms of how they manage their employees and do business in China. Although the logistics are quite complicated, Mr. Saltzman finds the project irresistible.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
War's Long Shadow Falls on 'Hearts'

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
THE word was out. "Hearts" at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is a loser. 
 Willy Holtzman's work, which opened on March 13, had already been called "the worst new play in memory" by one reviewer while another was driven to descriptions like hack, cliche, old hat, cheap and tawdry. 
 But a semblance of objective distancing is a critic's reason for being. Besides, Mr. Holtzman's biographically rooted play about the repressed memories of his father, a World War II veteran, won the Arthur Miller Award for Dramatic Writing, whatever that means. Various stagings in small regional theaters followed. 
Still, one could not help expecting a poorly attended house at Long Wharf last Sunday afternoon, presumably peopled by sorry subscribers.
Instead, a capacity audience stood during curtain calls, shouts of bravo resounding. Throughout the performance, which lasts little more than 90 minutes, people's reactions were more telling and interesting than virtually any onstage goings-on. Thank heaven for the audience.
Oh, the play. It is rambling, overextended and manipulative, shamelessly pushing emotional buttons. Wallowing in an excess of graphic toilet jokes at the expense of character development and carefully wrought details, "Hearts" is so lacking in a sense of economy, it appears to be on the promising brink of calling it quits for perhaps 40 minutes.
While this may not be the worst new play in this theatergoer's memory, it qualifies as the longest short one in ages.
What then does such dramaturgical intelligence have to do with the connection between five actors, playing some 20 parts, to an audience of almost 500? Is the recognition factor in a sketchy wartime memoir all it takes to move people? How can so many be visibly affected by a dreadful play? 
It wasn't until the 1998 film "Saving Private Ryan" that the memories of haunted World War II veterans were uncloseted in a big way. Veterans' support groups sprouted, emotionally scarred men in their 70's came forth, telling horrific stories, television shows discovered a newly resonant issue. 
The issues touched, just touched, by the playwright in "Hearts," creates sharing possibilities for many people. 
It should be noted that much of the Long Wharf audience last Sunday belonged to an age group still in touch with the immediacy of a life- altering event. After the performance, one woman could not stop weeping. Another, a subscriber for 10 years said, "This is the best play I have ever seen here." Most of the audience remained for a post-performance symposium, titled "Aftershock of the Greatest Generation," which was led by a psychiatrist and a historian. 
The great divide between critical endorsement and audience enthusiasm is a mysterious given. No one bothers to investigate the mystery. 
Critics jeer. Audiences cheer. So, what else is new?
But "Hearts" is not "Footloose." And it is not a tacky made-for-stock comedy. Does its box-office power depend on Dan Lauria, once a television name ("The Wonder Years")? Mr. Lauria is the only cast member assigned to one role, through which he roars, barks and bellows, stand-up style, when he isn't just declaiming lines at top volume.
Don't expect an attempt at audience-critic reconciliation here. What audiences and which critics should agree anyway? Perhaps "Hearts" represents a stage work desperately in need of niche marketing.
No theater savvy person will agree that content determines a play's value. Tedious plays have been written about the holocaust, about racism, about all manner of social injustice. Is "Hearts" so pertinent that it exists apart from theater standards and priorities, debatable as those are? Such are the new unanswerable questions to add to the age-old ones.
"Hearts" by Willy Holtzman. Long Wharf Theater, 222 Sargent Drive, New Haven. Performances through next Sunday. Box office: (203) 787-4282. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vasili Bogazianos, left, as Mike, and Dan Lauria as Donald in the World War II-based play, "Hearts," at New Haven's Long Wharf Theater. (T. Charles Erickson)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
16 Years Later, a Journey's End Nears

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A 110-ACRE hilltop site overlooking the Hudson here seemed a natural for development 16 years ago. The property, a former girls' boarding school with its extensive grounds, convent and a chapel with 55 stained-glass windows, even lent itself to an evocative name: Chapel Hill. 
 But economic forces frustrated the plans of a series of five developers, even as weather and disuse attacked the old school buildings. The mansion that had housed the nuns was torn down, and Peekskill gave one developer permission to tear down the chapel. Eventually, 245 of the planned 439 condominiums were built, but none of the developers were able to see their plans to completion. 
 Now a prominent Westchester builder, buoyed by a strong market for condominiums, is bringing the project to completion. Foundations and framing are under way for the first of what will be 194 condominium units, a remaining classroom building is to be turned into lofts and apartments, and the chapel itself is being restored and prepared for a new role. 
The 82-year-old chapel was built by the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, the Catholic order that operated the school, to which young women with difficulties were sent by the New York City Welfare Department. 
In its new incarnation, the building -- which was approved for demolition in 1995 by the City Council -- will become a residents' community center and exercise club. "Luckily for us, the previous developer who wanted to raze it never got that far," said Peekskill's mayor, John G. Testa. "My concern since 1998, when I first became a councilman, has been to preserve the chapel, the character of the property and its historical value.
"To have a development called Chapel Hill without the chapel doesn't make sense," said the 43-year-old mayor, who describes himself as passionate about Peekskill's history. His father, Joseph Testa, was a night watchman at the school for many years, and the mayor himself, when he was in high school and college, worked there as a dishwasher and groundskeeper. He recalled "a very tranquil place, where the nuns treated me as part of their family." He added, "It was like a second home to me."
Although the land today is much different than it was when Mayor Testa visited it as youth -- with the barns, the convent and most of the other buildings gone -- he said he was pleased to see the chapel being used and the old orchard intact.
The Chapel Hill site was one of four in the city owned by religious institutions that seemed destined for development in the 80's. Plans for them changed over time, and are still evolving -- early this month an order of Episcopal nuns, the Sisters of St. Mary, agreed to sell the last of its property to a developer who plans a health facility there. 
The earliest building on the Chapel Hill site was a 3,000-square-foot mansion built in 1865 by Daniel H. Craig, the founder of The Associated Press. The Italianate-style house in the country was built by the executive for his daughter, Florence, who suffered from tuberculosis. A history of the site, written in 1952 by Chester A. Smith, said Mr. Craig "saved his daughter's health but lost his fortune, and the property went to foreclosure." 
The site, which Mr. Craig called Mount Florence, was acquired for $32,000 by Marshall Lefferts, a colonel during the Civil War, who was president of a number of early telegraph companies. In 1874, the Craig estate was sold to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, and they began calling it Mount St. Florence even though there is no St. Florence. Girls from 12 to 16 were referred to the school by the Welfare Department of the City of New York.
The nuns built other structures on the site for the school, some of which still stand. But the Craig house, which fell into disrepair late in the 20th century, was taken down last year. 
The 16,000-square-foot chapel, which had 55 German-made stained-glass windows and an altar with a 25-foot-high marble canopy, was built by the sisters in 1920. John K. Karhu, an architect based in Oceanside, N.Y., who is overseeing the renovation, said the chapel is notable for its fine detail -- including exterior cornices and trim, very large arched windows, and crown and dentil trim inside. The church is listed on the New York State Register of Historic Places.
"We're trying to maintain the integrity of this special building, to have a reverence for it," the architect said.
Several small sections of the original stained-glass windows remain in the building, but most of the larger sections have been removed. They are being stored by the city, possibly to be displayed later in the city's museum. At least one entire window may be displayed in the new community center, Mayor Testa said. 
During the years after the nuns left in the late 1970's, the chapel suffered extensive water and weather damage, and Mr. Karhu said the renovation is expected to cost $2.5 million.
THE exterior brick has required extensive work, and the window lintels were rusting and are being repaired. The old wooden window frames were beyond repair, he said, although the original size and shape of the arched windows, which are 14 feet tall and 6 feet wide, have been retained.
Inside the chapel, the marble platform that held the altar with four rose-colored columns is to become a garden and a fountain. The vaulted ceilings and a round stained-glass panel in the ceiling are being restored.
Among other things, the community center will house a lounge, media center, exercise center and what Martin Ginsburg, the founder and president of Ginsburg Development, called "an awe-inspiring indoor basketball court," with several sections of the stained glass windows.
Outside, the developer is building a 40-foot-by-60-foot swimming pool, a playground and a tennis court. 
Mr. Ginsburg said it would have been less expensive to raze the chapel and build a new community center, but he wanted to keep the old building as a symbol of what came before.
The hilltop site was first developed for housing by the Mount Florence Group, which purchased it from the religious order in 1986. In the 1970's, the sisters had decided to divest themselves of the property because they believed it would be more beneficial to work with young people "in their own communities, in an environment familiar to them," said Sister Paulette LoMonaco, a spokeswoman for the order, which is based in Queens. They also closed another residential school, Villa Loretto, near Mount St. Florence.
Chapel Hill was one of four dormant church-owned sites that Peekskill rezoned for redevelopment in the early 1980's, when George E. Pataki was mayor of the city. The rezoning, along with the promise of quick approvals and public subsidies, lured several major developers into Peekskill.
Of the other formerly church-owned sites, only one, the former home of St. Peter's School, was developed; about 300 condominiums were built there during the 1980's.
At another site, St. Joseph's Home, which was a convent and orphanage, 20 acres are being considered for condominiums by Ginsburg Development. 
The third site has been owned by an Episcopal order of nuns, the Sisters of St. Mary, which moved to the property in 1872 and had a convent, a school and a home for orphans there. The nuns first sold 47 acres to Cappelli Enterprises, which planned to develop luxury high-rise condominiums. But after encountering objections from the public and from the city, Cappelli decided not to proceed with the project. Now, the national nonprofit Trust for Public Land has an option to acquire the site, known as Fort Hill, which was a lookout point for colonial troops during the Revolutionary War. The group is offering the company $3.75 million for the historic site and plans to preserve it as open space. 
Earlier this month, the Sisters of St. Mary contracted to sell their remaining 26 acres to a private developer, Top of the Mountain Inc., which is planning to build a wellness center and rehabilitation facilities there, according to Tom LaPerch, a broker with McGrath & Basciano Associates Inc., real estate consultants in Fishkill specializing in institutional properties. The developer is in discussions with medical institutions about setting up the facilities and intends to use the buildings that are already on the site, he said. The nuns plan to move in 2003 to Albany and to establish a new convent there.
At Chapel Hill, the first prospective developer, the Mount Florence Group, was a joint venture of I AM Properties of Newburgh, N.Y., and Corcoran, Mullins, Jennison Inc. of Quincy, Mass. But after failing to get the school buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places, which would have enabled them to receive tax credits to help turn the old school site into housing, the developers defaulted on a $10 million mortgage. By the time the last certificate of occupancy was issued to the Mount Florence Group in 1989, 70 town houses and 48 garden apartments had been built, records in City Hall show.
In 1991, another developer, M.M.E. Powers, built about 20 town houses before leaving the project in 1993.
In 1994, the undeveloped sections were acquired by the Chapel Hill Development Corporation from a subsidiary of Fleet Bank for $1.25 million, including back taxes, according to records in City Hall. That developer built 32 units.
In 1997, another company, called Lepack, completed 75 unfinished town houses started by M.M.E. Powers, bringing the total number of units to 245. 
Last summer, Ginsburg Development acquired the undeveloped property, along with the existing church buildings, from Chapel Hill Development for $4 million. Ginsburg, based in Hawthorne, expects to spend about $60 million to complete the project. 
Ginsburg has cleared away abandoned buildings, poured 32 foundations and framed in 10 housing units in addition to beginning work on the chapel. The first units are to be ready for occupancy in June.
When completed, Chapel Hill will consist of six residential areas, three of which were developed by the previous builders. Ginsburg is now developing two new phases of two- and three-bedroom, semiattached homes and attached town houses in seven models. Some of the three-bedroom models have room for an optional fourth bedroom.
Prices start at $288,900 for a 1,688-square-foot, two-bedroom model with a one-car garage and reach $429,900 for a 2,202-square-foot, three-bedroom model with a two car garage. Thirty-five of the new units have already been sold. 
THE developer is also planning to renovate the former St. Germaine School building, a five-story brick structure next door to the church. That building will be converted to condominium lofts and apartments. Sale prices for the apartments, which will not be ready for occupancy until 2004, have not yet been set. 
For Mayor Testa, completion of the project means that an important part of the city's history will be saved and that Peekskill's 22,441 residents will probably be spared a tax increase next year because of the income generated by the new residences. 
The residents of Chapel Hill say they are pleased that after other developers have come and gone without completing their projects, this developer may finally deliver amenities of the sort that had been promised over the years. "There were too many years when other developers broke too many promises to us," said Charlotte Sperling, a retired special education teacher and a resident of Chapel Hill since 1998. "Now things are really happening."
While many residents welcome the new recreation center, Robert Rubenfeld, a board member on the Chapel Hill Estate Homeowners Association, said that Mr. Ginsburg, like the other developers, was not making good on at least some of his promises to residents. As a board member, Mr. Rubenfeld contacted Mr. Ginsburg about two years ago and asked him if he would be interested in purchasing the property and finishing the project.
In particular, Mr. Rubenfeld, who moved into his two-bedroom condominium in 1989, said Mr. Ginsburg had promised to build an indoor pool, but was now reneging. Mr. Ginsburg said that an indoor pool had been under consideration but that the cost was found to be too high.
"I bought into this hoping for a full lifestyle community," said Mr. Rubenfeld, who grew up in Peekskill and works in Manhattan as a director of interagency coordination with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
But even without an indoor pool, Mr. Ginsburg's proposed amenities package will be appealing to most new buyers, said Suzanne Macci, a real estate agent and the owner of Vintage Hudson Realty in Peekskill. "In the last two years, the condo market has been so hot that things are selling well everywhere," she said.
According to Arlene and Gerald Kolosky, who live in a two-bedroom condo, what residents really need in Chapel Hill is a sense of community. "We need an outdoor pool and a clubhouse because we need a place for the neighbors to get to know each other," said Mrs. Kolosky, a residential sales agent with Coldwell Banker in Yorktown. "We want a place to spend an evening together, to play bridge, to build a lending library. An indoor pool is not worth fighting about now."
Mayor Testa echoed the residents' sentiments. "We've done everything to keep the character of what this place once was and at the same time finally move ahead," he said. "What's most important is that completion of the project is at last in sight."
