HEADLINE: Lab Space Is Bright Spot in Dim Cambridge Market 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
OVER the last 18 months, as Internet and telecommunications tenants have evaporated, the vacancy rate in this small, high-priced office market has been soaring. But as vacancies in office buildings increased, the market for laboratories -- the most expensive space of all -- tightened. As a result, several new commercial projects are being repositioned from offices, telecommunications facilities or industrial sites to laboratories for life science companies engaged in biotechnological and biopharmaceutical research, product development and manufacture.
 At the end of 2001, the overall vacancy rate for the 17.5 million square feet of commercial space here was 18.5 percent, compared with 1.2 percent at the end of 1999. In East Cambridge, a neighborhood fronting on the Charles River that is flush with new development, vacancies have reached 21 percent. 
 But for the 7.3 million square feet of existing biotechnology space, which is about 70 percent laboratories and 30 percent offices, the citywide vacancy rate is 0.25 percent as of the end of last year. When 11 commercial conversion projects (shell buildings that landlords are marketing or converting for laboratories), are included, the rate rises to 8.3 percent, according to Joseph P. Flaherty, senior vice president at Meredith & Grew Inc./Oncor, a full service real estate firm. 
In 2000, when the first signs of weakness appeared in the office market, some property owners who were designing offices scrapped those plans to build laboratories instead. The relative demand was so strong that in one case last year plans to build a rental apartment building -- in a city with a chronic housing shortage -- were replaced by blueprints for a more costly lab.
Now, other owners who find themselves with empty telecommunications, industrial or office building shells are trying to convert them into laboratories.
At University Park, a mixed-use project near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that is to have 1.6 million square feet of commercial space and 420 units of housing when completed, two buildings now under construction that had been planned as offices were redesigned in 2000 for biotechnology tenants, according to Peter Calkins, senior vice president of development for Forest City Enterprises, the project's developer. It owns the buildings at University Park, and M.I.T. owns the 27 acres of land.
The two buildings that became labs have 345,000 square feet of space and were converted to respond to space demands of expanding University Park biotechnology tenants. Another building at University Park was going to be the 235-apartment rental building, but last year Forest City decided to put a 241,000-square-foot biotechnology laboratory there. 
M.I.T. currently owns 10 million square feet of buildings for academic use, 3 million square feet of commercial property and the land at University Park. A year ago, the university purchased Technology Square, a complex that has 872,000 square feet in six buildings, of which 254,000 square feet is vacant.
OF the vacant space, only 36,000 square feet are laboratories, which M.I.T. may use itself. If not, "whatever lab space we bring to market we can lease," said Joseph T. McGuire Jr., M.I.T.'s director of real estate.
A significant portion of the empty space at Technology Square involves a single building. Completed last fall, it had been 90 percent preleased to the Internet company Akamai Technologies, which never occupied its 114,000 square feet of space. Instead, last month, Akamai paid M.I.T. $15 million to dissolve the lease. 
In total, 11 Cambridge buildings have recently been or soon may be repositioned for use by life science tenants: the three at University Park, one at Technology Square, four in East Cambridge (two owned by Lyme Properties, one by the Beal Companies and one by Laverty & Lohnes L.L.C.), a former candy factory near M.I.T. (owned by DSF Advisers) and two on Memorial Drive, which runs along the river (owned by Alexandria Real Estate Equities Inc., a biotechnology real estate investment trust). 
These property owners' preference for biotechnology is simply explained: demand is strong and rents are high. "Biotechnology is expanding, so the demand is there," said Mr. Calkins of Forest City. "With rising construction costs, the economics for offices isn't that great, but the return on investment for biotech is better, and they're always 100 percent preleased."
Current rents for labs are clearly more attractive. Offices here are now leasing for $25 to $40 a square foot annually, compared with $60 for labs. But the property owner who invests in developing laboratories must be prepared to make a big investment. 
To construct the shell of an office building here costs about $125 a square foot. For the landlord to fit it out for office tenants costs about another $25 a square foot.
The shell for a laboratory costs about $200 a square foot. The landlord must then invest another $75 a square foot to build out the space for a biotechnology tenant. The tenant will then invest an additional $150 to $300 a square foot to equip the space, said David L. Pergola, executive vice president of Meredith & Grew Inc./Oncor.
To convert an office building shell to a building that could serve the needs of life science tenants -- who require higher ceilings, sturdier floors and more intensive climate control, ventilation and electrical power -- calls for an investment of an additional $75 to $100 a square foot, Mr. Pergola estimated.
"Basically the major Cambridge developers -- M.I.T., the Beal Companies, the Lyme Company -- are attempting to recapture general purpose buildings for biotech use," he said. "While demand for offices has diminished, biotech is expanding, fueled by an increase in venture capital funding, the drive by pharmaceutical firms to develop new products and substantial National Institute of Health funds funneled to Massachusetts."
Of approximately 200 biotechnology companies in New England, about 85 percent, with 20,000 workers, are in Cambridge and Boston.
In the six-state region as a whole, perhaps 50 of the biotechnology companies are publicly traded. As a group, from June 2000 to June 2001, the revenues of the publicly traded companies totaled $3.6 billion, up 50 percent from a year earlier. Their losses that year were $1 billion, up 25 percent from the previous year, said Stephen Buckley, New England director of the life science practice for Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm.
Much of the space designated for conversion in Cambridge has not been leased yet, but brokers estimate that it will be absorbed in 9 to 12 months compared with an estimated 24 months to fill all the vacant office space.
However, they caution against considering biotech tenants to be the cure for all that ails the office market. "Biotech isn't the savior of the office market," said Gregory P. Lucas, senior managing director at Insignia/ESG Inc. "Cambridge has always been the East Coast center for the biotech industry. But, for the past decade or so, its growth here as an industry has been very steady and will continue to be so."
Furthermore, the investment in biotech space is so high that it is appropriate only for investors with deep pockets who plan to hold the property for a long time.
In addition, few properties designed for office use can be converted into biotech laboratories. Mr. Maguire at M.I.T. said, "Most office buildings can't be converted." Biotech laboratories require 30 watts of electrical power per square foot compared with 15 watts per square foot for offices; they also need floors that can hold more weight, and air control systems that recirculate 100 percent of the air versus 20 percent recirculated in offices. With more equipment in the building, floor to ceiling heights need to be higher and the penthouse that contains mechanical systems is larger.
The biotechnology sector may help bolster the Cambridge market until a resurgent economy revives the office market. But, over time, it is likely that the Cambridge commercial property market will continue to experience drastic swings in vacancies and rental rates. As the home of high-powered academic institutions, Cambridge is a center of innovation. 
"We deal with a lot of new, technology oriented industries that rely on venture capital funding," Mr. Maguire said. "As some companies move from research to product development, they leave for less expensive locations; others, like the dot-coms and telecom, just tank."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Next for Stamford's Harbor: a 40 Acre Development

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: STAMFORD 

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years, Stamford has struggled to refute the deprecatory phrase "city without an identity," as it worked its way through redevelopment, from fading industrial town to the commercial, financial and residential center that it has become.
 Now an ambitious plan for a 40-acre development on the city's waterfront has been prepared for the eastern shore of the West Branch of Stamford Harbor, and an application to build the project is to be presented this week to the Stamford Planning and Zoning Boards. At a projected cost of $250 million, the 1.12-million-square-foot complex, to be called Admiral's Wharf, would contain 620 apartments in four buildings, a 275,000-square-foot office building, a maritime center, a ferry terminal and a 275 to 300 slip marina. 
 Facing the project on the opposite shore of the West Branch are Avalon Harbor's 323 apartments and marina under construction and Stamford Landing, an established enclave of apartments, restaurants and marinas. When projects on both its shores are completed, the West Branch is expected to emerge as a maritime playground for tourists and Stamford residents, as well as a coveted residential address. 
Admiral's Wharf's 125,976-square-foot, clock-towered signature building called the Maritime Center will have a maritime museum on the ground floor, along with a fish market, grocery, oyster bar, shops and a 16,000-square-foot restaurant. A major catering service and several banquet rooms will fill the second floor, and on the third floor there are to be 21 live-work lofts of 2,000 square feet each offered to artists, computer companies, sales operations and small businesses as condominiums. They will be delivered to buyers as raw space to be finished by the new owners as they wish. 
The project was designed by Do H. Chung in Georgian colonial style and is being developed by a partnership of JHM Financial Group of Stamford, the Brownfields Recovery Corporation of Boston and Collins Enterprises of Stamford. Its Strand/BRC Group project team is led by Do H. Chung & Partners, architects and planners; Culpen & Wood Architects, associate architects; Thomas Balsey Associates, landscape architects; and Redniss & Mead, planners and civil engineers.
A similar concept, called the Strand, was proposed 10 years ago by Arthur Collins, principal of Collins Enterprises, but on only 14 acres of the southerly portion of the same tract at a projected cost of $90 million. Delayed several times by environmental difficulties, flood zone problems and the recession, it was sidelined but not forgotten. 
Mr. Collins, a developer with an intense focus on waterfront real estate projects, has built several of them. "Waterfronts are harder to do because of environmental issues," he said, "but the value is there and it stays there, resistant to recessions, maintaining its market and moving faster at higher value, because there's less and less of it."
In 2000 he negotiated a purchase agreement with Northeast Utilities, owner of the property, requiring the utility to include a $10 million to $15 million cleanup of contamination in the sale price of $40 million. The purchase will be concluded when the project obtains full approval from municipal, state and federal agencies.
ACCORDING to Richard Redniss, president of Redniss & Mead, a zoning change from "Coastal Water Dependent District," which does not allow housing or restaurants, to "Designer Waterfront District," which supports mixed use, must be obtained. In addition, inland wetlands development faces review by the state Environmental Protection Board and in-water activity needs approval by state and federal agencies.
Finally, the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection must approve the Brownfields Recovery Corporation's remediation of coal tars, cadmium, arsenic, lead, PCB's and petroleum left by a coal gasification plant that operated there decades ago. 
Public hearings are expected to take place this summer, and final approvals could come through in the fall, Mr. Redniss said. Subsequently, the first phase of construction could start at the end of the year with the construction of 150 apartments and the ferry terminal. Completion, Mr. Collins said, could be sometime in 2008.
No decision has been made on marketing the apartments as rentals or condominiums, or both. As condominiums they would sell in the $300,000 to $400,000 range; rentals would run from around $1,300 to $4,300. Each of the four residential buildings will have a landscaped rooftop garden with a decorative pool and paved courtyard for the use of the building's residents. In compliance with a Stamford ordinance, 10 percent of the entire project's units will be occupied by people whose family incomes do not exceed 80 percent of the area median, which is $109,000 for a family of four.
Construction of the six-story office building will be contingent on securing a major tenant. With 60,000 square feet on each floor, Mr. Collins said, "we would hope that tenants looking for 200,000 square feet would give us serious consideration."
Parking for 2,142 cars will be in basements and multilevel structures within the various buildings, with an additional 150 surface spaces.
People on foot, bicycles or in-line skates would enter the property where Washington Boulevard joins Admiral's Wharf's 4,000-foot-long, 12-foot-wide paved promenade, which is to follow the perimeter of the project and is to be landscaped with gardens, flowering trees, pergolas, a play area for tots, lawns and a paved overlook at the ferry dock. 
THE promenade is to be integrated into the city's Waterfront Public Access, a linear park running from the Mill River at Broad Street through downtown, into and around the entire South End. 
The marina, which is to be acquired by Admiral's Wharf, is widely known as Brewer's Yacht Haven, with land storage for 600 boats and full boat service. Jack Brewer, who leases the property from Northeast Utilities, did not respond to phone calls about comments by John H. McClutchy, a principal in JHM Financial Group, one of the project partners, who said: "Brewer might be replaced. We are taking proposals from other operators." 
Stamford's waterfront, the last of its land mass to be reclaimed from industrial and residential blight, includes the South End and Waterside, both left behind in the frenzy of office building and roadway expansion north of Interstate 95. They are now faced with massive increases in traffic navigating a maze of narrow one-way streets leading to the Stamford Railroad Station and highway. 
"Widening and deepening the Washington Boulevard portal under the railroad is under reconstruction," said Thomas Bruccoleri, Stamford's transportation planner, and grants from the Federal Highway Administration will build a new roadway south of the highway, with lanes for cars, buses, bikes and shuttles and a sidewalk from Elm Street to Atlantic Street and the station, eliminating the worst of the substandard streets. Also under way is a new 1,000-car parking garage at Station Place and Atlantic Street, to be attached by an elevated walkway to the existing 900-car garage. 
The city's commitment to reclaim its waterfront is perceived by some critics to be happening at the expense of history and diversity in Waterside and the South End -- the small former "company" houses once occupied by multitudes of factory workers and the long-established black, Polish and Italian neighborhoods.
Mayor Dannel Malloy insists that "we're not going to see a total displacement of industry, and a lot of older housing will probably be restored, so I think Waterside and the South End will be mixed communities with light industry, lots of offices, parks, a ferry service, and we're going to see 2,000 to 3,000 units of housing come to the South End over the next 10 years."
Dismissing fears among downtown merchants and office building owners that a second city is being born south of the highway, he said: "It's not going to compete with downtown. It's a different style of development -- low-rise, nowhere near the 350-foot height or commercial density of downtown Stamford."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Wall Street'sLatin Spotlight Dims

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
ON his recent sojourn through Latin America, President Bush extolled the economic potential of Mexico, Peru and other nations that are opening their markets and pursuing free trade.
 It was an encouraging message for the region, but it contrasted sharply with recent moves by several large American brokerage firms. In a major strategic shift, they have removed their most influential Latin American strategists and slimmed down their research and sales operations. 
 The firms now track just a handful of the biggest companies in the most stable countries and ignore hundreds of small and midsize Latin American enterprises that they used to follow.
It has all the makings of a retreat, and when combined with grim financial news out of Argentina, Venezuela and other countries, it further dims the allure of emerging-markets investments. 
But the firms say they are not retrenching. They say Latin America is still important, even if the economic slowdown in the United States has made it necessary to pare costs. The realignment, they say, simply reflects the changing attitudes of institutional investors, who want to lower risk and increase returns.
The new attitude has sent ripples across the hemisphere, but it is also opening opportunities for individual investors willing to do their own research and take local risks while the big firms focus on global markets.
"What we're seeing is a sudden understanding of the fact that globalization means that one makes choices on a global scale, and that implies less regionalism in markets," said Albert Fishlow, senior economist at Violy, Byorum & Partners. "The reactions of the big brokerage firms to this trend are, in part, a re-evaluation of their position in the regions as a whole, and more of a focus on individual companies and opportunities."
Over the last nine months, three of the leading Latin American strategists on Wall Street have either parted ways with their employers or left the positions they held for many years. The companies do not want to say much about the separations. Neither do their former employees, who may plan to re-enter the Latin American market. But it is clear that the catalyst for the moves was a shift in strategy.
Ian Laming, the chief Latin American equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for seven years, and twice named top Latin American strategist by Institutional Investor magazine, switched over to European equity research in July. Eduardo M. Cabrera, Merrill Lynch's chief Latin America strategist, along with four other members of the Latin strategy team, left the company in August. And Jorge O. Mariscal, chief emerging-markets strategist and head of Latin America research for Goldman, Sachs, left his company in October.
Early this month, Lehman Brothers melded its Latin American research group into its North American research group. In Latin America itself, Merrill Lynch has closed its retail sales offices in Santiago, Chile, and Buenos Aires over the last year. Goldman Sachs has cut its staff in Mexico, while selling its seat on the Mexican stock exchange.
THE realignment is being driven by several important trends. Most major privatizations of state-owned companies have been completed, ending what had been a lucrative opportunity for many investors. And a wave of acquisitions by Spanish and American companies led to the delisting of companies on local exchanges, reducing the number of interesting stocks available, lowering sales volumes and reducing the need for staff.
The new focus also reflects a shift in the structure and handling of emerging markets the world over. Big investors were originally lured to these markets as an alternative to overvalued American stocks; Mexico funds and other country-specific funds became the hot new thing.
But after the Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95, such funds were regarded as too risky. They were replaced by regional funds focusing on several Latin countries. That way, risk would be spread if there was a crisis in just one country.
The approach worked for a while, but the widespread fallout of the Asian financial collapse in 1997, Russia's devaluation in 1998 and the Brazilian devaluation in 1999 set in motion another change, this time from regional funds to international funds.
Most recently, as globalization has spread, investors have shifted focus again, this time to global emerging-market funds that encompass only the largest and most stable developing countries. These funds included a combination of stocks -- some picked for their nationality, others for their sector -- like telecommunications.
In the heyday of its Latin America strategy, the emerging-markets research division at Goldman, Sachs tracked as many as 120 Latin companies. The Latin America research group at Merrill Lynch typically followed as many as 200. At the same time, a Mexico fund could include up to 100 companies in Mexico alone.
Now, a global emerging-markets fund will include no more than 100 large, well-capitalized companies from around the world. Of those, perhaps 20 will be from Latin America, and of those, no more than seven or eight will be Mexican. 
"In the old days, diversification went deeper, and that meant that small and medium-sized companies were able to attract the foreign investment they needed to grow," said Mr. Mariscal, the former equities strategist at Goldman, Sachs. "Today, things are far more concentrated, and the small-cap companies just don't make it onto the radar screens of the big firms."
Mr. Mariscal, now a consultant in New York, says the big global fund managers are interested primarily in huge companies like Telefonos de Mexico, Groupo Televisa and Cemex in Mexico, Banco Itau and Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao in Brazil and a handful of others.
The big firms say the region remains crucial to their overall strategy, although in a different way. In essence, they say, parts of the market have matured faster than others. Corrado P. Varoli, managing director and head of Latin American investment banking at Goldman, Sachs, said this "segmentation" has made a few big, successful companies in large countries like Mexico and Brazil every investor's top choices while excluding just about everything else.
AS this new reality takes hold, opportunities emerge for individual investors. They can follow the big investment firms and concentrate on the few big-company stocks, most of which trade in New York either directly or as American depositary receipts.
But those stocks now tend to be overpriced. An alternative approach for those with a tolerance for risk is to pick up stocks of small and midsize companies now overlooked by the big firms. "Prices have drifted down, trading volumes have shrunk and the stocks are very attractively priced," said Peter Gruber, president of the Globalvest Management Company, which invests in Latin America.
Mr. Gruber said some stocks that have fallen out of favor with the big brokerage firms can be attractive. They include Telemig Celular Participacoes and Tele Norte Celular Participacoes, both telecommunications companies in Brazil. Mr. Mariscal named Internacional de Ceramica, a construction materials company, and Corporacion Interamerica de Entretenimiento, an entertainment company, in Mexico, and Lojas Arapua, a retailer, in Brazil.
Such second-tier stocks can pose a problem: once they are bought, they can be difficult to sell, because so few shares are traded. Mr. Gruber's company, which manages several funds that acquire emerging-market stocks trading at about half of book value, gets around that obstacle by looking for companies that are merger or acquisition candidates.
"If companies are discounted and they show me an exit," Mr. Gruber said, "I'll buy them."

An article last Sunday about brokerage firms' declining presence in Latin America referred incorrectly to moves by Merrill Lynch in the last year. Although it transferred some employees to New York from Santiago, Chile, and Buenos Aires, its retail sales offices in both South American cities remain open.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
For Resourceful Students, the Internet Is a Key to Scholarships

BYLINE:  By KATY MCLAUGHLIN 

 BODY:
STUDENTS and their families have been hearing stories for years about how millions of dollars in scholarship money goes unclaimed each year. While some money may be left over, scholarship experts say, the amount is probably much less than it used to be.
 "As fast as we get it in, we give it all out," said William H. Grey III, president of the United Negro College Fund, which awarded $45 million in scholarships in 2001, a 10 percent increase from the previous year. 
 More students have been applying for scholarships, Mr. Grey and other fund administrators say, because of a weak economy, a volatile stock market that has eaten away at college nest eggs, and easier access to scholarship information online. Some colleges and universities, meanwhile, have been relaxing financial-aid policies by promising not to cut or reduce aid when students receive certain scholarship money. 
The private-sector money flowing into scholarships has not stopped. "Foundations and corporations are maintaining their commitments," Mr. Grey said.
The Xerox Corporation, for instance, has not reduced the $2.5 million it gives each year for scholarships in its Xerox Foundation. "We know kids need this money right now, especially in this economy," said Joseph M. Calahan, the vice president of the foundation.
With more than 700,000 scholarships available from over 25,000 providers annually, careful planning is crucial for winning some of it. A good time to start is in a student's second or third year of high school -- scholarship deadlines are generally in the spring of the junior and senior years. High school guidance counselors can point students and their families in the right direction; they can recommend scholarships offered by specific colleges or community groups and discuss qualifications. Other sources to check include employers, trade organizations and labor unions.
Perhaps the best scholarship resource is the Internet. Web sites specializing in scholarships and college financial aid have proliferated in recent years, and many are free for users.
One of the most popular free services is Scholarships.com, which matches students to scholarships, grants, fellowships and internships from an extensive database. Lawrence Gerber, the president of Scholarships.com, says it has been receiving 15,000 visitors a day, on average, up from 7,500 at this time last year.
Another source is FastWeb.com. Tom Lubin, president of FastWeb, said the site does not have to charge fees for its services because it makes money by selling registered users' information to marketing partners.
In addition, there are pay sites like ScholarshipExperts.com, which charges annual fees starting at $29.95. It says it owns a database of more than two million scholarships totaling nearly $14 billion.
The service was founded in January 2001 by Ali Azhar, 24, of Jacksonville, Fla., who paid for his own college education with scholarships based on a relentless two-year search in public libraries. Mr. Azhar says he has no way to determine what percentage of his clients receive the scholarships for which they apply.
Mark Kantrowitz, the publisher of FinAid .com, an informational Web site owned by FastWeb, says 6 percent of FastWeb users get scholarships through the site, based on a 2000 study.
As they search the Internet, students and their families should be wary. Each year, many people fall prey to scholarship fraud, most of it online. The Federal Trade Commission warns consumers to be alert for companies that make guarantees, ask for money or credit card account numbers in order to "hold a scholarship" or promise to do all the work. The F.T.C. says that since 1996 it has sued nine companies accusing them of bilking consumers of more than $20 million by making false claims. (The agency posts a list of defendants and settlements on its Web site, www.ftc.gov.)
The legitimate online services maintain that they provide users with a list of only those programs for which they potentially qualify. This filter is a time saver, because many private-sector funds are designated for members of particular groups or for students who meet any other criteria based on financial need or merit.
THE Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, for example, set up a $1 billion program in 1999 to send 20,000 low-income students to college over 20 years. The fund, though, is restricted to students who are African-American, Native American, Alaskan native, Asian Pacific islander or Hispanic. Another example of a restricted scholarship is one from the King Faisal Foundation, sponsored by the Saudi Arabian monarchy, which offers generous grants that cover the full cost of a college education, a travel budget and a $400 monthly stipend. Only "good Muslims of good character" need apply.
Many scholarship funds have sprung up to help victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, and they also have restrictions. The W. M. Keck Foundation Scholarship, administrated by the United Negro College Fund, was set up for students who were indirectly affected. The students must attend private, historically black colleges and universities.
A recent recipient was Kimberly Usher, a freshman at Dillard University in New Orleans, who was awarded $12,500 in scholarship money last month. 
Ms. Usher, though, did not learn about the fund from a Web site, publication, or financial aid office. "I think it was God," she said. 
While Ms. Usher, 20, was driving through the campus parking lot last month, her car bumped into and scratched the car of John P. Donohue, the university's vice president for development. She told him she couldn't pay for the damage until the end of the semester, explaining that money was tight because her mother had lost her job at United Airlines after Sept. 11. Moved by her story, Mr. Donohue encouraged Ms. Usher to apply for the Keck scholarship; she was accepted two weeks after writing the required essay and completing the paperwork.
About 7 percent of undergraduate students receive private-sector money, according to the National Center for Educational Statistics. Most awards, though, are not as large as Ms. Usher's; the average is $2,000. 
With tuition at many colleges in the tens of thousands of dollars, and rising faster than the rate of inflation, that $2,000 average may seem like a drop in the bucket. 
Not so, says Dr. William C. Nelson, president of the Citizens' Scholarship Foundation of America, the administrator of the Dollars for Scholars Fund, which gave $114 million in scholarships in 2001, up from $57 million in 1996. The scholarships are financed by local chapters, which solicit money from businesses and individuals; the average Dollars for Scholars award last year was $1,250.
"Scholarships, even small ones, can often fill the gap between what the parents and the college can provide," Dr. Nelson said. "Sometimes $500 or $2,000 makes the difference between a student being able to go to college, or go to a particular college, or not." 
And, of course, the more ambitious student can go after more than just one scholarship.

College Money, Online
Looking for scholarship information? Here are Web sites that provide free search services:
* Wiredscholar.com, a financial aid site run by Sallie Mae, the education loan provider.
* Collegeboard.com, based on the College Board's annual survey of financial-aid programs.
* Scholarships.com, includes a database of 600,000 scholarships, grants, fellowships and internships.
* FastWeb.com, has a database of 600,000 scholarships totaling $1 billion.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 14, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 31 about the availability of college scholarships misstated the amount of scholarship money given by the Dollars for Scholars program. In 2001, it was $17.5 million, not $114 million; in 1996, it was $10.5 million, not $57 million; and the average award last year was $850, not $1,250. (The incorrect figures represented award money from the Citizens' Scholarship Foundation of America, which administers Dollars for Scholars and other programs.)
The article also misspelled the surname of the foundation's president. He is Dr. William C. Nelsen, not Nelson.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/'The Doomsday Scenario'; 
Blast From the Past: A Cold War Vision of a Nuclear Nightmare

BYLINE:  By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
ATOMIC bombs smuggled into America's cities and set off without warning. The nation under attack from the air. Communications and the economy crippled. Chaos in the streets. One in five Americans dead.
 An apocalyptic Hollywood movie plot? Hardly. In 1958, one year after Nevil Shute published his haunting nuclear holocaust classic "On the Beach," government planners drafted their own top-secret doomsday scenario, speculating in clinical detail about the consequences of a full-scale nuclear attack by the Soviet Union. 
 The Defense Department's Emergency Plans Book, which was declassified by mistake in 1998, has just been published as "The Doomsday Scenario" by MBI Publishing (the book was printed in China, of all places). A historian, L. Douglas Keeney, discovered the plans in the National Archives and annotated the unsugarcoated text, which resonates in the contingency strategies drawn up in Washington after Sept. 11 for preserving government operations and mounting nuclear retaliation. 
Excerpts from the document and Mr. Keeney's accompanying commentary follow. SAM ROBERTS
 The U.S.S.R. is capable of:
a. Producing atomic weapons of varying yields ranging from a few kilotons (thousands of tons) to megatons (millions of tons) of TNT equivalent, biological and chemical agents, and incendiary and high-explosive weapons.
b. Delivering these weapons anywhere within the United States and upon U.S.-deployed forces and Allies by piloted aircraft, submarine-launched missiles or mines or clandestine means. . . .
The planners here assume that the Soviets were at least on par with our own stockpiles, if not ahead. . . . Even in 1958, it was assumed that America would be attacked by biological and chemical weapons. . . . The ability to deliver weapons "anywhere in the United States" . . . acknowledges that the Soviets had superb aeronautical design and manufacturing capabilities.
Warning Capabilities:
Weapons launched from submarines may arrive without warning. Likewise, weapons emplaced by clandestine means may be detonated without warning. . . .
In 1958 little could forewarn when the first nuclear weapons would hit America -- these would be missiles launched from Soviet submarines or bombs hidden inside America. . . . The warning one might expect before a submarine-launched ballistic missile impacted was in the range of 13 minutes. An airborne attack might be preceded by 25 minutes' warning. There would be no warning for a weapon preplaced on American soil. As early as 1958, American intelligence agencies had reason to believe that it was possible to smuggle a nuclear weapon into the United States, place it in a desired location and then control its firing. This is information that has never before been released to the public. 
The Attack:
The U.S.S.R. has made attacks with large numbers of atomic weapons on the United States and on some of its territories, bases overseas and its allies. The domestic air defense warning yellow for the first attack was disseminated two hours before U.S.S.R. aircraft appeared over U.S. frontiers. At the same time as the air defense warning yellow was announced, submarine-launched missiles arrived and weapons emplaced by clandestine means were detonated. However, the major weight of attack has been delivered by manned aircraft. 
Air Defense operations in North America and overseas have destroyed a substantial portion of the attacking aircraft, but half of those destroyed had reached the bomb release line and had released their weapons. U.S. and Allied military operations have resulted in casualties and damage to the enemy at least as great as those received. 
Notwithstanding severe losses of military and civilian personnel and material, air operations against the enemy are continuing, and our land and naval forces are heavily engaged. Both sides are making use of atomic weapons for tactical air support and in land battle.
Unfortunately, half of the Soviet planes that they do shoot down have already dropped their bombs. . . . As we counterstrike, we will use nuclear weapons, some of which will explode in our own air space.
Both on the North American continent and overseas, the major weight of the attacks appears to have been directed on U.S. and Allied military installations. . . . In addition, the District of Columbia and many population and industrial centers have been attacked.
Washington D.C., is heavily hit (as would be expected). Civilian populations, however, do not seem to be targeted. Why did the planners presume this? The use of weapons against civilian populations is a tactic designed to break an opponent's will to fight, but it has rarely worked. . . . Thus, the Soviets are furiously trying to destroy our capacity to retaliate. They are wasting no bombs on terror strikes. 
The surface bursts have resulted in widespread radioactive fallout of such intensity that over substantial parts of the United States the taking of shelter for considerable periods of time is the only means of survival. . . .
The general level of casualties throughout the United States is extremely serious. In many localities it is catastrophic.
The population of the United States in 1958 was 140 million. Almost one in five will die.
Post-Attack Analysis:
With human casualties exceeding material losses, ultimate recuperative potential to meet the requirements of the surviving population is high, providing this population can be adequately motivated. In spite of the magnitude of the catastrophe that has struck the nation and the possibility of additional but lighter attacks, more than 100 million people and tremendous material resources remain. . . .
The attack has caused an almost complete paralysis in the functioning of the economic system in all of its aspects. . . . During the survival period the economy is operating in a highly disorganized manner. 
The utilized labor force is engaged in large numbers in disposing of the dead, taking care of surviving injured, decontaminating and cleaning up bombed areas, returning public works and utilities to operation, and other activities related to the direct and immediate effects of the attacks. . . . There are few workers left to produce goods. . . .
Government control is seriously jeopardized and central federal direction is virtually nonexistent. Many of the highest government officials are casualties although the presidential office is functioning. Washington was so severely damaged that no operations there are possible. . . .
In many areas, including several of the largest cities, where surviving injured outnumber the surviving uninjured active adults, the social fabric has ceased to exist in the pre-attack pattern. . . .
Here we see that even in 1958, the government actually agreed that shelters would be inadequate. Many would be destroyed. Most were too far away to be useful; a large number for whom the shelters were intended would die before they reached them. Those who did get in would be so badly contaminated that they would soon succumb to radiation sickness and die.
From a pre-attack total of 1.6 million hospital beds, approximately 100,000 are available for use. . . .
The medical care requirements are overwhelming. In addition to 25 million dead or dying, there are 25 million surviving casualties who require emergency medical care. . . . Of the 25 million radiation casualties, 12.5 million have received lethal dosages and have died or will die regardless of treatment. . . .
Inadequate provision for laboratory diagnostic aids has hampered the more accurate determination of degrees of radiation injury. Unless such determinations are made, many lives may be lost because treatment is being given to hopeless cases. . . . The housing situation is critical. . . . In only very isolated situations is the housing inventory adequate to rehouse survivors from attacked areas.
Does the author contradict an earlier assumption and now say that civilian populations were targeted? Probably not. But collateral damage in nuclear war would be unavoidable and extensive.
Blast damage has not only completely eliminated major water and sewer networks, but has at the same time dangerously impaired the function of water and sewer facilities in peripheral areas otherwise unaffected by blast and fire damage. . . .
The monetary and credit systems have collapsed in damaged areas and are under severe pressure in those areas overrun with refugees. . . . Bartering, unorganized confiscation and looting are in evidence. . . .
Severe disruption to transportation service exists in all attacked and contaminated areas. . . .
Yes, production will be curtailed or blocked due to damage, manpower losses and radiation. But the "X" factor is the will of American to get back on its feet. . . . Therein lies the great strength of America: the refusal to backslide into the abyss.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Two Wrongs Don't Make A Right in World Trade

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
DOES it make sense for countries to punish one another for erecting barriers to trade by -- get this -- erecting more barriers to trade?
 That is what they do in the World Trade Organization. In its dispute settlement system, a country that imposes trade barriers that break the organization's rules can be punished with big tariffs on its own exports. 
 In the most recent case, the European Union is suing the United States over new tariffs of up to 30 percent on imported steel. The union wants the tariffs dropped or else the trade organization's permission to punish the United States with new tariffs. 
The union might also make good on its threats to retaliate against the United States' Foreign Sales Corporation tax code, which the W.T.O. has already ruled an illegal subsidy to American exporters. If the United States fails to change its law, the union could retaliate with $4 billion a year in tariffs.
That would be unprecedented only in size: since 1999, the United States has been using $117 million in annual tariffs to retaliate against the European Union's ban on American beef imports, a ban the trade organization also deemed illegal. After the union declared its own tariffs last week, of up to 26 percent on steel, the United States warned of another possible suit in the W.T.O.
Most people say the retaliation rules and procedures of the W.T.O. are "not the best," said John H. Jackson, a law professor at Georgetown University who specializes in international trade. He offered three common-sense criticisms: the system punishes the wrong people, helps the wrong people and gives little incentive for the people who make policy to change.
Punishing the wrong people works two ways. First, retaliatory tariffs hurt people the same way other tariffs do. They not only take business away from companies abroad, but they also raise costs and prices for importers and consumers at home.
The retaliating countries have to hurt themselves to hurt others. It would be better, economically, if the trade organization required an offending country to lower other trade barriers until it eliminated the one that prompted the dispute. Doing so would violate the country's sovereignty, though, and that's one thing the W.T.O. can't do.
Retaliatory tariffs also punish the wrong people by hurting industries unaffected by the illegal trade barriers. The retaliatory tariffs by the United States in the beef case do not punish the beef industry in the European Union; the United States has not imported European beef for years because of objections to heavy subsidies and worries about mad cow and foot-and-mouth diseases. So the United States also put tariffs on European exports like mustard, tomatoes and chocolate.
This is a windfall for American mustard, tomato and chocolate producers, none of which were hurt by the union's ban. America's beef producers have complained that they have not benefited from the retaliation.
"We've always said from the beginning that these tariffs and all this retaliation stuff don't do us any good," said Chandler Keys, vice president for public policy at the National Cattlemen's Beef Association. "We just wish the European Union would comply with the W.T.O. ruling."
GETTING the European Union to comply, by lifting its ban on American beef, will not be easy. The retaliatory tariffs exercise no direct pressure on the policy makers in Brussels. The United States can only hope that aggrieved mustard, tomato and chocolate producers will call their legislators and complain loudly enough to effect a change.
That may work, after a time: the European Union agreed to dismantle its system of tariffs and quotas for importing bananas last year, after suffering $191 million a year in retaliatory American tariffs since 1999. In the meantime, American banana exporters paid the price: Chiquita says the European Union's system, which began in 1993, helped to send it into bankruptcy.
Ecuador, a big exporter of bananas, joined the United States in complaining to the W.T.O. about the European Union's import rules. Had Ecuador retaliated against the European Union alone, it might not have succeeded. Its imports from the union are negligible, so it can't apply much financial pressure simply by imposing new tariffs.
"It has been pointed out by the smaller countries of the world that the system is very asymmetric," Professor Jackson said. "It's just a pinprick for them against the big countries.
"What we really should be working on is an ethical sense driven home to the countries that they have an obligation to perform under the dispute settlement process," he added. Good luck.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Within Companies, Too, Education Proves Its Value

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
SHARES of companies that spend the most on employee training and development outperform those that spend the least, a study has found.
Nothing is new, of course, about the idea that in a so-called knowledge economy, a company's success depends greatly on the collective skills of its employees -- its human capital. Companies that invest more in developing that capital should fare better.
 For many years, however, investors had a big question about that investment theory: How can it be put into practice? Until recently, it was next to impossible to rank companies according to how much they spent on employee training and education. After all, companies typically do not report such expenditures on a separate line on their income statements, and annual reports and public pronouncements aren't much help, either, because they may pay only lip service to the notion that employees are the most important asset of a business. 
 Those practical barriers were lowered in the mid-1990's, when the American Society for Training and Development, a nonprofit group, created a database with standardized information on employee training expenditures at hundreds of publicly traded companies. That database allowed companies to be ranked according to their training expenditures, and for portfolios to be constructed based on those rankings.
Over the last five years, these portfolios performed as the theory predicts, according to a working paper by four researchers: Paul Harrison, an economist in the research and statistics division at the Federal Reserve Bank; Jens O. Ludwig, an associate professor of public policy at Georgetown University; Laurie J. Bassi, chairwoman of Knowledge Asset Management; and Daniel P. McMurrer, chief research officer of that money management firm, which aims to use this research in managing clients' investments.
Companies that ranked in the top 20 percent or so in spending on training and development would have earned an average of 16.2 percent, annualized, in the five years through 2001, or 6.5 percentage points a year more than the Wilshire 5000 index. Better yet, that market-beating performance was produced with about 10 percent less risk, as measured by the volatility of returns. Currently, that list of companies includes Accenture, Agilent Technologies, Allstate, Capital One Financial, Corning, FedEx, First Consulting Group, I.B.M., Intel, NCR and Storage Technology.
Over those same five years, companies at the bottom of the training-expense rankings had significantly lower returns. And the researchers obviously couldn't include companies that did not report training expenses and presumably performed even worse. 
Skeptics might worry about the objectivity of the results, given that the American Society for Training and Development is dedicated to encouraging companies to spend more on employee education. But the researchers focused only the performance of these companies after they had been identified by the society, so hindsight bias is not likely to be an issue.
Two standard caveats apply to the research. Because the data go back only five years, it is too early to predict confidently that the pattern, though crystal clear so far, will persist in coming years.
Second, knowledge of a strategy's profit potential can kill it, as more and more investors try to exploit it. But I am not particularly worried about that effect in this case, because Wall Street puts intense pressure on companies to increase current earnings by cutting expenses like those for employee training. Such expenses also carry indirect short-term costs, like reduced productivity while employees are being trained.
As a result, companies that resist short-term pressure and spend heavily on training are likely to remain few. The new research, however, suggests that investors will be rewarded for betting on them.

Graph shows the S.& P. 500 index top 20 percent of companies, ranked by spending on training (Source: Knowledge Asset Management)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Smiles And Frowns In Higher Oil Prices

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
NO one is ringing alarms yet, but in the last month or so oil prices have started to bubble. 
 A run-up of $5 to $6 in the price per barrel is both good news and bad news. As the economy has improved, so has demand for crude oil. But the spike in oil prices two years ago definitely contributed to the recent recession. 
 The improving prospects of petroleum have clearly helped oil stocks: the American Stock Exchange Oil Index rose 8.8 percent in the first quarter, trouncing the performance of major market benchmarks. 
Steven A. Pfeifer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, took some time last week to talk about Big Oil. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What caused the run-up in crude oil prices?

A. Several things have come together in the last month. The first is that inventories have declined for six straight weeks in the United States, something we haven't seen since last summer.
Second, OPEC has had a very high level of compliance with the production cuts they called for. They agreed to take five million barrels per day off the market, and have achieved about 85 percent of that. Anything over 70 percent is considered strong compliance. And there may be some premium in the price due to concerns about Iraq.

Q. Should we expect a rise in gasoline prices if this inventory drain continues?

A. Inventories in Europe and Asia are about normal, and the U.S. had an inventory surplus when the economy started to slow. That surplus has started to decline, and inventories are expected to be below normal as we move through the second quarter.
That suggests gasoline prices will be moving up, but it is still too early to tell if we will have price spikes of the magnitude we had last year or the year before. 
One thing that could perhaps help mute a gasoline price increase is that some refineries, which were down in the first quarter for maintenance, will be up again in the second quarter.

Q. Lack of refining capacity was an issue a couple of years ago. Is it still a problem?

A. No new major refineries have been built, and some small ones have closed. As the economy comes back and demand improves, that will quickly be reflected in straining existing capacity.
There are two reasons why no new refineries have been built: first, environmental regulations associated with the Clean Air Act make it difficult to expand refineries, let alone build new ones. And returns on refining in the last 20 years have been too low to justify new investment.

Q. Oil stocks were not world beaters two years ago, when oil prices spiked as high as $36 a barrel. Investors seemed to put a ceiling on the stocks because they did not believe per-barrel prices north of $30 were sustainable. Are things different now?

A. There is increasing evidence that the normalized oil price has moved into the mid-$20 range. In 2000, oil averaged a little over $30 a barrel with a growing economy. Even with a very weak global economy last year, prices only briefly went below $20 a barrel.
OPEC is very focused on making sure oil doesn't go above $30 a barrel. They don't want the market to overheat, which could be a negative for the economy.

Q. Some people say Russia, which is not part of OPEC, could upset things by producing a lot of oil. Is that a possibility?

A. The role of Russia as a swing producer has been overblown, in our opinion.
Russia is growing its production volume, but to understand the broader market you need to understand the growth in non-OPEC supply, which is expanding less quickly than it was in the 1990's. 
Back then, each year non-OPEC supply was growing 1 to 1.2 million barrels per day. Right now, it is only growing at a rate of 700,000 to 800,000 barrels per day.

Q. You like oil stocks, yet their prices are up. Why? Which stocks do you like?

A. Over the past three years, integrated oil stocks have enjoyed their best stock market performance since the 1970's. As measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index, they outperformed the stock market by 18 percent in 2000, by 11 percent last year and by a little over 8 percent so far this year.
The stocks have been very attractively valued. Integrated oil stocks are trading at an average of about 13 times 2003 earnings, assuming a $24 oil price. 
Our particular favorites are Phillips Petroleum, Amerada Hess, BP and TotalFinaElf. Those companies are best positioned to grow oil and gas production while many of the other majors are struggling to grow. 
In this market, which is much more focused on issues like dividends and cash flow, many of these companies are offering dividend yields of 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent. They have strong cash flows and earnings that are very visible.

HEADLINE: Youth Will Be Served at This Year's New York Auto Show 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS

 BODY:
BABY boomers, you're ancient history.
 For decades, automakers have pandered to the 76 million Americans born from 1946 to 1964 as they grow ever more gray, paunchy and affluent. And at auto shows, car companies got boomers' attention in recent years with fancy luxury cars and rugged-looking sport utilities. 
 But the 2002 New York International Auto Show, which runs through April 7 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, has a body-pierced, baggy-pants style. Exhibitors are trying to grab younger generations, many of them still too young to drive, with new sorts of vehicles, some of which defy definition. 
The youth market is alluring. By 2010, there will be 70 million potential drivers among the echo boomers born from 1977 to 1994. The industry is approaching this huge market with some apprehension, since research indicates that media-smart young people resist categorization and resent being the targets of blatant marketing campaigns. They also, like previous generations, reject what their parents drove -- which in this case includes minivans and traditional wagon-style sport utility vehicles.
Toyota, which has had incredible success with an aging group of customers, used the show to introduce a new subbrand called Scion, aimed at capturing prospective buyers who are just reaching their 20's. Toyota dealers will sell Scion vehicles -- the Toyota name will not appear on the cars -- in specially designated areas within existing dealerships. Two concept vehicles displayed at the show, the boxy bbX -- known as the Black Box in Japan, where it was designed -- and the swoopy ccX, hint at the designs of the first Scion vehicles. Scions will go on sale in June 2003 for less than $18,000.
The Honda Element, a box-on-wheels, is aimed specifically at young men. Honda executives say it is designed to be a combination of dorm room and base camp for young people involved in active sports like surfing or kayaking. The Element has a hose-down interior, flat floor and back seats that fold up for storage along the cabin walls. The Element goes on sale in December for $16,000 to $21,000. Features include an MP3 player and video game outlets as well as doors that swing open from the middle, with no pillar between.
At General Motors, a new small Saturn, the Ion, will replace the S-Series car that inaugurated the Saturn brand in 1991. The Ion will be available later this year as a five-passenger four-door sedan and a four-passenger "quad coupe." An industry first, the quad cab has two normal front-hinged doors and two small doors that provide access to the rear seat when the front doors are open. The car's 2.2-liter 137-horsepower four-cylinder engine is paired to a variable transmission that shifts continuously, rather than at fixed gear ratios, for high efficiency and improved fuel economy.
Mitsubishi, whose buyers are already among the industry's youngest, introduced the 2003 Outlander, a stylish five-passenger compact sport utility. With a starting price of less than $18,000, the boldly styled Outlander has an interior that resembles that of the Eclipse sports coupe.
Baby boomers have not been forgotten altogether. The auto show still features plenty of what they like, including new sport utilities, luxury cars and vehicles that are combinations of the two. Among these combination "crossovers" is the 2003 Nissan Murano, which will go on sale in the fall as Nissan's first entry in the fast-growing market for car-based sport wagons that can be equipped with all-wheel drive. The Murano, which is sleeker and less wagonlike than many crossovers, is built on the platform of the new Altima sedan.
More traditional luxury sport utilities were also on display. The 2003 Lincoln Aviator, which goes on sale in late summer, is the first midsize sport utility from Ford's domestic-luxury division. Isuzu, which is partly owned by General Motors, is adding another sport utility to its lineup. The Isuzu Ascender is yet another variation on G.M.'s midsize S.U.V.'s. The Ascender will come with three rows of seats that can accommodate seven passengers. 
The Infiniti luxury division of Nissan introduced a new rear-drive sedan, the M45. It will fit between the newly introduced G35 sport sedan and the flagship Q45 luxury car, with which it will share its 340-horsepower 4.5-liter V-8 engine.
Two automakers also displayed luxury performance concept vehicles. Acura brought a 400-horsepower hybrid-electric sport sedan called the DN-X. It combines a 300-horsepower V-6 engine with three electric motors that produce an additional 100 horsepower. And BMW showcased the CS1 concept car that it introduced earlier at the Geneva auto show. The CS1 foreshadows the design of small BMW's in the future, including a 1 Series that will arrive within a couple of years. 
Ford showed sketches of a new family sedan it will build to compete against the Toyota Avalon and Chevrolet Impala. The Five Hundred, a name borrowed from the Galaxie 500 of the '60's, will go on sale in 2004. The Five Hundred will be larger than the Taurus with a much more spacious interior and higher seating position. It will be built alongside the coming CrossTrainer, a car-based sport utility.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STAPLETON; 
A Borough's Old Naval Base Gives It Silver Screen Dreams

BYLINE:  By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
Call it Hollywood on the Harbor. As proposals to build film studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and other city sites attract much publicity, one company has quietly been making plans to turn the Staten Island Homeport, a former naval base, into New York's next big film complex.
 The area is a narrow slice of waterfront in the northeastern part of the island, with glorious views of Lower Manhattan and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. Since the Pentagon closed the base in 1994, it has lain underused because few developers could figure out what to do with the six large warehouselike buildings that cover most of its 36 acres. 
 But Robert E. DiMilia, the president of Stapleton Studios, decided they would be perfect for soundstages. In January, Mr. DiMilia persuaded the city's Economic Development Corporation, which manages the site, to give him six months to show that he could build a 14,000-square-foot soundstage in what was an industrial freezer in one building. 
"It's 90 percent done," said Mr. DiMilia, who has worked in the film industry for 30 years and produced such films as "Dirty Laundry," a 1998 movie with Tess Harper and Jay Thomas.
The corporation will review the work in June. If it approves, he can start the next phase of development. Mr. DiMilia ultimately wants to turn the site into a major film complex with 10 soundstages, a hotel, marina and waterfront esplanade. He estimated the project would cost $150 million and take more than two years to build.
Like any budding mogul, Mr. DiMilia has learned to drop names. 
"We have talked to Woody Allen's people and Bob Altman's people," he said. "They have been to the site and like what they see."
The city also seems to approve of the work. "They're doing state-of-the-art construction," said Janel Patterson, a corporation spokeswoman. "They've done more than they agreed to do initially."
She does not think a new studio would divert business from Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, Silvercup Studios in Long Island City or other film complexes. "The demand for more studio space in New York is there," she said.
Mr. DiMilia agreed. "We're looking to recapture some of the $4 billion of production that goes to Canada each year," he said.
One Stapleton homeowner, Cynthia Mailman, already has a plan if the films come. 
"What I'm going to do is sign up to be an extra," she said. JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Forbes L. Watson; 
Centura Mid Cap Equity Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
FORBES L. WATSON, who runs the $160 million Centura Mid Cap Equity fund, looks for midsize companies that are poised to expand greatly overseas.
 "You typically don't see overseas operations in smaller companies, and you expect them in bigger companies," he said from his office in Jackson, Miss. "But most midsize companies with the right products and distribution have big potential overseas." 
The fund returned 13.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, versus 4.4 percent for its peer group of midcap growth funds and a 2.4 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, according to Morningstar Inc. It gained 19.5 percent in the last 12 months, versus a decline of 2.2 percent for its group and a gain of 0.9 percent in the S.& P. 500. 
Mr. Watson, 41, works for Glenwood Capital Management, the fund's adviser, which is based in Raleigh, N.C. Glenwood, which manages about $1.5 billion, is a unit of the Royal Bank of Canada.
Mr. Watson describes himself as a "growth at a reasonable price" investor. He picks the fund's roughly 150 stocks from among United States companies with market capitalizations of $1.5 billion to $5 billion; the median market cap for the portfolio is about $4 billion.
He allocates the fund's assets about equally among the 10 economic sectors in the S.& P. 400 midcap index, which includes stocks with market caps of $300 million to $10 billion; the weighting of individual sectors must be within two percentage points of their weighting in the index.
Within sectors, Mr. Watson looks for companies with the potential for above-average earnings and cash-flow growth. His goal is stock price appreciation of at least 15 percent in the next 12 months.
He uses computer screens to find companies with low price-to-earnings multiples relative both to their own history and to their competitors. Over all, the portfolio companies trade for 22.5 times estimated 2002 earnings, versus a multiple of 21.5 for the S.& P. 400 midcap index.
Mr. Watson also screens for strong cash flow. "This tells me how the company will be able to finance its future," he said.
One consideration is the ownership stake of a company's officers and directors. "Our companies are still small enough so that there's the potential for meaningful amount of ownership by the people managing the firm," he said. Ideally, he prefers that directors and officers own 2 to 10 percent of a company, depending on its size.
Most important, he wants management with a clear business model: "Our question is, do they have the people, the capital equipment and the other resources they need available right now to implement their business plan today and over time?"
Mr. Watson does not trade often, relatively speaking; the fund's turnover is 66 percent, versus 153 percent, on average, for midcap growth funds, Morningstar said.
In September 1999, Mr. Watson began buying shares of American Standard, the bathroom fixtures, air-conditioning and auto parts business based in Piscataway, N.J. He paid $41.25 a share, on average; the stock now trades at $70.75.
American Standard, with a market cap of about $5.1 billion has been steadily increasing overseas sales, to about 45 percent of revenue, Mr. Watson said, and officers and directors own 3 percent of the shares. Wall Street expects three-year earnings growth to average 14 percent a year.
HE also likes the SPX Corporation, an industrial products company based in Muskegon, Mich., that has a market cap of roughly $5.8 billion. SPX sells products including valves and fire detection equipment. He has been buying shares since November 1998, paying an average of $89.19; they now trade at $141.58. 
"The best time to buy a multi-industry company is when it's building a global presence, which is what SPX is doing now," Mr. Watson said. Overseas sales account for 13 percent of revenue, he said, and analysts' consensus for earnings growth is 15 percent a year over three years.
In April 2001, Mr. Watson started buying shares of Golden State Bancorp, a $4 billion company in San Francisco that operates California Federal Bank and First Nationwide Mortgage. The company sells for nine times projected 2002 earnings, versus a multiple of 10 to 12 for its competitors, Mr. Watson said, and managment has a 46 percent stake -- higher than his usual range.
"Management has stated publicly that it will enhance shareholder value by selling itself or acquiring another company," he said. He paid an average of $27.79 for the shares; they now trade at $29.69.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Is the Best Already Past For Furniture Makers?

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
SHARES of major furniture makers outperformed the market last year, but with the economy strengthening, the companies may not fare as well this year, some analysts say.
 Among the biggest companies in the $23 billion wholesale furniture market is Furniture Brands International, based in St. Louis; its brands include Broyhill, Lane and Thomasville, as well as three added in a recent acquisition: Henredon, Drexel Heritage and Maitland-Smith. On March 4, after the company advised that its earnings were likely to be 5 cents a share higher than expected for the year, the stock hit a new 52-week high of $41.10. 
 It ended last week at $36.45, but it is still up more than 13 percent for the year. Other large manufacturers, including La-Z-Boy Inc. of Monroe, Mich., and Ethan Allen Interiors of Danbury, Conn., have also performed well in recent months. La-Z-Boy now trades at $27.45, up almost 26 percent for the year, and Ethan Allen closed last week at $38.06, down nearly 8.5 percent for the year.
Analysts predict that pent-up demand for furniture among recession-weary shoppers is likely to bolster sales and earnings in coming months. Furniture shipments dropped by 10 percent last year but are expected to increase by 4 percent this year, according to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association. The housing market remains strong, according to recent home-sales figures, and analysts say furniture sales tend to lag behind housing sales by about six months. 
But furniture stocks tend to be cyclical. They have performed poorly when interest rates begin to rise, as looks likely this year.
"There's a lot more risk today in some of these names than when they were trading in the $20's," said Beryl Bugatch, a furniture analyst at Raymond James Financial in St. Petersburg, Fla. Still, Mr. Bugatch currently has strong-buy ratings on Furniture Brands and Ethan Allen, with 12-month price targets of $48 on the two companies.
Wall Street's consensus earnings estimates for Furniture Brands are $2.37 a share this year and $2.83 for 2003, according to figures compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call. For Ethan Allen, the expected numbers are $2.12 this year and $2.44 in 2003, and for La-Z-Boy, $1.19 and $1.44.
Susie Hultquist, an analyst at Liberty Wanger Asset Management, which owns more than 650,000 shares of Furniture Brands in the Liberty Acorn fund, says the Wall Street estimates are too low. Using what she considers a conservative estimate, Ms. Hultquist said she expects Furniture Brands to earn at least $2.40 a share this year and more than $3 a share next year. 
"This company is not the same as it was in 2001," she said, referring to the company's acquisitions and reduced debt and payroll. "This stock has significant room to grow."
At year-end, Furniture Brands bought Henredon, Drexel Heritage and Maitland-Smith for about $275 million from LifeStyle Furnishings International, a privately held company. Ms. Hultquist called the acquisition "a huge opportunity" to increase market share and profit margins.
Lynn Chipperfield, the chief administrative officer at Furniture Brands, said the high-end furniture market, hit hard in 2001, was poised to rebound this year. Before the acquisition, Thomasville was the company's most upscale brand. Mr. Chipperfield added that Henredon, Drexel-Heritage and Maitland-Smith, which make higher-end furniture, all have healthy profit margins. 
"These are not fixer-uppers," Mr. Chipperfield said.
But Margaret M. Whelan, a furniture industry analyst at UBS Warburg, said she believed that the three acquisitions were ill-advised. Furniture companies in general are facing increased pressure from overseas manufacturers, she said. "This is a lousy industry period," Ms. Whelan said.
She has a hold rating on both Furniture Brands and La-Z-Boy, but she does rate Ethan Allen a buy and has a 12-month price target of $45 on the stock. "It has a good product, good brand name and good price points," she said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; 
The Hot Dog Wars Heat Up, and It's Not Just the Mustard That's Spicy

BYLINE:  By KYTJA WEIR 

 BODY:
Joe Anastasio was strolling around the East Village when his eye caught a chalkboard outside an Eighth Street storefront. The message, more or less: The hell with yoga, I'm having a chili dog. Whoever had scribbled those words had attributed them to Sri Chinmoy, a guru and running enthusiast. 
 Above the chalkboard, along with some highly suggestive -- some would say offensive -- language, a six-foot-long red plastic hot dog juts from the building like a flagpole. 
 The advertising is on behalf of Crif Dogs, a six-month-old restaurant and one of the latest hot dog shops to dot this increasingly trendy neighborhood. It takes its name from its owner Chris Antista -- because Crif sounds like Chris "if you have a mouth full of hot dogs," Mr. Antista said. Crif's competes against Dawgs on Park, less than two blocks away, and a shop advertising chili dogs around the corner. It also challenges Gray's Papaya, eight blocks to the west, plus a bevy of hot dog vendors in local parks. With so much competition, Mr. Antista must work hard to get his dogs noticed.
He changes the chalkboard messages daily, writing made-up quotes and tagging them with such well-known names as Freud and, no surprise, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, who is leading the American military assault in Afghanistan. 
His print ads go even further. One, in The Onion, the satiric newspaper, said, "To all the pigs and cows who have courageously sacrificed their lives for deliciousness, we thank you!"
But not everyone is a fan.
"I thought the sign was a bit much," said Peter Silvestri, who owns the vegan bakery across the street. "But this is the East Village. Let's have a creative nature about things."
A few disapproving citizens have complained to Mr. Antista about his street-side shenanigans, but he dismisses them: "If you can't take a joke, we don't want you here. It's a hot dog joint. It's what makes this place great."
The signs clearly have not discouraged fans. Cellphone-carrying lunchers wearing ill-fitting thrift-shop clothes occupy tables next to Roman Catholic schoolgirls and tattoo artists and munch on specialties like the Chihuahua, a deep-fried bacon-wrapped dog topped with avocado and jalapenos. 
One customer spent over an hour eating one dog after another while playing "Grand Theft Auto 3" on Crif's Sony PlayStation.
A few hundred Crif customers even carry laminated membership cards, which carry a slightly crass name and entitle them to free drink refills, 25 percent off their tabs on Mondays and the privilege of cutting ahead of other customers at the cash register.
Offering such perks helps Mr. Antista compete in the increasingly tight dog market. Dawgs on Park sells jackets for dogs to wear and displays photos of customers' dogs under the glass-topped counter. Gray's Papaya pitches its "recession special" of two dogs and a drink for $2.45.
At Crif's, the priciest dog is $3.75, though extras can bring the price to $5. Such cheap lunches appeal to Andrew Kist, a freelance photographer who sometimes entertains his clients here. 
Nutritionists dismiss hot dogs, but Mr. Antista, who keeps two kinds of antacid by the register, says, "They aren't as bad for you as people think they are." 
Then he reverses himself: "Who am I kidding? Yeah, they are." But he eats one every day. "I could eat two a day," he confessed. "Man, they're so good." KYTJA WEIR

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chris Antista will sell you a hot dog, if you can take a joke. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)
